<HEADLINE>
Chile swine flu cases jump to 276
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Santiago, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Chilean health authorities confirmed 26 new cases of swine flu on Sunday,
raising the number of patients with A(H1N1) virus in the country to 276, the
highest number on the continent.
</P>
<P>
The sometimes-deadly disease continued its rise across Latin America meanwhile
with Argentina, Brazil, Bolivia, Peru and the Dominican Republic all reporting
new cases.
</P>
<P>
Officials here said that most of the victims were in the capital, and that most
cases were mild and being treated at home. Three people remain in serious
condition in hospital, however.
</P>
<P>
Swine flu has killed nearly a hundred and infected over 15,500 worldwide,
according to World Health Organization (WHO) figures, since it emerged in North
America in late April.
</P>
<P>
According to figures released by individual governments, the virus has actually
now killed more than 110 people around the world.
</P>
<P>
In the southern hemisphere, health experts fear the new virus could take hold,
as winter sets in and the regular flu season gets underway.
</P>
<P>
Argentine health authorities meanwhile reported 15 new cases on Sunday, a day
after reporting 20 new cases, raising the country's total patient count to 115.
</P>
<P>
Officials in Buenos Aires said those with new swine flu infections were
recovering well and that most of them were found at several private schools in
the capital, where students had recently returned from the United States.
</P>
<P>
The outbreak has prompted officials to close the schools for two weeks in a bid
to contain the virus.
</P>
<P>
In the Dominican Republic officials confirmed nine cases of the disease, raising
the country's total to 11, a day after Santo Domingo rebuffed a Russian claim
that the Caribbean island was underreporting its cases in a bid to boost
tourism.
</P>
<P>
"We fear that in reality, the situation is very different," Gennady Onishchenko,
Russia's chief sanitary inspector, had told the Interfax news agency in response
to the island reporting only two cases.
</P>
<P>
On Sunday the island's Ministry of Public Health reported that of the nine new
cases one had been hospitalized.
</P>
<P>
In Peru health authorities said they had confirmed two more cases of the virus,
bringing the country's total to 40.
</P>
<P>
Both cases were found in Lima and are recovering well on medication at home,
officials said.
</P>
<P>
Brazil also confirmed four new cases, which brought the country's total number
to 20.
</P>
<P>
At its last count at the end of last week Mexican authorities said 97 people had
died from the disease and that 4,932 had been infected. Officials however
maintained that the epidemic was on the wane there.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0002" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Basketball: Despite sting of defeat, James says Cavs on right track
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
National Basketball Association Most Valuable Player LeBron James insisted
Sunday that Cleveland were on the right track, despite their painful failure to
reach the NBA finals.
</P>
<P>
James couldn't bring himself to address the media or congratulate the players of
the Orlando Magic on Saturday night, after the Magic defeated the Cavs in game
six of the Eastern Conference finals to reach the league's championship series.
</P>
<P>
But as he and teammates gathered for the last team meeting of the season here on
Sunday, James tried to put a positive spin on the Cavaliers season.
</P>
<P>
Cleveland notched the best record in the regular season with 66 victories, won
their division and swept to victory in four games in each of their first two
playoff series.
</P>
<P>
Then they ran into the surprising Magic, who had already ousted reigning
champions Boston in seven games, and even "King" James's heroics couldn't save
them.
</P>
<P>
"You want to continue to get better, that's all you can ask," said James, whose
team lost to Boston in the conference finals last year.
</P>
<P>
"We got better this season and I feel this team will be better next season. You
don't want to take a step backward. I thought we went forward from the Boston
series to this year and hopefully we can go forward one more time next year."
</P>
<P>
James certainly did all he could to take his team one step further.
</P>
<P>
His buzzer-beating 3-pointer saved Cleveland in game two against Orlando. He had
21 points, 17 in the second half, in game five, a contest that saw him finish
with 37 points, 14 rebounds and 12 assists.
</P>
<P>
Now the big question exercising Cleveland - the club's management, his teammates
and Cavs fans - is how this defeat will influence his future with the team.
</P>
<P>
The Cavaliers can offer him a contract extension in July. He can extend the
contract up to four years, or play out his current contract that ends after next
season and make a move via free agency. He could also exercise a player option
for the 2010-11 season.
</P>
<P>
"I haven't thought about it just yet," James said. "I'm just going to take time
off from basketball and not think about contracts or the game, period, and relax
with my family."
</P>
<P>
James defended his actions in Orlando on Saturday, when he strode off the court
- to a smattering of taunts from Magic fans - without congratulating his
opponents.
</P>
<P>
"I just didn't have much to say," said James, who said he had since e-mailed
Orlando star Dwight Howard. "One thing about me you've got to understand - it is
hard for me to congratulate somebody after just losing to him.
</P>
<P>
"I'm a winner. That's not being a poor sport or anything like that. If somebody
beats you up, you are not going to congratulate them (for) beating you up. That
doesn't make sense to me."
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Business says British politicians distracted by expenses row
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, June 1, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The row over MPs' expenses is distracting Britain's politicians from confronting
the serious economic issues facing the country, a prominent business leader said
Monday.
</P>
<P>
Richard Lambert, director-general of the CBI, told the Financial Times that all
the main parties should be focusing on their plans to deal with the recession
ahead of European and local elections later this week.
</P>
<P>
"I've just been talking to business people in Brussels and the sense of
bewilderment about what's happening and what it means for the UK and Europe is
palpable," Lambert told the FT.
</P>
<P>
"We've got important elections and they are being completely overshadowed by
these disclosures."
</P>
<P>
He added: "Clearly there's an enormous, understandable public outrage... but
we've got big decisions to be taken by all the big political parties about the
future shape and role of the state, and these have been completely brushed to
one side."
</P>
<P>
Polls over the weekend suggested British Prime Minister Gordon Brown's Labour
party is in danger of coming third in the elections for the European Parliament
on Thursday, largely because of disillusionment over the expenses row.
</P>
<P>
The main opposition Conservatives have also suffered from the scandal and
analysts expect fringe parties such as the anti-EU UK Independence Party (Ukip)
and the far-right British National Party to benefit.
</P>
<P>
Brown insisted Sunday that he was focused on the recession, brushing aside calls
for him to quit in favour of a more popular leader and saying: "I am dealing
with the economy every day."
</P>
<P>
In an article in the Daily Mirror, he also launched a strong attack on the BNP,
describing them as a "nasty extreme party" made up of "Nazi thugs" and urging
voters not to back them when they go to the polls this week.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Golf: Stricker claims Colonial crown at second hole of sudden death
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
FORT WORTH, Texas, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Steve Stricker birdied the second playoff hole to win the 6.2 million-dollar
Colonial on Sunday, leaving South African Tim Clark still in search of his first
USPGA tour title.
</P>
<P>
Stricker defeated Clark and Steve Marino in the playoff to claim his first title
of 2009 to go with his runner-up, third-place, fourth-place, sixth- and seventh-
place finishes this year.
</P>
<P>
For Clark it was yet another near miss. His 12.7 million dollars in US earnings
are the most of any player without a victory in PGA Tour history.
</P>
<P>
He squandered a two-shot lead with five holes left, including a bogey on the
72nd hole that forced the playoff.
</P>
<P>
He also missed a putt that would have given him the victory at the first playoff
hole.
</P>
<P>
On the second, Stricker stuck his approach within a few feet and Clark almost
followed suit.
</P>
<P>
But Clark's hit the stick and rolled more than 20 feet away. The South African
missed his birdie attempt and Stricker made his for a fifth career crown.
</P>
<P>
Clark, meanwhile, settled for a seventh second-place finish, including at this
tournament behind Phil Mickelson last year.
</P>
<P>
Clark, who started the day with a two-stroke lead, carded a 70 to finish
regulation on 263. Stricker and Marino both shot 68 to join him in the playoff.
</P>
<P>
Australian Jason Day carded a 69 to finish alone in fourth on 264, one shot in
front of England's Paul Casey.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
2,000 to leave Australian flu ship after all-clear: officials
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Sydney, June 1, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
About 2,000 passengers were given the all-clear to leave the Pacific Dawn cruise
ship here on Monday after Australian officials found none was carrying swine
flu.
</P>
<P>
The ship has been at the centre of an outcry after infected passengers were
allowed to disembark last week, prompting an explosion in Australia's swine flu
cases.
</P>
<P>
"No evidence of any additional cases of human swine influenza has been found on
board the Pacific Dawn, and most importantly, there has been no person-to-person
transmission on board the ship," New South Wales' top health official, Kerry
Chant, said in a statement.
</P>
<P>
Three crew members who caught the disease have now recovered and remain in
quarantine, P&amp;O Cruises said in a statement.
</P>
<P>
Infected passengers were among 2,000 who disembarked here last Monday following
an earlier cruise on the ship. Australia's swine flu cases, then fewer than 20,
had shot up to 303 by Sunday.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Britain's Prince Harry admits finding army training tough
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, June 1, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Britain's Prince Harry admitted Monday that he sometimes questions whether he
will succeed in his army training -- but said his brother Prince William helps
take the pressure off by cooking for him.
</P>
<P>
The 24-year-old, the youngest son of Prince Charles and the late princess Diana,
is currently training to be a pilot with the Army Air Corps.
</P>
<P>
Based at RAF Shawbury in the West Midlands, he lives with William, who is
training to become a search and rescue pilot with the Royal Air Force (RAF).
</P>
<P>
"We hardly ever see each other. And now we are living together and it's
fantastic," Harry said in a syndicated interview.
</P>
<P>
"(William) does most of the cooking. I spend time just lying around, watching TV
and doing my work," he said, and joked: "The RAF don't have to work as hard as
the army."
</P>
<P>
William is reportedly giving his brother advice ahead of his first helicopter
flight in the coming weeks, and Harry admitted that he had found the training
difficult.
</P>
<P>
"The flying courses are so intense," he said, adding: "It's surprised me."
</P>
<P>
He said: "There's times when I thought, you know, I'm really not cut out for
this, mentally. I hope I've got the physical skills to fly a helicopter.
</P>
<P>
"But mentally, there are the exams and everything. I mean, I can't do maths, I
gave that up when I left school, as anyone does at that age. But I've been
throwing myself back in the deep end."
</P>
<P>
Harry has recently returned from a two-day visit to New York, which he described
as a "nice break" from the training. It was his first trip abroad as official
representative of Buckingham Palace.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Football: Perez to take reins at Real Madrid again
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
MADRID, June 1, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Spanish construction magnate Florentino Perez will be sworn in as president of
Real Madrid again later on Monday as no other candidate stood against him before
the deadline, the club said.
</P>
<P>
The 62-year-old will be sworn in at the Real's Santiago Bernabeu stadium at 1 pm
(1100 GMT), the club said in a statement posted on its website shortly after the
deadline of midnight (2200 GMT) on Sunday had expired.
</P>
<P>
Several challengers who had been expected to oppose him pulled out or were not
able to lodge a bank guarantee of 57.4 million euros (81.1 million dollars)
required by the club to be able to run for president.
</P>
<P>
Perez last led Real, Spain's historically most successful team and the world's
richest football club by revenues, from 2000 to 2006.
</P>
<P>
Under his rein Real earned the nickname "Los Galacticos", winning the Primera
Liga twice and the European Champions League with such stars as Zinedine Zidane,
Ronaldo, Luis Figo and David Beckham.
</P>
<P>
He officially presented his candidacy on Thursday under the slogan "the dream is
back" and said the team he would help build would be world beaters.
</P>
<P>
"We will build a spectacular team with top notch players. We have set up a
strong and stable sporting project which will be able to call upon footballers
who will turn each Real Madrid match into a fascinating rendez-vous," he said.
</P>
<P>
Perez has not mentioned any names regarding top signings but Spanish media has
reported that Chilean Manuel Pellegrini, currently at Villarreal, would become
coach in place of Juande Ramos and the club would also land AC Milan's Brazilian
playmaker Kaka.
</P>
<P>
Media reports also constantly speculate that Cristiano Ronaldo, Liverpool's
Spanish star Xabi Alonso and Bayern Munich's French star Franck Ribery will don
the all-white strip next term.
</P>
<P>
Real has been led on an interim basis by Vicente Boluda, who took the reins of
the club after Ramon Calderon stepped down in January following allegations that
he rigged voting at the club's last annual general assembly in December.
</P>
<P>
Had another candidate stood against Perez, elections for president -- normally
held every four years -- would have taken place on June 14.
</P>
<P>
Real's arch-rivals Barcelona won the Champions League, the Spanish title and the
Spanish Cup this season under debutante coach Pep Guardiola.
</P>
<P>
But in an interview published Sunday in daily newspaper El Pais, Perez said
Barcelona's success this season "motivates me even more".
</P>
<P>
"I do not place any limit on myself," he told the newspaper, adding the club
"needs a revolution".
</P>
<P>
Real ended the season on Sunday with a 2-1 loss to lowly Osasuna.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0014" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Football: FIFA 'in compliance' with world anti-doping code - Blatter
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
NASSAU, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
World football's governing body has been notified that its policies are "totally
in compliance" with those of the World Anti-Doping Agency, apart from the issue
of reintegrating players after a suspension, FIFA president Joseph Blatter said
Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Blatter, speaking at the conclusion of FIFA executive committee meetings here,
said WADA had confirmed that "FIFA's disciplinary code and FIFA's anti-doping
code, is totally in compliance with the WADA code".
</P>
<P>
The lone exception, he said had to do with when suspended players can resume
training with their clubs.
</P>
<P>
FIFA secretary general Jerome Valcke said that FIFA's position is that a player
suspended for 12 months should be allowed to resume training after nine months.
</P>
<P>
FIFA and WADA had been at odds recently over WADA requirements on availablity of
players for out-of-competition drugs testing.
</P>
<P>
Since the beginning of January, the world anti-doping code requires elite
athletes to give notice of their location at a chosen one-hour period each day,
seven days a week.
</P>
<P>
FIFA had contended that players should be subject to testing when with their
teams, but not when on holiday.
</P>
<P>
World anti-doping chief John Fahey said FIFA's stance "ignores the reality of
doping in sport."
</P>
<P>
"There is no problem between the WADA organization and FIFA," Blatter said.
</P>
<P>
"The only problem that we had, which has now been put away ... is the question,
'Is WADA a service organization for the world of sport?' The answer is yes. WADA
is not a police organization."
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0015" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Abortion doctor shot dead in Kansas church
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
WICHITA, Kansas, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Authorities here on Sunday arrested a suspect in the death of a controversial
provider of late-term abortions, who was fatally shot as he walked into services
at his Kansas church, officials said.
</P>
<P>
Abortion doctor George Tiller was shot to death just after 10:00 am (1500 GMT)
in the lobby of Reformation Lutheran Church in Wichita, Kansas, police and city
officials said.
</P>
<P>
President Barack Obama expressed outrage at the fatal shooting of the
controversial doctor, in a statement released by the White House.
</P>
<P>
"I am shocked and outraged by the murder of Dr George Tiller as he attended
church services this morning," said Obama.
</P>
<P>
"However profound our differences as Americans over difficult issues such as
abortion, they cannot be resolved by heinous acts of violence."
</P>
<P>
Wichita officials said the suspect, who was not identified, was arrested some
three hours after the killing. Local media identified the suspect as a 51-year-
old man, who would be returned to Wichita to be charged.
</P>
<P>
"It's an unfortunate incident to happen on a Sunday morning," Wichita police
captain Brent Allred told reporters. "These things should not occur at a any
time."
</P>
<P>
Long a lightning rod in the bitter US culture war over abortion, Tiller, 67,
over the years had been picketed, bombed and shot in the arms, before being
killed Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Tiller's was one of only three clinics in the United States that perform late-
term abortions, which are performed on fetuses that would be viable outside the
mother's womb.
</P>
<P>
Late-term abortions are legal in Kansas if two independent physicians agree that
the mother could suffer irreparable harm by giving birth.
</P>
<P>
The shooting occurred just two weeks after Obama sought "common ground" over the
divisive abortion debate in a controversial speech at one of the top Catholic
universities in the United States.
</P>
<P>
President Obama has attempted to defuse one of the most emotive issues in US
public life by arguing that while abortion should remain legal, the government
should do all it can to limit unwanted pregnancies.
</P>
<P>
But Obama has angered the anti-abortion movement by reversing predecessor George
W. Bush's restrictions on federal funding for embryonic stem-cell research and
for family-planning groups that carry out or facilitate abortions overseas.
</P>
<P>
Obama's choice for health secretary, former Kansas governor Kathleen Sebelius,
has been widely condemned by the anti-abortion movement because of her ties to
Tiller.
</P>
<P>
His family released a statement saying Tiller "dedicated his life to providing
women with high-quality heath care despite frequent threats and violence,"
according to the local KWCH TV station.
</P>
<P>
"We ask that he be remembered as a good husband, father and grandfather and a
dedicated servant on behalf of the rights of women everywhere."
</P>
<P>
Tiller had been demonized by abortion opponents who regularly protested outside
his clinic.
</P>
<P>
In 1986, someone placed a bomb on the roof of the clinic, seriously damaging the
building. In 1993, Tiller was shot in both arms outside the clinic. Tiller
recovered, and his assailant received an 11-year prison term.
</P>
<P>
Some 2,000 protesters were also arrested outside the clinic during summer-long
demonstrations in 1991.
</P>
<P>
He was acquitted in March on charges that he performed 19 illegal abortions in
2003 in a case which his lawyer described as a witch hunt.
</P>
<P>
Tiller testified during the trial that he spent years under the protection of
federal agents after the FBI discovered an anti-abortion assassination list in
1994 that listed Tiller as the top target.
</P>
<P>
Tiller was also acquitted of having an illegal financial relationship with the
doctor who provided the second opinion for the late-term abortions.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Obama to speak on GM bankruptcy: White House
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Washington, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
President Barack Obama will discuss General Motors' expected bankruptcy filing,
in remarks planned for 11:55 am (1555 GMT) Monday, the White House announced.
</P>
<P>
In a statement Sunday, the White House said that Obama would deliver remarks on
the roiling US auto industry after meeting Monday with his senior advisors.
</P>
<P>
Obama's comments are to come shortly after the auto giant officially files
bankruptcy paperwork, which US media reported will likely happen at around 8:00
am (1200 GMT) Monday.
</P>
<P>

<HEADLINE>
US seeks slower Lat Am rapprochement with Cuba
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
San Salvador, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Secretary of State Hillary Clinton began a visit to Central America Sunday, amid
new US steps toward ties with Cuba that Washington hopes will slow a sudden
regional push to end Havana's isolation.
</P>
<P>
Clinton landed in San Salvador from Washington where a senior State Department
official announced that Cuba had agreed to resume talks with the United States
on migration and direct mail service.
</P>
<P>
The chief US diplomat is in El Salvador for Monday's inauguration of president-
elect Mauricio Funes before traveling to neighboring Honduras for Tuesday's
general assembly of the Organization of American States (OAS).
</P>
<P>
The OAS is beset by a row over the pace of normalization with Cuba.
</P>
<P>
President Barack Obama's administration insists Cuba release political prisoners
and improve political freedoms before it is readmitted to the 35-member
organization. Some OAS states however want Cuba readmitted right away.
</P>
<P>
A senior US official, who is traveling with Clinton, told reporters that Havana
informed Washington on Saturday that it will take up the US offer to resume
long-stalled talks on migration issues and on direct mail service.
</P>
<P>
"We and the Cubans have to determine a mutually convenient place and time," he
added on the condition of anonymity.
</P>
<P>
The official said the Cubans "also indicated they would like to explore areas of
additional dialogue," such as in counter-narcotics, counter-terrorism, hurricane
and disaster preparedness response.
</P>
<P>
US officials said May 23 that the Obama admistration had proposed to resume the
discussions on migration issues, wihch had been conducted every two years until
they were suspended in 2003 by former president George W. Bush.
</P>
<P>
It was also Washington that proposed recently to resume direct mail service, the
official said, adding mail has for years, if not decades, been sent between the
United States and Cuba through a third country.
</P>
<P>
When asked if the new steps to engage Cuba would affect the OAS meeting in San
Pedro Sula, the senior official said "it is hoped ... that the region will
recognize that anything done within the ambit of the OAS ... should support and
foster this development, as opposed to hinder it."
</P>
<P>
US officials earlier declined to even rule out the possibility of Clinton's
skipping the OAS meeting altogether if negotiators fail to agree on terms for
bringing Cuba back within the OAS.
</P>
<P>
Even though Cuba itself rejects the OAS, analysts said, many countries want to
use the issue to either push for a lifting of the US embargo on Havana or for
their own private agendas, such as to embarrass the United States.
</P>
<P>
Since a popular Obama took office in January, analysts say, he has raised hopes
among many of his southern neighbors that he will soon lift the embargo, even if
he insists that Cuba first undertake democratic reforms.
</P>
<P>
Apart from the new steps, the Obama administration has called past US policy a
failure and moved to repair ties with Cuban President Raul Castro, who
officially took over the reins from older brother Fidel last year.
</P>
<P>
In April, Obama lifted travel and money transfer restrictions on Cuban-Americans
with relatives in Cuba.
</P>
<P>
Instead of having Cuba as the burning issue, analyst Michael Shifter said, the
Obama team would have preferred to highlight a new era of US cooperation with
leftist but pragmatic democratic governments like those in El Salvador, Brazil
and Chile.
</P>
<P>
Her visit to San Salvador is symbolic of the shift because Funes brought to
power the Farabundo Marti Front for National Liberation, former leftist
guerrillas who fought the US-backed right-wing government in the 1980s civil
war.
</P>
<P>
US Congressman Eliot Engel, who chairs a subcommittee on Western hemisphere
affairs who is traveling with Clinton, saw Clinton's visit to El Salvador as
halting a lurch in Latin America toward the extreme left.
</P>
<P>
"I think it means we want to engage with El Salvador because we don't them
drifting all the way left," Engel told reporters.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
GM set for bankruptcy as Treasury readies rescue plan
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Washington, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The US Treasury Department on Sunday put final touches on a plan to restructure
General Motors, once the world's largest automaker and now expected to join
rival Chrysler in filing for bankruptcy protection.
</P>
<P>
Monday will be a historic day for the US automobile industry, with  President
Barack Obama poised to discuss General Motors' bankruptcy in remarks planned for
11:30 am (1530 GMT) Monday, after the auto giant officially files its bankruptcy
paperwork, US media reported.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile, GM's new chief executive, Fritz Henderson, has scheduled a news
conference for the middle of the day in New York, where the number one US
automaker would file for bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
The developments came as creditors holding about 54 percent of General's Motors
bonds approved a restructuring plan proposed by the US Treasury, a spokesman for
the bondholders said Sunday.
</P>
<P>
The 54 percent represented 975 institutions, a spokesman for the ad hoc
committee of bondholders, Elliot Sloane told AFP. Washington had warned that if
the plan were rejected, creditors risked losing everything.
</P>
<P>
The US administration had given GM until June 1 to present a viable
restructuring plan, in return for government aid, and the US Treasury Department
had given holders of General Motors until the end of the day Saturday to respond
to the rescue plan.
</P>
<P>
Agreement boosted the Treasury's plan for creating a new company shorn of labor
costs and money losing assets, in a rescue that could reach 60 billion dollars
as the state takes a 72.5 per cent ownership stake in the 101 year old company.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile Canada, which has several GM factories, is also set to be digging into
its pockets for the rescue plan.
</P>
<P>
Among the backers was a committee of large investors holding about 20 percent of
GM's 27.2 billion dollars in outstanding bonds, The New York Times reported.
</P>
<P>
Under the plan, the bondholders would obtain the rights to buy an extra 15
percent of GM's stock at a low price. They would also control 25 percent of the
new GM, after having supported the new company's creation in bankruptcy court.
</P>
<P>
Bondholders who rejected the plan could still fight it in court, but the
government maintains they could end up with little or nothing if they take that
path.
</P>
<P>
On Monday, New York bankruptcy judge Arthur Gonzales was set to rule on number
three US automaker Chrysler, which filed for bankruptcy protection a month ago.
</P>
<P>
Under an expedited process, Gonzales was expected to approve the creation of a
new Chrysler that would preserve the automaker's healthiest assets and liquidate
the rest.
</P>
<P>
The new entity will be controlled by a consortium consisting of the Italian
automaker Fiat, the United Auto Workers union, and the US and Canadian
governments.
</P>
<P>
Fiat will have a 20 percent stake with the option to increase it to 35 percent;
the UAW 55 percent; and the US and Canadian governments 10 percent.
</P>
<P>
The automakers' fate, the subject of debate on television talks shows, is being
closely watched in US political and economic circles.
</P>
<P>
"This is a real sad day," said former Republican presidential contender Mitt
Romney.
</P>
<P>
"I'm a son of Detroit. My dad was an auto executive. You know, I drive American
cars. I love American cars. My heart bleeds for the people in Michigan and
Detroit, for all these auto workers," he said on Fox News Sunday.
</P>
<P>
At the end of last year, GM had 244,000 employees around the world, about half
of them in the United States.
</P>
<P>
Republican Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, called the auto rescue
plan "a big mistake," arguing that the government had done too much to keep GM
and Chyrsler out of bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
In an interview with CNN, he held up the example of Ford, the number two US
automaker, as "an American company that hasn't taken government money and is
still producing automobiles."
</P>
<P>
Corporate leaders, meanwhile, urged the government not to overstay its welcome
in the private sector.
</P>
<P>
"I think all of us understand the need for the government to intervene and take
the actions they did," said Anne Mulcahy, chief executive of Xerox. "But I also
think there's a need for an exit plan."
</P>
<P>
The possibility of bankruptcy for such an iconic American company has been
viewed with great foreboding in a country where the automobile is deeply
embedded in the national imagination.
</P>
<P>
"The phrase 'bankrupt General Motors,' which we expect to hear uttered on Monay,
leaves Americans my age in economic shock," the writer PJ O'Rourke said in the
Wall Street Journal. "The words are as melodramatic as 'Mom's nude photos.'"
</P>
</TEXT>

Alegre, Recife, Rio De Janeiro, Salvador, Sao Paulo

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0030" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
New therapies to treat breast, lymph cancer: studies
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ORLANDO, Florida, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
New therapies developed following groundbreaking clinical trials appear to
effectively target breast cancer and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, according to
research unveiled Sunday at a major cancer conference.
</P>
<P>
The first therapy targeting the capacity of cancer cells to repair themselves
shows promise in treating breast cancer, according to results of two small
clinical trials.
</P>
<P>
The new agent, especially adept at targeting cancers that are most difficult to
cure, neutralizes an enzyme called PARP (poly-ADP-ribose-polymerase) and
prevents it from playing its usual role in repairing the DNA of damaged cells.
</P>
<P>
Like healthy cells, cancerous cells employ PARP to regenerate themselves after
they have been damaged by chemo-therapy treatments.
</P>
<P>
The studies examined whether breast cancers are more susceptible to chemotherapy
when the PARP enzymes have been neutralized.
</P>
<P>
The first clinical trial was conducted with 116 women suffering from so-called
triple negative breast cancer.
</P>
<P>
These involve fast-spreading tumors that account for 15 percent of the 170,000
annual cases worldwide of breast cancer.
</P>
<P>
Some of the cases were treated with chemotherapy and a PARP inhibitor called
BSI-201 made by the firm BiPar Sciences, a US affiliate of the French-owned
laboratory Sanofi-Aventis.
</P>
<P>
The rest of the group was treated only with chemotherapy.
</P>
<P>
After six months, about 62 percent of the patients treated with BSI-201 combined
with chemotherapy showed a comparative clinical improvement of 21 percent over
the control group, said Joyce O'Shaughnessy, of the Baylor-Charles Sammons
cancer center in Dallas, Texas.
</P>
<P>
She presented the results of the study at a conference of the American Society
of Clinical Oncology this weekend in Orlando, Florida.
</P>
<P>
The women treated with BSI-201 survived 9.2 months on average, including 6.9
months in which the cancer did not spread, compared to an average survival of
6.9 months and 3.3 months in which the cancer was in check for those who were
treated solely with chemotherapy.
</P>
<P>
The second clinical study involved 54 women suffering from advanced breast
cancer linked to the gene mutation BRCA1 or BRCA2. They were treated with the
PARP blocker Olaparib made by the Anglo-Swedish pharmaceutical AstraZenica.
There was no control group.
</P>
<P>
The test showed that 40 percent of the patients who took the drug experienced a
reduction in their tumors, said Andrew Tutt, a cancer specialist at Kings
College in London.
</P>
<P>
In another study presented here researchers examined a vaccine on patients over
eight years that targeted follicular non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a particularly
aggressive form of lymphatic cancer.
</P>
<P>
The study found that patients who received the BiovaxID vaccine experienced on
average disease-free survival of approximately 44 months, compared to about 30
months for patients who received a control vaccine -- an increase of 47 percent.
</P>
<P>
The BiovaxID vaccine is patient-specific, in that each dose must be individually
manufactured from tissue obtained from a patient's own cancerous tumor.
</P>
<P>
"With this vaccine, we've now moved into an era where we can safely use a
patient's immune system to effectively fight follicular lymphoma and enhance the
response to conventional chemotherapy" said lead study author Stephen Schuster.
</P>
<P>
"Because this vaccine uniquely recruits the patient's immune system to seek and
destroy only tumor B-cells, this approach may be applicable to the treatment of
other B-cell lymphomas," Schuster added.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0031" type="story" >

"The troops of JTF were fired at from the militants' camp over night and the
security outfit has no choice but to locate and destroy the camp," he said in an
e-mail to AFP.
</P>
<P>
He said the military would get "rid of the criminals who are bent on causing
unnecessary tension and apprehension in the region".
</P>
<P>
Abubakar said the military also recovered some arms and ammunition during the
raid.
</P>
<P>
Several camps operated by militants have been destroyed since May 13 when
federal troops launched their operation against fighters of the Movement for the
Emancipation of Niger Delta (MEND), Nigeria's main militant group.
</P>
<P>
But MEND said in a statement late Sunday there was no fresh attack on its camp
at Buguma.
</P>
<P>
"The leader of a small group of fighters around the Buguma creek axis in Rivers
state, Egbele has confirmed that there was no attack in his camp as claimed by
the military JTF," the group said.
</P>
<P>
"He (Egbele) said they actually asked him to cooperate by giving the impression
his camp has been over-run," MEND added.
</P>
<P>
In the past three and a half years MEND, which says it is fighting to ensure
local people have a greater share in the oil wealth, has been behind a series of
kidnappings of staff and attacks on oil installations in the region.
</P>
<P>
Unrest in the Niger Delta has reduced Nigeria's daily output to 1.76 million
barrels compared with 2.6 million barrels in January 2006.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0032" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Abortion doctor shot dead at his Kansas church
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
WICHITA, Kansas, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Authorities here on Sunday arrested a suspect in the death of a controversial
provider of late-term abortions, who was fatally shot as he walked into services
at his Kansas church, officials said.
</P>
<P>
Abortion doctor George Tiller, was shot to death just after 10:00 am (1500 GMT)
in the lobby of Reformation Lutheran Church in Wichita, Kansas, police and city
officials said.
</P>
<P>
Wichita officials said the suspect, who was not identified, was arrested some
three hours after the killing, and said they would have more details about the
alleged shooter at a press conference planned for 4 pm local time (2100 GMT
Sunday).
</P>
<P>
"It's an unfortunate incident to happen on a Sunday morning," Wichita police
captain Brent Allred told reporters.
</P>
<P>
"These things should not occur at a any time."
</P>
<P>
Long a lightning rod in the bitter US culture war over abortion, Tiller, 67,
over the years had been picketed, bombed and shot in the arms, before being
killed Sunday.
</P>
<P>
The shooting occurred just two weeks after President Barack Obama sought "common
ground" over the divisive abortion debate in a controversial speech at one of
the top Catholic universities in the United States.
</P>
<P>
The president has attempted to defuse one of the most emotive issues in US
public life by arguing that while abortion should remain legal, the government
should do all it can to limit unwanted pregnancies.
</P>
<P>
But Obama has angered the anti-abortion movement by reversing predecessor George
W. Bush's restrictions on federal funding for embryonic stem-cell research and
for family-planning groups that carry out or facilitate abortions overseas.
</P>
<P>
Obama's choice for health secretary, former Kansas governor Kathleen Sebelius,
has been widely condemned by the anti-abortion movement because of her ties to
Tiller.
</P>
<P>
Tiller, one of the few doctors who still performs late-term abortions in the
United States, has been demonized by abortion opponents who regularly protested
outside his clinic.
</P>
<P>
In 1986, someone placed a bomb on the roof of the clinic, seriously damaging the
building.
</P>
<P>
In 1993, Tiller was shot in both arms outside the clinic. Tiller recovered, and
his assailant received an 11-year prison term.
</P>
<P>
Some 2,000 protesters were also arrested outside the clinic during summer-long
demonstrations in 1991.
</P>
<P>
He was acquitted in March on charges that he performed 19 illegal abortions in
2003 in a case which his lawyer described as a witch hunt.
</P>
<P>
Tiller testified during the trial that he spent years under the protection of
federal agents after the FBI discovered an anti-abortion assassination list in
1994 that listed Tiller as the top target.
</P>
<P>
Tiller also testified that he owns one of only three clinics in the United
States that perform late-term abortions, which are performed on fetuses that
would be viable outside the mother's womb.
</P>
<P>
Late-term abortions are legal in Kansas if two independent physicians agree that
the mother could suffer irreparable harm by giving birth.
</P>
<P>
Tiller was acquitted of having an illegal financial relationship with the doctor
who provided the second opinion.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0033" type="multi" >

AFP world news agenda

<DATELINE>
Hong kong, June 1, 2009 (AFP)

What's coming up around the world:

+ Tensions remain on Korean peninsula

+ Pakistan military 'days away' from reclaiming northwest

SEOUL: Monitoring for possible clashes between North and South Korea after
Pyongyang tested a nuclear weapon and said it was abandoning the armistice
between the two countries.(NKOREA-NUCLEAR-WEAPONS)

PESHAWAR: Reporting as Pakistan's military claims it is just days away from
reclaiming the northwest from Taliban militants, after seizing the main town in
Swat valley and as fighting spills into nearby tribal areas (PAKISTAN-UNREST)

BEIJING: US Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner begins first official trip to
Beijing with issues ranging from the fate of Chinese holdings of dollar-based
assets to the global economic turmoil in the spotlight. Geithner meets with
China's Vice Premier for economic affairs, Wang Qishan, at 0545 GMT (US-CHINA-
ECONOMY-FINANCE-GEITHNER)

BONN: The United Nations' Framework Convention on Climate Change opens a key
session to prepare for the crunch summit in Copenhagen in December on drafting a
new global warming treaty. (UN-CLIMATE-WARMING)

GAZA CITY: A United Nations mission arrives in the Gaza Strip to gather
information for its inquiry on Israel's offensive there. (MIDEAST-CONFLICT-GAZA-
UN-RIGHTS)

GENEVA: Russian and US officials meet for a second round of talks on replacing
the Cold War-era START nuclear disarmament treaty in preparation of the meeting
in July between presidents Dmitry Medvedev and Barack Obama. (RUSSIA-US-NUCLEAR-
WEAPONS)

HELSINKI: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs holds a meeting
on the conflict-torn Sri Lanka and Pakistan. (SRILANKA-PAKISTAN-UN)

JERUSALEM: Monitoring amid rising tension with main ally the United States over
Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank.

- Israel continues "doomsday" exercise to test readiness for missile attacks,
suicide bombings and natural disasters. (to June 4)

NEW YORK: General Motors is expected to file for bankruptcy protection Monday
amid news reports President Barack Obama will issue remarks on his
administration's efforts to rescue the auto giant. (US-COMPANY-AUTO-BANKRUPTCY-
GM)

RAMALLAH, West Bank/GAZA STRIP: Monitoring tensions between the rival two main
Palestinian factions after an arrest of a Hamas militant in the West Bank goes
awry, leaving six people dead. (MIDEAST-UNREST-PALESTINIAN)

SAN SALVADOR: El Salvador inaugurates leftist TV journalist turned politician
Mauricio Funes as its president, at a ceremony to be attended by dignitaries and
officials from across the region. (SALVADOR-POLITICS)

TBILISI: Last day of controversial NATO exercises in Georgia which provoked a
furious reaction from Russia. (GEORGIA-NATO-RUSSIA-DIPLOMACY)

TEHRAN: Monitoring after security officials defuse a bomb on a domestic
passenger plane, two days after 25 people died in a blast at a mosque. (IRAN-
VOTE-UNREST)

TSKHINVALI, Georgia: Developments after Georgia's breakaway region of South
Ossetia votes in elections expected to secure the grip of its separatist leader
nine months after it was the subject of war between Russia and Georgia.
(GEORGIA-RUSSIA-SOSSETIA-CONFLICT-VOTE)

YANGON: Reporting as lawyers in the trial of Aung San Suu Kyi prepare their
final arguments, a day after Myanmar's military junta trades barbs with the pro-
democracy leader (MYANMAR-POLITICS-SUUKYI)

<HEADLINE>
First president of Guinea-Bissau dies aged 78
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
BISSAU, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Luis Cabral, the first post-independence president of Guinea-Bissau who was
later toppled in a military coup, has died of a heart attack in Lisbon,
officials announced on Sunday. He was 78.
</P>
<P>
"It is with shock and sadness that the government and people of Guinea-Bissau
have learnt of the loss of one of their most illustrious sons, Luis Cabral," the
government announced in a statement.
</P>
<P>
The government was to hold an emergency session to organise preparations for a
three-day period of national mourning, the statement added.
</P>
<P>
Natural Resources Minister Oscar Barbosa, a close ally of the former president,
said that Cabral had died of a heart attack in the Portuguese capital on
Saturday night.
</P>
<P>
Cabral was a half-brother of Amilcar Cabral, long-time leader of the
Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde (PAIGC) liberation movement, who was
assassinated in 1973 -- the year before Guinea-Bissau attained its independence
from Portugal.
</P>
<P>
Cabral ruled in Guinea-Bissau until he was overthrown in a coup led by "First
Commissar", or prime minister, Joao Bernardo Vieira on November 14, 1980.
</P>
<P>
After his ouster, Cabral was imprisoned for six months before being released
after the intervention of the Cuban government.
</P>
<P>
He then spent most of the rest of his life in exile in Portugal, although he did
make a brief return to Guinea-Bissau 1999 after Vieira was toppled in another
coup.
</P>
<P>
News of his death comes less than three months after Vieira, who returned to
power in 2005 elections, was assassinated by soldiers in the hours after a bomb
attack which claimed the life of the West African country's military chief.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0036" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
British PM says won't quit as poll predicts Euro election rout
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
British Prime Minister Gordon Brown insisted Sunday he would not quit despite a
scandal over MPs expenses and dire poll ratings for his ruling Labour Party
before crunch European and local elections.
</P>
<P>
He said the expenses furore, which has shown how lawmakers claimed from the
public purse for everything from moat cleaning to a duck island, was "appalling"
and "offends everything that I believe in".
</P>
<P>
Every member of parliament would be forced to account for all their expenses
from the last four years, he promised.
</P>
<P>
Some 13 lawmakers from Labour and the main opposition Conservatives have said
they will resign since the Daily Telegraph newspaper began publishing the leaked
claims three weeks ago.
</P>
<P>
A new Sunday Telegraph/ICM poll suggested the revelations would hit Brown hard
at the European and local elections, in which Britons vote Thursday.
</P>
<P>
It suggested Labour would come third in the elections for the European
Parliament with just 17 percent, behind David Cameron's Conservatives and the
smaller centrist Liberal Democrats.
</P>
<P>
Even more damagingly, it suggested Labour would also come third in a general
election with just 22 percent of the vote -- the worst Brown's party has done in
an opinion poll since 1987.
</P>
<P>
Some 54 percent of those polled thought Labour had been worst affected by the
expenses scandal, compared to 13 percent for the Conservatives.
</P>
<P>
But Brown, who must call a general election by the middle of next year,
dismissed suggestions he could step down to make way for a more popular leader.
</P>
<P>
"Things go up and down," he said in an interview with BBC television. "We're
going through the most difficult economic circumstances the country has faced.
</P>
<P>
"People are angry rightly because they are worried when they see taxpayers'
money wasted on their MPs and they're finding it very difficult... in a
difficult economic situation," he added, referring to Britain's recession.
</P>
<P>
He also said he wanted to introduce a "constitutional renewal" bill and was
looking at reforms including the case for a written constitution, lowering the
voting age to 16 and reform of the unelected upper chamber, the House of Lords.
</P>
<P>
Cameron, meanwhile, renewed his calls for a snap general election, telling the
BBC the public wanted to "sit in judgement on MPs".
</P>
<P>
Public anger over expenses is widespread and in a sermon Sunday, the leader of
the Scottish Catholic church expressed concern at the "fall from grace" of many
people in politics, saying "money (was) at the root of many difficulties".
</P>
<P>
Cardinal Keith O'Brien called on "those in public service of whatever kind who
have failed us to reclaim the high standards which we expect of them".
</P>
<P>
Turnout at European elections in Britain is usually low, due partly to
widespread Eurosceptic sentiment, and in 2004 turnout was just 38 percent.
</P>
<P>
This time, fringe parties such as the anti-EU UK Independence Party and the far-
right British National Party are expected to benefit. Commentators say the BNP
could even win its first seat at the European Parliament.
</P>
<P>
An Economist magazine/YouGov poll last week found that only 31 percent of
Britons think its membership of the European Union is a good thing, compared to
37 percent who think it is bad.
</P>
<P>
ICM interviewed 1,013 adults by telephone May 27-28 for the Sunday Telegraph
poll, while YouGov questioned 2,322 adults in Britain May 22-26.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0039" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Football: Betis relegated after Osasuna, Sporting heroics
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
MADRID, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Real Betis were relegated from the Spanish top-flight on a heart-breaking final
Sunday of the season, drawing 1-1 at home to Valladolid while relegation rivals
Osasuna and Sporting Gijon both won.
</P>
<P>
Betis started a point above the drop zone knowing a win would keep them in the
top tier but Sporting's 2-1 comeback win over Recreativo Huelva coupled with
Osasuna's sensational 2-1 victory against nine-man Real Madrid saw them
relegated with 42 points.
</P>
<P>
Betis, who are based in the southern city of Seville, were last relegated in
2000 but immediately won promotion the following season and have been in the
first division since 2001, finishing as high as fourth in 2005.
</P>
<P>
"It is a sad day because once again the football gods weren't on our side," said
Betis coach Jose Maria Nogues. "Betis now have to get back in the top division
for its fans and history."
</P>
<P>
Getafe, who drew 1-1 with Racing Santander, also finished on 42 points but
stayed up on goal difference while Valladolid's draw at Betis was enough to keep
them safe.
</P>
<P>
It was particularly tough for Betis duo Sergio Garcia and Ricardo Oliveira, who
cost a combined 19 million euros after being relegated with Real Zaragoza last
season.
</P>
<P>
At half-time Sporting Gijon, trailing Recre 1-0, were set to be relegated but
came back to win 2-1 and secure their top-flight status.
</P>
<P>
Sporting had spent a decade in the second division before winning promotion last
season and defied the odds to stay up with Luis Moran scoring a dramatic winner.
</P>
<P>
"It was an agonising game that felt like seven days," said Sporting coach Manolo
Preciado. "Our fans are special and their contribution throughout this season
has been pivotal."
</P>
<P>
Osasuna were third from bottom before kick off and fell behind against Real
Madrid when Gonzalo Higuain scored early on.
</P>
<P>
However, Jose Camacho's men battled back, equalising through Jaroslav Plasil
before Juanfran smashed a stunning volley past Iker Casillas to keep them in the
division.
</P>
<P>
"We reached our target although it was a bit last minute," said Camacho.
"It is clear that Osasuna need to reconstruct the squad a bit because for the
past two seasons we have been fighting for survival on the final weekends of the
season."
</P>
<P>
Michel Salgado and Klaas-Jan Huntelaar were both sent off for Real, who crashed
to a fifth successive defeat.
</P>
<P>
Earlier, Espanyol bid farewell to their Montjuic stadium in style with captain
Raul Tamudo scoring a hat-trick in a 3-0 win over 10-man Malaga.
</P>
<P>
Tamudo, the club's all-time top-scorer and an icon after spending his entire
career at Espanyol, scored twice in the first half and completed his treble with
a 56th-minute penalty to give the Montjuic the perfect send-off.
</P>
<P>
Espanyol's new Cornella-El Prat stadium looked destined to host second-division
football next season before the club produced a sensational late run to beat the
drop.
</P>
<P>
With 26 games played Espanyol were bottom of the table, seven points from
safety, but Argentine coach Mauricio Pochettino turned things around and a burst
of form saw the club win eight out of their ten final games.
</P>
<P>
Malaga coach Antonio Tapia confirmed that he would not be in charge of the club
next season, saying that the time was right to step down.
</P>
<P>
"I won't be coach next season," said Tapia. "After an excellent season I think
it is the ideal time for my family and I to end this chapter in my life."
</P>
<P>
Elsewhere, Sevilla defeated relegated Numancia 2-0 in a game with little at
stake.
</P>
<P>
Sevilla already had a Champions League spot wrapped up before the game and coach
Manolo Jimenez tested fringe players with next season in mind.
</P>
<P>
Jimenez was recently rewarded with a contract extension until 2010 after getting
Sevilla into the Champions League by finishing third and now has the task of
trying to close the gap on the top two of Barcelona and Real Madrid.
</P>
<P>
Numancia will prepare for life in the second division with the highlight of
their campaign a 1-0 victory over treble-winners Barcelona in Soria on the
opening day of the season.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0041" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Golf: Frenchman Cevaer shocks field to win European Open
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 30, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
France's Christian Cevaer, ranked a lowly 449th in the world, shocked a strong
field to win the European Open here on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
After four rounds of golf that saw 45 changes of the lead, the 39-year-old
Frenchman, who has failed to make the top-30 in his last 15 starts and whose
only previous Tour victory was the 2004 Spanish Open, beat England's Steve
Webster, Scot Gary Orr and Spaniard Alvaro Quiros by a shot.
</P>
<P>
His winning total of 281, seven under par, was 13 strokes more than Ross Fisher
took on the same London Club course last year - and his 74 was the highest last
round by a winner all season.
</P>
<P>
But while Webster and Quiros both became more victims of the 471-yard last when
tied for the lead - both carved their drives into the crowd, with Quiros hitting
spectators with his first and second shots - Cevaer kept his nerve.
</P>
<P>
During the week the par four played to an average of nearly 4.7, with 154
bogeys, 48 doubles and 26 sevens or worse, but Cevaer parred it the first two
days, birdied it in the third round and finished with the par he needed.
</P>
<P>
"I'm not a long player, but I used my utility club and it worked out great," he
said.
</P>
<P>
"I made a point that no matter what happened just enjoy my golf, enjoy my skills
and hang in there."
</P>
<P>
He played the front nine in 39 and did not have a birdie until the long 15th,
but the problems meant that it brought him back into a share of top spot.
</P>
<P>
And then three closing pars were good enough to give him the 300,000 pounds
first prize - easily the biggest of his 16-year professional career.
</P>
<P>
At 196th on the "Race to Dubai" money list entering the week he would have been
delighted just to secure his card for next season, but now he has a five-year
Tour exemption.
</P>
<P>
bur/lp09
</P>
<P>
Overnight leader Jeev Milkha Singh of India was still at the top of the
leaderboard in the European Open after windy conditions took a toll of scores at
the London Club in Kent on Saturday.
</P>
<P>
Singh shot a one under par 71 to leave him in the joint lead with France's
Christian Cevaer who went one better with a round of 70.
</P>
<P>
But hot on their heels was 20-year-old rising star Rory McIlroy who caught the
eye with a four-under-par 68 that saw the Northern Irishman close to within
three shots of the leading duo after he'd been in 25th place overnight.
</P>
<P>
Alongside McIlroy in joint third place were England's Chris Wood and Spain's
Alvaro Quiros.
</P>
<P>
Singh, the world number 39, defied the conditions to cover the final six holes
in a superb four under par on a day where Spain's Sergio Garcia was one of
several players to finish with a triple bogey seven.
</P>
<P>
Before his round Singh said it was vital for the progress of golf in India that
it became an Olympic sport.
</P>
<P>
"Golf not being an Olympic sport we have not been getting any funding from the
government," Singh said.
</P>
<P>
"Hopefully in October it does and I think what happens after that is the
government is going to allocate land in each and every city to have a public
driving range so that a normal human being can go there and try a hand at it.
</P>
<P>
"That's when it's going to be really big in our country. It's the fastest-
growing sport in our country, but it's the only way this game is going to get
famous and close to cricket.
</P>
<P>
"Our population is more than a billion and I'm sure there's going to be a lot of
talent out there.
</P>
<P>
"I don't think there's a public driving range in our country and there's only
one public golf course right now. Everything is private.
</P>
<P>
"I remember there were a lot of good players when I was growing up who just
didn't take it up - they just went back to the parents' business."
</P>
<P>
Last week McIlroy shot 65 at Wentworth before falling back in the final round
and it appears injury may have been a factor, although it seems as if he is
getting close to finding a cure.
</P>
<P>
McIlroy, who revealed he'd been struggling with a "little niggle" in his back,
said: "I had a really nice bath last night, got into bed and watched the golf in
the States. I'm a bit of a golf geek to be honest."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
South Ossetia poll set to bolster rebel leader
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
TSKHINVALI, Georgia, June 1, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The party backing South Ossetia's leader Eduard Kokoity was on course Sunday to
sweep legislative elections and tighten the grip of the strongman president on
the Georgian rebel region.
</P>
<P>
Initial results showed Yedinstvo (Unity) well ahead in the vote in the
mountainous rebel region that was the subject of a war last year between Moscow
and Tbilisi and is recognised as independent by Russia and Nicaragua alone.
</P>
<P>
The elections were marked by a sidelining of the local opposition who accuse
Kokoity of seeking a loyal parliamentary majority to push through an amendment
allowing him to run again for office when his second term lapses in 2011.
</P>
<P>
Based on an initial count of almost 61 percent of the vote, South Ossetia's
central election commission said Unity had polled 48.04 percent while the
People's Party, also largely uncritical of Kokoity, won 18.47 percent.
</P>
<P>
The Communists were second with 23.51 percent of the vote.
</P>
<P>
Final results were due at 0600 GMT on Monday with officials estimating the
turnout at 80 percent.
</P>
<P>
Only four parties are competing for the 34 seats in the parliament and the
central election commission barred the only two parties not loyal to Kokoity.
</P>
<P>
The name of Unity also bears more than a passing resemblance to Russia's ruling
party Edinaya Rossiya (United Russia) and it even used pictures of United Russia
party leader Boris Gryzlov on its campaign literature.
</P>
<P>
But Russia -- which outraged the West by recognising South Ossetia as
independent in the wake of the August war with Georgia -- has said South Ossetia
should not amend the existing term limits in its constitution.
</P>
<P>
Kokoity said it was too early to say whether he planned to run again to lead the
region of 50,000 people although he did not rule out that possibility.
</P>
<P>
"There are two and half years left till then and a lot left to do. We are
working and working now. I am not thinking about it yet," he said in an
interview with AFP.
</P>
<P>
"With what happened in August we need three to four years to rebuild," Kokoity
said.
</P>
<P>
Opposition activities said voting would not make a difference. "I plan to sit at
home. There's nothing we can do," said Alan Gassiyev, an opposition leader,
calling the polls "completely illegal."
</P>
<P>
Critics accuse Kokoity, an ex-wrestling champion, of muzzling opponents and
stealing the money sent from Russia.
</P>
<P>
As the reconstruction in the province stalled this winter, the opposition also
accuses the separatist leader and his circle of diverting lorries carrying
construction material and humanitarian aid to traffic the goods in Russia.
</P>
<P>
But despite the slow pace of reconstruction in the republic many praise Kokoity
for his leadership during the August conflict.
</P>
<P>
"Kokoity has done a lot for the people of South Ossetia, he's fought 20 years
for this country," Angela Tedeyeva, a 32-year-old teacher, said as she cast her
ballot.
</P>
<P>
Georgia ridiculed the vote, with the country's reintegration minister Temur
Iakobashvili saying the elections were "nothing but clownery, a farce and a
redistribution of a criminal power."
</P>
<P>
But Kokoity insisted the elections were in strict accordance with law, saying
the polls were "a maturity test for the small independent state."
</P>
<P>
His domestic critics are concerned that the high number of polling stations  in
the villages which were used to be populated by ethnic Georgians and which are
now nearly empty will be used to falsify the election results.
</P>
<P>
As the row over Kokoity's push for a third term threatens to become an
embarrassment for Moscow, there are signs the Kremlin is scaling back its
support for the South Ossetian leader.
</P>
<P>
Sergey Naryshkin, the head of the Russian presidential administration, said on
Russian television this month that South Ossetia should not change the existing
term limits in its constitution.
</P>
<P>
Moscow and Tbilisi fought a brief but intense war last August over the region,
which had enjoyed de facto independence since the early 1990s thanks to tacit
Russian support.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
GM set for bankruptcy as Treasury readies rescue plan
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Washington, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The US Treasury Department on Sunday put final touches on a plan to restructure
General Motors, once the world's largest automaker and now expected to join
rival Chrysler in filing for bankruptcy protection.
</P>
<P>
Monday will be a historic day for the US automobile industry, with  President
Barack Obama poised to discuss General Motors' bankruptcy in remarks planned for
11:30 am (1530 GMT) Monday, after auto giant officially files its bankruptcy
paperwork, US media reported.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile, GM's new chief executive, Fritz Henderson, has scheduled a news
conference for the middle of the day in New York, where the number one US
automaker would file for bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
The US administration had given GM until June 1 to present a viable
restructuring plan, in return for government aid, and the US Treasury Department
had given holders of General Motors until the end of the day Saturday to respond
to the rescue plan.
</P>
<P>
The plan was approved by holders of about 54 percent of the company's bond debt
according to Elliot Sloane, spokesman for an ad hoc bondholders committee.
Washington had warned that if the plan were rejected, creditors risked losing
everything.
</P>
<P>
Agreement boosted the Treasury's plan for creating a new company shorn of labor
costs and money losing assets, in a rescue that could reach 60 billion dollars
as the state takes a 72.5 per cent ownership stake in the 101 year old company.
</P>
<P>
Canada, which has several GM factories, is also set to be digging into its
pockets for the rescue plan.
</P>
<P>
Among the backers was a committee of large investors holding about 20 percent of
GM's 27.2 billion dollars in outstanding bonds, The New York Times reported.
</P>
<P>
Under the plan, the bondholders would obtain the rights to buy an extra 15
percent of GM's stock at a low price. They would also control 25 percent of the
new GM, after having supported the new company's creation in bankruptcy court.
</P>
<P>
Bondholders who rejected the plan could still fight it in court, but the
government maintains they could end up with little or nothing if they take that
path.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile Monday New York bankruptcy judge Arthur Gonzales was set to rule on
number three US automaker Chrysler, which filed for bankruptcy protection a
month ago.
</P>
<P>
Under an expedited process, Gonzales was expected to approve the creation of a
new Chrysler that would preserve the automaker's healthiest assets and liquidate
the rest.
</P>
<P>
The new entity will be controlled by a consortium consisting of the Italian
automaker Fiat, the United Auto Workers union, and the US and Canadian
governments.
</P>
<P>
Fiat will have a 20 percent stake with the option to increase it to 35 percent;
the UAW 55 percent; and the US and Canadian governments 10 percent.
</P>
<P>
The automakers' fate, the subject of debate on television talks shows, is being
closely watched in US political and economic circles.
</P>
<P>
"This is a real sad day," said former Republican presidential contender Mitt
Romney.
</P>
<P>
"I'm a son of Detroit. My dad was an auto executive. You know, I drive American
cars. I love American cars. My heart bleeds for the people in Michigan and
Detroit, for all these auto workers," he said on Fox News.
</P>
<P>
At the end of last year, GM had 244,000 employees around the world, about half
of them in the United States.
</P>
<P>
Republican Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, called the auto rescue
plan "a big mistake," arguing that the government had done too much to keep GM
and Chyrsler out of bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
In an interview with CNN, he held up the example of Ford, the number two US
automaker, as "an American company that hasn't taken government money and is
still producing automobiles."
</P>
<P>
Corporate leaders, meanwhile, urged the government not to overstay its welcome
in the private sector.
</P>
<P>
"I think all of us understand the need for the government to intervene and take
the actions they did," said Anne Mulcahy, chief executive of Xerox. "But I also
think there's a need for an exit plan."
</P>
<P>
The possibility of bankruptcy for such an iconic American company has been
viewed with great foreboding in a country where the automobile is deeply
embedded in the national imagination.
</P>
<P>
"The phrase 'bankrupt General Motors,' which we expect to hear uttered on Monay,
leaves Americans my age in economic shock," the writer PJ O'Rourke said in the
Wall Street Journal. "The words are as melodramatic as 'Mom's nude photos.'"
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
palermo, Italy, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Sicily's city of Palermo was buried in a mountain of waste on Sunday as garbage
collectors pressed on with a strike over fears that their struggling employer
will not pay them.
</P>
<P>
Piles of trash as high as two metres (6 feet 5 inches) lined apartment buildings
and church walls across the city, as firefighters received reports of some 200
rubbish fires sparked by hot temperatures on the island.
</P>
<P>
Garbagemen have been on strike or have done limited trash pick-ups as they
refuse to work overtime for fear of not getting paid by their employer, the
trash collection company Amia, which is 150 million euros in the hole.
</P>
<P>
The city council dropped Sunday a plan to raise the waste management tax by 30
percent to help Amia after a stormy municipal meeting.
</P>
<P>
Mayor Diego Cammarata said the strike was "seriously irresponsible" as the city
was more and more "invaded by trash in an intolerable and indecent way."
</P>
<P>
The collectors' union decided to remain on strike until they received guarantees
on the future of their employer.
</P>
<P>
They also demanded better work equipment, saying that they were not working in
safe conditions.
</P>
<P>
The strike recalls the rubbish problems that have hit Naples, where the mafia
has been blamed for a garbage crisis in a city that has been on a "waste state
of emergency" for 14 years.

<HEADLINE>
Yachting: Volvo race changes rules to attract more women
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Galway, Ireland, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Organisers of the Volvo Ocean Race announced Sunday changes to the next edition
of the round-the-world yacht race aimed at boosting the number of women who take
part.
</P>
<P>
For the first time in the 36-year history of the event, formerly called the
Whitbread race, no women sailors are taking part in the 2008-09 edition of the
race, which involves eight teams and began in Alicante, Spain in October.
</P>
<P>
Organisers decided that female teams will be allowed to carry 12 sailors, two of
whom may be men, instead of just 10 for an all male team during the next edition
of the world's most grueling offshore yacht race scheduled for 2011-12.
</P>
<P>
The change in the rules for the crew make-up for the next race was "an effort to
encourage female participation", they said in a statement following a meeting in
Galway, Ireland where current race entries have made a stop.
</P>
<P>
Specialists say female entries have disappeared from the race due to the
selection of the more powerful Volvo Open 70 yachts in 2004, which are longer
and require more physical force to control than the old Ocean 60 yachts that
were used before.
</P>
<P>
"These boats are animals," said Lisa McDonald, who attempted to raise a mixed
campaign for the last race with her husband Neal after skippering Amer Sports
Too in 2001.
</P>
<P>
"They are wild and furious and pretty powerful so until there is a new rule, it
is difficult to imagine girls being competitive in them," she told the Volvo
Ocean Race website in January.
</P>
<P>
The organisers of the Volvo Ocean Race also announced several other changes for
future editions designed to make the race more competitive and less costly.
</P>
<P>
The maximum weight for the keel fin and bulb of participating yachts in the
future will be set at 7,400 kilogrammes and headfoils will be banned.
</P>
<P>
Organisers are also looking to ban two-boat testing which favours teams with
bigger budgets. One of Swedish team Ericsson's two entries in the ongoing Volvo
Ocean Race, the Ericsson 4, currently leads the overall classification.
</P>
<P>
Volvo is seeking to make it possible for a team to be competitive with a budget
of between 15-20 million euros in future race. They hope lower costs will
attract about a dozen teams, instead of the 7 or 8 in recent editions.
</P>
<P>
The current Volvo Ocean Race is to conclude in Saint Petersburg, Russia, in June
after negotiating 10 stages over 37,000 nautical miles.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0052" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Millvina Dean, last Titanic survivor, dies in England: reports
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Millvina Dean, the last remaining survivor of the sinking of the Titanic in
1912, died in a care home in England on Sunday, media reports said. She was 97.
</P>
<P>
Elizabeth Gladys Dean, known to friends as Millvina, was only nine weeks old
when the liner hit an iceberg in the Atlantic Ocean on the night of April 14,
1912, and sank killing 1,500 people.
</P>
<P>
She survived after being bundled up in a sack and carried to safety. Her mother
Georgette Eva and brother Bertram also made it, but her father, Bertram Frank,
was among those who died.
</P>
<P>
Dean died in a private nursing home near Ashurst in the southern English county
of Hampshire, according to the BBC and Britain's domestic Press Association news
agency. Staff there refused to comment late Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Dean's family had boarded the Titanic at Southampton, heading for a new life in
Kansas where her father hoped to open a tobacconist shop.
</P>
<P>
Born on February 12, 1912, Dean was the youngest passenger on board. At the
time, RMS Titanic was the most luxurious, most technically advanced and largest
passenger liner in the world.
</P>
<P>
She was dubbed "unsinkable", but it took just two hours and 40 minutes for her
to disappear into the icy waters of the Atlantic after striking an iceberg at
11:40 pm on April 14.
</P>
<P>
Dean was taken back to Southampton with her family after the disaster and did
not find out that she had been on board until she was eight years old and her
mother was planning to remarry.
</P>
<P>
According to enthusiasts' website Encyclopedia Titanica (ET), Dean worked for
the government as a cartographer during World War II and then for an engineering
company.
</P>
<P>
She told reporters that it was not until the wreckage of the liner was found in
1985 that she suddenly became a celebrity, taking part in documentaries and
giving media interviews.
</P>
<P>
Dean was invited to complete her family's ill-fated journey to the United States
in 1997 aboard the QE2, and accepted, although she turned down an offer to
attend the premier of the movie "Titanic" because it would be too upsetting.
</P>
<P>
She moved into a private nursing home in Hampshire after breaking her hip three
years ago, and after struggling to pay the bills was forced to sell off some of
her memorabilia.
</P>
<P>
At auction in October 2008 she raised 31,150 pounds (40,000 euros, 53,900
dollars), selling off rare prints of the liner signed by the artists as well as
compensation letters sent to her mother by the Titanic Relief Fund.
</P>
<P>
Dean was also forced to sell a 100-year-old suitcase filled with clothes donated
to her family by the people of New York when they arrived after being rescued.
</P>
<P>
In the wake of the auction, friends including members of the British Titanic
Society and the Belfast Titanic Society -- the liner was built in Belfast in
Northern Ireland-- set up a campaign to secure her future.
</P>
<P>
Among the donors to the Millvina Fund were Hollywood actors Kate Winslet and
Leonardo DiCaprio, who starred in the 1997 "Titanic" film. The pair and the
film's director, James Cameron, reportedly donated 30,000 US dollars in total.
</P>
<P>
The last remaining US survivor, Lillian Asplund, died in her home in May 2006 at
the age of 99. She was just five years old when the Titanic went down.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0053" type="other" >

Support for EU treaty rising in ailing Ireland: poll
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
dublin, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Support for the European Union's Lisbon treaty is consolidating in recession-hit
Ireland, according to a poll released Sunday, ahead of a second referendum
likely to be held by October.
</P>
<P>
The TNS mrbi poll for Monday's Irish Times found support has increased by two
points to 54 percent on a similar survey a fortnight ago, while the percentage
of "no" voters has fallen one point to 28 percent.
</P>
<P>
Eighteen percent said they did not know, down one point.
</P>
<P>
In a shock result in a referendum last June, 53.4 percent voted "no" and 46.6
percent voted "yes", sparking a major crisis in the European Union.
</P>
<P>
Of the 27 EU nations, only Ireland is constitutionally bound to hold a
referendum on the treaty, which is designed to improve decision-making in a
greatly expanded bloc. It must be ratified by all member states.
</P>
<P>
Dublin is seeking a number of guarantees from Brussels, including on the right
to make its own laws on tax, defence and abortion, before holding another vote,
likely before the end of the October.
</P>
<P>
The Irish Times said the "yes" side has maintained a consistent and steadily
growing lead in its three polls since the beginning of 2009, despite a collapse
in support for the coalition government of Prime Minister Brian Cowen.
</P>
<P>
The former Celtic Tiger economy has been devastated by the financial crisis, and
voters were asked if, in the light of the recession, they thought it was better
to be part of the EU.
</P>
<P>
A substantial 81 percent thought it was (up two points), 10 percent thought it
was not (no change) and nine percent had no opinion (down two).
</P>
<P>
The pollsters interviewed 2,000 voters face-to-face between May 26 and 28.
</P>

Recession-hit Croatia votes in local polls
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ZAGREB, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Voters in recession-hit Croatia cast ballots in the second round of local and
regional elections on Sunday seen as a referendum on the governing coalition's
handling of the global economic crisis.
</P>
<P>
Partial results released several hours after polls closed at 7:00pm (1700 GMT)
showed that the main opposition Social Democrats were set to retain power in the
capital Zagreb as their candidate and incumbent mayor was re-elected.
</P>
<P>
Milan Bandic, seeking his fourth term, garnered 61.74 percent of the votes,
according to results from 573 out of 601 polling stations.
</P>
<P>
But in the second city of Split, on the central Adriatic coast, independent
Zeljko Kerum appeared set for victory, according to partial results.
</P>
<P>
The polls gave some four million voters the right for the first time to directly
elect mayors, county prefects and municipal heads, along with 21 county
assemblies and more than 550 city and town councils.
</P>
<P>
Although a final figure was not yet available, turnout appeared to be low with
the electoral commission saying that 26.53 percent of the electorate had voted
by 1400 GMT.
</P>
<P>
On May 17, Prime Minister Ivo Sanader's ruling conservative Croatian Democratic
Union (HDZ) was re-elected in most counties in the first round while the SDP
asserted their control in major cities.
</P>
<P>
The HDZ and its coalition partners won seven prefect posts and held a majority
in 14 out of 21 county assemblies. The SDP got four county prefects and secured
control of five county assemblies.
</P>
<P>
Local analysts said the vote confirmed that the SDP and left bloc dominate in
more developed parts of Croatia as well as in cities, while the HDZ and right-
wing parties are more popular in less developed and rural areas.
</P>
<P>
The HDZ, founded by late nationalist leader Franjo Tudjman, returned to power in
2003 after three years in opposition. Sanader has since shaken off the HDZ's
hardline nationalist legacy and transformed it into a party that is aiming to
lead Croatia to becoming the European Union's 28th member by 2011.
