<HEADLINE>
GM poised for bankruptcy as Treasury readies rescue plan
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Washington, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
President Barack Obama discuss General Motor's bankruptcy in remarks planned for
11:30 am (1530 GMT) Monday, after auto giant officially files its bankruptcy
paperwork, US media reported.
</P>
<P>
CNN reported Sunday that Obama will explain the rationale for the filing and his
hopes that the bankruptcy filing offers the best hope for the company's
turnaround.
</P>
<P>
The president's administration had given GM until June 1 to present a viable
restructuring plan, in return for government aid, and the US Treasury Department
had given holders of General Motors until the end of the day Saturday to respond
to the plan.
</P>
<P>
The plan was approved by holders of about 54 percent of the company's bond debt
according to Elliot Sloane, spokesman for an ad hoc bondholders committee.
</P>
<P>
GM's new chief executive, Fritz Henderson, also has scheduled a news conference
for midday Monday in New York.
</P>
<P>
General Motors got a boost Sunday as holders of more than half its bond debt
agreed to a US Treasury rescue plan that would create a new company shorn of
labor costs and money losing assets.
</P>
<P>
The rescue could reach 60 billion dollars with the state taking a 72.5 per cent
ownership stake in the 101 year old company. Canada, which has several GM
factories, also will be digging into its pockets.
</P>
<P>
The new Treasury rescue plan would give bondholders up to 25 percent of the
company. Washington had warned that if the plan were rejected, creditors risked
losing everything.
</P>
<P>
Among the backers was a committee of large investors holding about 20 percent of
GM's 27.2 billion dollars in outstanding bonds, The New York Times reported.
</P>
<P>
Under the plan, the bondholders would obtain the rights to buy an extra 15
percent of GM's stock at a low price. They would also control 25 percent of the
new GM, after having supported the new company's creation in bankruptcy court.
</P>
<P>
Bondholders who rejected the plan could still fight it in bankruptcy court, but
the government has warned they could end up with little or nothing if they take
that path.
</P>
<P>
The New York bankruptcy court also is expected to rule Monday on number three US
automaker Chrysler, which filed for bankruptcy protection a month ago.
</P>
<P>
Under an expedited process, judge Arthur Gonzales was expected to approve the
creation of a new Chrysler, called 'New Carco,' which would preserve the
automaker's healthiest assets and liquidate the rest.
</P>
<P>
The new entity will be controlled by a consortium consisting of the Italian
automaker Fiat, the United Auto Workers union, and the US and Canadian
governments.
</P>
<P>
Fiat will have a 20 percent stake with the option to increase it to 35 percent;
the UAW 55 percent; and the US and Canadian governments 10 percent.
</P>
<P>
The automakers fate, the subject of debate on television talks shows, is being
closely watched in US political and economic circles.
</P>
<P>
"This is a real sad day," said former Republican presidential contender Mitt
Romney.
</P>
<P>
"I'm a son of Detroit. My dad was an auto executive. You know, I drive American
cars. I love American cars. My heart bleeds for the people in Michigan and
Detroit, for all these auto workers," he said on Fox News.
</P>
<P>
At the end of last year, GM had 244,000 employees around the world, about half
of them in the United States.
</P>
<P>
Mitch McConnell, the senate minority leader, called the auto rescue plan "a big
mistake," arguing that the government had done too much to keep GM and Chyrsler
out of bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
In an interview with CNN, he held up the example of Ford, the number two US
automaker, as "an American company that hasn't taken government money and is
still producing automobiles."
</P>
<P>
Corporate leaders, meanwhile, urged the government not to overstay its welcome
in the private sector.
</P>
<P>
"I think all of us understand the need for the government to intervene and take
the actions they did," said Anne Mulcahy, chief executive of Xerox. "But I also
think there's a need for an exit plan."
</P>
<P>
The possibility of bankruptcy for such an iconic American company has been
viewed with great foreboding in a country where the automobile is deeply
embedded in the national imagination.
</P>
<P>
"The phrase 'bankrupt General Motors,' which we expect to hear uttered on Monay,
leaves Americans my age in economic shock," the writer PJ O'Rourke said in the
Wall Street Journal. "The words are as melodramatic as 'Mom's nude photos.'"
</P>
</TEXT>

Iraq's May death toll lowest since invasion
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
BAGHDAD, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The month of May witnessed 155 deaths from violence in Iraq, the fewest of any
month since the US-led invasion in 2003, official figures showed on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Statistics compiled by the defence, interior and health ministries showed that
124 civilians, six soldiers and 25 policemen were killed by attacks in May.
</P>
<P>
People wounded included 285 civilians, four soldiers and 55 police.
</P>
<P>
Some 40 presumed insurgents were killed and 904 arrested, according to the
statistics.
</P>

Deaths from violence fell by more than half from the 355 registered in April,
which was the deadliest month since September last year.
</P>
<P>
However, 24 US soldiers died in Iraq in May, up from 19 in April and the
heaviest toll since September.
</P>
<P>
According to an AFP count based on the independent website icasualties.org,
4,306 American troops have been killed in Iraq since the 2003 invasion that
ousted Saddam Hussein but sparked a deadly insurgency.

<HEADLINE>
South Ossetia poll set to bolster rebel leader
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
TSKHINVALI, Georgia, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The party backing South Ossetia's leader Eduard Kokoity was on course Sunday to
sweep legislative elections and tighten the grip of the strongman president on
the Georgian rebel region.
</P>
<P>
Initial results showed Yedinstvo (Unity) well ahead in the vote in the
mountainous rebel region that was the subject of a war last year between Moscow
and Tbilisi and is recognized as independent by Russia and Nicaragua alone.
</P>
<P>
The elections were marked by a sidelining of the local opposition who accuse
Kokoity of seeking a loyal parliamentary majority to push through an amendment
allowing him to run again for office when his second term lapses in 2011.
</P>
<P>
Based on an initial count of almost eight percent of the vote, South Ossetia's
central election commission said Unity had polled 58.62 percent while the
People's Party, also largely uncritical of Kokoity, won 20.35 percent.
</P>
<P>
The Communists were third with 14.6 percent of the vote. Final results were due
at 0600 GMT on Monday with officials estimating the turnout at 80 percent.
</P>
<P>
Only four parties are competing for the 34 seats in the parliament and the
central election commission barred the only two parties not loyal to Kokoity.
</P>
<P>
The name of Unity also bears more that a passing resemblance to Russia's ruling
party Edinaya Rossiya (United Russia) and it even used pictures of United Russia
party leader Boris Gryzlov on its campaign literature.
</P>
<P>
But Russia -- which outraged the West by recognising South Ossetia as
independent in the wake of the August war with Georgia -- has said South Ossetia
should not amend the existing term limits in its constitution.
</P>
<P>
Kokoity said it was too early to say whether he planned to run again to lead the
region of 50,000 people although he did not rule out that possibility.
</P>
<P>
"There are two and half years left till then and a lot left to do. We are
working and working now. I am not thinking about it yet," he said in an
interview with AFP.
</P>
<P>
"With what happened in August we need three to four years to rebuild," Kokoity
said.
</P>
<P>
Opposition activities said voting would not make a difference. "I plan to sit at
home. There's nothing we can do," said Alan Gassiyev, an opposition leader,
calling the polls "completely illegal."
</P>
<P>
Critics accuse Kokoity, an ex-wrestling champion, of muzzling opponents and
stealing the money sent from Russia.
</P>
<P>
As the reconstruction in the province stalled this winter, the opposition also
accuses the separatist leader and his circle of diverting lorries carrying
construction material and humanitarian aid to traffic the goods in Russia.
</P>
<P>
But despite the slow pace of reconstruction in the republic many praise Kokoity
for his leadership during the August conflict.
</P>
<P>
"Kokoity has done a lot for the people of South Ossetia, he's fought 20 years
for this country," Angela Tedeyeva, a 32-year-old teacher, said as she cast her
ballot.
</P>
<P>
Georgia ridiculed the vote, with the country's reintegration minister Temur
Iakobashvili saying the elections were "nothing but clownery, a farce and a
redistribution of a criminal power."
</P>
<P>
But Kokoity insisted the elections were in strict accordance with law, saying
the polls were "a maturity test for the small independent state."
</P>
<P>
His domestic critics are concerned that the high number of polling stations  in
the villages which were used to be populated by ethnic Georgians and which are
now nearly empty will be used to falsify the election results.
</P>
<P>
As the row over Kokoity's push for a third term threatens to become an
embarrassment for Moscow, there are signs the Kremlin is scaling back its
support for the South Ossetian leader.
</P>
<P>
Sergey Naryshkin, the head of the Russian presidential administration, said on
Russian television this month that South Ossetia should not change the existing
term limits in its constitution.
</P>
<P>
Moscow and Tbilisi fought a brief but intense war last August over the region,
which had enjoyed de facto independence since the early 1990s thanks to tacit
Russian support.
</P>
</TEXT>

</P>
<P>
Civilians have started fleeing the area fearing a fresh military onslaught, but
the army has denied an imminent assault on Waziristan, where militants branded
by Washington as the greatest terror threat to the West are holed up.
</P>
<P>
The United States, which is firmly backing the current military drive, had
warned that the rebels threaten Pakistan's very existence.
</P>
<P>
Officials have said that lower-ranking Taliban leaders had been killed but it
was harder to get to the top leaders, who had a network of hardcore militants
around them and had slipped into the rugged mountain terrain.
</P>
<P>
"They will be eliminated wherever we find them," said one military official, who
did not wish to be named as he was not authorised to speak to the media, adding:
"We believe that they are somewhere in the mountains."
</P>
<P>
Pakistan has slapped a 600,000-dollar price on the head of firebrand Swat
Taliban commander Maulana Fazlullah for masterminding the nearly two-year
uprising in the valley to enforce sharia law.
</P>
<P>
The government has also offered rewards for 21 rebel chiefs -- wanted dead or
alive -- from Swat. The military claims to have killed 1,244 militants since the
offensive began, although the numbers are impossible to verify.
</P>
<P>
As the government ups its campaign to stamp out the militants, fears are growing
of a wave of revenge attacks.
</P>
<P>
The northwestern capital Peshawar and the eastern cultural centre of Lahore have
both been rocked by deadly explosions in the last five days, killing a total of
39 people and wounding hundreds more.
</P>
<P>
A spokesman for Pakistan Taliban chief Baitullah Mehsud has claimed Wednesday's
suicide bombing on a police building in Lahore, and warned of more "massive
attacks" to avenge the Swat military operation.
</P>
<P>
Nearly 2.4 million people have fled the current offensive, and the military
relaxed a curfew Sunday in most parts of the northwest including Mingora to
allow people trapped on the roads to return home or leave the region.
</P>
<P>
Senior Red Cross officials said Sunday they were "gravely concerned" over the
situation in Swat Valley, after an ICRC team reported problems with running
water, food, electricty and communications.
</P>
<P>
"The people of Swat need greater humanitarian protection and assistance
immediately," said Pascal Cuttat, head of the organisation's delegation in
Pakistan.
</P>
<P>
"Given what we have already seen on the ground, we are mobilising additional
resources, but safe and unimpeded access to the area remains essential for our
teams to deliver."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Iraq delays Kirkuk election report by a week: MP
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Baghdad, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The final report on staging provincial elections in Iraq's disputed region of
Kirkuk has been delayed by another week because of disagreements among
commission members, an MP said on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
"The commission on Sunday notified parliament speaker Iyad al-Samarrai that it
had not succeeded in reaching a compromise" acceptable to Kirkuk's Kurdish,
Turkmen and Arab communities, Mohammad Mahdi al-Bayati, a Turkmen member of the
commission, told AFP.
</P>
<P>
Samarrai asked commission members "to continue their mission another week" and
said he will submit "his own suggestions for a solution," Bayati added.
</P>
<P>
Arabs and Turkmen oppose to any further extension beyond a week although the
Kurds have no objection, he said.
</P>
<P>
The commission should have delivered its report on elections in the province by
mid-April, but the deadline was put back to the end of May.
</P>
<P>
Oil-rich Kirkuk, 250 kilometres (150 miles) north of the capital, has a
population of around 900,000.
</P>
<P>
The Arab and Turkmen communities want seats on the provincial council to be
divided into three equal blocs, but the Kurds say they form the majority of the
population and want better representation.
</P>
<P>
Intercommunal tensions prevented the staging of provincial elections in Kirkuk
on January 31, when the rest of Iraq except the three Kurdish provinces voted
for new councils.
</P>
<P>
The national parliament in Baghdad, backed by the United Nations, set up a
commission to look for a solution.
</P>
</TEXT>

</P>
<P>

</P>

outside her father's home in the southeastern Bulgarian town of Asenovgrad.
</P>

old brother Pavel managed to escape and is still missing.
</P>

Todor Vasilev, of kidnapping them from their home in Poland.
</P>
<P>
The father denied having taken the children to Bulgaria against their will, and
accused Jadwigd of being a poor parent.
</P>

have denounced the mother's behaviour while recognising the fact that a court
had indeed granted her the right to take them from the father.
</P>

saying that it "regrets the fact that some media reports on this case are far
from objective ... and cause unnecessary emotions in the society that do not
contribute to solving the case."
</P>
<P>
"The Bulgarian court ruled at two instances that the children must be returned
to the place from which they were kidnapped, against the will and in the absence
of one of the parents," it added.

<TEXT>
<P>
Atletico Madrid striker Diego Forlan won the 'pichichi' crown for the Spanish
league's top-scorer after finishing the season with 32 goals as his side
finished fourth to secure Champions League football.
</P>
<P>
Uruguayan international Forlan, 30, finishes two goals above long-time leader,
Barcelona's Samuel Eto'o, to lift his second pichichi title having won it in
Villarreal's colours in 2005.
</P>
<P>
"I'm very happy because we qualified for the Champions League for the second
consecutive year and because I won the pichichi in a very strong Spanish
league," said Forlan.
</P>
<P>
Forlan, a 21-million-euro signing from Villarreal in 2007, hit a real purple
patch scoring in eight consecutive games to top the charts and become the first
player to score 30 goals in a season since Brazilian great Ronaldo netted 34
goals with Barcelona in 1997.
</P>
<P>

attracted interest from several clubs but Forlan has insisted he is happy at
Atletico where he is contracted until 2011.

<HEADLINE>
Football: Betis relegated after Osasuna, Sporting heroics
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
MADRID, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Real Betis were relegated from the Spanish top-flight on a heart-breaking final
Sunday of the season, drawing 1-1 at home to Valladolid while relegation rivals
Osasuna and Sporting Gijon both won.
</P>
<P>
Betis started a point above the drop zone knowing a win would keep them in the
top tier but Sporting's 2-1 comeback win over Recreativo Huelva coupled with
Osasuna's sensational 2-1 victory against nine-man Real Madrid saw them
relegated with 42 points.
</P>
<P>
Betis, who are based in the southern city of Seville, were last relegated in
2000 but immediately won promotion the following season and have been in the
first division since 2001, finishing as high as fourth in 2005.
</P>
<P>
Getafe, who drew 1-1 with Racing Santander, also finished on 42 points but
stayed up on goal difference while Valladolid's draw at Betis was enough to keep
them safe.
</P>
<P>
It was particularly tough for Betis duo Sergio Garcia and Ricardo Oliveira, who
cost a combined 19 million euros after being relegated with Real Zaragoza last
season.
</P>
<P>
At half-time Sporting Gijon, trailing Recre 1-0, were set to be relegated but
came back to win 2-1 and secure their top-flight status.
</P>
<P>
Sporting had spent a decade in the second division before winning promotion last
season and defied the odds to stay up with Luis Moran scoring a dramatic winner.
</P>
<P>
Osasuna were third from bottom before kick off and fell behind against Real
Madrid when Gonzalo Higuain scored early on.
</P>
<P>
However, Jose Camacho's men battled back, equalising through Jaroslav Plasil
before Juanfran smashed a stunning volley past Iker Casillas to keep them in the
division.
</P>
<P>
Michel Salgado and Klaas-Jan Huntelaar were both sent off for Real, who crashed
to a fifth successive defeat.
</P>
<P>
Earlier, Espanyol bid farewell to their Montjuic stadium in style with captain
Raul Tamudo scoring a hat-trick in a 3-0 win over 10-man Malaga.
</P>
<P>
Tamudo, the club's all-time top-scorer and an icon after spending his entire
career at Espanyol, scored twice in the first half and completed his treble with
a 56th-minute penalty to give the Montjuic the perfect send-off.
</P>
<P>
Espanyol's new Cornella-El Prat stadium looked destined to host second-division
football next season before the club produced a sensational late run to beat the
drop.
</P>
<P>
With 26 games played Espanyol were bottom of the table, seven points from
safety, but Argentine coach Mauricio Pochettino turned things around and a burst
of form saw the club win eight out of their ten final games.
</P>
<P>
Malaga coach Antonio Tapia confirmed that he would not be in charge of the club
next season, saying that the time was right to step down.
</P>
<P>
"I won't be coach next season," said Tapia. "After an excellent season I think
it is the ideal time for my family and I to end this chapter in my life."
</P>
<P>
Elsewhere, Sevilla defeated relegated Numancia 2-0 in a game with little at
stake.
</P>
<P>
Sevilla already had a Champions League spot wrapped up before the game and coach
Manolo Jimenez tested fringe players with next season in mind.
</P>
<P>
Jimenez was recently rewarded with a contract extension until 2010 after getting
Sevilla into the Champions League by finishing third and now has the task of
trying to close the gap on the top two of Barcelona and Real Madrid.
</P>
<P>
Numancia will prepare for life in the second division with the highlight of
their campaign a 1-0 victory over treble-winners Barcelona in Soria on the
opening day of the season.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Last Titanic survivor dies in England: BBC
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Millvina Dean, the last remaining survivor of the sinking of the Titanic, died
Sunday at a care home in England, the BBC reported, citing two of her friends.
She was 97.
</P>
<P>
Dean was a two-month-old baby and her family were emigrating to Kansas in the
United States when the Titanic sank after hitting an iceberg in the Atlantic
Ocean on its maiden voyage in 1912.
</P>
<P>
She was placed in a sack and carried to safety. Her mother and brother also
survived, but her father was among the 1,500 passengers and crew who died.
</P>
<P>
Two of Dean's unnamed friends told the BBC that she died at the care home in
Hampshire, in southern England. She had spent most of her life in Southampton in
the county of Hampton, from where the Titanic set out.
</P>
<P>
Dean had been struggling to pay the bills for her care home and in October 2008
raised 31,150 pounds (40,000 euros, 53,900 dollars) by auctioning off items from
the liner.
</P>
<P>
She was forced to sell a 100-year-old suitcase filled with clothes which was
donated to her family by the people of New York when they arrived in the United
States after being rescued.
</P>
<P>
Rare prints of the liner signed by the artists along with compensation letters
sent to her mother by the Titanic Relief Fund also went under the hammer in
Devizes, southwest England.
</P>
<P>
The last remaining US survivor, Lillian Asplund, died in her home in May 2006 at
the age of 99. She was just five years old when the Titanic went down.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Football: Sad exit for Jose as Ahly stunned in Angola
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
JOHANNESBURG, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Manuel Jose ended his title-strewn career as Al-Ahly coach disastrously when the
Egyptian giants were dumped out of the African Confederation Cup by Santos in
Angola on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Ahly, winners of the African Champions League a record six times, took a 3-0
lead into the return match and even the absence of star midfielder Mohamed
Aboutraika was not expected to prevent them reaching the group phase.
</P>
<P>
But a Santos team competing in Africa for the first time this year had other
ideas and triumphed 3-0 in Luanda to level the aggregate score before winning
the fourth-round tie 6-5 on penalties.
</P>
<P>
"It is unbelievable to be out of this competition and to have lost by three
goals today. My players have won so many trophies with me," a stunned Jose told
AFP at Coqueiros Stadium in the Angolan capital.
</P>
<P>
"But, at the same time, the team was tired as we have just finished the Egyptian
championship and we also had three players missing on national duty in Oman.
</P>
<P>
"I am sad to have ended my time at Ahly in this way, but I have fantastic
memories. I love and respect the club so much and it was the best time in my
life as a coach."
</P>
<P>
Among those who failed from the spot for Ahly was Angola-born striker Flavio
Amado, whose agent claims he is quitting the Cairo 'Red Devils' for a three-year
contract with Saudi Arabian outfit Al-Shabab.
</P>
<P>
Bebucho put the Angolans ahead mid-way through the first half, Milex set up a
thrilling finish with a second goal as the game entered the closing stages and
Saul struck the crucial third two minutes from full-time.
</P>
<P>
All the goals were brilliantly executed by a team who scored four goals each in
previous home encounters against USM of Gabon and Union Douala of Cameroon
having received a first round bye.
</P>
<P>
Bebucho strode forward before unleashing an unstoppable 30-metre shot past
goalkeeper Ramzi Saleh, Milex volleyed a loose ball into the net from close
range and Saul clinically sidefooted home a cross.
</P>
<P>
Success for Santos completed a wonderful weekend for the oil-rich southern
Africa nation in the second-tier African club competition, as Primeiro Agosto
eliminated holders CS Sfaxien in Tunisia on Saturday, also after a shootout.
</P>
<P>
Ahly have campaigned in Africa regularly since 1975 and this was only the fourth
time they had suffered a three-goal loss, with Mouloudia Alger of Algeria,
Hearts of Oak of Ghana and Al-Hilal of Sudan inflicting the other defeats.
</P>
<P>
The heavy reverses against Mouloudia and Hearts came three decades ago while
Hilal triumphed two years ago in Omdurman against a club that claims 40 million
supporters in Egypt and the Middle East.
</P>
<P>
It was a sad exit for Jose, who stays in Luanda to take over a struggling
Angolan national team from June 1 with the task of building a team capable of
using home advantage to win the 2010 African Nations Cup.
</P>
<P>
The 63-year-old Portuguese led Ahly to four of their six African Champions
League titles and many African media observers consider him the greatest foreign
coach to have worked at club level on the continent.
</P>
<P>
Primeiro lost 2-0 to Sfaxien only to convert all their post-match penalties and
win the shootout 5-4, while Stade Malien of Mali outplayed Al-Ittihad Khemisset
of Morocco 3-1 in Bamako to advance 4-2 on aggregate.
</P>
<P>
Another five ties in the final qualifying round will be decided later on Sunday
before the mini-league phase kicks off in mid-July.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Cycling: Menchov wins Tour of Italy despite dramatic fall
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ROME, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Russian rider Denis Menchov won the Tour of Italy here on Sunday despite
suffering a dramatic fall in the last kilometre of the final stage, a 14.4km
time-trial round.
</P>
<P>
The Rabobank cyclist, who is the third Russian to win the race, added the title
to his two Tour of Spain victories in 2005 and 2007.
</P>
<P>
The 31-year-old beat Italian 2007 champion Danilo Di Luca into second at 41sec
with his compatriot Franco Pellizzoti rounding off the podium finishers a
further 1min 18sec adrift.
</P>
<P>
Lithuanian Ignatas Konovalovas of the Cervelo team won the final stage in a time
of 18:42 with Briton Bradley Wiggins only a second back and Norway's Edvald
Boasson Hagen in third.
</P>
<P>
Menchov finished 10th on the stage with Di Luca 16th.
</P>
<P>
"I didn't have time to think, it all happened so quickly," Menchov said of his
tumble. "In my earpiece I heard 'no risks, no risks'.
</P>
<P>
"My first move was to get the back back up, but it was too risky. Luckily the
mechanic, in a very professional way, already had another bike there for me.
</P>
<P>
"This win on the Giro is the biggest of my career. It gives me a lot of
confidence. I know I can win the Tour (de France)," he added.
</P>
<P>
Second-placed Di Luca said he had "nothing to regret. "I attacked each time I
could, whenever it was possible".
</P>
<P>
"I can take a lot away from this race: two stage wins, seven days in the pink
jersey, and the final points jersey. It's been the greatest race of my life."
</P>
<P>
The Russian had a 20sec lead coming into the final day in one of the closest
ever finishes to a Giro, in its centenary year.
</P>
<P>
Di Luca briefly looked to be on the brink of a famous victory when he got to the
first time-check fastest of all and 5sec up on Menchov.
</P>
<P>
But the LPR rider had blasted out too fast, gradually fading from there and he
was 14sec down on Menchov at the next time check.
</P>
<P>
When he came over the line, Di Luca had lost 45sec to Konovalovas whereas
Menchov, who had won the 12th stage time-trial to take over the pink jersey last
Thursday, was getting stronger.
</P>
<P>
The Russian looked like he may even win the final time-trial as well but with
rain spitting down drama unfolded in the final kilometre.
</P>
<P>
Riding in a straight line but on a cobbled section, Menchov suddenly crashed
with just 1km left to ride, but quick thinking from his mechanic may have
secured him the victory.
</P>
<P>
As Menchov was still sliding along the wet surface, his mechanic had already
jumped out of the team car and was unloading another bike from the roof.
</P>
<P>
Menchov went to pick up his splayed bike but received a shout from the mechanic
and instead jumped straight onto the new one and was back on his way, courtesy
of a push from the mechanic as well.
</P>
<P>
He had been going so well, though, that he still had time to spare on Di Luca
and despite the crash he gained a further 21sec on his rival.
</P>
<P>
Tour de France champion Carlos Sastre finished fourth and seven-time Tour winner
Lance Armstrong came in 12th.
</P>
<P>
Sastre said the race had left a "bitter-sweet taste".
</P>
<P>
"I came with an ambition different from what I achieved," he said.
</P>
<P>
"I won two stages but I missed out on the podium. For three weeks we haven't had
a quiet stage. It's been a really tough course."
</P>

<DATELINE>
Los ANGELES, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Animated family film "Up" shot to the top of the North American box office this
weekend, according to industry estimates, pulling in 68.2 million dollars in
receipts.
</P>
<P>
The movie features a balloon salesman who finds his long-dreamed adventure to
South America has an 8-year-old stowaway.
</P>
<P>
Last weekend's leader, comedy sequel "Night at the Museum: Battle of the

Exhibitor Relations.
</P>

night-time museum adventures, moving from New York to Washington.
</P>
<P>

million dollars.
</P>
<P>

apocalyptic role of a resistance leader fighting power-hungry machines, took in
16.1 million dollars in box office receipts for fourth place.
</P>
<P>

"Star Trek," earning 12.8 million dollars for a whopping 209.5 million over four
weeks in theaters.
</P>
<P>
"Angels and Demons" -- sequel to the hit 2006 thriller "The Da Vinci Code" came
in sixth place. Directed by Ron Howard and with Tom Hanks reprising his starring
turn,  "Angels" took in 11.2 million dollars.
</P>
<P>
In seventh place was "Dance Flick," about a street dancer from the wrong side of
the tracks bonding with a beautiful girl to battle it out at a dance
competition. It drew 4.9 million dollars in ticket sales.
</P>
<P>
Superhero spinoff "X-Men Origins: Wolverine," which took 87 million dollars in
its opening weekend, drew only 3.9 million in receipts for eighth place.
</P>
<P>
In ninth was romantic comedy "Ghosts of Girlfriends Past," starring Matthew
McConaughey and Jennifer Garner, earning 1.9 million dollars.
</P>
<P>
Rounding out the top 12 was Beyonce's thriller "Obsessed," "The Brothers Bloom"
and "The Soloist," all earning less than one million dollars.

<HEADLINE>
GM: 54 percent of bondholders approve Treasury plan
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Washington, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Creditors holding about 54 percent of General's Motors bonds have approved a
restructuring plan proposed by the US Treasury, a spokesman for the bondholders
said Sunday.
</P>
<P>
The 54 percent represented 975 institutions, a spokesman for the ad hoc
committee of bondholders, Elliot Sloane told AFP.
</P>
<P>
The Treasury had given the bondholders until the end of the day Saturday to
respond to its proposal to create a new company and shed assets that were
causing losses.
</P>
<P>
The creditors collectively would receive 10 percent of GM's stock in return for
their shares, and warrants, or options to buy stock, allowing them to acquire up
to an additional 15 percent of the company's stock.
</P>
<P>
If the options are exercised, they would control up to 25 percent of the "new
GM," while the Treasury would at least initially hold a 72.5 percent stake in
the company that emerges from a bankruptcy court reorganization.
</P>
<P>
Bondholders who rejected the plan account for about 46 percent of GM's bond
debt. They can contest it in court and try to get as much of what they are owed
as they can through the bankruptcy proceedings.
</P>
<P>
The government has warned that they may end up with little or nothing if they
take that route.
</P>
<P>
Once the world's biggest auto company, General Motors was poised Sunday to file
for bankruptcy protection.
</P>
</TEXT>

</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Italy's Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi hit out at coverage of his private life

<P>

take photos of the interior of his house," he said at the press conference in

<P>

life and to confidentiality are fundamental liberties," he added.
</P>
<P>
According to Il Corriere della Sera newspapers, the pictures showed girls in
bikinis or topless wandering in the garden or standing under open-air showers.
</P>
<P>
Other girls, dressed, were pictured at Berlusconi's side.
</P>
<P>
The photos came from a New Years Eve party at the villa. The teenager at the
centre of the row between Berlusconi and wife earlier this month, which led her
to file for divorce, attended the party, the paper reported.
</P>
<P>
Berlusconi was also asked about a report in the daily newspaper Libero, in which
right-wing politician Daniela Santanche alleged that Berlusconi's wife, Veronica
Lario, had a "companion" -- naming the man in question.
</P>
<P>
Berlusconi said he was annoyed to see that his family's private life was being
splashed over the front page of a newspaper.
</P>
<P>
"I would like not to respond," said the prime minister.
</P>
<P>
Defending Berlusconi, Santanche said he had not wrecked anyone's family, but his
wife had had a companion for a long time.
</P>
<P>
"Berlusconi had tried everything to keep his family together," said Santanche,
the leader of the small Movement for Italy party.
</P>

of patience over Berlusconi's well-known penchant for pretty women.

A party strongly supportive of the leader of Georgia's breakaway region of South

The apparent dominance of Yedinstvo (Unity) in the legislative elections should

at 0600 GMT on Monday.
</P>
<P>
The elections were marked by the sidelining of the anti-Kokoity opposition amid
talk he wants a loyal parliamentary majority to push through an amendment
allowing him to run again for office when his second term lapses in 2011.

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0094" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Tennis: Soderling ends Nadal's French Open reign
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Rafael Nadal's four-year Roland Garros reign came to a sensational end at the
hands of feuding rival Robin Soderling on Sunday as the race for the 2009 title
was thrown wide open.
</P>
<P>
Nadal, bidding for a record fifth successive French Open crown, slumped to his
first ever defeat here after winning all of his 31 matches since his 2005 debut.
</P>
<P>
His 6-2, 6-7 (2/7), 6-4, 7-6 (7/2) fourth round loss was made harder to swallow
as it came against a man he described as one of the most unpopular in the locker
room after an acrimonious Wimbledon clash in 2007.
</P>
<P>
"It's not a tragedy, I had to lose one day. I must accept my defeats with the
same level of calm that I accept my victories," said Nadal, who had routed
Soderling 6-1, 6-0 at the Rome Masters just a month ago.
</P>
<P>
"He didn't surprise me because I know how he plays and how dangerous he can be.
I didn't play my best. I played very short and I couldn't attack. I made it easy
for him."
</P>
<P>
Soderling, whose win meant that compatriot Bjorn Borg kept level on four
successive wins with Nadal, said he always thought he could prevail.
</P>
<P>
"It's the biggest challenge to play the best claycourt player in history," said
the 24-year-old.
</P>
<P>
"But I had to believe I had a chance or I may as well go home. If he thinks that
he made it easy for me then that's his choice. I would never say anything like
that."
</P>
<P>
Soderling, who has battled back from a serious wrist injury, sent down a massive
61 winners to Nadal's 33 as the champion, looking jaded after another marathon
claycourt season, struggled to get any meaningful foothold in the tie.
</P>
<P>
Nadal's first set loss was the first time he had dropped a set in the tournament
since the 2007 final against Roger Federer, ending a run of 32 in a row.
</P>
<P>
The Spaniard was reeling from the outset as the 23rd seeded Soderling unleashed
a brutal power game based on big serving and pinpoint accuracy with one of the
event's most devastating forehands.
</P>
<P>
Soderling will now face Russian 10th seed Nikolay Davydenko, twice a semi-
finalist, who completed Spain's miserable day with a 6-2, 6-2, 6-4 win over
eighth seed Fernando Verdasco.
</P>
<P>
Third seed Andy Murray reached his first French Open quarter-final with a
convincing 7-5, 7-6 (7/4), 6-1 win over Croatia's Marin Cilic.
</P>
<P>
The ever-improving 22-year-old Murray looked in impressive physical condition
with a series of long, punishing rallies eventually telling on the 13th seeded
Cilic, the youngest man left in the draw.
</P>
<P>
"I'm playing well." said Murray, only the third British man to make the last
eight here in the Open era.
</P>
<P>
"You don't reach the French Open quarter-finals without playing well.
</P>
<P>
"I've had a good claycourt season. I reached the quarters in Monte Carlo and
Madrid and now the last eight here. It's better than previous years but I will
try to keep on improving."
</P>
<P>
Murray next meets Chilean 13th seed Fernando Gonzalez who revealed how an injury
signing autographs almost shattered his French Open campaign.
</P>
<P>
The 28-year-old, who outgunned Romania's Victor Hanescu 6-2, 6-4, 6-2 to reach
the quarter-finals for the third time, injured his ankle while signing photos
and tennis balls for fans at the Rome Masters in April.
</P>
<P>
As a result, he spent a month on the sidelines.
</P>
<P>
"I was signing autographs and someone called me from the other side of the court
and when I ran over to them, I twisted my ankle," said Gonzalez.
</P>
<P>
"I think I only managed to sign two and then I had to go back to the locker room
because my ankle was so painful."
</P>
<P>
dj/ak09
</P>

internal affairs.

autonomy for his Himalayan homeland.

<HEADLINE>
Tennis: Defeat not tragedy as Nadal vows to bounce back
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Dethroned French Open champion Rafael Nadal vowed to bounce back from his
stunning loss to Robin Soderling, which shattered his dreams of a record fifth
successive Roland Garros title.
</P>
<P>
The world number one insisted he'd be better and stronger in time for his
Wimbledon title defence in three weeks' time.
</P>
<P>
"It's the end of the road and I have to accept it," said the world number one,
who was beaten for the first time at Roland Garros following 31 wins in 31
matches since his 2005 debut which propelled him to super-stardom.
</P>
<P>
"I have to accept my defeat as I accept my victories - with calm. I have to keep
a cool head to try and analyze what I did wrong.
</P>
<P>
"I need to learn, and you learn more when you lose than when you win. I need to
work on those points on which I wasn't good, and from there try and do better
for my next tournament.
</P>
<P>
"So this is not a tragedy, losing here in Paris. It had to happen one day."
</P>
<P>
For Nadal, losing his proud record could not have come at the hands of the worst
possible opponent after he and Soderling, who are not on speaking terms, fell
out after an acrimonious Wimbledon defeat in 2007.
</P>
<P>
Nadal was irritated by the big Swede's on-court imitation of his habit of
pulling at the rear of his shorts while Soderling dismissed the criticisms as
"bullshit".
</P>
<P>
Nadal, who turns 23 on Wednesday, said he would not get too downcast about his
fourth round 6-2, 6-7 (2/7), 6-4, 7-6 (7/2) defeat.
</P>
<P>
The first thing he will do is head to the swimming pool at his Mallorca home and
convince himself that one defeat has not suddenly made him a bad player
following a 12 months where he won Wimbledon, the Olympics and the Australian
Open.
</P>
<P>
"This is sport, and you can have victories or defeats. No one remembers defeats
in the long run. People remember victories," added the Spaniard.
</P>
<P>
"So I have to move forward. I have a little time to prepare for Wimbledon, but I
have to move forward and try and prepare the best I can."
</P>
<P>
Soderling, who had never got beyond the third round of a Grand Slam before this
French Open, insists his feud with Nadal is a thing of the past, but he simply
refused to be intimidated by the Spaniard.
</P>
<P>
"He's just another player on the tour. He's the best claycourt player of all
time, but he's just like someone else to me," said the Swede who goes on to
tackle two-time semi-finalist Nikolay Davydenko for a place in the last four.
</P>
<P>
Soderling believes that the time he spent out of action at the end of 2007 and
the start of 2008, nursing a wrist injury, may have proved a crucial part in his
victory on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
"I was a little bit lucky because it was my left wrist. I was off the tour for
maybe five or six months, but I practiced a lot of tennis," he explained.
</P>
<P>
"I practiced my slice and my forehand. I couldn't do anything except for my two
handed backhand. I used the time very well.
</P>
<P>
"Instead of just waiting for the wrist to heal, I did everything I could.  I was
working out three, four hours in the gym every day."
</P>
<P>
Soderling also paid tribute to compatriot and coach Magnus Norman who made the
2000 final here.
</P>
<P>
"He definitely helped me a lot. He was a great player. What I like is that I can
really ask him anything - 'Did you feel the same when you were playing?', 'How
did you feel?' I think that is really helping me."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Four killed in Yemen clashes
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Sanaa, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Four Yemenis, including a policeman, were killed and 13 others wounded in two
days of clashes between police and anti-government protesters in southern Yemen,
medics and witnesses said.
</P>
<P>
The deaths bring the toll of Yemenis killed since demonstrations broke out in
the south in late April to 16, including five security force members. The Sanaa
government has blamed the protests on southern separatists.
</P>
<P>
A policeman and a demonstrator were killed on Sunday in the village of Labouss
in the southern province of Lahij, while another demonstrator was wounded in
confrontations in the nearby village of al-Eind, witnesses said.
</P>
<P>
Protesters chanted slogans against the government, which is controlled by
northerners, and carried posters of Ali Nasser Mohammed, the former president of
South Yemen, which was united with North Yemen in 1990.
</P>
<P>
Earlier on Sunday, one Yemeni protester was killed and five others wounded in
clashes when police opened fire to disperse a demonstration in Dali, north of
the southern port of Aden, capital of the former South Yemen.
</P>
<P>
"One protester, Tufiq al-Jaadi, died while being operated on in hospital. He was
hit by a bullet," medical sources said.
</P>
<P>
Witnesses said police exchanged fire with demonstrators carrying banners with
anti-government slogans.
</P>
<P>
Violence broke out again at the hospital as police tried to arrest a wounded
demonstrator, resulting in injuries to a policeman and a protester, witnesses
said.
</P>
<P>
The demonstration in Dali was in its second day.
</P>
<P>
On Saturday, one protester was killed and five others wounded in a clash with
police in the village of Ashehir, in the southeastern region of Hadramawt,
witnesses said.
</P>
<P>
The disturbance was triggered by demands to release locals arrested over earlier
protests against the government, they said.
</P>
<P>
Socialists who formerly ruled the south led a secession bid in 1994 that sparked
a two-month civil war before the uprising was crushed by northern forces loyal
to veteran President Ali Abdullah Saleh.
</P>
<P>
The president has warned against the risks of Yemen breaking up into "several
entities" amid trouble in the south over the past year, sparked by social
demands and charges of negligence in the impoverished state.
</P>
<P>
Saleh, speaking on Sunday during a visit to Riyadh, thanked northern neighbour
Saudi Arabia for its support for Yemeni unity.
</P>
<P>
In a statement reported by Saudi official news agency SPA, Saleh praised King
Abdullah for "his support for Yemen, its security, its stability and its unity
as well as his strong backing of Yemen's development efforts."
</P>
<P>
"A strong, safe and stable Yemen is in the interest of the Saudi kingdom" and
the other members of the Gulf Cooperation Council, Saleh said.
</P>
<P>
The GCC also comprises Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Oman and
Qatar.
</P>

</P>
<P>

<HEADLINE>
Football: Sad exit for Jose as Ahly stunned in Angola
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
JOHANNESBURG, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Manuel Jose ended his title-strewn career as Al-Ahly coach disastrously when the
Egyptian giants were dumped out of the African Confederation Cup by Santos in
Angola on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Ahly, winners of the African Champions League a record six times, took a 3-0
lead into the return match and even the absence of star midfielder Mohamed
Aboutraika was not expected to prevent them reaching the group phase.
</P>
<P>
But a Santos team competing in Africa for the first time this year had other
ideas and triumphed 3-0 in Luanda to level the aggregate score before winning
the fourth-round tie 6-5 on penalties.
</P>
<P>
Among those who failed from the spot for Ahly was Angola-born striker Flavio
Amado, whose agent claims he is quitting the Cairo 'Red Devils' for a three-year
contract with Saudi Arabian outfit Shabab.
</P>
<P>
Bebucho put the Angolans ahead mid-way through the first half, Milex set up a
thrilling finish with a second goal as the game entered the closing stages and
Saul struck the crucial third two minutes from full-time.
</P>
<P>
All the goals were brilliantly executed by a team who scored four goals each in
previous home encounters against USM of Gabon and Union Douala of Cameroon
having received a first round bye.
</P>
<P>
Bebucho strode forward before unleashing an unstoppable 30-metre shot past
goalkeeper Ramzi Saleh, Milex volleyed a loose ball into the net from close
range and Saul clinically sidefooted home a cross.
</P>
<P>
Success for Santos completed a wonderful weekend for the oil-rich southern
Africa nation in the second-tier African club competition, as Primeiro Agosto
eliminated holders CS Sfaxien in Tunisia on Saturday, also after a shootout.
</P>
<P>
Ahly have campaigned in Africa regularly since 1975 and this was only the fourth
time they had suffered a three-goal loss, with Mouloudia Alger of Algeria,
Hearts of Oak of Ghana and Al-Hilal of Sudan inflicting the other defeats.
</P>
<P>
The heavy reverses against Mouloudia and Hearts came three decades ago while
Hilal triumphed two years ago in Omdurman against a club that claims 40 million
supporters in Egypt and the Middle East.
</P>
<P>
It was a sad exit for Jose, who stays in Luanda to take over a struggling
Angolan national team from June 1 with the task of building a team capable of
using home advantage to win the 2010 African Nations Cup.
</P>
<P>
The 63-year-old Portuguese led Ahly to four of their six African Champions
League titles and many African media observers consider him the greatest foreign
coach to have worked at club level on the continent.
</P>
<P>
Primeiro lost 2-0 to Sfaxien only to convert all their post-match penalties and
win the shootout 5-4, while Stade Malien of Mali outplayed Al-Ittihad Khemisset
of Morocco 3-1 in Bamako to advance 4-2 on aggregate.
</P>
<P>
Another five ties in the final qualifying round will be decided later on Sunday
before the mini-league phase kicks off in mid-July.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0111" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Abortion doctor shot dead at his Kansas church
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
WICHITA, Kansas, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
A controversial provider of late-term abortions was shot to death Sunday as he
walked into services at his Kansas church, officials said.
</P>
<P>
A lightning rod in the bitter culture war over abortion, George Tiller had
already been picketed, bombed and shot in the arms.
</P>
<P>
He was shot to death just after 10 am (1500 GMT) in the lobby of Reformation
Lutheran Church in Wichita, Kansas, police and city officials said.
</P>
<P>
A white man wielding a handgun shot Tiller, 67, and then fled in a powder blue
Ford Taurus.
</P>
<P>
"It's an unfortunate incident to happen on a Sunday morning," Wichita police
captain Brent Allred told reporters.
</P>
<P>
"These things should not occur at a any time."
</P>
<P>
The FBI and state police were called in to help search for the shooter, whose
license plate was registered to a home in a suburb of Kansas City, some 200
miles away on the border with Missouri.
</P>
<P>
The shooting came just two weeks after President Barack Obama sought "common
ground" over the divisive abortion debate in a controversial speech at one of
the top Catholic universities in the United States.
</P>
<P>
The president has attempted to defuse one of the most emotive issues in US
public life by arguing that while abortion should remain legal, the government
should do all it can to limit unwanted pregnancies.
</P>
<P>
But Obama has angered the anti-abortion movement by reversing predecessor George
W. Bush's restrictions on federal funding for embryonic stem-cell research and
for family-planning groups that carry out or facilitate abortions overseas.
</P>
<P>
Obama's choice for health secretary, former Kansas governor Kathleen Sebelius,
has been widely condemned by the anti-abortion movement because of her ties to
Tiller.
</P>
<P>
Tiller, one of the few doctors who still performs late-term abortions in the
United States, has been demonized by abortion opponents who regularly protested
outside his clinic.
</P>
<P>
In 1986, someone placed a bomb on the roof of the clinic, seriously damaging the
building.
</P>
<P>
In 1993, Tiller was shot in both arms outside the clinic. Tiller recovered, and
his assailant received an 11-year prison term.
</P>
<P>
Some 2,000 protesters were also arrested outside the clinic during summer-long
demonstrations in 1991.
</P>
<P>
He was acquitted in March on charges that he performed 19 illegal abortions in
2003 in a case which his lawyer described as a witch hunt.
</P>
<P>
Tiller testified during the trial that he spent years under the protection of
federal agents after the FBI discovered an anti-abortion assassination list in
1994 that listed Tiller as the top target.
</P>
<P>
Tiller also testified that he owns one of only three clinics in the United
States that perform late-term abortions, which are performed on fetuses that
would be viable outside the mother's womb.
</P>
<P>
Late-term abortions are legal in Kansas if two independent physicians agree that
the mother could suffer irreparable harm by giving birth.
</P>
<P>
Tiller was acquitted of having an illegal financial relationship with the doctor
who provided the second opinion.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
GM poised for bankruptcy as Treasury readies rescue plan
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Washington, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The US Treasury put the final touches Sunday on a plan to restructure General
Motors, once the world's largest automaker and now expected to join rival
Chrysler in filing for bankruptcy protection.
</P>
<P>
Monday will be a historic day for the US automobile industry. GM's new chief
executive, Fritz Henderson, has scheduled a news conference for the middle of
the day in New York, where the number one US automaker would file for
bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
The administration of President Barack Obama has given GM until June 1 to
present a viable restructuring plan, in return for government aid.
</P>
<P>
The rescue could reach 60 billion dollars with the state taking a 72.5 per cent
ownership stake in the 101 year old company. Canada, which has several GM
factories, also will be digging into its pockets.
</P>
<P>
According to The New York Times, holders of GM's secured bonds agreed by a small
majority on Saturday to a new Treasury rescue plan that would give them 25
percent of the company. Washington had warned that if the plan were rejected,
creditors risked losing everything.
</P>
<P>
Among the backers was a committee of large investors holding about 20 percent of
GM's 27.2 billion dollars in outstanding bonds, The Times said.
</P>
<P>
No official announcement of the vote tally has yet been made.
</P>
<P>
Under the plan, the bondholders would obtain the rights to buy an extra 15
percent of GM's stock at a low price. They would also control 25 percent of the
new GM, after having supported the new company's creation in bankruptcy court.
</P>
<P>
The New York bankruptcy court also is expected to rule Monday on number three US
automaker Chrysler, which filed for bankruptcy protection a month ago.
</P>
<P>
Under an expedited process, judge Arthur Gonzales was expected to approve the
creation of a new Chrysler, called 'New Carco,' which would preserve the
automaker's healthiest assets and liquidate the rest.
</P>
<P>
The new entity will be controlled by a consortium consisting of the Italian
automaker Fiat, the United Auto Workers union, and the US and Canadian
governments.
</P>
<P>
Fiat will have a 20 percent stake with the option to increase it to 35 percent;
the UAW 55 percent; and the US and Canadian governments 10 percent.
</P>
<P>
The automakers fate, the subject of debate on television talks shows, is being
closely watched in US political and economic circles.
</P>
<P>
"This is a real sad day," said former Republican presidential contender Mitt
Romney.
</P>
<P>
"I'm a son of Detroit. My dad was an auto executive. You know, I drive American
cars. I love American cars. My heart bleeds for the people in Michigan and
Detroit, for all these auto workers," he said on Fox News.
</P>
<P>
At the end of last year, GM had 244,000 employees around the world, about half
of them in the United States.
</P>
<P>
Mitch McConnell, the senate minority leader, called the auto rescue plan "a big
mistake," arguing that the government had done too much to keep GM and Chyrsler
out of bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
In an interview with CNN, he held up the example of Ford, the number two US
automaker, as "an American company that hasn't taken government money and is
still producing automobiles."
</P>
<P>
Corporate leaders, meanwhile, urged the government not to overstay its welcome
in the private sector.
</P>
<P>
"I think all of us understand the need for the government to intervene and take
the actions they did," said Anne Mulcahy, chief executive of Xerox. "But I also
think there's a need for an exit plan."
</P>
<P>
The possibility of bankruptcy for such an iconic American company has been
viewed with great foreboding in a country where the automobile is deeply
embedded in the national imagination.
</P>
<P>
"The phrase 'bankrupt General Motors,' which we expect to hear uttered on Monay,
leaves Americans my age in economic shock," the writer PJ O'Rourke said in the
Wall Street Journal. "The words are as melodramatic as 'Mom's nude photos.'"
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0114" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Cycling: Menchov wins Tour of Italy despite dramatic fall
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ROME, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Russian rider Denis Menchov won the Tour of Italy here on Sunday despite
suffering a dramatic fall in the last kilometre of the final stage, a 14.4km
time-trial round.
</P>
<P>
The Rabobank cyclist, who is the third Russian to win the race, added the title
to his two Tour of Spain victories in 2005 and 2007.
</P>
<P>
The 31-year-old beat Italian 2007 champion Danilo Di Luca into second at 41sec
with his compatriot Franco Pellizzoti rounding off the podium finishers a
further 1min 18sec adrift.
</P>
<P>
Lithuanian Ignatas Konovalovas of the Cervelo team won the final stage in a time
of 18:42 with Briton Bradley Wiggins only a second back and Norway's Edvald
Boasson Hagen in third.
</P>
<P>
Menchov finished 10th on the stage with Di Luca 16th.
</P>
<P>
"I have nothing to regret," said Di Luca. "I attacked each time I could,
whenever it was possible.
</P>
<P>
"I can take a lot away from this race: two stage wins, seven days in the pink
jersey, and the final points jersey. It's been the greatest race of my life."
</P>
<P>
The Russian had a 20sec lead coming into the final day in one of the closest
ever finishes to a Giro, in its centenary year.
</P>
<P>
Di Luca briefly looked to be on the brink of a famous victory when he got to the
first time-check fastest of all and 5sec up on Menchov.
</P>
<P>
But the LPR rider had blasted out too fast, gradually fading from there and he
was 14sec down on Menchov at the next time check.
</P>
<P>
When he came over the line, Di Luca had lost 45sec to Konovalovas whereas
Menchov, who had won the 12th stage time-trial to take over the pink jersey last
Thursday, was getting stronger.
</P>
<P>
The Russian looked like he may even win the final time-trial as well but with
rain spitting down drama unfolded in the final kilometre.
</P>
<P>
Riding in a straight line but on a cobbled section, Menchov suddenly crashed
with just 1km left to ride, but quick thinking from his mechanic may have
secured him the victory.
</P>
<P>
As Menchov was still sliding along the wet surface, his mechanic had already
jumped out of the team car and was unloading another bike from the roof.
</P>
<P>
Menchov went to pick up his splayed bike but received a shout from the mechanic
and instead jumped straight onto the new one and was back on his way, courtesy
of a push from the mechanic as well.
</P>
<P>
He had been going so well, though, that he still had time to spare on Di Luca
and despite the crash he gained a further 21sec on his rival.
</P>
<P>
Tour de France champion Carlos Sastre finished fourth and seven-time Tour winner
Lance Armstrong came in 12th.
</P>
<P>
Sastre said the race had left a "bitter-sweet taste".
</P>
<P>
"I came with an ambition different from what I achieved," he said.
</P>
<P>
"I won two stages but I missed out on the podium. For three weeks we haven't had
a quiet stage. It's been a really tough course."
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0115" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Yemen to inaugurate first LNG plant
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
SANAA, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Yemen will inaugurate its first liquefied natural gas plant next month and begin
exporting in August with the first shipment destined for South Korea, the oil
minister said on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
The plant at Balhaf on the south coast is ready "for its official inauguration
on June 16, and the export of its first shipment of gas to South Korea will come
eight weeks later," Oil Minister Amir Salem al-Aydarus said.
</P>
<P>
In addition to South Korea, LNG from Yemen will also be exported to Europe and
north America, the minister said in a statement posted online on the defence
ministry's website, 26Sep.net.
</P>
<P>
Yemen has already taken delivery of two of four LNG tankers on order, the
statement said, quoting Aydarus as saying the remaining two ships will be
delivered "in the coming days."
</P>
<P>
A tanker carrying the first shipment of 120,000 cubic metres (more than four
million cubic feet) of LNG will sail for South Korea in August.
</P>
<P>
The maiden cargo of gas will mark the culmination of a project launched in
October 2005 at a total cost of four billion dollars, making it the largest ever
project in the country's history.
</P>
<P>
The LNG project is vital to the economic future of Yemen, where oil revenues
currently make up 70 percent of state revenue.
</P>
<P>
When a second liquefying unit becomes operational towards the end of the year
Yemen will be able to export 6.7 million tonnes of gas annually -- equivalent to
180,000 barrels of oil per day (bpd).
</P>
<P>
It will remain a small player on the LNG market nevertheless, with reserves of
259 billion cubic metres.
</P>
<P>
Yemen is one of the poorest countries on Earth despite its proximity to oil
powerhouse Saudi Arabia.
</P>
<P>
Its own oil exports are tiny compared with its northern neighbour. Last year it
produced less than 300,000 bpd of crude oil, and production is decreasing by
five to six percent a year.
</P>
<P>
Deputy Prime Minister for Economic Affairs Abdulkarim Ismail al-Arhabi told AFP
in March that he expects the country's modest oil reserves to be exhausted by
2020.
</P>
<P>
"Gas will make up for the decrease in oil production," he said.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Iraqi journalist killed by bomb: police
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
MOSUL, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
An Iraqi sports reporter was killed and a television host wounded on Sunday when
a bomb attached to the victim's car exploded in the northern city of Mosul, a
police official told AFP.
</P>
<P>
The blast killed Alaa Abdul Wahab, a correspondent for the Al-Baghdadia channel
and a leading newspaper journalist, and wounded Dr Sultan Jurjis, a university
academic and sports presenter with a rival TV station.
</P>
<P>
"Mr Abdul Wahab was killed and Dr Jurjis was injured when a sticky bomb put in
the former's car exploded," said a Mosul police official.
</P>
<P>
The bomb went off in Al-Shurta district in the north of Mosul, 370 kilometres
(230 miles) north of Baghdad.
</P>
<P>
Mosul remains plagued by violence despite security improvements in many other
areas of Iraq. Elements from Al-Qaeda and former insurgents who have fled other
parts of the country regularly carry out attacks in the city.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Tennis: Soderling ends Nadal's French Open reign
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Rafael Nadal's four-year Roland Garros reign came to a sensational end at the
hands of feuding rival Robin Soderling on Sunday as the race for the 2009 title
was thrown wide open.
</P>
<P>
Nadal, bidding for a record fifth successive French Open crown, slumped to his
first ever defeat here after winning all of his 31 matches since his 2005 debut.
</P>
<P>
His 6-2, 6-7 (2/7), 6-4, 7-6 (7/2) fourth round loss was made harder to swallow
as it came against a man he described as one of the most unpopular in the locker
room after an acrimonious Wimbledon clash in 2007.
</P>
<P>
"It's not a tragedy, I had to lose one day. I must accept my defeats with the
same level of calm that I accept my victories," said Nadal, who had routed
Soderling 6-1, 6-0 at the Rome Masters just a month ago.
</P>
<P>
"He didn't surprise me because I know how he plays and how dangerous he can be.
I didn't play my best. I played very short and I couldn't attack. I made it easy
for him to play at his level."
</P>
<P>
Soderling, whose win meant that compatriot Bjorn Borg kept level on four
successive wins with Nadal, said he always thought he could win.
</P>
<P>
"It's the biggest challenge to play the best claycourt player in history," said
the 24-year-old.
</P>
<P>
"But I had to believe I had a chance or I may as well go home. But if he thinks
that he made it easy for me then that's his choice. I would never say anything
like that."
</P>
<P>
Soderling, who has battled back from a serious wrist injury, sent down a massive
61 winners to Nadal's 33 as the champion, looking jaded after another marathon
claycourt season, struggled to get any meaningful foothold in the tie.
</P>
<P>
Nadal's first set loss was the first time he had dropped a set in the tournament
since the 2007 final against Roger Federer, ending a run of 32 in a row.
</P>
<P>
The Spaniard was reeling from the outset as the 23rd seeded Soderling unleashed
a brutal power game based on big serving and pinpoint accuracy with one of the
event's most devastating forehands.
</P>
<P>
The Swede's sensational victory, which will now boost Roger Federer's lifetime
dream of adding an elusive French Open to his 13-title Grand Slam collection,
overshadowed Sunday's three other last 16 ties.
</P>
<P>
Third seed Andy Murray reached his first French Open quarter-final with a
convincing 7-5, 7-6 (7/4), 6-1 win over Croatia's Marin Cilic.
</P>
<P>
The ever-improving 22-year-old Murray looked in impressive physical condition
with a series of long, punishing rallies eventually telling on the 13th seeded
Cilic, the youngest man left in the draw.
</P>
<P>
"I'm playing well." said Murray, only the third British man to make the last
eight here in the Open era.
</P>
<P>
"You don't reach the French Open quarter-finals without playing well.
</P>
<P>
"I've had a good claycourt season. I reached the quarters in Monte Carlo and
Madrid and now the last eight here. It's better than previous years but I will
try to keep on improving."
</P>
<P>
Murray next meets Chilean 13th seed Fernando Gonzalez who revealed how an injury
signing autographs almost shattered his French Open campaign.
</P>
<P>
The 28-year-old, who outgunned Romania's Victor Hanescu 6-2, 6-4, 6-2 to reach
the quarter-finals for the third time, injured his ankle while signing photos
and tennis balls for fans at the Rome Masters in April.
</P>
<P>
As a result, he spent a month on the sidelines.
</P>
<P>
"I was signing autographs and someone called me from the other side of the court
and when I ran over to them, I twisted my ankle," said Gonzalez.
</P>
<P>
"I think I only managed to sign two and then I had to go back to the locker room
because my ankle was so painful."
</P>
<P>
In the day's other last 16 tie, Russian 10th seed Nikolay Davydenko, twice a
semi-finalist, faces Spanish eighth seed Fernando Verdasco who is looking for a
first quarter-final place.
</P>
<P>
The winner will tackle Soderling for a place in the semi-finals.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Britain to fight lawsuit from US shock-jock
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The British government said Sunday it would fight any legal action brought by
right-wing US radio host Michael Savage after he was barred from entering the
country for "unacceptable behaviour".
</P>
<P>
Savage has threatened to sue Home Secretary Jacqui Smith for defamation after he
was named on a list she announced this month of 16 banned individuals, which
included a Hamas lawmaker, anti-gay protesters and a Jewish extremist.
</P>
<P>
The Mail on Sunday reported that Savage, whose real name is Michael Alan Weiner,
was planning to sue for 100,000 pounds (160,000 dollars, 115,000 euros) and had
instructed London-based solicitors Olswang to begin proceedings.
</P>
<P>
According to the newspaper, the lawyers have written to Smith and demanded she
retract the allegations and make a personal apology.
</P>
<P>
But a spokesman for the Home Office said it would not back down.
</P>
<P>
"He was excluded for engaging in unacceptable behaviour by making comments that
might provoke others to serious criminal acts and foster hatred that might lead
to inter-community violence," the spokesman said.
</P>
<P>
"Any legal proceedings would be robustly defended; we stand by our decision to
exclude this individual.
</P>
<P>
"Coming to the UK is a privilege that we refuse to extend to those who abuse our
standards and values to undermine our way of life."
</P>
<P>
Savage has been accused of racism and homophobia and once wished that a critical
caller would die of AIDS.
</P>
<P>
However, an appeal for donations to support his legal challenge posted on his
website insists he has never advocated violence.
</P>
<P>
"He has repeatedly called for the lawful enforcement of America’s borders,
language, and culture. He has never advocated violence, or he would not have
lasted in radio for 15 minutes, let alone 15 years," the appeal says.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0119" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Football: Sad exit for Jose as Ahly stunned in Angola
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Johannesburg, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Manuel Jose ended his title-strewn career as Al-Ahly coach disastrously when the
Egyptian giants were dumped out of the African Confederation Cup by Santos in
Angola on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Ahly, winners of the African Champions League a record six times, took a 3-0
lead into the return match and even the absence of star midfielder Mohamed
Aboutraika was not expected to prevent them reaching the group phase.
</P>
<P>
But a Santos team competing in Africa for the first time this year had other
ideas and triumphed 3-0 in Luanda to level the aggregate score before winning
the fourth-round tie 6-5 on penalties.
</P>
<P>
Bebucho put the Angolans ahead mid-way through the first half, Milex set up a
thrilling finish with a second goal as the game entered the closing stages and
Saul struck the crucial third two minutes from full-time.
</P>
<P>
Success for Santos completed a wonderful weekend for the oil-rich southern
Africa nation in the second-tier African club competition, as Primeiro Agosto
eliminated holders CS Sfaxien in Tunisia on Saturday, also after a shootout.
</P>
<P>
Ahly have campaigned in Africa regularly since 1975 and this was only the fourth
time they had suffered a three-goal loss, with Mouloudia Alger of Algeria,
Hearts of Oak of Ghana and Al-Hilal of Sudan inflicting the other defeats.
</P>
<P>
The heavy reverses against Mouloudia and Hearts came three decades ago while
Hilal triumphed two years ago in Omdurman against a club that claims 40 million
supporters in Egypt and the Middle East.
</P>
<P>
It was a sad exit for Jose, who stays in Luanda to take over a struggling
Angolan national team from June 1 with the task of building a team capable of
using home advantage to win the 2010 African Nations Cup.
</P>
<P>
The 63-year-old Portuguese led Ahly to four of their six African Champions
League titles and many African media observers consider him the greatest foreign
coach to have worked at club level on the continent.
</P>
<P>

<HEADLINE>
French physicists claim breakthrough in ultra-fast data access
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
French physicists said on Sunday they had used ultra-fast lasers that could
accelerate storage and retrieval of data on hard discs by up to 100,000 times,
pointing the way to a new generation of IT wizardry.
</P>
<P>
The research builds on achievements that earned the 2007 Nobel physics prize for
Albert Fert of France and Peter Gruenberg of Germany, who ushered in a
revolution in miniaturised storage in the 1990s.
</P>
<P>
Fert and Gruenberg discovered that tiny changes in magnetic fields can yield a
large electric output.
</P>
<P>
These differences in turn cause changes in the current in the readout head that
scans a hard disk to spot the ones and zeroes in which data is stored.
</P>
<P>
That discovery opened the way to "spintronics", a form of electronics that uses
not only electrical charge but also the spin of electrons in individual atoms to
provide a more compact, denser storage on hard drives.
</P>
<P>
But reading and writing data through spintronics has been hampered by the
relative slowness of magnetic sensors.
</P>
<P>
In a study published in the specialist journal Nature Physics, a team led by
Jean-Yves Bigot of the Institute of Materials Physics and Chemistry in
Strasbourg employed a "femtosecond" laser, using ultra-fast bursts of laser
light, to alter electron spin and thus speed up retrieval and storage.
</P>
<P>
"Our method is called the photonics of spin, because it is photons [particles of
light] that modify the state of the electrons' magnetisation" on the storage
surface, Bigot told AFP.
</P>
<P>
Data is retrieved with a burst that lasts just a millionth of a billionth of a
second, said Bigot.
</P>
<P>
Femtosecond lasers currently measure around 30 centimetres (12 inches) by 10
centimetres (four inches) which means they are too big for consumer electronics,
he cautioned.
</P>
<P>
Bigot added, though, that their miniaturisation is likely to be achieved over
the next decade.
</P>
<P>
IBM, Hitachi and other corporations are "extremely interested" by the research,
Bigot said.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0127" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
First genes spotted for testicular cancer
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Scientists in Britain said Sunday they had found the first genes that are
associated with testicular cancer, the commonest form of cancer for men between
the ages of 15 and 45.
</P>
<P>
Telltale variants in chromosomes 5, 6 and 12 are linked with an increased risk
of the disease, according to their study, which compared the genetic code of 730
men who had testicular cancer with that of healthy men.
</P>
<P>
Inheriting the basket of three factors boosts the risk of the cancer, called
testicular gem cell tumour, by up to fourfold.
</P>
<P>
The study is published online in the journal Nature Genetics.
</P>
<P>
"We have known for some time that men whose father, brothers or sons had
testicular cancer are much more likely to get it themselves and we have been
searching for this genetic link," said one of the investigators, Elizabeth
Rapley of the Institute of Cancer Research, in the southern English county of
Surrey.
</P>
<P>
"We believe there are more (risk factors) still to be found and we are working
on identifying the rest."
</P>
<P>
The three telltales lie near genes that nurture testicular cells which are
precursors in sperm development.
</P>
<P>
Worldwide incidence of testicular cancer is 7.5 cases per 100,000 men, but the
rates vary remarkably between countries and according to ancestry, the ICR said
in a press release.
</P>
<P>
Why this is so is unclear. Inheritance, though, is a well-known risk factor and
seems to be far higher than for other cancer types.
</P>
<P>
Studies have found that the risk to brothers of testicular cancer patients is
eight to 10 times higher than the general population, while for fathers of
patients, the risk is four to six times higher.
</P>
<P>
Testicular cancer is 99 percent curable if caught in its early stages, the ICR
said.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

Tennis: Nadal five-title dream crushed by Soderling sledgehammer
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Rafael Nadal's hopes of a record fifth successive French Open title were crushed
into the Roland Garros red dust by Robin Soderling's Swedish sledgehammer on
Sunday.
</P>
<P>
In one of the greatest upsets in the history of the tournament, the Spanish king
of clay slumped to a first ever defeat here having racked up 31 wins in 31
outings since his 2005 debut.
</P>
<P>
Soderling's stunning 6-2, 6-7 (2/7), 6-4, 7-6 (7/2) fourth round victory came
just a month after he'd won only one game in a 6-1, 6-0 rout at the Rome
Masters, his third defeat in three matches against the world number one.
</P>
<P>
But he was a man transformed on Sunday with the 24-year-old unleashing a
formidable service game and a relentless, pinpoint accurate forehand which
forced Nadal to constantly scramble for a foothold in the match.
</P>
<P>
"He didn't surprise me because I know how he plays and how dangerous he can be,"
said Nadal who had won the Monte Carlo, Rome and Barcelona events in the run-up
to Roland Garros.
</P>
<P>
"I didn't play my best. I played very short and I couldn't attack. I made it
easy for him to play at his level. But I lost.
</P>
<P>
"It's not a tragedy, I had to lose one day. I must accept my defeats with the
same level of calm that I accept my victories."
</P>
<P>
Soderling was in tears by the end.
</P>
<P>
"I just couldn't believe it when I won that last point," said the Swede who has
never gone this far before in a Grand Slam.
</P>
<P>
"I'm so proud of myself. This is the best win of my career against a man who is
the greatest claycourt player in history."
</P>
<P>
Nadal's first set loss was the first time he had dropped a set in the tournament
since the 2007 final against Roger Federer, ending a run of 32 in a row.
</P>
<P>
The Spaniard was reeling from the outset at the hands of a man whom he'd accused
of being one of the most unpopular players in the locker room after an
acrimonious Wimbledon clash two years ago.
</P>
<P>
Nadal was broken in the fourth game as 23rd seeded Soderling went to 4-1 ahead
and again in the crucial eighth as the free-flowing, uninhibited Swede continued
to find the corners with devastating accuracy.
</P>
<P>
The 24-year-old deservedly claimed the opening set when the champion netted a
backhand.
</P>
<P>
Nadal, despite missing his usual fluency and rattled by the unrelenting assault,
broke for the first time to lead 2-1 in the second set only to surrender his
advantage in the 10th game.
</P>
<P>
With most people inside Court Philippe Chatrier expecting a Nadal drive to fly
past the big Swede, Soderling executed a fine backhand volley to go to 5-5.
</P>
<P>
Despite those heroics, Nadal ran away with the tiebreaker to level the match
when, for once, Soderling's forehand missed its target and flew long.
</P>
<P>
The Swede, coached by compatriot and 2000 finalist Magnus Norman, refused to
yield, breaking to lead 4-3 before backing it up for a 5-3 advantage in the
third set.
</P>
<P>
He took the set when Nadal netted another weary forehand off yet another deep
Soderling drive.
</P>
<P>
Nadal broke to lead 2-0 in the fourth set, but Soderling hit back immediately as
another tiebreak loomed where the gallant Swede clinched his famous win on a
second match point when Nadal went wide with a pick-up.
</P>
<P>
Soderling sent down nine aces in the match and fired a decisive 61 winners to
the Spaniard's 33.
</P>
<P>
His reward is a match-up with either Russian 10th seed Nikolay Davydenko or
Fernando Verdasco, the eighth-seeded Spaniard for a place in the semi-finals.
</P>
<P>
Sunday's drama would have delighted Roger Federer, who has lost the last three
finals to Nadal, and who still needs a French Open to complete a career Grand
Slam.
</P>
<P>
He plays his last 16 tie on Monday against Germany's Tommy Haas.
</P>
</TEXT>
