<HEADLINE>
Football: Milan promote Leonardo as Ancelotti exits
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ROME, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
AC Milan on Sunday replaced coach Carlo Ancelotti with former player and
Brazilian World Cup winner Leonardo, who was the club's technical director.
</P>
<P>
Ancelotti told Italian Sky Sport TV of his departure following the 2-0 win at
Fiorentina that ensured the seven-time European champions finished third and
avoided having to play two qualifying rounds to reach next season's Champions
League group stages.
</P>
<P>
At the same time, Milan vice-president Adriano Galliani was announcing his
replacement on Rai TV.
</P>
<P>
Ancelotti, who still had a year to run on his contract, confirmed what had
become the worst-kept secret in Italian football in announcing his departure,
but he refused to confirm that English side Chelsea would be his destination.
</P>
<P>
"Today my beautiful Milan adventure has come to an end," said a visibly
emotional Ancelotti.
</P>
<P>
"Our paths are separating. I spoke after the match to Mr Galliani and we decided
to terminate the contract.
</P>
<P>
"We spoke a while back but the decision was taken at the end of the season and
it was mutual. London is not certain as a destination."
</P>
<P>
Ancelotti won two Champions League titles, one Serie A crown and the Club World
Cup during his eight seasons at Milan but has received heavy criticism in the
last two years for failing to mount a serious challenge to champions Inter
Milan.
</P>
<P>
But he will remain a legend at the club where he also won two European Cups as a
player, thus becoming one of the few people in history to claim Europe's premier
competition as both player and coach.
</P>
<P>
He also played for Parma and Roma and coached Reggiana, Parma and Juventus
before joining Milan in 2001.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile Galliani told Rai: "Leonardo will be the new Milan coach. He will be
officially presented tomorrow (Monday) at midday.
</P>
<P>
"With Ancelotti the story is not finished. We will stay friends, we had eight
marvellous years together.
</P>
<P>
"Carlo and I are very good friends and there were a few tears in the changing
rooms."
</P>
<P>
Leonardo had long been tipped to take over from Ancelotti, with Friday's
Gazzetta dello Sport reporting that it was a done deal.
</P>
<P>
The 39-year-old former midfielder and left-back played for the club from
1997-2001, winning the league title in 1999.
</P>
<P>
He was part of the Brazil squad that beat Italy to win the World Cup in 1994,
although he disgraced himself earlier in the tournament by getting sent off
against hosts the United States for elbowing Tab Ramos, resulting in a four-game
suspension that saw him miss the final.
</P>
<P>
Leonardo has no previous coaching experience but Barcelona's Pep Guardiola has
proved novices can shine after winning an incredible treble in his debut season
in charge of the Catalans.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Motorcycling: Stoner ends Rossi's seven year reign at Mugello
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
SCARPERIA, Italy, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Casey Stoner held off the fast-finishing Jorge Lorenzo to win the Italian Grand
Prix on Sunday and bring to an end Valentino Rossi's seven-year reign here.
</P>
<P>
The Australian also took over the lead in the world championship standings with
his second win of the season having also triumphed in Qatar in the opening race
of the season.
</P>
<P>
He now leads Lorenzo, who started on pole here, by four points in the
championship standings with Rossi third, a further five points back.
</P>
<P>
In a dramatic race that began in wet conditions, Stoner seized the advantage
when switching bikes after 10 laps for a change of tyres.
</P>
<P>
"Once I got onto the slicks I found a good feeling immediately and I was able to
get to the front quite quickly, but then I started having a problem with the
clutch," he said.
</P>
<P>
"It was a really hard race and I just wanted to finish it. I just tried to stay
smooth and keep the same lap times even if I couldn’t ride the way I wanted
to."
</P>
<P>
He was the fastest man on the track by some margin in those first few laps after
the switch and although Yamaha pair Lorenzo and Rossi were quickest at the end,
they had both lost too much time and too many places to hit back.
</P>
<P>
Rossi blamed his team for making the wrong choice of tyre in the dry, going for
the harder compound.
</P>
<P>
"It's a precious result, it's also nice to be on the podium. The race was really
difficult, we knew the weather would be terrible," he said.
</P>
<P>
"In the dry we made a mistake in going with the hard tyres. The choice of hards
was made even though I wanted the soft ones."
</P>
<P>
Lorenzo said he was delighted with his finish having slid off on the warm-up lap
and skidded at the start.
</P>
<P>
"Honestly, this is as good as a win for me and I can't really believe the race
today, it was like a movie," he said.
</P>
<P>
"It's a really amazing result because things could have been much worse today,
so thank you again to everyone for making it possible. I'm really happy with
this result."
</P>
<P>
Stoner completed the 23 laps in 45min 41.894sec to beat Lorenzo by just over a
second.
</P>
<P>
In an exciting race the pole-sitter got off to a terrible start in the wet and
immediately dropped to eighth.
</P>
<P>
Quickest off the mark were Australian Chris Vermeulen, who started 11th, and
Andrea Dovizioso, who began seventh but Stoner passed them both on the long
straight at the beginning of the second lap.
</P>
<P>
Vermeulen quickly started heading backwards, eventually finishing 10th, as Rossi
started to move up from fifth.
</P>
<P>
However Italian Marco Melandri on a Kawasaki, who started 15th on the grid, was
clearly fastest in the wet.
</P>
<P>
Rossi took the lead from Dovizioso, who had got back past Stoner, on the seventh
lap and two laps later he lost that to Melandri.
</P>
<P>
However, on the 10th lap all the front runners came into the pits for a change
of bikes and when they came out, Stoner was quickest to find his pace.
</P>
<P>
Melandri immediately started heading backwards, eventually finishing 11th and
35sec back, while Loris Capirossi propelled himself into race contention with
Stoner and Dovizioso.
</P>
<P>
Lorenzo and Rossi initially struggled with their bikes down in fifth and sixth
and the time they lost over those first three laps coming out of the pits
essentially cost either of them a chance of victory.
</P>
<P>
While Stoner had soon taken the race lead, both Yamaha riders had to then pass
Melandri, Capirossi and Dovizioso and by the time they had done so, Stoner was
over a second ahead and with only a couple of laps remaining.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile former Superbikes champion James Toseland of Britain got his best
finish of the season in seventh, benefitting from being the first man into the
pits to change his bike.
</P>
<P>
It meant that his tyres were warm and he was flying as the fastest man on track
for a few laps when everyone else was simply trying to get temperature into
their new tyres.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0136" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Rugby League:Huddersfield grab last gasp victory over Castleford
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Danny Kirmond's late try saw Huddersfield reach the Challenge Cup semi-finals on
Sunday as they beat Castleford 16-14.
</P>
<P>
Kirmond's 77th minute try completed a great comeback for the hosts.
</P>
<P>
Castleford had one foot in the semi-finals when Brett Ferres' converted try gave
them a 14-6 lead ten minutes after the break.
</P>
<P>
But the Giants hit back in the final 12 minutes through Stephen Wild before
Kirmond crossed to snatch the win.
</P>
<P>
Castleford had taken a fifth minute lead through Michael Shenton's try but Kevin
Brown's four-pointer, converted by former Wests full-back Brett Hodgson, made it
6-6 at the break.
</P>
<P>
Ferres and two goals from Kirk Dixon gave Cas a cushion but they were left
stunned at the death.
</P>
<P>
On Saturday Warrington stand-off Lee Briers dropped a golden-point drop-goal to
dump in-form Hull KR out of the Challenge Cup, 25-24.
</P>
<P>
In a desperate search for the winning points, Briers had already failed with
three drop goal attempts.
</P>
<P>
However, Briers refused to throw in the towel and finally succeeded on his
fourth attempt to send the Wolves into the semi-finals.
</P>
<P>
The tense victory avenged Warrington's quarter-final defeat in 2006, when then
National League One side Rovers sprung a famous victory to secure a place in the
last four.
</P>
<P>
The nailbiting quarter-final went to golden point time after the clash finished
24-24 after 80 minutes, thanks to Michael Dobson's last-gasp penalty.
</P>
<P>
The home side took the lead inside three minutes when Paul Cooke's pass allowed
Peter Fox to send through Kris Welham under the posts.
</P>
<P>
The lead didn't last long as Warrington drew level thanks to Vinnie Anderson,
which saw the first-half finish all square.
</P>
<P>
Warrington took the lead after the break as Jon Clarke touched down but the
Robins bounced back with quick tries from ex-Newcastle Knights forward Clint
Newton, Ben Galea and Jake Webster.
</P>
<P>
The visitors regained their composure and reduced the deficit to four points
when Matt King touched down before Chris Bridge once again put the visitors in
front.
</P>
<P>
A Dobson penalty levelled the scores just before full-time, forcing the match
into a sudden-death golden-point thriller, until Briers' settled it.
</P>
<P>
St Helens eased into the semi-finals of the Challenge Cup with a thumping 12-try
66-6 victory over Gateshead.
</P>
<P>
The win also included Sean Long's 1,000th goal for the club, while former
Australia centre Matt Gidley and ex-Sydney Roosters second-row Chris Flannery
grabbed doubles for Saints.
</P>
<P>
Wigan moved to within a sight of a return to Wembley after an 11-year absence
with a 28-6 win over Salford.
</P>
<P>
Former Wests winger Pat Richards was the star of the show with a hat-trick of
tries and eight points with the boot.
</P>
<P>
In the weekend's only Super League fixture, Wakefield racked up a half century
of points against Celtic Crusaders, winning 50-6.
</P>
<P>
Wakefield ran in nine tries, with the game all but over at the break as Trinity
led by 30 points.
</P>
<P>
Trinity's tries came from Ryan Atkins, Michael Korkidas, Scott Grix, Danny
Brough and Brad Drew before the break, while Jamie Rooney went over twice,
before Steve Snitch and Drew, with his second, completed the rout.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Israel names new negotiator for Hamas prisoner swap
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Jerusalem, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday appointed a new envoy to
head indirect negotiations on a prisoner swap with the Islamist Hamas rulers of
the Gaza Strip.
</P>
<P>
Hagai Hadas, a former commander in the Mossad spy agency, will oversee talks on
the release of soldier Gilad Shalit, held in Gaza since his capture by
Palestinian militants in June 2006, the premier's office said in a statement.
</P>
<P>
Hamas and Israel blame each other for the failure of negotiations in Cairo in
mid-March aimed at securing a deal under which Israel would free hundreds of
Palestinian prisoners in exchange for Shalit.
</P>
<P>
Ofer Dekel, the previous Israeli prisoner negotiator who was appointed by former
prime minister Ehud Olmert, stepped down shortly after Netanyahu took office in
March.
</P>
<P>
The talks on a swap have not resumed since Netanyahu's right-leaning government
took office at the start of April, and the premier has so far refused to say
whether he accepts the framework of the previous negotiations.
</P>
<P>
Israel, which launched a devastating 22-day onslaught on Hamas in Gaza in
December, has made the release of Shalit a precondition for a lasting ceasefire
and an end to its blockade of the enclave.
</P>
<P>
A corporal at the time of his capture, Shalit has since been promoted to staff
sergeant.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0139" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Tennis: Safina powers on, Ivanovic heads home
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Top seed Dinara Safina won at a canter to reach the French Open quarter-finals
on Sunday but it will not be title-holder Ana Ivanovic she meets there after the
Serb lost 6-2, 6-3 to Victoria Azarenka
</P>
<P>
The 23-year-old Russian brushed aside the challenge of France's Aravane Rezai
6-1, 6-0 in a centre-court mis-match and has conceded just five games in four
matches.
</P>
<P>
Also through and into her first Grand Slam quarter-final was Slovakia's Dominika
Cibulkova who had too much movement about the court and allround ability for
Agnes Szavay of Hungary winning 6-2, 6-4.
</P>
<P>
She will play the winner of the day's remaining fourth round tie between former
world No 1 Maria Sharpova of Russia and Li Na who is bidding to become the first
Chinese player to reach the last eight at Roland Garros.
</P>
<P>
Azaranka's win over Ivanovic was no great surprise as she has won three titles
this year already while Ivanovic has been laid low with injury and poor form.
</P>
<P>
Two breaks of serve in the sixth and eighth games were enough to clinch the
first set for the Arizona-based player and when she went 4-0 up in the second it
was all but over.
</P>
<P>
With the crowd cheering for Ivanovic and jeering Azarenko, the Serb did manage
two breaks of her own after that, but she could not hold onto her own serve
allowing the Belarussian to close out the tie.
</P>
<P>
Azarenka said she had not been upset by the crowd clearly favouring her
opponent.
</P>
<P>
"It was expected because she was the champion, but I hope they will be little
bit more for me now," she said.
</P>
<P>
"It's the first time I have made the quarter-finals (of a Grand Slam) and it's a
big step for me.
</P>
<P>
"It will be tough against Safina because she has lost only one match on clay
this year and has been killing people, but I will be ready."
</P>
<P>
Ivanovic said she had been feeling unwell from the middle of the first set.
</P>
<P>
"I started really well and felt good, but after the third point of the fourth
game I started to feel dizzy and lost my balance. It was really hard after
that."
</P>
<P>
Safina's win over Rezai was the perfect result for her as she closes in on
winning a first Grand Slam title and proving to herself and her detractors that
she is a worthy world No.1.
</P>
<P>
But it was a poor advertisement for women's tennis as the stage-struck
Frenchwoman, who won her first tournament as a professional in Strasbourg
earlier this month, capitulated in just 53 minutes.
</P>
<P>
"Getting into the quarter-finals like this feels good," said Safina.
</P>
<P>
"I remember Australia (where she reached the final) this year and I don't know
how many hours I needed there so I am feeling good right now.
</P>
<P>
"Since I became number one I am playing better and better."
</P>
<P>
Safina's quickfire win was her 18th win out of 19 matches on clay this season
and confirmed her status as favourite to win her first Grand Slam title.
</P>
<P>
Cibulkova, at 1.61 metres one of the smallest players on the WTA circuit,
dominated the rallies against Szavay from the start of their match jumping out
into a 4-0 lead.
</P>
<P>
The Hungarian, who stunned Venus Williams in the third round, steadied the ship
in the fifth game but by that time the first set was out of her reach, Cibulkova
taking it 6-2 in 38 minutes.
</P>
<P>
Cibulkova wiped out an early break against her in the second set as she won five
games in a row but failed to convert a match point in the following game and had
to wait till her next service game to wrap things up.
</P>
<P>
She will next go up against the winner of the tie between Sharapova and Li
knowing that she has already taken a step up the career ladder at Roland Garros.
</P>
<P>
"I have nothing to lose from now on in," the Slovak said.
</P>
<P>
"I was injured before Roland Garros (leg muscle) and didn't play the big
tournaments, so I was a bit afraid. But now it's amazing."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Football: Mazzarri leaves Sampdoria
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Rome, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Walter Mazzarri on Sunday said he was leaving Sampdoria, following the club's
2-2 draw at Palermo on the last day of the season.
</P>
<P>
Mazzarri had been with the club two years following a career in the lower
divisions, and this season guided Samp to the Italian Cup final.
</P>
<P>
"Tomorrow (Monday) the club will announce that our paths have separated. We took
this decision in a mutual way," said the 47-year-old.
</P>
<P>
Mazzarri has been tipped as a possible replacement for Palermo's Davide
Ballardini, who is widely tipped to leave his post in Sicily.
</P>
<P>
"I would like that, I like Sicily. But I'll think about my future tomorrow,"
Mazzarri told Rai TV when asked about Palermo.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Tennis: Robin Soderling factfile
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
Factfile on Sweden's Robin Soderling who knocked four-time French Open champion
Rafael Nadal out of Roland Garros in the fourth round on Sunday:

Name: Robin Soderling (SWE)

Birthdate: Aug 14, 1984

Birthplace: Tibro, Sweden

Residence: Monte Carlo, Monaco

Height: 6'4'' (193 cm)

Weight: 192 lbs (87 kg)

Plays: Right-handed

Turned Pro: 2001

Coach: Magnus Norman

Current world ranking: 25

Best world ranking: 15 (Feb 2, 2009)

Career details

Singles Record: 177 - 128

Singles Titles: 3 (2004/Lyon; 2005/Milan; 2008/Lyon)

Doubles Record: 29 - 39

Prize Money: 3,307,332 US dollars (up to start of French Open)

<HEADLINE>
Abortion doctor shot dead at his Kansas church: report
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Wichita, Kansas, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
A controversial provider of late-term abortions was shot to death Sunday as he
walked into services at his Kansas church, local media reports.
</P>
<P>
A lightning rod in the bitter culture war over abortion, George Tiller has been
picketed, bombed and shot in the arms.
</P>
<P>
He was shot to death just after 10 am (1500 GMT) as he walked into Reformation
Lutheran Church in Wichita, Kansas, the Wichita Eagle reported.
</P>
<P>
Police contacted by AFP could not immediately confirm the report but said
details of an incident at the church would be released later in the day.
</P>
<P>
Tiller, 67, one of the few doctors who still performs late-term abortions in the
United States, has been demonized by abortion opponents who regularly protest
outside his clinic, located just off a busy highway that runs through Wichita.
</P>
<P>
In 1986, someone placed a bomb on the roof of the clinic, seriously damaging the
building.
</P>
<P>
In 1993, Tiller was shot in both arms outside the clinic. Tiller recovered, and
his assailant received an 11-year prison term.
</P>
<P>
Some 2,000 protesters were also arrested outside the clinic during summer-long
demonstrations in 1991.
</P>
<P>
He was acquitted in March on charges that he performed 19 illegal abortions in
2003.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Football: AC Milan replace Ancelotti with Leonardo
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ROME, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
AC Milan on Sunday replaced coach Carlo Ancelotti with former player and
Brazilian World Cup winner Leonardo, who was the club's technical director on
Sunday.
</P>
<P>
While Ancelotti was telling Italian Sky Sport TV that he was leaving, Galliani
was announcing his replacement to Rai.
</P>
<P>
"Leonardo will be the new Milan coach. He will be officially presented tomorrow
(Monday) at midday," he told them, confirming a claim made in Friday's Gazzetta
dello Sport.
</P>
<P>
The 39-year-old played for the club from 1997-2001, winning the league title in
1999.
</P>
<P>
He was part of the Brazil squad that beat Italy to win the World Cup in 1994,
although he disgraced himself earlier in the tournament by getting sent off
against hosts the United States for elbowing Tab Ramos, resulting in a four-game
suspension that saw him miss the final.
</P>
<P>
Leonardo has no previous coaching experience but Barcelona's Pep Guardiola has
proved novices can shine after winning an incredible treble in his season in
charge of the Catalans.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0146" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Zimbabwe PM's party bemoans pace of change
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
HARARE, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai's party bemoaned the slow pace of change in
Zimbabwe's fledgling coalition on Sunday, calling for the central bank chief and
attorney general to quit immediately.
</P>
<P>
In resolutions at the end of its annual conference, the Movement for Democratic
Change also called for a regional summit to resolve differences dogging the
unity government between Tsvangirai and President Robert Mugabe.
</P>
<P>
The MDC has long criticised Mugabe's decision to retain central bank chief
Gideon Gono and attorney-general Johannes Tomana but Tsvangirai tried to take
the heat out of the issue last week when he said their future should be decided
by the Southern African Development Community (SADC), a regional bloc.
</P>
<P>
However in the resolutions, the MDC said both men should go immediately.
</P>
<P>
"Aware of the conflict and divisive effect of the issues ... conference calls
that in the national interest Johannes Tomana and Gideon Gono resign forthwith,"
the MDC said in resolutions read by secretary-general Tendai Biti, who is also
Zimbabwe's finance minister.
</P>
<P>
Tsvangirai encountered tough resistance within the MDC about entering a power-
sharing deal with Mugabe in February and the resolution made clear the party is
unhappy about what it sees as a lack of reform and continued intimidation of its
supporters by pro-Mugabe militias.
</P>
<P>
The party said the government must address "the slow pace of media reforms, slow
implementation of the government 100-day plan, continued deployment of the
military in villages and the existence of militia and ghost workers on the
government payroll."
</P>
<P>
The prime minister sought to reassure his supporters at the end of the
conference saying he had not abandoned the party's objectives.
</P>
<P>
"The transitional government, which is a coalition government is a stepping
stone to a new and democratic Zimbabwe," he said but expressing disappoitment at
delays in implementing the coalition agreement.
</P>
<P>
"We are disappointed at the pace of the implementation of some of the issues in
the global political agreement.
</P>
<P>
"The party's agenda must not be diluted by the government's agenda. We must also
acknowledge that in a marriage like this there are likely to be compromises but
we must not demobilise saying 'we have arrived.' We must continue to streng our
party structures in preparations for elections."
</P>
<P>
The MDC is particularly keen to see the back of Gono, who has been widely
criticised for failing to stop the Zimbabwean economy's freefall and slide into
world record inflation.
</P>
<P>
Tomana is also accused of having overseen politically-inspired prosecutions in
the aftermath of last year's disputed presidential election.
</P>
<P>
Tsvangirai won the first round of voting in March last year but pulled out of a
run-off after scores of MDC were killed in attacks the party blamed on Mugabe's
followers.
</P>
<P>
The conference also called on the inclusive government to support victims of
political violence.
</P>
<P>
"Concerned with the plight of victims of political violence ... conference
resolves that the inclusive government vigilantly addresses the issue of the
welfare of victims," the party said.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Football: Ancelotti quits Milan after eight seasons
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ROME, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Carlo Ancelotti announced he was quitting AC Milan following their 2-0 win at
Fiorentina on the last day of the Serie A season on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Milan vice-president Adriano Galliani then announced that former player and
Brazil World Cup winning midfielder Leonardo, the club's technical director,
would be taking over the hot-seat.
</P>
<P>
A visibly emotional Ancelotti, who is widely tipped to take over at Chelsea,
told Italian Sky Sport TV: "Today my beautiful Milan adventure has come to an
end."
</P>
<P>
Ancelotti, who still had a year to run on his contract, confirmed what had
become the worst kept secret in Italian football in announcing his departure,
however he refused to confirm that Chelsea would be his destination.
</P>
<P>
"Our paths are separating. I spoke after the match to Mr Galliani and we decided
to terminate the contract.
</P>
<P>
"We spoke a while back but the decision was taken at the end of the season and
it was mutual.
</P>
<P>
"London is not certain as a destination."
</P>
<P>
Ancelotti won two Champions League titles, one Serie A crown and the Club World
Cup during his eight seasons at Milan but was coming under heavy criticism the
last two years for failing to push champions Inter Milan closer.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Tennis: Nadal crushed by Soderling sledgehammer
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Rafael Nadal's hopes of a record fifth successive French Open title were crushed
into the Roland Garros red dust by Robin Soderling's Swedish sledgehammer on
Sunday.
</P>
<P>
In one of the greatest upsets in the tournament's history, the Spanish king of
clay slumped to a first ever defeat here having racked up 31 wins in 31 outings
since his 2005 debut.
</P>
<P>
Soderling's stunning 6-2, 6-7 (2/7), 6-4, 7-6 (7/2) victory came just a month
after he'd won only one game in a 6-1, 6-0 rout at the Rome Masters, his third
defeat in three matches against the world number one.
</P>
<P>
But he was man transformed on Sunday with the 24-year-old unleashing a
formidable service game and a relentless, pinpoint accurate forehand which
forced Nadal to constantly scramble for a foothold in the match.
</P>
<P>
"I just couldn't believe it when I won that last point," said a tearful
Soderling who has never gone this far before in a Grand Slam.
</P>
<P>
"I'm so proud of myself. This is the best win of my career against a man who is
the greatest claycourt player in history. But I told myself before the match
that I had to believe I could win."
</P>
<P>
Nadal's first set loss was the first time he had dropped a set in the tournament
since the 2007 final against Roger Federer, ending a run of 32 in a row.
</P>
<P>
The Spaniard was reeling from the outset at the hands of a man whom he'd accused
of being one of the most unpopular players in the locker room after an
acrimonious Wimbledon clash two years ago.
</P>
<P>
Nadal was broken in the fourth game as 23rd seeded Soderling went to 4-1 ahead
and again in the crucial eighth as the free-flowing, uninhibited Swede continued
to find the corners with devastating accuracy.
</P>
<P>
The 24-year-old deservedly claimed the opening set when the champion netted a
backhand.
</P>
<P>
Nadal, despite missing his usual fluency and rattled by the unrelenting assault,
broke for the first time to lead 2-1 in the second set only to surrender his
advantage in the 10th game.
</P>
<P>
With most people inside Court Philippe Chatrier expecting a Nadal drive to fly
past the big Swede, Soderling executed a fine backhand volley to go to 5-5.
</P>
<P>
Despite those heroics, Nadal ran away with the tiebreaker to level the match
when, for once, Soderling's forehand missed its target and flew long.
</P>
<P>
The Swede, coached by compatriot and 2000 finalist Magnus Norman, refused to
yield, breaking to lead 4-3 before backing it up for a 5-3 advantage in the
third set.
</P>
<P>
He took the set when Nadal netted another weary forehand off yet another deep
Soderling drive.
</P>
<P>
Nadal broke to lead 2-0 in the fourth set, but Soderling hit back immediately as
another tiebreak loomed where the gallant Swede clinched his famous win on a
second match point when Nadal went wide with a pick-up.
</P>
<P>
Soderling sent down nine aces in the match and fired a decisive 61 winners to
the Spaniard's 33.
</P>
<P>
His reward is a match-up with either Russian 10th seed Nikolay Davydenko or
Fernando Verdasco, the eighth-seeded Spaniard for a place in the semi-finals.
</P>
<P>
Sunday's drama would have delighted Roger Federer, who has lost the last three
finals to Nadal, and who still needs a French Open to complete a career Grand
Slam.
</P>
<P>
He plays his last 16 tie on Monday against Germany's Tommy Haas.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
AFP Europe news summary
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
PARIS, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
Top European news stories on Sunday:

EU-vote

BRUSSELS: European leaders stepped up a desperate battle to persuade people to
vote for the EU parliament this week, but the campaign has opened up new
political divisions across the continent.

Britain-politics

LONDON: British Prime Minister Gordon Brown insisted he would not quit despite a
scandal over MPs expenses and dire poll ratings for his ruling Labour Party
before crunch European and local elections.

Georgia-Russia-SOssetia-conflict-vote

TSKHINVALI, Georgia: The rebel Georgian region of South Ossetia voted in polls
expected to secure the grip of its separatist leader nine months after it was
the subject of war between Russia and Georgia.

Russia-politics-demo

MOSCOW: Police arrested Russian radical leftist leader Eduard Limonov and up to
20 other activists at an unauthorised anti-government demonstration in Moscow,
said an AFP journalist at the scene.

Britain-France-royals-history-WWII

LONDON: British Prime Minister Gordon Brown pledged that he would ensure Queen
Elizabeth II could attend a commemoration of the World War II D-Day landings
amid a furore over her not being invited.

Italy-US-Vatican-pope-Obama

ROME: US President Barack Obama may meet with Pope Benedict XVI in July when he
is in Italy for a Group of Eight summit, the ANSA news agency reported.

Britain-politics-history

LONDON: Big Ben, arguably the world's most famous clock which towers over
London, marked its 150th anniversary.

Entertainment-Britain-music-Internet-YouTube-people

LONDON: Unlikely Scottish singing sensation Susan Boyle was plotting her future
after her defeat in the "Britain's Got Talent" television show, which made her a
worldwide star thanks to Internet exposure.

Latvia-social-economy-offbeat

RIGA: Several hundred blondes marched through the Latvian capital Riga in a bid
cheer up the crisis-hit Baltic nation, suffering the worst recession in the
27-member EU.

<HEADLINE>
Notorcycling: Stoner ends Rossi's seven year reign at Mugello
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
SCARPERIA, Italy, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Casey Stoner held off the fast-finishing Jorge Lorenzo to win the Italian Grand
Prix on Sunday and bring to an end Valentino Rossi's seven-year reign here.
</P>
<P>
The Australian also took over the lead in the world championship standings with
his second win of the season having also triumphed in Qatar in the opening race
of the season.
</P>
<P>
He now leads Lorenzo, who started on pole here, by four points in the
championship standings with Rossi third, a further five points back.
</P>
<P>
Rossi blamed his team for making the wrong choice of tyre in the dry, going for
the harder compound.
</P>
<P>
"It's a precious result, it's also nice to be on the podium. The race was really
difficult, we knew the weather would be terrible," he said.
</P>
<P>
"In the dry we made a mistake in going with the hard tyres. The choice of hards
was made even though I wanted the soft ones."
</P>
<P>
Lorenzo said he was delighted with his finish having slid off on the warm-up lap
and skidded at the start.
</P>
<P>
"Honestly, this is as good as a win for me and I can’t really believe the race
today, it was like a movie," he said.
</P>
<P>
"This morning in the warm-up I was quite worried because I was slow in the rain,
then on the formation lap I slid off into the gravel pit.
</P>
<P>
"On the grid I tried not to think about the crash, I just tried to focus. But
then I had a big slide off the line and the first part of the race wasn’t so
good for me.
</P>
<P>
"It’s a really amazing result because things could have been much worse today,
so thank you again to everyone for making it possible. I’m really happy with
this result."
</P>
<P>
In a dramatic race that began in wet conditions, Stoner seized the advantage
when switching bikes after 10 laps for a change of tyres.
</P>
<P>
He was the fastest man on the track by some margin in those first few laps after
the switch and although Yamaha pair Lorenzo and Rossi were quickest at the end,
they had both lost too much time and too many places to hit back.
</P>
<P>
Stoner completed the 23 laps in 45min 41.894sec to beat Lorenzo by just over a
second.
</P>
<P>
In an exciting race the pole-sitter got off to a terrible start in the wet and
immediately dropped to eighth.
</P>
<P>
Quickest off the mark were Australian Chris Vermeulen, who started 11th, and
Andrea Dovizioso, who began seventh but Stoner passed them both on the long
straight at the beginning of the second lap.
</P>
<P>
Vermeulen quickly started heading backwards, eventually finishing 10th, as Rossi
started to move up from fifth.
</P>
<P>
However Italian Marco Melandri on a Kawasaki, who started 15th on the grid, was
clearly fastest in the wet.
</P>
<P>
Rossi took the lead from Dovizioso, who had got back past Stoner, on the seventh
lap and two laps later he lost that to Melandri.
</P>
<P>
However, on the 10th lap all the front runners came into the pits for a change
of bikes and when they came out, Stoner was quickest to find his pace.
</P>
<P>
Melandri immediately started heading backwards, eventually finishing 11th and
35sec back, while Loris Capirossi propelled himself into race contention with
Stoner and Dovizioso.
</P>
<P>
Lorenzo and Rossi initially struggled with their bikes down in fifth and sixth
and the time they lost over those first three laps coming out of the pits,
essentially cost either of them a chance of victory.
</P>
<P>
While Stoner had soon taken the race lead, both Yamaha riders had to then pass
Melandri, Capirossi and Dovizioso and by the time they had done so, Stoner was
over a second ahead and with only a couple of laps remaining.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile former Superbikes champion James Toseland of Britain got his best
finish of the season in seventh, benefitting from being the first man into the
pits to change his bike.
</P>
<P>
It meant that his tyres were warm and he was flying as the fastest man on track
for a few laps when everyone else was simply trying to get temperature into
their new tyres.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Cycling: Russian delight as Menchov wins Tour of Italy
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ROME, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Russian rider Denis Menchov won the Tour of Italy here on Sunday following the
14.4 kilometres time-trial round.
</P>
<P>
The Rabobank cyclist - who is the third Russian to win the race - won despite
suffering a dramatic fall in the last kilometre of the stage.
</P>
<P>
Italian 2007 champion Danilo Di Luca finished second with his compatriot Franco
Pellizzoti rounding off the podium finishers.
</P>
<P>
Lithuanian Ignatas Konovalovas of the Cervelo team won the final stage in a time
of 18min 42sec with Briton Bradley Wiggins only a second back and Norway's
Edvald Boasson Hagen in third.
</P>
<P>
Menchov finished 10th on the stage with Di Luca 16th.
</P>
<P>
The Russian had a 20sec lead coming into the final day in one of the closest
ever finishes to a Giro, in it's centenary year.
</P>
<P>
Di Luca briefly looked to be on the brink of a famous victory when he got to the
first time check fastest of all and 5sec up on Menchov.
</P>
<P>
But the LPR rider had blasted out too fast, gradually fading from there and he
was 14sec down on Menchov at the next time check.
</P>
<P>
When he came over the line, Di Luca had lost 45sec to Konovalovas whereas
Menchov, who had won the 12th stage time-trial to take over the pink jersey last
Thursday, was getting stronger.
</P>
<P>
The Russian looked like he may even win the final time-trial as well but with
rain spitting down drama unfolded in the final kilometre.
</P>
<P>
Riding in a straight line but on a cobbled section, Menchov suddenly crashed
with just 1km left to ride.
</P>
<P>
However quick thinking from his mechanic may have secured him the victory.
</P>
<P>
As Menchov was still sliding along the wet surface, his mechanic had already
jumped out of the team car and was unloading another bike from the roof.
</P>
<P>
Menchov went to pick up his splayed bike but received a shout from the mechanic
and instead jumped straight onto the new one and was back on his way, courtesy
of a push from the mechanic as well.
</P>
<P>
He had been going so well, though, that he still had time to spare on Di Luca
and despite the crash he gained 21sec on his rival to win by 41sec overall.
</P>
<P>
Pellizotti finished just under two minutes down with Tour de France champion
Carlos Sastre fourth and seven-time Tour winner Lance Armstrong 12th.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
ICRC 'gravely concerned' at Pakistan's Swat Valley situation
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Geneva, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Senior Red Cross officials who visited Pakistan's Swat Valley said Sunday they
were "gravely concerned" over the humanitarian situation as Pakistani soldiers
battled to crush the Taliban.
</P>
<P>
"The organisation is gravely concerned about the plight of civilians in Swat and
believes their situation demands a prompt and comprehensive humanitarian
response," said a statement released from the Geneva headquarters of the
International Committee for the Red Cross (ICRC).
</P>
<P>
"The ICRC will do its utmost to meet those needs without delay," said Pascal
Cuttat, head of the organisation's delegation in Pakistan.
</P>
<P>
"Given what we have already seen on the ground, we are mobilising additional
resources, but safe and unimpeded access to the area remains essential for our
teams to deliver," he added.
</P>
<P>
Aid workers had been alarmed at what they saw when they entered the region,
where the fighting between the Pakistani army and Taliban fighters for the pass
month has left civilians trapped and isolated for weeks.
</P>
<P>
"There is no running water, no electricity, and food is scarce," said Daniel
O'Malley, who led the IRCR team into the region.
</P>
<P>
"Phone lines are down, so people have been cut off from the outside world and
are anxious for contact with relatives who fled the area," he added.
</P>
<P>
Red Cross workers were also disturbed at conditions in Khwazakhela hospital, one
of the few medical facilities still left operating in Swat.
</P>
<P>
"The handful of hospital staff left are struggling to work without any water,
electricity or supplies," said O'Malley.
</P>
<P>
"They simply cannot cope with the influx of patients."
</P>
<P>
The Red Cross evacuated 14 patients from the hospital.
</P>
<P>
Pakistan's defence secretary Syed Athar Ali said Sunday the army was gaining on
the Taliban and fighting could be over in a few days.
</P>
<P>
Swat valley's main town Mingora is back in government hands, a critical
milestone in an offensive launched after the Taliban thrust to within 100
kilometres (60 miles) of Islamabad in April.
</P>
<P>
The defence chief told a security forum in Singapore that three targeted
northwest districts were almost clear of Taliban rebels.
</P>
<P>
"Only five to 10 percent of the job is remaining and hopefully within the next
two to three days these pockets of resistance will be cleared," he said.
</P>
<P>
The United States, which is firmly backing the current military drive, had
warned that the rebels threaten Pakistan's very existence.
</P>
<P>
Also Sunday the military relaxed a curfew Sunday in most parts of the northwest
including Mingora to allow people trapped on the roads to return home or leave
the region.
</P>
<P>
The ICRC is one of the very few humanitarian organizations working in Swat
before the conflict broke out and has been trying to return there since early
this month. Despite some openings it said access to areas affected by the
fighting remains too limited.
</P>
<P>
It also continues to support camps run by the Pakistan Red Crescent Society,
where over 20,000 people driven from their homes by the fighting are currently
living.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Tennis: Nadal crushed by Soderling sledgehammer
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Rafael Nadal's hopes of a record fifth successive French Open title were crushed
into the Roland Garros red dust by Robin Soderling's Swedish sledgehammer on
Sunday.
</P>
<P>
In one of the greatest upsets in the tournament's history, the Spanish king of
clay slumped to a first ever defeat here having racked up 31 wins in 31 outings
since his 2005 debut.
</P>
<P>
Soderling's stunning 6-2, 6-7 (2/7), 6-4, 7-6 (7/2) victory came just a month
after he'd won only one game in a 6-1, 6-0 rout at the Rome Masters, his third
defeat in three matches against the world number one.
</P>
<P>
But he was man transformed on Sunday with the 24-year-old unleashing a
formidable service game and a relentless, pinpoint accurate forehand which
forced Nadal to constantly scramble for a foothold in the match.
</P>
<P>
Nadal's first set loss was the first time he had dropped a set in the tournament
since the 2007 final against Roger Federer, ending a run of 32 in a row.
</P>
<P>
The Spaniard was reeling from the outset at the hands of a man whom he'd accused
of being one of the most unpopular players in the locker room after an
acrimonious Wimbledon clash two years ago.
</P>
<P>
Nadal was broken in the fourth game as 23rd seeded Soderling went to 4-1 ahead
and again in the crucial eighth as the free-flowing, uninhibited Swede continued
to find the corners with devastating accuracy.
</P>
<P>
The 24-year-old deservedly claimed the opening set when the champion netted a
backhand.
</P>
<P>
Nadal, despite missing his usual fluency and rattled by the unrelenting assault,
broke for the first time to lead 2-1 in the second set only to surrender his
advantage in the 10th game.
</P>
<P>
With most people inside Court Philippe Chatrier expecting a Nadal drive to fly
past the big Swede, Soderling executed a fine backhand volley to go to 5-5.
</P>
<P>
Despite those heroics, Nadal ran away with the tiebreaker to level the match
when, for once, Soderling's forehand missed its target and flew long.
</P>
<P>
The Swede, coached by compatriot and 2000 finalist Magnus Norman, refused to
yield, breaking to lead 4-3 before backing it up for a 5-3 advantage in the
third set.
</P>
<P>
He took the set when Nadal netted another weary forehand off yet another deep
Soderling drive.
</P>
<P>
Nadal broke to lead 2-0 in the fourth set, but Soderling hit back immediately as
another tiebreak loomed where the gallant Swede clinched his famous win on a
second match point when Nadal went wide with a pick-up.
</P>
<P>
His reward is a match-up with either Russian 10th seed Nikolay Davydenko or
Fernando Verdasco, the eighth-seeded Spaniard for a place in the semi-finals.
</P>
<P>
Sunday's drama would have delighted Roger Federer, who has lost the last three
finals to Nadal, and who still needs a French Open to complete a career Grand
Slam.
</P>
<P>
He plays his last 16 tie on Monday against Germany's Tommy Haas.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Boyle looks to the future despite British talent show defeat
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Unlikely Scottish singing sensation Susan Boyle was plotting her future Sunday
after her defeat in the "Britain's Got Talent" television show, which made her a
worldwide star thanks to Internet exposure.
</P>
<P>
Boyle, a frumpy, 48-year-old church volunteer, will reportedly earn up to eight
million pounds (nine million euros, 13 million dollars) in the next year from a
record deal, a book about her life and even a film.
</P>
<P>
She is set to start rehearsing for an album of showtunes this week and will fly
to Prague next month for recording sessions with the Czech National Symphony
Orchestra, British media said.
</P>
<P>
Boyle's career looks likely to reach new heights even though she lost to the
multi-ethnic street dancers Diversity in a public vote after the live talent
show final late Saturday.
</P>
<P>
Despite winning praise from the audience and the judges, she was forced into
second place. The "best people won", she said, wishing the dance troupe winners
"all the best".
</P>
<P>
After the contest, "Britain's Got Talent" judge Piers Morgan called her "the
greatest discovery the show's ever found".
</P>
<P>
He added: "I'm only sorry that the extraordinary tidal wave of publicity she
attracted meant so many people got either bored or irritated by Boyle mania and
decided not to vote for her as a result," he wrote on his blog.
</P>
<P>
Boyle has enjoyed a meteoric rise to fame over the past two months after video
footage of her audition piece for the show, "I Dreamed A Dream" from the musical
"Les Miserables", was posted on YouTube.
</P>
<P>
It has had at least 100 million hits and brought her celebrity fans including
actress Demi Moore and rock star Jon Bon Jovi, who embraced the dowdy spinster
from small-town Scotland with a voice worthy of Broadway.
</P>
<P>
Bookmakers made her the favourite to win, but after an unconvincing semi-final
performance, there were fears that Boyle, who was starved of oxygen at birth and
has mild learning difficulties, was suffering under the pressure.
</P>
<P>
She was spoken to by police after an outburst at the London hotel where she was
staying, while Morgan described her as "a frightened rabbit in headlights" and
said she had considered quitting the contest.
</P>
<P>
But in a live performance in the final Saturday, she proved the critics wrong
and repeated her audition piece with gusto.
</P>
<P>
Following her performance, Boyle -- wearing a grey-blue, long sequined dress --
was asked if it was worth all the media pressure, she replied: "Well worth
it!... I really feel at home on stage, I'm among friends."
</P>
<P>
As for her future plans, she added: "I hope to get an album out -- I'll just
play it by ear. What a journey -- unbelievable, and very humbling."
</P>
<P>
A total of 19.2 million people watched the show in Britain, making it the most
popular television programme for five years.
</P>
<P>
Just under four million people voted, broadcaster ITV said, with 24.9 percent
backing Diversity and 20.2 percent Boyle.
</P>
<P>
Boyle's performance was also watched by hundreds of fans in her home town of
Blackburn, outside Edinburgh, where she lives in social housing with only her
cat Pebbles for company.
</P>
<P>
"She told me that after the final, she wants to come back and resume her
previous life," one of Boyle's neighbours, 24-year-old housewife Vicky McLean
told the Mail on Sunday newspaper.
</P>
<P>
"She doesn't want to make millions and go to America, she just wants to sing. I
think all she really hopes to have out of it is enough money to buy her house."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Cricket: Younus glad Pakistan back on world stage
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Pakistan captain Younus Khan said the upcoming ICC World Twenty20 in England had
a special significance for his side after their country had become a virtual
'no-go zone' for international cricket.
</P>
<P>
A terror attack on the Sri Lanka team bus in Lahore in March saw seven of their
players and English assistant coach Paul Farbrace injured.
</P>
<P>
Eight Pakistanis, including six security force personnel, were killed.
</P>
<P>
With no international side willing to travel to Pakistan, Younus's men recently
returned to international action in the United Arab Emirates against Australia,
where they lost 3-2 in a one-day series but won the lone Twenty20.
</P>
<P>
"It is special to be back on the world stage, especially in Twenty20 and in
England, the media are here so lots of hopes are here," the talented batsman
told reporters at Lord's here on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
"We are suffering from not playing regularly, and no-one is coming to Pakistan,"
he added.
</P>
<P>
Pakistan endured a nailbiting defeat at the hands of arch-rivals India in the
2007 World Twenty20 final in South Africa and Younus would love nothing more
than for his team to go one better this time.
</P>
<P>
"My confidence is that I'll take this trophy to Pakistan," he said. But such has
been Pakistan's relative lack of international cricket that he added: "It will
be an achievement for us to finish in the top four."
</P>
<P>
Reflecting on the 2007 final, Younus said: "The finishing touches were not
there. We needed only five runs. But it was fantastic to be a part of that team
in the final.
</P>
<P>
"Some guys were crying at the end, but hopefully we'll have the finishing
touches," Younus said.
</P>
<P>
Twenty20 tends to put a premium on big-hitting batsmen at the start of the
innings but Younus, whose team face England and the Netherlands in Group B, said
it was not necessary to start going for big shots right from the off.
</P>
<P>
"Twenty20 looks short, but it's not - 120 balls is enough.
</P>
<P>
"If you bat normally but with energy, especially in the middle order and with
good runners between the wickets, 180-90 is very easy.
</P>
<P>
"In English conditions the new ball does seam, so you need someone like Salman
Butt who can play for 20 overs. But in the middle order, we have big hitters
like Shahid Afridi and Misbah-Ul-Haq."
</P>
<P>
English officials have already announced that plans are well advanced for
Pakistan to play two Tests against Australia in England next year as well as a
series with Andrew Strauss's men.
</P>
<P>
Large Asian communities in England provide Pakistan with a ready-made fan base
and Younus said: "Playing in England is everyone's dream. My first Test at
Lord's was fantastic for me.
</P>
<P>
"England is the home of cricket, it is an achievement for us to play Tests here,
and maybe ODIs too. It's good for the youngsters to play in England and the old
guys have a lot of friends here.
</P>
<P>
"We need the passion in Twenty20 and in England, a lot of followers all the
time, a lot of cities have Pakistanis and Indians. That's the main reason I'm
happy to be in England."
</P>
<P>
Younus added: "If we play good cricket it will be good for our nation. These
days all the nation is depressed.
</P>
<P>
"Only cricket - if we play well and win something - they will cheer. To finish
in the top four, my nation will come again and start cheering."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Myanmar's Suu Kyi trades barbs with junta over trial
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
YANGON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Myanmar's military junta accused Aung San Suu Kyi Sunday of covering up a visit
to her home by a US man which led to her trial, as the pro-democracy icon hit
back against the "bullying" generals.
</P>
<P>
The regime said the Nobel laureate was not above the law and issued its sternest
warning yet against foreign interference in the case, under which she faces up
to five years' jail for breaching her house arrest.
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi has proclaimed her innocence at the closed prison trial,
insisting that she only offered "temporary shelter" to American John Yettaw
after he swam to her lakeside house, and has branded the proceedings as biased.
</P>
<P>
"It is no doubt that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi has committed a cover-up of the truth
by her failure to report an illegal immigrant to the authorities concerned,"
Major General Aye Myint, Myanmar's deputy defence minister, told a security
forum in Singapore.
</P>
<P>
"Thus there was no option but to open legal proceedings in accordance with the
law," Aye Myint said. "She permitted him to stay.... She communicated, provided
him food and shelter."
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi has spent 13 of the last 19 years in detention, mostly at her
crumbling lakeside mansion. She was moved to Yangon's notorious Insein prison
and charged on May 14.
</P>
<P>
The 63-year-old opposition leader met with her lawyers at the jail on Saturday
ahead of final arguments in the case, which are due to be heard on Friday. A
guilty verdict is widely expected.
</P>
<P>
Her party said Sunday that she was upset that Myanmar authorities had entered
her residential compound without permission to stage a reconstruction of
Yettaw's visit for the purposes of the trial.
</P>
<P>
"Aung San Suu Kyi said she is not completely satisfied as Mr Yettaw and the
authorities went into her compound last week for a demonstration (of how he got
into the property)," party spokesman Nyan Win told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"It was not in accordance with the law. She said it was unjust bullying," added
Nyan Win, who is also part of her legal team.
</P>
<P>
Yettaw, a 53-year-old Mormon and former US military veteran, was arrested on May
6 after swimming to Aung San Suu Kyi's house using a pair of homemade flippers
and spending two nights there.
</P>
<P>
He has told the court that he had had a vision that Aung San Suu Kyi would be
assassinated by "terrorists" and was told by God to warn both the opposition
leader and the Myanmar government.
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi said in a statement to the court this week that she could not
be held responsible as the junta had failed to boost security despite her having
reported that Yettaw made a previous visit to the house in November 2008.
</P>
<P>
However Nyan Win quoted the democracy campaigner as saying that she "has no
grudge to Mr Yettaw and his family."
</P>
<P>
International critics accuse Myanmar's military regime of trumping up the
charges in a bid to keep her locked up ahead of elections in 2010, as the latest
six-year period of her house arrest expired on Wednesday.
</P>
<P>
But in his speech in Singapore, Myanmar's Aye Myint said the case against Aung
San Suu Kyi was an internal matter.
</P>
<P>
"Countries should refrain from interfering in the internal affairs of Myanmar
that will affect peace and security of the region," said Aye Myint.
</P>
<P>
"It is the universal legal principle that no one is above the law," he said
</P>
<P>
US Defence Secretary Robert Gates, speaking at the same forum on Saturday,
pressed Myanmar to free Aung San Suu Kyi and said there needed to be "real
change in Burma". Burma is Myanmar's former name.
</P>
<P>
Ann Taylor, Britain's minister for international defence and security, made a
similar call on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Myanmar last week hit back at rare criticism from the normally placid fellow
members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) over the treatment
of the democracy campaigner.
</P>
<P>
Thai Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva, whose country holds the rotating
chairmanship of the 10-member bloc, said ASEAN leaders would discuss Myanmar at
a summit in South Korea on June 1-2.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile more than 100 people rallied in Singapore late Sunday as part of a
regional effort by civil rights groups to press Myanmar's military rulers to
release Aung San Suu Kyi.
</P>
<P>
Similar rallies were also held simultaneously in Indonesia, the Philippines,
Malaysia, Cambodia and Thailand, organisers said.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
British PM says won't quit as poll predicts Euro election rout
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
British Prime Minister Gordon Brown insisted Sunday he would not quit despite a
scandal over MPs expenses and dire poll ratings for his ruling Labour Party
before crunch European and local elections.
</P>
<P>
He said the expenses furore was "appalling" and "offends everything that I
believe in".
</P>
<P>
Every lawmaker would be forced to account for all their expenses from the last
four years, he promised.
</P>
<P>
Some 13 lawmakers from Labour and the main opposition Conservatives have said
they will resign since the scandal broke.
</P>
<P>
The leaked expenses claims have shown that Members of Parliament have claimed
from the public purse for everything from moat cleaning to a duck island.
</P>
<P>
A new Sunday Telegraph/ICM poll suggested that three weeks of revelations by the
Daily Telegraph newspaper would hit Brown hard at the European and local
elections, in which Britons vote Thursday.
</P>
<P>
It suggested Labour would come third in the European elections with just 17
percent, behind David Cameron's Conservatives and second opposition centrist
Liberal Democrats.
</P>
<P>
Even more damagingly, it suggested Labour would also come third in a general
election with just 22 percent of the vote -- the worst Brown's party has done in
an opinion poll since 1987.
</P>
<P>
Some 54 percent of those polled thought Labour had been worst affected by the
expenses scandal, compared to 13 percent for the Conservatives.
</P>
<P>
ICM interviewed 1,013 adults by telephone between May 27-28.
</P>
<P>
But Brown, who must call a general election by the middle of next year,
dismissed suggestions he could step down to make way for a more popular leader
in an interview with BBC television.
</P>
<P>
"Things go up and down," he said. "We're going through the most difficult
economic circumstances the country has faced.
</P>
<P>
"People are angry rightly because they are worried when they see taxpayers'
money wasted on their MPs and they're finding it very difficult... in a
difficult economic situation," he added, referring to Britain's recession.
</P>
<P>
He also said he wanted to introduce a "constitutional renewal" bill and was
looking at reforms including the case for a written constitution, lowering the
voting age to 16 and reform of the unelected upper chamber, the House of Lords.
</P>
<P>
Brown said he did not accept the case for an unelected House of Lords and said
he was always open to arguments for reforming of the voting system.
</P>
<P>
Cameron, meanwhile, renewed his calls for a snap general election, telling the
BBC the public wanted to "sit in judgement on MPs".
</P>
<P>
Turnout at European elections in Britain is usually low -- in the last polls in
2004, it was just 38 percent, due in part to strong Eurosceptic sentiment among
many.
</P>
<P>
This time, fringe parties such as the anti-EU UK Independence Party and the far-
right British National Party are expected to benefit. Commentators say the BNP
could even win its first seat at the European Parliament.
</P>
<P>
An Economist magazine/YouGov poll last week found that only 31 percent of
Britons think its membership of the European Union is a good thing, compared to
37 percent who think it is bad.
</P>
<P>
A total of 2,322 adults in Britain were questioned between May 22 and May 26.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Tennis: Azarenka dethrones Queen Ana at French Open
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Belarussian teenager Victoria Azarenka sunk Ana Ivanovic's hopes of defending
her French Open crown with a comprehensive 6-2, 6-3 win in the fourth round on
Sunday.
</P>
<P>
It is the first time the 19-year-old has reached the last eight at a Grand Slam
event and she will play Russian top seed Dinara Safina for a place in the semi-
finals.
</P>
<P>
The 21-year-old Ivanovic, meanwhile, was left pondering what she has to do to
re-discover the form that brought her the title and world No.1 spot a year ago.
</P>
<P>
Azarenka, with three titles to her name this year already, was the first to
break thanks to a blistering crosscourt backhand in the third game.
</P>
<P>
Ivanovic, who has battled for form and fitness since her triumph here last year,
had her chances to break back in the following game but failed to take them.
</P>
<P>
She paid the penalty for that three games later when Azarenka collected a second
break of serve forcing her opponent to hit long on break point at the end of a
long, punishing rally.
</P>
<P>
Azarenka, a former world junior No.1, comfortably served out for the set despite
opening with a double fault.
</P>
<P>
Both players were wearing high-tech strapping on their knees, the right for
Ivanovic and the left for Azarenko, a clear sign of the injury epidemic that has
beset women's tennis.
</P>
<P>
Ivanovic was put under severe pressure on her serve again at the start of the
second set and after saving a handful of break points she finally succumbed by
hitting a forehand a fraction long.
</P>
<P>
That was all Azarenka needed to further assert her authority in the match with
Ivanovic looking increasingly out of sorts and unsure of herself.
</P>
<P>
The crowd were firmly behind the Serb, but it made no difference as Azarenko
jumped out into a commanding 4-0 lead.
</P>
<P>
Ivanovic did manage to claw two games back to get to 4-2, but Azarenka snuffed
out any hope she had of a comeback by breaking the Serbian's serve again in the
next game.
</P>
<P>
She failed to serve out for the match but broke Ivanovic for the sixth time in
the match in the following game to go through.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Kuwait opposes high oil price
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
kuwait city, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Kuwait's Oil Minister Sheikh Ahmad Abdullah al-Sabah said on Sunday the OPEC
member does not favour a high price for oil because this would dampen the global
economy.
</P>
<P>
"We are not in favour to see the prices in the hundreds (of dollars a barrel)
because this will fuel recession again," the minister told reporters outside
parliament.
</P>

He said Kuwait, the fourth largest Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries
producer, is happy with OPEC's decision to keep production unchanged and ruled
out any output cut when the organisation meets again in September.
</P>
<P>
Asked about the recent increase in oil prices, Sheikh Ahmad said: "The market is
reacting to sentiment rather than fundamentals. There is a lot of supply but the
prices are rising."
</P>
<P>
The minister expects prices to increase to around 70 dollars a barrel as winter
appoaches. "We are approaching winter and definitely demand will increase."
</P>
<P>
Last July oil prices surged above 147 dollars a barrel before plunging to barely
32 dollars in December.
</P>
<P>
Continuing their recent recovery, prices shot back above 66 dollars a barrel on
Friday on further signs of economic recovery and a weakening of the US currency.
</P>
<P>
New York's main futures contract, light sweet crude for delivery in July ended
at 66.31 dollars, while Brent North Sea closed at 65.52 dollars.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Palestinian tensions flare in deadly shoot-out
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
NABLUS, West Bank, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Six people were killed in a West Bank shoot-out on Sunday when an attempt to
arrest a senior Hamas commander went awry, deepening the rift between the two
main Palestinian factions.
</P>
<P>
The Islamist Hamas movement ruling the Gaza Strip warned that the rival Fatah
group loyal to president Mahmud Abbas had crossed a "red line" over the killing
of one of its top fighters in the arrest operation.
</P>
<P>
The firefight erupted when Palestinian police dominated by Fatah tried to arrest
Mohammed al-Samman, commander of Hamas's armed wing in the northern West Bank,
who was also on Israel's wanted list.
</P>
<P>
Samman barricaded himself into a house in the town of Qalqiliya in the north of
the Israeli-occupied territory together with Mohammed Yassin, another Hamas
militant, police and Hamas said.
</P>
<P>
The ensuing shoot-out killed both Hamas men, three Palestinian policemen and a
civilian. A curfew was imposed on the town near the border with Israel following
the incident, police said.
</P>
<P>
Hamas branded the incident a "red line" and said it laid "complete
responsibility of this ugly crime on Abbas and his security forces."
</P>
<P>
Describing Abbas and his forces as agents of arch-enemy Israel, Hamas said in a
statement that it would respond "with acts," without elaborating.
</P>
<P>
"There is no difference between the occupation who shoots and the people who
carry out their missions for them," a spokesman for Hamas's armed wing said at a
news conference in Gaza.
</P>
<P>
The deep-seated rivalries between Hamas and Fatah boiled over in June 2007 when
the Islamists violently seized control of Gaza, causing a split in Palestinian
ranks that has become a key stumbling block in efforts to reach Middle East
peace.
</P>
<P>
Hamas spokesman Fawzi Barhum said there was no chance of further reconciliation
talks with Fatah after the "escalation by security services of Abu Mazen and
Fatah against Hamas and its leaders in the West Bank."
</P>
<P>
"Fatah should choose -- dialogue with us or doing the dirty work of the Zionist
enemy," Barhum said as Hamas decried the killing over mosque loudspeakers in
Gaza City.
</P>
<P>
A senior official from the Fatah-led Palestinian Authority dismissed the Hamas
accusations as "lies."
</P>
<P>
"The Palestinian Authority has one duty -- to impose security and the law and we
will not allow what happened in Gaza to happen here in the West Bank under any
circumstances," he said on condition of anonymity.
</P>
<P>
A spokesman for Palestinian security forces, Adnan Damiri, defended the arrest
operation.
</P>
<P>
"We in the Palestinian security branches are not a political force. We are
security. We will not allow any Palestinian party to have guns and threaten
civilians."
</P>
<P>
Damiri also said that during the arrest, police discovered Hamas leaflets
containing "incitement against the Palestinian Authority and against the
Palestinian security branches."
</P>
<P>
"We consider what happened today as very dangerous," he said. "It was an attempt
to destroy any hope of resuming the (reconciliation) dialogue."
</P>
<P>
Abbas's power base has been limited to the occupied West Bank since Hamas ousted
his Fatah party from the Gaza Strip, which remains under a crippling Israeli
blockade.
</P>
<P>
The rival factions held five rounds of talks under Egyptian mediation in an
attempt to reconcile but to no avail, and each side frequently accuses the other
of launching campaigns of persecution.
</P>
<P>
Palestinians are pessimistic about the two sides reconciling, with 51 percent
saying that unity between Gaza and the West Bank will happen only after a long
time and 27 percent saying the split is permanent, said a poll released on
Sunday by the Palestinian Centre for Policy and Survey Research (PSR).
</P>
<P>
Rights group Amnesty International has lambasted both Hamas and Fatah for
arbitrary detentions, torture and suppression of freedom of speech in their
respective areas of control.
</P>
<P>
On May 20 the Western-backed Abbas swore in a new Palestinian cabinet that
includes members of Fatah but not Hamas, further widening the sectarian rift.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Execs urge "exit strategy" for auto takeovers
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
WASHINGTON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
With bankruptcy and a government takeover looming for auto giant General Motors,
three prominent US business leaders cautioned Sunday that the government should
get out of corporate boardrooms as quickly as possible.
</P>
<P>
"I think all of us understand the need for the government to intervene and take
the actions they did," said Anne Mulcahy, chief executive of Xerox. "But I also
think there's a need for an exit plan."
</P>
<P>
General Motors was poised to file for bankruptcy protection as early as Monday
when a deadline imposed by the administration of President Barack Obama for
submitting a viable restructuring or declare bankruptcy comes due.
</P>
<P>
A government rescue plan for GM could put as much as 72.5 percent of the
country's biggest automaker under state ownership. Chrysler already has led the
way to bankruptcy courts.
</P>
<P>
The CEOs interviewed on NBC television's Sunday talk show said GM should use the
bankruptcy courts and a government bailout to dramatically restructure, shedding
labor costs and excess capacity to emerge stronger, leaner and more competitive.
</P>
<P>
But they also expressed concern about the longer-term implications of government
control of the auto giants.
</P>
<P>
"I think that's fundamentally unhealthy," said Jim Owens, chief executive of
Caterpillar. "The federal government needs to be in and out."
</P>
<P>
"They need to help get the restructuring done. But I think, fundamentally, the
American public, I think they want to choose the best vehicle, the best car. And
American manufacturers need to be focused on competing," he said.
</P>
<P>
Google's Eric Schmidt noted that the US stimulus package was designed to cover a
two year period.
</P>
<P>
"It's very important that government get out of business and let business do its
thing," he said. "The most important thing to remember, I think, is that jobs,
wealth, are created in the private sector. That's about capitalism."
</P>
<P>
"The other thing that has to happen is you've got to change the rules so we
don't end up with all these organizations that are too big to fail again," he
said. "We've done a fine job bailing them out.  Let's only do this once per
lifetime."
</P>
<P>
He said the auto companies are going to be "highly incentivized to get all that
government money back out."
</P>
<P>
"Because the last thing you want is the government in your board room telling
you what to do," he said.
</P>
</TEXT>

</HEADLINE>

</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Cuba has agreed to resume talks with the United States on migration and direct
mail, a US official said here Sunday, as a US-Cuban thaw gathers pace under
President Barack Obama's administration.
</P>
<P>
The announcement came as Secretary of State Hillary Clinton prepared to attend

"We and the Cubans have to determine a mutually convenient place and time," he
added.
</P>
<P>
The official said the Cubans "also indicated they would like to explore areas of
additional dialogue," such as in counter-narcotics, counter-terrorism, hurricane
and disaster preparedness response.
</P>
<P>
US officials said May 23 that the Obama administration had proposed to resume
the discussions on migration issues, which had been conducted every two years
until they were suspended in 2003 by former president George W. Bush.
</P>
<P>
It was also Washington that recently proposed to resume direct mail, the
official said, adding mail has for years, if not decades, been sent between the
United States and Cuba through a third country.
</P>
<P>
The official called the moves a "very positive development and step forward" as
the Obama administration pursues engagement with Cuba, which has been under a
decades-old US embargo.
</P>
<P>
He said diplomatic notes were handed to US officials by Jorge Bolanos, the head
of the Cuban interests section in Washington.
</P>
<P>
Cuba has a longstanding interest in seeing migration dialogue progress. The
Caribbean nation of more than 11 million is bothered by embarrassing illegal
emigration by Cubans across the shark-infested Florida Straits.
</P>
<P>
Havana, the Americas' only one-party communist regime, has long argued the
United States should increase its number of standard legal immigration visas for
Cubans.
</P>
<P>
Since coming to office in January, the Obama administration has called past US
policy a failure and moved to repair ties with Cuban President Raul Castro, who
officially took over the reins from older brother Fidel last year.
</P>
<P>
In April, Obama lifted travel and money transfer restrictions on Cuban-Americans
with relatives in Cuba.
</P>
<P>
When asked if the announcement would affect the OAS meeting on Tuesday in San
Pedro Sula, the official said "it is hoped that this will be understood in the
region in a positive way."
</P>
<P>
US officials earlier declined to even rule out the possibility of Clinton's
skipping the OAS meeting altogether if negotiators fail to agree on terms for
bringing Cuba back within the 35-member organization's fold.
</P>
<P>
The United States wants Cuba to free political prisoners and respect political
freedoms for it to participate fully in the OAS, saying Havana should be held to
the democratic principles enshrined in the 2001 OAS charter.
</P>
<P>
Other OAS members say that Cuba can be nudged toward democracy once part of the
international body.
</P>
<P>
Since a popular Obama took office in January, he has raised hopes among many of
his southern neighbors that he will soon lift the controversial embargo, even if
he insists that Cuba first undertake democratic reforms.
</P>
<P>
"This is going to be a complicated challenge for her (Clinton) to deal with,"
said Michael Shifter, an analyst for the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington
think tank.
</P>
<P>
"I sense the Obama people are a little bit nervous. I think they're aware that
it's a minefield, Cuba," said Shifter.
</P>
<P>
Clinton was preparing to leave Sunday for El Salvador to attend Monday's
inauguration of Mauricio Funes, the first stop on a two-country tour.
</P>
</TEXT>

<P>

</P>
<P>

</P>

the statement.
</P>
<P>

team into the region.
</P>
<P>
"There is no running water, no electricity, and food is scarce," he added.
</P>
<P>
"There is no fuel left for generators and most medical facilities in the
district are no longer functioning.
</P>
<P>

are anxious for contact with relatives who fled the area," he added.
</P>

of the few medical facilities left in Swat, said the statement.
</P>

electricity or supplies," said O'Malley.
</P>

</P>

The Red Cross evacuated 14 patients from the hospital.
</P>

Pakistan's defence secretary said Sunday that fighting in the region could be
over in a few days.
</P>
<P>

announced late Saturday, and security officials said they were now pursuing the
top leadership of the hardline Taliban movement into the nearby mountains.

<HEADLINE>
585 Franco symbols still on Spanish public buildings: report
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Madrid, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Nearly 600 symbols of the right-wing dictatorship of General Francisco Franco
still adorn public buildings in Spain more than 30 years after his death, a
newspaper reported Sunday.
</P>
<P>
More than half of the remaining 585 symbols of the regime are on defence
ministry buildings as many military leaders are reluctant to have them removed,
said the daily newspaper Publico, citing a government report.
</P>
<P>
Under a law passed in 2007 by the governing Socialists, towns are obliged to
remove public symbols of the Franco era and rename streets named after the
dictator or the generals who fought with him in Spain's 1936-1939 civil war.
</P>
<P>
But it allows for exceptions to be made if valid artistic, historical or
religious reasons are given for a symbol to remain in place.
</P>
<P>
The government report cited by Publico was drawn up to determine which symbols
of the regime should be "removed, hidden or neutralised" and which should be
allowed to remain.
</P>
<P>
The Franco symbols that remain are mostly depictions of the coat of arms of the
regime, which include the Eagle of St John.
</P>
<P>
The last public statue of Franco still on display on mainland Spain was taken
down from a central square in the northern city of Santander in December 2008.
</P>
<P>
Franco ruled Spain with an iron fist from 1939 until his death in 1975 at the
age of 82, which paved the way for the country's return to democracy.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Danish Tiananmen sculptor denied entry to Hong Kong
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Hong Kong, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
A Danish sculptor who flew to Hong Kong to protest the bloody crackdown on pro-
democracy protests in Beijing 20 years ago has been refused entry to the city,
an official and a legislator said Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Jens Galschiot, whose sculpture commemorating those who died in the 1989
military crackdown, "Pillar of Shame," is displayed at Hong Kong University, was
stopped by officials Saturday, an immigration spokesman said.
</P>
<P>
Albert Ho, the chairman of the Democratic Party and a lawyer, said the Dane was
detained for five hours before being put on a flight to Zurich late Saturday.
</P>
<P>
Galschiot, who was also refused entry to the city ahead of the Beijing Olympics
last year, had planned to join the annual June 4 vigil to mark the anniversary
of the crackdown.
</P>
<P>
In Copenhagen, the sculptor told AFP he thought his being turned back from Hong
Kong was retaliation by China for the visit by Tibet's exiled spiritual leader
the Dalai Lama in Denmark.
</P>
<P>
"I was supposed to exhibit two bronze sculptures in Hong Kong in remembrance of
the 20th anniversary of the bloodly crackdown on protesters in Tiananmen
Square," he said.
</P>
<P>
He said he was held by police for about eight hours before being "escorted by
two dozen agents to the entrance of the plane" which took him to Copenhagen,
where he arrived Sunday morning.
</P>
<P>
He says the only reason he was given for being denied entry to Hong Kong --
although his two sons and a filmmaker with him were allowed into the former
British colony -- was "questions of immigration".
</P>
<P>
"This denying me entry without valid reasons shows that Hong Kong, which has a
particular status within China and larger freedom, obeys orders from Beijing,"
he said.
</P>
<P>
Ho, who had been allowed to see Galschiot during his detention, said: "We are
looking at the possibility of legal action following the decision."
</P>
<P>
The immigration department spokesman said it had acted in accordance with the
law.
</P>
<P>
The 20th anniversary of the crackdown on the protests -- which left hundreds,
possibly thousands, dead across the Chinese capital -- will be marked on
Thursday in Hong Kong with a candlelight vigil expected to draw tens of
thousands.
</P>
<P>
Hong Kong, which has a different legal system from the mainland, is the only
place in China where the anniversary is publicly commemorated.
