<HEADLINE>
Kuwait ruler urges end to political crises
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
KUWAIT CITY, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The Kuwaiti emir opened on Sunday the new parliament, calling on lawmakers to
end political turmoil that has rocked the oil-rich Gulf state and focus on
economic development.
</P>
<P>
"We must overcome this phase with all its ramifications and open a new page to
build the nation," the emir, Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah, told the new
parliament which was elected on May 16 in snap polls.
</P>
<P>
The election, the third in the past three years, was called after the emir
dissolved the previous parliament following a standoff between MPs and the
government.
</P>
<P>
Sheikh Sabah said that the cornerstone for forging ahead with stalled
development programmes is through a strong cooperation between the government
and the legislature.
</P>
<P>
Four women made history when they won seats for the first time in the 50-member
parliament, while the election saw the Sunni Islamists reduced to a minority.
</P>
<P>
Three Islamist MPs raised objections when two female MPs and a minister showed
up at the inaugural session without the hijab, or head cover, accusing them of
violating the election law that requires women to abide by Islamic law.
</P>
<P>
Prime Minister Sheikh Nasser Mohammad al-Ahmad al-Sabah, a nephew of the emir,
said his government wants to cooperate with the new parliament to get the
country back on development track.
</P>
<P>
But even before new MPs and ministers took the oath, 14 lawmakers walked out of
the session in protest against the government's failure to submit its programme
and a delayed five-year development plan.
</P>
<P>
Deputy premier for economic affairs Sheikh Ahmad Fahad al-Sabah later told
reporters that the government will submit the main guidelines of the five-year
plan next month.
</P>
<P>
He also said the government will push for the approval of several economic bills
including a privatisation draft law that has been in parliament since 1992.
</P>
<P>
Wealthy businessman Jassem al-Khorafi was unanimously elected speaker for a
record fifth consecutive time.
</P>
<P>
The new parliament is due to vote next week on a multi-billion dollar economic
stimulus bill which was issued by the previous government when parliament was
dissolved.
</P>
<P>
Several MPs have vowed to vote against the legislation, charging that public
money was being used to bailout rich people only, ignoring the poor.
</P>
<P>
A group of MPs submitted a draft law calling on the state to purchase billions
of dollars of consumer loans for citizens and then reschedule them without
interest.
</P>
<P>
Parliament also formed a special committee entrusted to resolve the issue of
over 100,000 bidoons, or stateless Arabs, who are living in the emirate but are
deprived of their basic rights like education and work.
</P>
<P>
Kuwait, which says it sits on 10 percent of global crude reserves, pumps about
2.2 million barrels of oil daily. It has 1.1 million of native population
besides 2.35 of foreign residents.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
London's Big Ben ticks over to 150th anniversary
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Big Ben, arguably the world's most famous clock which towers over London, marked
its 150th anniversary Sunday.
</P>
<P>
The clock started ticking on May 31 1859 and has continued with only occasional
interruptions for maintenance, bad weather and even bird strikes ever since.
</P>
<P>
The clock, housed in St Stephen's Tower which adjoins Britain's House of
Commons, is one of the capital's most popular tourist attractions and boasts
some amazing statistics.
</P>
<P>
Each of the four Gothic clock faces is seven metres wide, with a minute hand
over four metres long which travels the equivalent of 190 kilometres per year.
</P>
<P>
A Latin inscription is carved beneath each one -- "Domine salvam fac Reginam
nostrum Victoriam primam" which means: "O Lord, save our Queen Victoria the
First." Queen Victoria was on the throne in Britain at the time.
</P>
<P>
The 96 metre-high tower which houses the clock was built as part of the
rebuilding of the Houses of Parliament by architects Charles Barry and Augustus
Pugin following a major fire in 1843.
</P>
<P>
A competition was opened in 1846 to decide who should build the clock, but it
took seven years to decide a winner.
</P>
<P>
Eventually, the winner was named as Edward Dent, who had already made a
chronometer for the HMS Beagle, the ship which carried Charles Darwin on a
worldwide voyage which led him to the theory of evolution.
</P>
<P>
The clock cost 2,500 pounds to build and was completed in 1854 but it was not
installed until the clock tower was finished five years later.
</P>
<P>
Even then, there was a last-minute hitch -- the original cast-iron minute hands
were too heavy and had to be replaced with copper ones.
</P>
<P>
The famous bell chimes -- which are used at the start of many television and
radio news bulletins in Britain -- did not sound for another six weeks
afterwards.
</P>
<P>
The name Big Ben originally referred to the bell in the clocktower, but has come
to be used for the tower and the clock as well.
</P>
<P>
It is not entirely clear where the name Big Ben comes from -- some say refers to
Sir Benjamin Hall, an MP at the time, while others claim it was after
heavyweight boxer Benjamin Caunt.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Football: Massoud is hero and villain as holders Sfaxien crash
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
JOHANNESBURG, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Amir Massoud was the hero and villain as African Confederation Cup holders CS
Sfaxien of Tunisia made a shock fourth round exit this weekend despite a 2-0 win
over Primeiro Agosto of Angola.
</P>
<P>
The club from the Mediterranean town of Sfax entered the second leg at home
needing to wipe out a 2-0 deficit from the first encounter against the military
club in Luanda two weeks ago.
</P>
<P>
Sfaxien laid siege to the Angolan goalmouth from the kick-off at the 20,000-seat
Tayeb Mhiri Stadium as they sought to clear the final qualifying hurdle and
continue to challenge for a third consecutive title.
</P>
<P>
Primeiro had numerous narrow escapes before finally cracking on the stroke of
half-time when they conceded a penalty that experienced African campaigner Issam
Merdassi converted.
</P>
<P>
Sfaxien continued to squander chances in the second half in pursuit of a
aggregate-levelling second goal before Massoud rescued an increasingly desperate
situation by scoring direct from an 84th-minute free kick.
</P>
<P>
A 2-0 win for the home team meant a shoot-out with five mandatory kicks each and
all were converted except that taken by Massoud, giving the visitors a 5-4
victory on penalties.
</P>
<P>
The exit of Sfaxien means the holders of both African Football Confederation
(CAF) competitions failed to defend their title with Champions League holders
Al-Ahly of Egypt eliminated by international rookies Kano Pillars of Nigeria.
</P>
<P>
Also through to the group phase of the second-tier African Confederation Cup are
Stade Malien, the first Malian club to reach this stage of a competition that
replaced the African Cup Winners Cup and CAF Cup five years ago.
</P>
<P>
Boosted by a first-minute goal, Malien defeated Al-Ittihad Khemisset of Morocco
3-1 in Bamako having drawn the first leg and qualified 4-2 on aggregate.
</P>
<P>
Abdoulaye Sidibe put Stade ahead with his first goal of a competition modelled
on the European UEFA Cup, staged for the last time this season and won by
Ukrainian side Shakhtar Donetsk.
</P>
<P>
Adama Toure scored either side of half-time in the Malian capital to put Stade
in a commanding position before Rahhal al-Khaddouri snatched a late consolation
goal for the Moroccans.
</P>
<P>
The other six second leg fixtures will be staged later Sunday with title
favourites Al-Ahly defending a 3-0 advantage over African debutants Santos of
Angola in Luanda.
</P>
<P>
Portuguese coach Manuel Jose will be making his final appearance as Ahly coach
after leading the Cairo 'Red Devils' to 21 domestic and international titles in
two spells at a club that claims 40 million supporters.
</P>
<P>
He takes over 2010 African Nations Cup hosts Angola next month, charged with
transforming a struggling national team into one capable of winning the biennial
showcase of football on the continent.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Iraq's Kurdish region to export oil for first time
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
DOHUK, Iraq, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Iraq's self-ruled Kurdish region will begin exporting crude oil for the first
time on June 1, piping up to 90,000 bpd to its neighbours in a landmark step for
the area, officials said on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Companies chosen by the regional government will pump oil from two Kurdish
fields via an Iraqi pipeline to Turkey with the consent of Baghdad in a step
that could pave the way to ending bitter domestic feuds over Iraq's oil wealth.
</P>
<P>
Initial exports will be around 40,000 barrels per day from the Taq Taq field in
the province of Arbil and another 50,000 bpd from the Tawke field in Dohuk,
company officials told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"Piping of the oil will start Monday morning from the Taq Taq field, pumping it
from seven wells," said Mohammed Okotan, director of the Taq Taq project for
Turkey's Genel Enerji, which is partnered with Calgary-based Addax Petroleum.
</P>
<P>
"We will try to reach 60,000 barrels a day by the end of this year," said
Okotan, adding that the project aims to double exports in two years.
</P>
<P>
"The quality of the crude is excellent," he said.
</P>
<P>
At the Tawke field, northwest of Taq Taq, Norwegian oil firm DNO will also start
pumping oil for export on Monday.
</P>
<P>
"We'll start with 50,000 bpd and we'll see how this operation goes and if we can
increase it," said DNO director of operations Jon Sargent.
</P>
<P>
Exports from Tawke will link with the Iraq-Turkey main export pipeline at the
border town of Fishkhabur, while crude from Taq Taq will be trucked from the
capital Arbil before connecting with the Iraq-Turkey export pipeline.
</P>
<P>
Regional president Massud Barzani will preside over an official ceremony on
Monday.
</P>
<P>
Disagreements over oil rights, especially between Baghdad and the Kurdish
government, have held up exploitation of much of Iraq's massive reserves as well
as long-delayed hydrocarbons legislation.
</P>
<P>
Terms of the Taq Taq deal are for Baghdad to receive 88 percent of revenues of
which the Kurd region will get back 17 percent. Genel Enerji and Addax will
share 12 percent, Okotan told reporters.
</P>
<P>
Executives from DNO refused to provide revenue sharing figures, although one DNO
official confided that the terms are quite similar to those in the Taq Taq
field.
</P>
<P>
Baghdad has repeatedly said that it is opposed to Arbil signing its own
contracts, a position which Kurdish officials have thumbed their nose at by
signings dozens of agreements with foreign firms.
</P>
<P>
Earlier this month Kurd officials announced an eight billion dollar plan to
develop Kurdish gas fields with four European and two United Arab Emirates
partners that could later supply the EU's flagship Nabucco pipeline.
</P>
<P>
Oil minister Hussein al-Shahristani responded by calling the deal illegal,
although he has come under heavy criticism for failing to lift the nation's
anaemic oil and gas output as crude prices have plunged.
</P>
<P>
Iraq is in dire need of revenue to rebuild its shattered economy, especially
after oil prices tumbled a peak of 147 dollars a barrel last July to a current
level just above 60 dollars, putting huge pressure on Iraq's budget.
</P>
<P>
The nation derives more than 90 percent of its revenues from the energy sector.
</P>
<P>
Iraq wants pump six million barrels per day, up from its current stated output
of around 2.2 million, within the next four to five years as new projects come
online.
</P>
<P>
The conflict-ravaged country has the world's third largest proven reserves of
oil, with more than 115 billion barrels, behind only Saudi Arabia and Iran.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Breakaway South Ossetia votes for parliament
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
TSKHINVALI, Georgia, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The rebel Georgian region of South Ossetia voted Sunday in polls expected to
secure the grip of its separatist leader nine months after it was the subject of
war between Russia and Georgia.
</P>
<P>
The local opposition says Eduard Kokoity is seeking to use the elections to
forge a loyal parliamentary majority to push through an amendment allowing him
to run again for office when his second term lapses in 2011.
</P>
<P>
Officials estimated the voter turnout at over 70 percent by 4:00 pm (1300 GMT).
According to law, the vote is deemed valid if the voter turnout reached 50
percent plus one vote.
</P>
<P>
Voting was due to end at 1600 GMT, with the first results expected two hours
later.
</P>
<P>
Russia -- which outraged the West by recognising South Ossetia as independent in
the wake of the August war with Georgia --- has said South Ossetia should not
amend the existing term limits in its constitution.
</P>
<P>
Kokoity said, however, it was too early to say whether he planned to run again,
although he did not rule out that possibility.
</P>
<P>
"There are two and half years left till then and a lot left to do. We are
working and working now. I am not thinking about it yet," he said in an
interview with AFP.
</P>
<P>
"With what happened in August we need three to four years to rebuild," Kokoity
said.
</P>
<P>
Four parties are competing for the 34 seats in the parliament, but the central
election commission has barred the only two parties not loyal to Kokoity.
</P>
<P>
Opposition activities said voting would not make a difference. "I plan to sit at
home. There's nothing we can do," said Alan Gassiyev, an opposition leader,
calling the polls "completely illegal."
</P>
<P>
Critics accuse Kokoity, an ex-wrestling champion, of muzzling opponents and
stealing the money sent from Russia.
</P>
<P>
As the reconstruction in the province stalled this winter, the opposition also
accuses the separatist leader and his circle of diverting lorries carrying
construction material and humanitarian aid to traffic the goods in Russia.
</P>
<P>
But despite the slow pace of reconstruction in the republic many praise Kokoity
for his leadership during the August conflict.
</P>
<P>
"Kokoity has done a lot for the people of South Ossetia, he's fought 20 years
for this country," Angela Tedeyeva, a 32-year-old kindergarden teacher, said as
she cast her ballot.
</P>
<P>
"If people are happy with him, they will vote for him again," she said.
</P>
<P>
Georgia ridiculed the vote, with the country's reintegration minister Temur
Iakobashvili saying the elections were "nothing but clownery, a farce and a
redistribution of a criminal power."
</P>
<P>
Kokoity insists the elections were in strict accordance with law, saying the
polls were "a maturity test for the small independent state."
</P>
<P>
He said the large number of voters at the polling stations was proof that the
vote was deemed "genuine" by people.
</P>
<P>
Eighty-eight polling stations have been set up for the region's 50,000 residents
as well as additional sites in Russia for expatriates and refugees from the
fighting.
</P>
<P>
Kokoity's critics are concerned that the high number of polling stations placed
in the villages which were used to be populated by ethnic Georgians and which
are now nearly empty will be used to falsify the election results.
</P>
<P>
Kokoity -- who built connections in Moscow working as a trade official for the
rebel region when it was known as a highway for smuggling in the early 1990s --
has rejected accusations against him as Georgian propaganda.
</P>
<P>
But as the looming political scandal in the region threatens to become an
embarrassment for Moscow, there are signs that the Kremlin is scaling back its
support for the South Ossetian leader.
</P>
<P>
Sergey Naryshkin, the head of the Russian presidential administration, said on
Russian television this month that South Ossetia should not mend the existing
term limits in its constitution.
</P>
<P>
Moscow and Tbilisi fought a brief but intense war last August over the region,
which had enjoyed de facto independence since the early 1990s thanks to tacit
Russian support.
</P>
<P>
Following the conflict Russia formally recognised the region as independent, a
move followed only by Nicaragua.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Troops hunt Taliban as Pakistan says victory near
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
PESHAWAR, Pakistan, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Pakistan's defence secretary said Sunday that a month-long offensive to crush
Taliban fighters in northwest Swat could end within days, as fierce fighting
spilled into a nearby tribal area.
</P>
<P>
Swat valley's main town Mingora is back in government hands, the military
announced late Saturday, and security officials said they were pursuing the
leadership of the hardline Taliban movement into the nearby mountains.
</P>
<P>
Secretary of Defence Syed Athar Ali told a security forum in Singapore that
three targeted northwest districts were almost clear of Taliban rebels.
</P>
<P>
"Operations in Swat, Buner and adjoining areas have almost met complete
success," he said.
</P>
<P>
"Only five to ten percent of the job is remaining and hopefully within the next
two to three days these pockets of resistance will be cleared."
</P>
<P>
However, chief military spokesman Major General Athar Abbas told AFP that it was
impossible to estimate when the offensive would end.
</P>
<P>
"The operation is continuing in all of the areas and at this stage we cannot
give any timeframe," he said.
</P>
<P>
The army remains locked in battle in some areas, but the fall of Mingora was a
critical milestone in an offensive launched after the Taliban thrust to within
100 kilometres (60 miles) of Islamabad in April.
</P>
<P>
Pakistan's military also reported that 25 militants and seven soldiers were
killed in clashes in South Waziristan near the Afghan border, a bolt-hole for
Taliban and Al-Qaeda-linked militants south of the current army bombardment.
</P>
<P>
"Miscreants attacked a security forces checkpost last night (Saturday) in
Spinkai Raghzai, South Waziristan agency. The attack was repulsed successfully,
inflicting heavy casualties on militants," it said in a statement.
</P>
<P>
Fifteen militants and three soldiers died in the clash in Spinkai Raghzai, while
elsewhere, in the semi-autonomous tribal area 10, insurgents and four troops
including a lieutenant died when rebels attacked a military convoy.
</P>
<P>
Civilians have started fleeing the area fearing a fresh military onslaught, but
the army has denied an imminent assault on Waziristan, where militants branded
by Washington as the greatest terror threat to the West are holed up.
</P>
<P>
The United States, which is firmly backing the current military drive, had
warned that the rebels threatened Pakistan's very existence.
</P>
<P>
Officials have said that lower-ranking Taliban leaders had been killed but it
was harder to get to the top leaders, who had a network of hardcore militants
around them and had slipped into the rugged mountain terrain.
</P>
<P>
"They will be eliminated wherever we find them," said one military official, who
did not wish to be named as he was not authorised to speak to the media."We
believe that they are somewhere in the mountains," he added.
</P>
<P>
Pakistan has slapped a 600,000-dollar price on the head of firebrand Swat
Taliban commander Maulana Fazlullah for masterminding the nearly two-year
uprising in the valley to enforce sharia law.
</P>
<P>
The government has also offered rewards for 21 rebel chiefs -- wanted dead or
alive -- from Swat. The military claims to have killed 1,244 militants since the
offensive began, although the numbers are impossible to verify.
</P>
<P>
As the government steps up its campaign to stamp out the militants, fears are
growing of a wave of revenge attacks.
</P>
<P>
The northwestern capital Peshawar and the eastern cultural centre of Lahore have
both been rocked by deadly explosions in the last five days, killing a total of
39 people and wounding hundreds more.
</P>
<P>
A spokesman for Pakistan Taliban chief Baitullah Mehsud has claimed Wednesday's
suicide bombing on a police building in Lahore, and warned of more "massive
attacks" to avenge the Swat military operation.
</P>
<P>
Nearly 2.4 million people have fled the current offensive, and the military
relaxed a curfew Sunday in most parts of the northwest including Mingora to
allow people trapped on the roads to return home or leave the region.
</P>
<P>
Senior Red Cross officials said Sunday they were "gravely concerned" over the
situation in Swat Valley.
</P>
<P>
"The people of Swat need greater humanitarian protection and assistance
immediately," said Pascal Cuttat, head of the organization's delegation in
Pakistan, in a statement.
</P>
<P>
Also Sunday, Taliban militants attacked a school in Hangu town south of
Peshawar, killing one administrator and kidnapping three other people, local
policeman Shoukat Hussain said.
</P>
<P>
And in North Waziristan, suspected militants killed a former government doctor
and an Afghan national, officials said.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Activists rally in Singapore to demand Aung San Suu Kyi release
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Singapore, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
More than 100 people rallied in Singapore late Sunday as part of a regional
effort by civil rights groups to press Myanmar's military rulers to release
democracy icon Aung San Suu Kyi.
</P>
<P>
The yellow-clad demonstrators observed a minute of silence and released yellow
balloons bearing good wishes for the pro-democracy leader during their gathering
at a park designated as Singapore's free-speech corner.
</P>
<P>
Similar rallies were also held simultaneously in Indonesia, the Philippines,
Malaysia, Cambodia and Thailand, organisers said.
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi has spent 13 of the last 19 years in detention, mostly at her
crumbling lakeside mansion after the junta refused to honour elections won by
her political party in 1990.
</P>
<P>
The Nobel Peace Prize winner was moved to Yangon's notorious Insein prison and
charged on May 14 for allegedly breaching the terms of her house arrest after
John Yettaw, 53-year-old Mormon and former US military veteran, swam to her home
and stayed there for two nights.
</P>
<P>
On Sunday, Myanmar's deputy defence minister Major General Aye Myint told a
regional security forum in Singapore that Aung San Suu Kyi had "covered up" the
truth by failing to report Yettaw’s visit.
</P>
<P>
Braema Mathi, one of the organisers of the rally, slammed the Myanmar official's
comments.
</P>
<P>
"It’s devastating that they are alluding to this collusion between her and
Yettaw. They need to look at their own security lapses," Mathi told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"It is my hope that this event will be the beginning of concerted efforts by the
people of ASEAN to write to their governments and lobby for her release," she
said, referring to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
</P>
<P>
Wunna, a Myanmar citizen working in Singapore, said the Myanmar junta was
"trying to find an excuse" to continue detaining Aung San Suu Kyi.
</P>
<P>
"I don’t see any legal basis in the accusations. It is a sham," said Wunna,
who was at the demonstration but would not give her full name because of fear of
reprisals by the Myanmar government.
</P>
<P>
Singapore allows protests without a permit at the specially designated
Speakers' Corner, otherwise other unauthorised political gatherings are banned.

<HEADLINE>
Israel fumes over US settlement demands
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Jerusalem, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Israel refused on Sunday to bow to US calls for a freeze of all settlement
activity in the occupied West Bank, as it fumed over the "unfair" demands that
have raised tensions between the key allies.
</P>
<P>
"I want to say in a crystal clear manner that the current Israeli government
will not accept in any fashion that legal settlement activity be frozen," said
Transport Minister Yisrael Katz, a close ally of Prime Minister Benjamin
Netanyahu.
</P>
<P>
The premier also held firm on Israel's controversial blockade of Hamas-run Gaza
Strip, warning that the Islamists were rearming and that the ceasefire that
ended a 22-day war on January 18 remained very fragile.
</P>
<P>
Netanyahu did not himself address the settlements issue during the weekly
cabinet meeting, but Katz's fighting words were echoed by other members of the
largely right-wing cabinet, including from its most liberal party, Labour.
</P>
<P>
A senior Israeli official complained that Washington under President Barack
Obama -- who has vowed to pursue Middle East peace talks as part of a changed
approach to the region -- was placing unfair demands on the Jewish state.
</P>
<P>
"The Americans have demanded almost nothing from the Palestinians but are asking
Israel to take steps that are a real sacrifice. These demands are unfair," he
told AFP on condition of anonymity.
</P>
<P>
"The Palestinians are taking a passive approach. They're not even ready to meet
the Israeli side and Abu Mazen (Palestinian president Mahmud Abbas) wants the
Americans to do all the work," he said.
</P>
<P>
Abbas, who met Obama last week 10 days after the US president met Netanyahu, has
vowed that that he will not resume talks unless Israel freezes settlements in
the occupied West Bank.
</P>
<P>
The Obama administration has demanded that Israel stop all its activity in the
settlements, including so-called natural growth construction that allows for
building to accommodate a rising population.
</P>
<P>
The unusually blunt talk over one of the top stumbling points in the stalled
Middle East peace process has raised alarm bells that the new US president could
put pressure on Israel as part of his new approach to the Muslim world.
</P>
<P>
"This is an unjustifiable demand that the government and the public do not
accept," said Interior Minister Eli Yishai of the ultra-Orthodox Shas party.
</P>
<P>
Social Affairs Minister Isaac Herzog of the centre-left Labour party, the most
liberal in Netanyahu's government, said that "one has to understand that there
are various statuses within the settlements" and "saying that the picture is
black and white or write or wrong is wrong."
</P>
<P>
More than 280,000 Israelis live in settlements dotted throughout the West Bank,
which Israel captured in the 1967 war.
</P>
<P>
Although the international community considers all settlements to be illegal,
Israel makes a distinction between those built with the state's blessing and
outposts constructed without authorisation.
</P>
<P>
Netanyahu has said he would dismantle outposts, but that it made "no sense" to
ask for a complete freeze of construction.
</P>
<P>
Israeli officials have also complained that Obama's administration has yet to
say it will honour commitments in a letter that then US president George W. Bush
sent to then Israeli premier Ariel Sharon in 2004.
</P>
<P>
Bush said that given the existence of major settlement blocs in the West Bank it
was "unrealistic" to expect Israel to fully withdraw from the territory as part
of a final peace deal.
</P>
<P>
Aside from the settlements, there is stark disagreement between Washington and
Israel over creating a Palestinian state, with Obama repeatedly saying he was
committed to the principle and Netanyahu so far refusing to endorse it in
public.
</P>
<P>
Obama is due in Saudi Arabia and Egypt this week in a bid to reach out to
Muslims and end the deep mistrust of the United States felt across much of the
Islamic world.
</P>
<P>
Netanyahu on Sunday also held firm on maintaining the blockade of Gaza, saying
that "we do not want to strengthen Hamas" by allowing the Islamist group to
rebuild its defences.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Israeli FM to Russia, Belarus
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Jerusalem, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Israeli Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman leaves for his first official visits
to Russia and Belarus on Monday to discuss Iran and bilateral issues, his
ministry said in a statement.
</P>
<P>
In Moscow, Lieberman, a Russian-speaking Soviet emigrant, will meet Russian
President Dmitry Medvedev, Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, counterpart Sergei
Lavrov and heads of the Jewish community.
</P>
<P>
He will discuss "political developments and regional threats with his hosts" as
well as bilateral relations, said the statement.
</P>
<P>
Topping the agenda for the visit is the issue of Iran's controversial nuclear
programme, a "severe geopolitical threat to Israel and the entire region," it
said.
</P>
<P>
Russia is helping build the first nuclear reactor in the Islamic Republic, which
Israel considers its arch-enemy after repeated statements by President Mahmoud
Ahmadinejad calling for the Jewish state to be "wiped off the map."
</P>
<P>
Widely considered to be the Middle East's sole if undeclared nuclear power,
Israel along with main ally Washington suspects Iran of trying to develop atomic
weapons under the guise of a civilian nuclear programme, a charge Tehran has
repeatedly denied.
</P>
<P>
Moscow is seeking a greater role in the Middle East and a Russian foreign
ministry spokesman said on Friday that Russia hopes Lieberman's visit will boost
the country's hopes of hosting a Middle East peace conference this year.
</P>
<P>
The statement from Lieberman's ministry made no mention of the conference idea
but Israel has so far been unenthusiastic.
</P>
<P>
Israel is unhappy about Russia's contacts with the Islamist Hamas movement
ruling the Gaza Strip, an Iranian-backed group pledged to the destruction of the
Jewish state.
</P>
<P>
Russia is the only member of the Quartet -- the European Union, the United
Nations and the United States -- to be formally on speaking terms with Hamas,
classified as a terrorist group by the EU, Israel and the US.
</P>
<P>
During his trip to Damascus a week ago, Lavrov met with Hamas supremo Khaled
Meshaal, telling the Vesti-24 channel later that "we felt a more realistic
assessment of the situation" following the talks with the exiled leader.
</P>
<P>
Lavrov also reiterated that Moscow wanted to see Israel lift a blockade it
slapped on Gaza after Hamas assumed power there in June 2007, saying "we hope
that we can push toward its removal in the foreseeable future."
</P>
<P>
At the time, Israel said it was said it was "deeply disappointed" by the
meeting.
</P>
<P>
Following his stay in Russia, Lieberman will travel to Belarus where he will
meet President Alexander Lukashenko and Foreign Minister Sergei Martynov on
Thursday in Minsk.
</P>
<P>
It will mark Lieberman's first trip to Russia or Belarus since he was sworn in
as foreign minister along with the rest of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's
largely right-wing government on March 31.
</P>
<P>
Lieberman emigrated from Soviet Moldova to Israel in 1978.
</P>

<TEXT>
<P>
Andy Murray reached his first French Open quarter-final on Sunday where he will

</P>
<P>
Third seed Murray became only the third British man in the Open era to reach the
last eight here with a convincing 7-5, 7-6 (7/4), 6-1 win over Croatia's Marin
Cilic.
</P>
<P>
The ever-improving 22-year-old, with former two-time Roland Garros finalist Alex

condition with a series of long, punishing rallies eventually telling on the
13th seeded Cilic, the youngest man left in the draw.
</P>
<P>

any player in the last 16, was wilting by the time he slipped 0-3 down in the
third set.
</P>
<P>
He needed treatment on his left leg after falling awkwardly before Murray went
on to secure a convincing victory in the seventh game.
</P>
<P>
Chilean 13th seed Gonzalez revealed how an injury signing autographs almost
shattered his French Open dreams.
</P>
<P>
The 28-year-old, who outgunned Romania's Victor Hanescu 6-2, 6-4, 6-2 to reach
the Roland Garros quarter-finals for the third time, injured his ankle while
signing photos and tennis balls for fans at the Rome Masters in April.
</P>
<P>
As a result, he spent a month on the sidelines.
</P>
<P>
"I was signing autographs and someone called me from the other side of the court
and when I ran over to them, I twisted my ankle," said Gonzalez.
</P>
<P>

because my ankle was so painful."
</P>
<P>
The freak accident meant Gonzalez had to skip the rest of the claycourt season
to recover in time for the French Open.
</P>
<P>
But despite the Rome scare, he believes he is now playing some of the best
tennis of his 10-year career.
</P>
<P>

finished off by his injury.

courts and into practice although as I am getting older I tend to practice less
but with more intensity."

</P>
<P>

<P>

a Vatican spokesman said at the time.
</P>
<P>
Obama and the leader of the Roman Catholic Church spoke by telephone several
days after the US election.
</P>

abortion and is in favour of recognising civil unions for homosexuals -- both
positions strongly opposed by the Vatican.

<HEADLINE>
Rights group slams Niger's 'institutional coup'
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LAGOS, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
African rights campaigners on Sunday condemned Niger's president Mamadou Tandja
over his planned referendum on whether to extending his legal term of office,
describing it as "an institutional coup".
</P>
<P>
The international community should put pressure on the president and if
necessary apply sanctions, said Alioune Tine, head of African Defence for Human
Rights (RADDHO) in comments broadcast on Radio France Internationale.
</P>
<P>
"In fact this is an institutional coup," said Tine. "This is the start of a new
chapter of political instability in Niger," he added.
</P>
<P>
"The international community needs to react, as in all coups, initially by
negotiating," said Tine.
</P>
<P>
"And if he (Tandja) does not accept, sanctions need to be imposed."
</P>
<P>
In a broadcast address to the nation on Friday night, Tandja, 71, said he
planned to go ahead with a referendum on a new constitution enabling him to stay
in power after the normal end of his second five-year term.
</P>
<P>
He spoke only days after the country's highest court, the Constitutional Court,
ruled against such a referendum on Monday.
</P>
<P>
Article 49 of the current constitution, which authorises the president to call a
referendum on certain issues, could not serve as a basis for changing the
constitution, it said in its ruling.
</P>
<P>
The day after the court's ruling Tandja dissolved parliament.
</P>
<P>
Tandja, whose tenure should end 22 December, gave no date for the referendum.
</P>
<P>
Washingon expressed its concern on Saturday, a statement from the State
Department warning that it could be "a setback for democracy".
</P>
<P>
Canada also asked the Niger authorities to "respect the spirit and the letter"
of its constitution.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Over 40 injured in protests over Kashmiri women's deaths
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Srinagar, India, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
More than 40 people have been wounded in two days of clashes between Indian
police and Kashmiris demonstrating over the recent deaths of two young Muslim
women, police said Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Police said they have launched an investigation into the "mystery deaths" of the
women, aged 17 and 22. Their families have accused Indian security forces of
abducting, raping and subsequently killing them.
</P>
<P>
Angry demonstrators on Sunday hurled stones at riot police and paramilitary
forces, who retaliated by firing teargas shells and charging at them with
batons.
</P>
<P>
"Over 40 people, including several policemen, have been wounded in two days of
clashes between police and protesters," a Muslim police officer said, requesting
not to be named.
</P>
<P>
Protesters ransacked a government hospital and a number of other government
buildings after the bodies of the women, who were related, were found on
Saturday.
</P>
<P>
They were fished out from a shallow stream in Shopian town about 50 kilometres
(31 miles) south of the summer capital Srinagar.
</P>
<P>
Their families said the bodies had marks of violence and their clothes were
torn.
</P>
<P>
An autopsy report will be available on Monday, a police statement said.
</P>
<P>
Indian security forces battling militancy in Kashmir have frequently been
accused of committing human rights violations in the scenic Himalayan region.
Officials say they investigate all the cases and punish those found guilty.
</P>
<P>
Kashmir is in the grip of a nearly 20-year insurgency against Indian rule that
has so far left more than 47,000 people dead by official count.
</P>
<P>
However, violence has dropped sharply since India and Pakistan started a peace
process in January 2004 to resolve pending disputes, including Kashmir, which is
divided between the two countries but claimed in full by both.
</P>
<P>
Senior Kashmir minister Ali Sagar said those involved in the two women's
killings will be "given exemplary punishment."
</P>
<P>
A hardline separatist Syed Ali Geelani has called for a one-day token strike on
Monday to mourn and protest the deaths, a press release said.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile, a policeman and an Indian trooper were killed by militants in two
separate strikes in northern Kashmir's Baramulla district on Sunday, a police
statement said.
</P>
<P>
Rebels also made an unsuccessful attempt on the life of a lesser-known pro-India
leader, Feroz Malik, the police said, without giving further details.
</P>
<P>

</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
WASHINGTON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Cuba has agreed to resume talks with the United States on migration and direct
mail, a US official said here Sunday, as tense ties continue to thaw under
President Barack Obama's administration.
</P>
<P>
The announcement came as US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton prepared to
travel to the Organization of American States general assembly in Honduras,
where Washington and its southern neighbors are caught in a row over the pace of
normalization with Cuba.
</P>
<P>
The Cuban government informed Washington on Saturday that it "would like to
resume migration talks.... (and) engage in talks on direct mail service," the
senior State Department official told reporters on the condition of anonymity.
</P>
<P>
But he said the two governments still have to decide on a time and place.
</P>
<P>
US officials said May 23 that the Obama administration had proposed to resume
the discussions on the thorny issue, which had been conducted every two years
until they were suspended in 2003 by former president George W. Bush.
</P>
<P>
The official called the moves a "very positive development and step forward" as
the Obama administration pursues engagement with Cuba, which has been under a
decades-old US embargo.
</P>
<P>
The official said the Cubans "also indicated they would like to explore areas of
additional dialogue," such as in the area of counternarcotics, counter
terrorism, hurricane and disaster preparedness response.

<HEADLINE>
Tennis: Murray reaches French Open quarter-finals
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Andy Murray became only the third British man in the Open era to reach the
quarter-finals of Roland Garros on Sunday with a 7-5, 7-6 (7/4), 6-1 win over
Croatia's Marin Cilic.
</P>
<P>
The third-seeded Briton will now tackle three-time quarter-finalist Fernando
Gonzalez, the Chilean 12th seed, for a place in the semi-finals.
</P>
<P>
Ever-improving Murray, 22, has now won four successive matches on clay for the
first time in his career and he looked impressive on Sunday with his physical
fitness proving crucial in a tie of long, punishing rallies.
</P>
<P>
He broke Cilic, whom he had beaten twice in their two previous meetings, in the
opening game and although the tall Croatian hit back immediately, Murray nipped
ahead again in the 11th game on his way to taking the opener 7-5.
</P>
<P>
Breaks were traded again in the seventh and eighth games of the second before
Murray's greater experience told in the tiebreak.
</P>
<P>
Murray was soon a break to the good in the third set against the 20-year-old
Cilic, the youngest player left in the men's draw, whose miserable afternoon got
worse when he needed treatment to his left leg at 0-3 after falling awkwardly.
</P>
<P>
The Scotsman, with a claycourt game honed by the help of former two-time French
Open runner-up Alex Corretja, was soon 4-0 ahead over the wilting Croatian.
</P>
<P>
Cilic, who came into the fourth round having lost the fewest number of games of
any player in the last 16, pulled one break back, surrendered it to trail 1-5
before Murray secured a convincing victory in the seventh game.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Europe's desperate bid to bring out voters
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
brussels, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
European leaders on Sunday stepped up a desperate battle to persuade people to
vote for the EU parliament this week, but the campaign has opened up new
political divisions across the continent.
</P>
<P>
With polls indicating a record low turnout for the June 4-7 election, French
President Nicolas Sarkozy and German Chancellor Angela Merkel issued a joint
plea to voters, saying a strong parliament was essential to confront the
economic crisis.
</P>
<P>
The two leaders said they want "a strong Europe that protects" its people and
called for "all Europeans to vote" in the statement, published by the Journal du
Dimanche newspaper in France and Die Welt am Sonntag in Germany.
</P>
<P>
A "strong Europe does not necessarily mean more powers for the European Union,
even more European legislation or even more financial means," said Merkel and
Sarkozy.
</P>
<P>
First steps "to assure real European regulation in the financial sector, based
on coordination and cooperation between regulators" should be taken at the next
EU summit in June, they said.
</P>
<P>
"For speculative funds, tax havens, payment for executives and financial
traders, we want an exemplary Europe," they added.
</P>
<P>
The pair also gave strong backing to the Lisbon reform treaty, intended to
streamline EU decision-making but deadlocked by Ireland's rejection in a
referendum last year.
</P>
<P>
"Europe must play a leading role in the world. For that, it must have efficient
institutions. That is why we need the Lisbon Treaty," they said.
</P>
<P>
Merkel and Sarkozy also reaffirmed opposition to Turkey joining the EU, without
naming the country. "To be able to act, the EU needs frontiers. Unlimited
enlargement is not possible."
</P>
<P>
The joint statement highlighted fears that the vote for the 736 member European
assembly could prove a new embarrassment for the 27-nation European Union, after
a record 45 percent abstention at the last election in 2004.
</P>
<P>
In France, a poll for the Le Parisien newspaper Sunday suggested that 55 percent
of the nation's would not bother going to the polls. In Britain, Poland and
Romania, fewer than one in three plan to vote, according to recent surveys.
</P>
<P>
In Spain, which has benefited enormously from EU development funds, political
analysts expect turnout of 40 percent at best. Portugal expects a record
abstention rate.
</P>
<P>
The stakes are higher now, however, as the European Parliament -- the only
directly elected EU institution -- will have a bigger voice in decisions that
affect 500 million Europeans if the Lisbon treaty comes into force.
</P>
<P>
"A lot of voters don't understand what the European Parliament does," said
Philip White, senior research fellow at the Centre for European Reform think-
tank in London.
</P>
<P>
"You're not voting to keep a government in office or kick it out. The stakes can
seem a little bit less clear than they are in national elections."
</P>
<P>
But in many countries the EU vote will be a test of the national governments in
power, with far-right and left-wing parties expected to benefit from protest
votes and low turnouts in some member states.
</P>
<P>
In Britain, where euroscepticism runs deep, the governing Labour Party is
expected to garner only 16 to 17 percent of the vote, putting it in third place
against the rival Conservatives and Liberal Democrats, weekend polls in the
Times and Sunday Telegraph suggested.
</P>
<P>
Turnout at European elections in Britain is usually low -- in the last polls in
2004, it was just 38 percent, and this time, fringe parties like the anti-EU UK
Independence Party and the far-right British National Party are expected to
benefit.
</P>
<P>
An Economist magazine/YouGov poll last week found that only 31 percent of
Britons think its membership of the European Union is a good thing, compared to
37 percent who think it is bad.
</P>
<P>
The leader of the main opposition Conservatives, David Cameron, has opened up
new divisions in Europe by saying he would withdraw his party from the main
centre-right bloc in the EU parliament, the European People's Party (EPP), and
join a new eurosceptic alliance with Czech and Polish parties.
</P>
<P>
The EPP is still expected to remain the biggest single party in the parliament,
which already has a key role approving the EU budget and passing laws on a wide
range of issues.
</P>
<P>
The parliament will also endorse the new president of the European Commission
after a nomination is made by the EU summit. Jose Manuel Barroso, the
conservative former Portuguese prime minister, is widely expected to get a
second term.
</P>
</TEXT>

<P>
Casey Stoner held off the fast-finishing Jorge Lorenzo to win the Italian Grand

<P>
The Australian also took over the lead in the world championship standings with

<P>
He now leads Lorenzo, who started on pole here, by four points in the

</P>
<P>
In a dramatic race that began in wet conditions, Stoner seized the advantage
when switching bikes after 10 laps for a change of tyres.
</P>
<P>
He was the fastest man on the track by some margin in those first few laps after
the switch and although Yamaha pair Lorenzo and Rossi were quickest at the end,
they had both lost too much time and too many places to hit back.
</P>
<P>
Stoner completed the 23 laps in 45min 41.894sec to win by just over a second to
Spaniard Lorenzo.
</P>
<P>
In an exciting race the pole-sitter got off to a terrible start in the wet and
immediately dropped to eighth.
</P>
<P>
Quickest off the mark were Australian Chris Vermeulen, who started 11th, and
Andrea Dovizioso, who began seventh but Stoner passed them both on the long
straight at the beginning of the second lap.
</P>
<P>
Vermeulen quickly started heading backwards, eventually finishing 10th, as Rossi
started to move up from fifth.
</P>
<P>
However Italian Marco Melandri on a Kawasaki, who started 15th on the grid, was
clearly fastest in the wet.
</P>
<P>
Rossi took the lead from Dovizioso, who had got back past Stoner, on the seventh
lap and two laps later he lost that to Melandri.
</P>
<P>
However, on the 10th lap all the front runners came into the pits for a change
of bikes and when they came out, Stoner was quickest to find his pace.
</P>
<P>
Melandri immediately started heading backwards, eventually finishing 11th and
35sec back, while Loris Capirossi propelled himself into race contention with
Stoner and Dovizioso.
</P>
<P>
Lorenzo and Rossi initially struggled with their bikes down in fifth and sixth
and the time they lost over those first three laps coming out of the pits,
essentially cost either of them a chance of victory.
</P>
<P>
While Stoner had soon taken the race lead, both Yamaha riders had to then pass
Melandri, Capirossi and Dovizioso and by the time they had done so, Stoner was
over a second ahead and with only a couple of laps remaining.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile former Superbikes champion James Toseland of Britain got his best
finish of the season in seventh, benefitting from being the first man into the
pits to change his bike.
</P>
<P>
It meant that his tyres were warm and he was flying as the fastest man on track
for a few laps when everyone else was simply trying to get temperature into
their new tyres.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Cricket: Dhoni relishing World Twenty20 after IPL
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
India captain Mahendra Singh Dhoni is looking forward to uniting all the talents
at his disposal during the World Twenty20 in England after competing against his
team-mates in the Indian Premier League.
</P>
<P>
India are the defending World Twenty20 champions after winning the inaugural
edition in South Africa two years ago.
</P>
<P>
Since then the IPL, a lucrative franchise Twenty20 tournament that features the
world's best players, has burst on the scene although this year it was played in
South Africa because of security concerns.
</P>
<P>
"Of course it is a pleasure representing your country after the IPL where you
have limited talent in your side," Dhoni told reporters at Lord's here on
Sunday.
</P>
<P>
"But here we have plenty of options and we have the cream of the IPL so there is
less pressure on each and every individual."
</P>
<P>
India supply more IPL players than any other nation but wicket-keeper batsman
Dhoni, the captain of the Chennai Super Kings, said this was not an advantage in
itself.
</P>
<P>
"The IPL will help us but not only us. There are quite a few players from other
countries but most of our players are in the IPL.
</P>
<P>
"The best thing is that our youngsters will know how to handle pressure, when in
the last over you need 10 or 15 runs, everyone in our side has faced that
situation.
</P>
<P>
"It's good exposure for our guys to play against guys like Brett Lee and Shane
Warne.
</P>
<P>
India have been drawn in Group A alongside Asian rivals Bangladesh - who
defeated India at the 2007 50-over World Cup in the Caribbean and Ireland - who
beat both Bangladesh and Pakistan in the West Indies two years ago.
</P>
<P>
"In Twenty20, there is  no such thing as a weak side, an individual can take the
game away from you," Dhoni explained. "If we take care of the immediate steps,
the result takes care of itself."
</P>
<P>
Reflecting on India's success in South Africa, where they beat arch-rivals
Pakistan in a thrilling final, Dhoni said: "We can't live on or relish the
memories, we have to turn up and do everything from scratch again, it's not
about the past.
</P>
<P>
"Cricket is a very cruel game, the moment you relax is when you are in trouble,"
Dhoni said.
</P>
<P>
Asked how the team had developed, Dhoni joked: "I've got quite a few grey hairs.
That's one change, the plus point is that in the last three years there have
been fewer changes in the side.
</P>
<P>
"The individuals involved have played 80 to 90 one-day internationals, helps me
personally. I can pick ideas according to the situation. Also the fielding has
evolved compared to what it was. We have raised the bar."
</P>
<P>
India, who still have a doubt over the fitness of fast bowler Zaheer Khan's
shoulder injury, come into this event without batting great Sachin Tendulkar.
</P>
<P>
'The Little Master' has opted out of international Twenty20s and Dhoni said:
"He's among the greatest, it's tough, you always want a player like Sachin in
your side.
</P>
<P>
"But he wasn't at the last T20, the guys are getting used to it. But he has a

<HEADLINE>
Iraq's Kurdish region to export oil for first time
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
DOHUK, Iraq, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Iraq's self-ruled Kurdish region will begin exporting crude oil for the first
time on Monday, piping up to 90,000 bpd to its neighbours, officials said.
</P>
<P>
Companies chosen by the regional government will pump oil from two Kurdish
fields via an Iraqi pipeline to Turkey with the consent of Baghdad in a step
that could pave the way to ending bitter domestic feuds over Iraq's oil wealth.
</P>
<P>
Initial exports will be around 40,000 barrels per day from the Taq Taq field in
the province of Arbil and another 50,000 bpd from the Tawke field in Dohuk,
company officials told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"Piping of the oil will start Monday morning from the Taq Taq field, pumping it
from seven wells," said Mohammed Okotan, director of the Taq Taq project for
Turkey's Genel Enerji, which is partnered with Calgary-based Addax Petroleum.
</P>
<P>
"We will try to reach 60,000 barrels a day by the end of this year," said
Okotan, adding that the project aims to double exports in two years.
</P>
<P>
"The quality of the crude is excellent," he said.
</P>
<P>
At the Tawke field, northwest of Taq Taq, Norwegian oil firm DNO will also start
pumping oil for export on Monday.
</P>
<P>
"We'll start with 50,000 bpd and we'll see how this operation goes and if we can
increase it," said DNO director of operations Jon Sargent.
</P>
<P>
Disagreements over oil rights, especially between Baghdad and the Kurdish
government, have held up exploitation of much of Iraq's massive reserves as well
as long-delayed hydrocarbons legislation.
</P>
<P>
Terms of the Taq Taq deal are for Baghdad to receive 88 percent of revenues. of
which the Kurd region will get back 17 percent. Genel Enerji and Addax will
share 12 percent, Okotan told reporters.
</P>
<P>
Executives from DNO refused to provide revenue sharing figures, although one DNO
official confided that the terms are quite similar to those in the Tawke field.
</P>
<P>
Iraq is in dire need of revenue to rebuild its shattered economy, especially
after oil prices fell from a peak of 147 dollars a barrel last July to a current
level just above 60 dollars, putting huge pressure on Iraq's budget.
</P>
<P>
The nation derives more than 90 percent of its revenues from the energy sector.
</P>
<P>
Iraq hopes to be able to pump six million barrels per day, up from its current
stated output of around 2.2 million, within the next four to five years as new
projects come online.
</P>
<P>
The conflict-ravaged country has the world's third largest proven reserves of
oil, with more than 115 billion barrels, behind only Saudi Arabia and Iran.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<P>
"People here are entitled to decide if Taiwan people, through a referendum,
approve such an agreement with China," he said.
</P>
<P>
The Ma Ying-jeou administration is targeting the pact -- similar in scope to a
free trade agreement -- with Beijing to boost the flow of goods and personnel
across the Strait and to help the island tackle recession.
</P>
<P>
Chinese President Hu Jintao told visiting Wu Poh-hsiung, chairman of the
Kuomintang, in Beijing last week that talks on the ECFA were likely to start in
the second half of the year.
</P>
<P>
Hu said the mainland would like to see an economic agreement that will benefit
economic development on both sides and improve people's welfare,  according to
the Xinhua news agency.
</P>
<P>
Taiwan's Economic Minister Yiin Chii-ming had defended the trade pact, claiming
that the island's economy could rise by 1.4 percentage points by forging an
economic pact with China.
</P>
<P>
In particular, the petrochemical sector, machinery and auto components makers
are expected to benefit from closer cross-strait ties, Yiin said.
</P>
<P>
But the DPP has strongly opposed the potential pact, which it claims would
demote Taipei to the status of local government in any rapprochement talks.
</P>
<P>
China still regards Taiwan as part of its territory awaiting reunification by
force if necessary, although the two sides have been governed separately since
the end of a civil war in 1949.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Tennis: Cibulkova into last eight at French Open
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Dominika Cibulkova of Slovakia underlined her growing potential on Sunday by
brushing aside Agnes Szavay of Hungary 6-2, 6-4 to reach the quarter-finals of
the French Open.
</P>
<P>
It is the first time that the 20-year-old from Bratislava has made it through to
the last eight of a Grand Slam event at her eighth attempt.
</P>
<P>
"It was difficult because we were both nervous at the beginning and it was a
case of not making mistakes," she said.
</P>
<P>
"But I prepared well for this game and knew how she would play."
</P>
<P>
One of the smallest players on the WTA circuit at just 1.61 metres, Cibulkova
had failed to take a set of Szavay in their three previous encounters, but she
was quickly out of the blocks this time breaking serve twice for a 4-0 lead.
</P>
<P>
Szavay, who stunned Venus Williams in the third round, steadied the ship in the
fifth game but by that time the first set was out of her reach, Cibulkova taking
it 6-2 in 38 minutes.
</P>
<P>
It was a different story at the start of the second half with Cibulkova
tightening up and dropping serve to go 0-2 down, but she snatched one back in
the next to level at 2-2.
</P>
<P>
The 20th seed then broke again in the fifth game keeping up a steady stream of
baseline groundstrokes and allowing Szavay to make the errors as she sought a
solution to her opponent's dominance of the rallies.
</P>
<P>
There looked to be no way back for the demoralised Hungarian as Cibulkova got to
match point on her own serve at 5-2 ahead.
</P>
<P>
But a wild forehand let that slip away and she followed up with a double fault
at break point to hand her opponent an unlikely lifeline.
</P>
<P>
Szavay staved off another match point on her own serve by coming into the net
more often, but Cibulkova this time held steady on her own service game to set
up a quarter-final tie against either former world No. 1 Maria Sharapova of
Russia or Li Na of China.
</P>
<P>
"I have nothing to lose from now on in," the Slovak said.
</P>
<P>
"I was injured before Roland Garros (leg muscle) and didn't play the big
tournaments, so I was a bit afraid. But now it's amazing."
</P>

</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Top seed Dinara Safina eased into the French Open quarter-finals on Sunday
defeating Aravane Rezai of France 6-1, 6-0 in a 53-minute centre-court mismatch.
</P>
<P>
It was the Russian's 18th win out of 19 matches on clay this season and

all Grand Slams, then stepped on the accelerator to also take the next three
games and the set in just 30 minutes.

the Philippe Chatrier centre court against her much bigger and more physical
opponent.

there was no way back for the struggling Frenchwoman.

<HEADLINE>
Troops hunt Taliban as Pakistan says victory near
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
PESHAWAR, Pakistan, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Pakistan's defence secretary said Sunday that a month-long offensive to crush
Taliban fighters in the northwest could end within days, as fierce fighting
spilled into a nearby tribal area.
</P>
<P>
Swat valley's main town Mingora is back in government hands, the military
announced late Saturday, and security officials said they were now pursuing the
top leadership of the hardline Taliban movement into the nearby mountains.
</P>
<P>
Secretary of Defence Syed Athar Ali told a security forum in Singapore that
three targeted northwest districts were almost clear of Taliban rebels.
</P>
<P>
"Operations in Swat, Buner and adjoining areas have almost met complete
success," he said.
</P>
<P>
"Only five to ten percent of the job is remaining and hopefully within the next
two to three days these pockets of resistance will be cleared."
</P>
<P>
The army remains locked in battle in some areas, but the fall of Mingora was a
critical milestone in an offensive launched after the Taliban thrust to within
100 kilometres (60 miles) of Islamabad in April.
</P>
<P>
Pakistan's military also reported that 25 militants and seven soldiers were
killed in clashes in South Waziristan near the Afghan border, a bolt-hole for
Taliban and Al-Qaeda-linked militants south of the current army bombardment.
</P>
<P>
"Miscreants attacked a security forces checkpost last night (Saturday) in
Spinkai Raghzai, South Waziristan agency. The attack was repulsed successfully,
inflicting heavy casualties on militants," it said in a statement.
</P>
<P>
Fifteen militants and three soldiers died in the clash in Spinkai Raghzai, while
elsewhere in the semi-autonomous tribal area 10 insurgents and four troops
including a lieutenant died when rebels attacked a military convoy.
</P>
<P>
Civilians have started fleeing the area fearing a fresh military onslaught, but
the army has denied an imminent assault on Waziristan, where militants branded
by Washington as the greatest terror threat to the West are holed up.
</P>
<P>
The United States, which is firmly backing the current military drive, had
warned that the rebels threaten Pakistan's very existence.
</P>
<P>
Officials have said that lower-ranking Taliban leaders had been killed but it
was harder to get to the top leaders, who had a network of hardcore militants
around them and had slipped into the rugged mountain terrain.
</P>
<P>
"They will be eliminated wherever we find them," said one military official, who
did not wish to be named as he was not authorised to speak to the media, adding:
"We believe that they are somewhere in the mountains."
</P>
<P>
Pakistan has slapped a 600,000-dollar price on the head of firebrand Swat
Taliban commander Maulana Fazlullah for masterminding the nearly two-year
uprising in the valley to enforce sharia law.
</P>
<P>
Fazlullah led thousands of supporters in a campaign that has beheaded opponents,
burned schools and fought government troops since November 2007.
</P>
<P>
The government has also offered rewards for 21 rebel chiefs -- wanted dead or
alive -- from Swat. The military claims to have killed 1,244 militants since the
offensive began, although the numbers are impossible to verify.
</P>
<P>
As the government ups its campaign to stamp out the militants, fears are growing
of a wave of revenge attacks.
</P>
<P>
The northwestern capital Peshawar and the eastern cultural centre of Lahore have
both been rocked by deadly explosions in the last five days, killing a total of
39 people and wounding hundreds more.
</P>
<P>
A spokesman for Pakistan Taliban chief Baitullah Mehsud -- who has a five-
million-dollar bounty on his head posted by the United States -- has claimed
Wednesday's suicide bombing on a police building in Lahore.
</P>
<P>
Hakimullah Mehsud also warned of more "massive attacks" to avenge the Swat
military operation and in protest at Islamabad's ties with Washington.
</P>
<P>
Nearly 2.4 million people have fled the current offensive, and the military
relaxed a curfew Sunday in most parts of the northwest including Mingora to
allow people trapped on the roads to return home or leave the region.
</P>
<P>
Also Sunday, Taliban militants attacked a school in Hangu town south of
Peshawar, killing one administrator and kidnapping three other people, local
policeman Shoukat Hussain said.
</P>
<P>
In North Waziristan, meanwhile, a former government doctor and an Afghan
national were killed by suspected militants, officials said.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Palestinian tensions mount after deadly shoot-out
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
NABLUS, West Bank, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Six people were killed in a West Bank shoot-out on Sunday when an attempt to
arrest a senior Hamas commander went awry, deepening the rift between the two
main Palestinian factions.
</P>
<P>
The Islamist Hamas movement ruling the Gaza Strip warned that the rival Fatah
group loyal to president Mahmud Abbas had crossed a "red line" over the killing
of one of its top fighters in the arrest operation.
</P>
<P>
The gunfight erupted when Palestinian police dominated by Fatah tried to arrest
Mohammed al-Samman, the commander of Hamas's armed wing in the northern West
Bank who was also on Israel's wanted list.
</P>
<P>
Samman barricaded himself in a house in the town of Qalqiliya in the north of
the Israeli-occupied territory together with Mohammed Yassin, another Hamas
militant, police and Hamas said.
</P>
<P>
The ensuing shoot-out killed both Hamas men, three Palestinian policemen and a
civilian. A curfew was imposed on the town near the border with Israel following
the incident, police said.
</P>
<P>
Hamas branded the incident a "red line" and said it laid "complete
responsibility of this ugly crime on Abbas and his security forces."
</P>
<P>
Describing Abbas and his forces as agents of arch-enemy Israel, Hamas said in a
statement that it would respond "with acts," without elaborating.
</P>
<P>
"There is no difference between the occupation who shoots and the people who
carry out their missions for them," a spokesman for Hamas's armed wing said at a
press conference in Gaza.
</P>
<P>
The deep-seated rivalries between Hamas and Fatah boiled over in June 2007 when
the Islamists violently seized control of Gaza, causing a split in Palestinian
ranks that has become a key stumbling block in efforts to reach Middle East
peace.
</P>
<P>
Hamas spokesman Fawzi Barhum said there was no chance of further reconciliation
talks with Fatah after the "escalation by security services of Abu Mazen and
Fatah against Hamas and its leaders in the West Bank."
</P>
<P>
"Fatah should choose -- dialogue with us or doing the dirty work of the Zionist
enemy," Barhum said as Hamas decried the killing over mosque loudspeakers in
Gaza City.
</P>
<P>
A senior official from the Fatah-led Palestinian Authority dismissed the Hamas
accusations as "lies."
</P>
<P>
"The Palestinian Authority has one duty -- to impose security and the law and we
will not allow what happened in Gaza to happen here in the West Bank under any
circumstances," he said on condition of anonymity.
</P>
<P>
A spokesman for Palestinian security forces, Adnan Damiri, defended the arrest
operation.
</P>
<P>
"We in the Palestinian security branches are not a political force. We are
security. We will not allow any Palestinian party to have guns and threaten
civilians."
</P>
<P>
Damiri also said that during the arrest, police discovered Hamas leaflets
containing "incitement against the Palestinian Authority and against the
Palestinian security branches."
</P>
<P>
"We consider what happened today as very dangerous," he said. "It was an attempt
to destroy any hope of resuming the (reconciliation) dialogue."
</P>
<P>
Abbas's power based has been limited to the occupied West Bank since Hamas
booted his Fatah party out of the Gaza Strip, which remains under a crippling
Israeli blockade.
</P>
<P>
The two factions held five rounds of talks under Egyptian mediation in an
attempt to reconcile but to no avail and the two sides have frequently accused
their rivals of campaigns of persecution.
</P>
<P>
Rights group Amnesty International has lambasted both Hamas and Fatah for
arbitrary detentions, torture and suppression of freedom of speech in their
respective areas of control.
</P>
<P>
The Western-backed Abbas swore in a new Palestinian cabinet that includes
members of Fatah but not Hamas on May 20, further widening the sectarian rift.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Thousands march in Hong Kong to mark Tiananmen crackdown
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Hong Kong, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Thousands of protesters marched through Hong Kong on Sunday to commemorate the
crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing 20 years ago, including one
of the leaders from Tiananmen Square.
</P>
<P>
Organisers said around 5,000 people rallied through the streets of the city to
mark the anniversary of the military crackdown, which left hundreds, possibly
thousands dead following weeks of protests in the capital.
</P>
<P>
Among the marchers was Xiong Yan, a leading student activist during the 1989
demonstrations who now lives in exile in the United States.
</P>
<P>
He was surprisingly allowed into Hong Kong on Saturday.
</P>
<P>
Lee Cheuk-yan, a pro-democracy legislator in Hong Kong and one of the organisers
of the annual march, said it was crucial that the city continued to mark the
events of 20 years ago.
</P>
<P>
"We are the only place on Chinese soil that can commemorate June 4," he told
AFP.
</P>
<P>
"Hong Kong has become the conscience of China to remember... the crime of the
Tiananmen Square massacre and push the regime (in Beijing) to admit their
mistakes."
</P>
<P>
The attendance at the march was sharply up on last year's figures. An annual
candlelit vigil on Thursday is expected to attract tens of thousands.
</P>
<P>
Xiong, who was put on a list of the authorities' 21 "most-wanted" student
protesters after the occupation of Tiananmen was broken up, spent two years in
jail before being smuggled to the US via Hong Kong.
</P>
<P>
His entry was unexpected because of China's sensitive attitude to any criticism
of the crackdown.
</P>
<P>
Other 1989 campaigners have been refused entry to Hong Kong in the past,
although it has a separate legal and immigration system from the mainland,
including the right to protest.
</P>
<P>
"I was very surprised as I have tried many, many times to come," said Xiong, who
arrived Saturday night, the first time he had set foot on Chinese soil in 17
years.
</P>
<P>
"I hope in the future I can not only go to Hong Kong, but also to Beijing," he
added.
</P>
<P>
The marchers gathered in the city's Victoria Park, waving banners with slogans
such as "Pass the torch on, relay the message of democracy to those who come
after us" and "Speak the truth, never forget."
</P>
<P>
The rally included a small group of mainland Chinese students, who wore T-shirts
citing former Communist leader Mao Zedong: "Whoever suppresses student movements
is going to have a bad ending."
</P>
<P>
"I am very excited to see so many people, as this is forbidden on the mainland,"
said one of the students, 20, who did not want to be named.
</P>
<P>
"(It shows) there is hope," he added.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile, a Danish sculptor who flew to Hong Kong to protest the bloody
crackdown was refused entry.
</P>
<P>
Jens Galschiot, whose sculpture commemorating those who died in the 1989
military crackdown, "Pillar of Shame," is displayed at Hong Kong University, was
stopped by officials Saturday and sent back to Zurich, an immigration spokesman
confirmed.
</P>
<P>
Albert Ho, chairman of the Democratic Party and a lawyer, said the Dane was
detained for five hours before being put on a flight to Zurich late Saturday. Ho
said he was looking at possible legal action over the decision.
</P>
<P>
Many of Hong Kong's leading democrats joined the march, including veteran
campaigner Martin Lee, who on Saturday revealed he had been the target of an
assassination plot.
</P>
<P>
Two men have been charged in relation to the plot which was foiled last year,
but only revealed on Saturday. The pair will appear in a Hong Kong court on June
16.
</P>
<P>
Lee, who has been at the forefront of the campaign to overturn Beijing's
official condemnation of the Tiananmen protesters, said he was sure there was no
involvement of the Communist Party.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Armenia opposition pins hopes on Yerevan poll
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
YEREVAN, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Residents of the Armenian capital voted in a municipal election Sunday in which
the main opposition movement is seeking to gain an important foothold on power
after losing political ground last year.
</P>
<P>
The Armenian National Congress is hoping it can win enough seats on the 65-seat
Yerevan city council for its leader -- former president Levon Ter-Petrosian --
to be elected mayor.
</P>
<P>
The vote has raised fears of a repeat of the violence after last year's
presidential elections that saw 10 people killed in clashes between riot police
and opposition supporters.
</P>
<P>
Ter-Petrosian and his backers accused the authorities of rigging the vote to
guarantee a win for President Serzh Sarkisian, who defeated Ter-Petrosian.
</P>
<P>
Analysts say it is likely the opposition will hold protests if it loses again,
risking another confrontation.
</P>
<P>
"The municipal elections are the first stage of ridding the country of this
criminal regime," said 29-year-old voter Astkhik Petrosian. "I voted for the
opposition. Once they have taken power in the city we will be able to have new
early presidential elections."
</P>
<P>
Voting began at 8:00 am (0400 GMT) and by three hours later voter turnout had
reached 11.72 percent, the Central Election Commission said.
</P>
<P>
The city council will chose the mayor under constitutional amendments adopted in
2005. Armenia's president previously made the appointment for the four-year
term.
</P>
<P>
If any party wins 40 percent of the seats, its candidate becomes the city mayor,
otherwise the mayor is to be elected by the city council.
</P>
<P>
Preliminary results are to be announced within 24 hours after the vote and the
final results during the next seven days.

Controversial NATO military exercises in former Soviet republic Georgia were

</P>
<P>
The month-long drills involving about 1,100 troops from 10 NATO countries and
six of the alliance's partner countries were to end on Monday.
</P>
<P>
Russia, which fought a brief war with Georgia in August over the rebel South
Ossetia region, denounced the exercises as "provocative" and announced plans to
step up its own military training exercises near the Georgian border next month.
</P>
<P>
Analysts say that although they were planned before last year's war, the
exercises have boosted Georgia's hopes of building closer ties with the Western
military alliance.
</P>
<P>
"They prove that the West, and NATO in particular, has not lost interest in
Georgia after the August war," political analyst Soso Tsintsadze told AFP.
</P>
<P>

Moscow is a cold shower for the Kremlin," he said.
</P>
<P>
The manoeuvres were aimed at improving the way nations operate together in
crisis situations under a UN mandate.
</P>
<P>
The exercises had two components, NATO headquarters said.
</P>
<P>
The first -- "Cooperative Longbow" -- was a "command post" exercise done almost
exclusively on computers. The second -- "Cooperative Lancer" -- which started on
May 18 and ends Monday, is a field exercise involving around 400 troops and is
designed to provide training on peacekeeping operations.
</P>
<P>
Russian leaders denounced the drills, with Prime Minister Vladimir Putin calling
them "a step backwards" in resetting Russia-US relations.
</P>
<P>
Russian officials also said the NATO exercises would lead to "adjustments" in
strategic and tactical manoeuvres entitled "Caucasus 2009" that are scheduled to
take place in the region in June.
</P>
<P>
The exercises were held amid political uncertainty in Georgia as opposition
supporters have protested for weeks to demand President Mikheil Saakashvili's
resignation.
</P>
<P>
Opponents accuse Saakashvili of mishandling the war with Russia and of becoming
increasingly autocratic since taking power after the peaceful Rose Revolution in
2003.
</P>
<P>
Minor clashes have broken out between police and protesters, raising fears of
wider unrest.
</P>
<P>
The day before the exercises began, Georgia also said it had peacefully put down
a mutiny at a military base outside Tbilisi aimed at disrupting the drills.
Georgia initially accused Russia of backing an armed coup -- an accusation
Moscow described as "insane."
</P>

</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
KHARTOUM, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Sudan on Sunday buried former president Gaafar al-Nimeiry, the man who imposed
Islamic rule on Africa's largest nation, at a funeral attended by ordinary
Sudanese, politicians and military officials.
</P>
<P>
President Omar al-Beshir led the funeral procession as Nimeiry's body, wrapped
in a Sudanese flag, was carried by military officials to his burial site in
Omdurman, Khartoum's twin city.
</P>
<P>
"There is no God but Allah," chanted about 3,000 men dressed in traditional
white robes, as well military officers, policemen and a handful of politicians
gathered at a stadium in Omdurman.
</P>
<P>
Nimeiry, who came to power in a coup in 1969 with the support of communist and
socialist leaders, died in a military hospital on Saturday at the age of 79
after a long illness.
</P>
<P>
Hundreds of his relatives and supporters gathered outside his home in Omdurman's
Wad Nabawi neighbourhood on Saturday to recite prayers after news of his death.
</P>
<P>
In 1972, he oversaw the end of a civil war that had plagued the country since
1955, pitting the north against the mainly Christian and animist south but an
economic crisis in the late 70s and early 80s saw his grip on power weaken.
</P>
<P>
In 1983, bowing to pressure from the Islamists, he introduced Islamic sharia law
to Africa's largest nation but two years later, in 1985, he was ousted in
another coup.
</P>
<P>
Nimeiry was also a career officer who received military training in an academy
in the United States in the 1960s.
</P>
<P>
Beshir said in a statement that Nimeiry would be remembered as the man who
brought Islamic law to Sudan, and which is still imposed in the north of the
country.
</P>
<P>
"Nimeiry was a sincere man, a leader with a heart," said Abel Alier, who served
as vice president under Nimeiry between 1971-1981. "He achieved many good things
but he also did things he should not have done."
</P>
<P>
"He signed peace with the south in 1972. Many people have forgotten that but (at
the time) it was the good thing to do," he said.
</P>
<P>
Nimeiry's ouster from power in 1985 by General Sawar al-Dahab paved the way for
democratic elections in Sudan which saw the head of the powerful Umma Party,
Sadeq al-Mahdi, elected to the presidency.
</P>
<P>
But Mahdi was overthrown by Beshir in 1989.
</P>
<P>
Nimeiry lived 14 years in exile in Egypt after his ouster, returning to Sudan in
1999.
</P>

crumbling lakeside mansion. She was moved to Yangon's notorious Insein prison
and charged on May 14.

ahead of final arguments in the case, which are due to be heard on Friday. A

Yettaw's visit for the purposes of the trial.
