Nyan Win, who is also part of her legal team.
</P>
<P>
Yettaw, a 53-year-old Mormon and former US military veteran, was arrested on May
6 after swimming to Aung San Suu Kyi's house using a pair of homemade flippers
and spending two nights there.
</P>
<P>
He has told the court that he had had a vision that Aung San Suu Kyi would be
assassinated by "terrorists" and was told by God to warn both the opposition
leader and the Myanmar government.
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi said in a statement to the court this week that she could not
be held responsible as the junta had failed to boost security despite her having
reported that Yettaw made a previous visit to the house in November 2008.
</P>
<P>
However Nyan Win quoted the democracy campaigner as saying that she "has no
grudge to Mr Yettaw and his family."
</P>
<P>
International critics accuse Myanmar's military regime of trumping up the
charges in a bid to keep her locked up ahead of elections in 2010, as the latest
six-year period of her house arrest expired on Wednesday.
</P>
<P>
But in his speech in Singapore, Myanmar's Aye Myint said the case against Aung
San Suu Kyi was an internal matter.
</P>
<P>
"Countries should refrain from interfering in the internal affairs of Myanmar
that will affect peace and security of the region," said Aye Myint.
</P>
<P>
"It is the universal legal principle that no one is above the law," he said
</P>
<P>
US Defence Secretary Robert Gates, speaking at the same forum on Saturday,
pressed Myanmar to free Aung San Suu Kyi and said there needed to be "real
change in Burma". Burma is Myanmar's former name.
</P>
<P>
Ann Taylor, Britain's minister for international defence and security, made a
similar call on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Myanmar last week hit back at rare criticism from the normally placid fellow
members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) over the treatment
of the democracy campaigner.
</P>
<P>
Thai Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva, whose country holds the rotating
chairmanship of the 10-member bloc, said ASEAN leaders would discuss Myanmar at
a summit in South Korea on June 1-2.

dimensional Hanescu in the first game of the third set Gonzalez on his way.
</P>
<P>
Gonzalez, whose best Grand Slam performance remains his runner-up spot to
Federer at the 2007 Australian Open, broke through again in the seventh game to
stretch to 5-2.
</P>
<P>
The 1998 Roland Garros junior champion then wrapped up the tie with his 50th
winner to finish off Hanescu after only 87 minutes.

<HEADLINE>
Tennis: Cibulkova into last eight at French Open
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Dominika Cibulkova of Slovakia underlined her growing potential on Sunday by
brushing aside Agnes Szavay of Hungary 6-2, 6-4 to reach the quarter-finals of
the French Open.
</P>
<P>
It is the first time that the 20-year-old from Bratislava has made it through to
the last eight of a Grand Slam event at her eighth attempt.
</P>
<P>
One of the smallest players on the WTA circuit at just 1.61 metres, Cibulkova
had failed to take a set of Szavay in their three previous encounters, but she
was quickly out of the blocks this time breaking serve twice for a 4-0 lead.
</P>
<P>
Szavay, who stunned Venus Williams in the third round, steadied the ship in the
fifth game but by that time the first set was out of her reach, Cibulkova taking
it 6-2 in 38 minutes.
</P>
<P>
It was a different story at the start of the second half with Cibulkova
tightening up and dropping serve to go 0-2 down, but she snatched one back in
the next to level at 2-2.
</P>
<P>
The 20th seed then broke again in the fifth game keeping up a steady stream of
baseline groundstrokes and allowing Szavay to make the errors as she sought a
solution to her opponent's dominance of the rallies.
</P>
<P>
There looked to be no way back for the demoralised Hungarian as Cibulkova got to
match point on her own serve at 5-2 ahead.
</P>
<P>
But a wild forehand let that slip away and she followed up with a double fault
at break point to hand her opponent an unlikely lifeline.
</P>
<P>
Szavay staved off another match point on her own serve by coming into the net
more often, but Cibulkova this time held steady on her own service game to set
up a quarter-final tie against either former world No. 1 Maria Sharapova of
Russia or Li Na of China.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Recession-hit Croatia votes in local polls
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ZAGREB, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Croatians cast ballots on Sunday in a second round of local and regional
elections, including a mayoral race in the capital Zagreb, which are expected to
be influenced by the economic crisis.
</P>
<P>
The elections are seen as a test of the ability of the Croatia's governing
coalition to handle the effects of the global economic crisis, which sent the
Adriatic country into recession late last year.
</P>
<P>
Some four million voters were eligible to elect 221 mayors and municipal heads.
</P>
<P>
Polling stations opened at 0500 GMT and were to close 12 hours later. First
results were expected later on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
At 0900 GMT, four hours after voting started, turnout was at 10.8 percent, the
electoral commission said. It was some three percent lower than in the first
round voting held two weeks ago.
</P>
<P>
In Zagreb, incumbent mayor Milan Bandic of the opposition Social Democrats (SDP)
is being tipped to see off a challenge from independent candidate Josip Kregar
and win a fourth mandate.
</P>
<P>
On May 17, Prime Minister Ivo Sanader's ruling conservative Croatian Democratic
Union (HDZ) was re-elected in most counties in the first round while the SDP
asserted their control in major cities.
</P>
<P>
The HDZ and its coalition partners won seven prefect posts and held a majority
in 14 out of 21 county assemblies. The SDP got four county prefects and secured
control of five county assemblies.
</P>
<P>
The conservatives lost the mayoral post in the country's second biggest town of
Split, on the Adriatic coast, where an SDP candidate is to face an independent.
</P>
<P>
Local analysts said the vote confirmed that the SDP and left bloc dominate in
more developed parts of Croatia as well as in cities, while the HDZ and right-
wing parties are more popular in less developed and rural areas.
</P>
<P>
The polls give voters the right for the first time to directly elect mayors,
county prefects and municipal heads, along with 21 county assemblies and more
than 550 city and town councils.
</P>
<P>
The HDZ, founded by late nationalist leader Franjo Tudjman, returned to power in
2003 after three years in opposition. Sanader has since shaken off the HDZ's
hardline nationalist legacy and transformed it into a party that is aiming to
lead Croatia to becoming the European Union's 28th member by 2011.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Israel fumes over US settlement demands
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Jerusalem, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Israel refused on Sunday to bow to US calls for a freeze to all settlement
activity in the occupied West Bank, as it fumed over the "unfair" demands that
have raised tensions between the close allies.
</P>
<P>
"I want to say in a crystal clear manner that the current Israeli government
will not accept in any fashion that legal settlement activity be frozen," said
Transport Minister Yisrael Katz, a close ally of Prime Minister Benjamin
Netanyahu.
</P>
<P>
The premier himself did not address the issue at the opening of the weekly
cabinet meeting but the fighting words were echoed by other members of the
largely right-wing cabinet, including from its most liberal party, Labour.
</P>
<P>
A senior Israeli official complained that Washington under President Barack
Obama -- who has vowed to pursue Middle East peace talks as part of a changed
approach to the region -- was placing unfair demands on its close ally.
</P>
<P>
"The Americans have demanded almost nothing from the Palestinians but are asking
Israel to take steps that are a real sacrifice. These demands are unfair," he
told AFP on condition of anonymity.
</P>
<P>
"The Palestinians are taking a passive approach. They're not even ready to meet
the Israeli side and Abu Mazen (Palestinian president Mahmud Abbas) wants the
Americans to do all the work," he said.
</P>
<P>
Abbas, who met Obama last week, 10 days after the US president met Netanyahu,
has vowed that that he will not relaunch talks unless Israel freezes settlements
in the occupied West Bank.
</P>
<P>
The Obama administration has demanded that Israel stop all its activity in the
settlements, including the so-called natural growth construction that allows for
building to accommodate a growing population.
</P>
<P>
The unusually blunt talk over one of the top stumbling points in the stalled
Middle East peace process has raised alarm bells in Israel that the new US
president could put pressure on the Jewish state as part of his new approach to
the Muslim world.
</P>
<P>
"This is an unjustifiable demand that the government and the public do not
accept," Interior Minister Eli Yishai of the ultra-Orthodox Shas party.
</P>
<P>
Social Affairs Minister Isaac Herzog of the centre-left Labour party that is the
most liberal in Netanyahu's government, said that "one has to understand that
there are various statuses within the settlements" and "saying that the picture
is black and white or write or wrong is wrong."
</P>
<P>
More than 280,000 Israelis live in settlements dotted throughout the West Bank,
which Israel captured in war in 1967.
</P>
<P>
Although the international community considers all settlements illegal, Israel
makes a distinction between those that were built with the state's blessing and
outposts, those constructed without authorisation.
</P>
<P>
Netanyahu has said he would dismantle outposts, but that it made "no sense" to
ask for a complete freeze to construction.
</P>
<P>
Israeli officials have also complained that Obama's administration has yet to
say it will honour commitments in a letter that then US president George W. Bush
sent to then Israeli premier Ariel Sharon in 2004.
</P>
<P>
Bush said that given the existence of major settlement blocs in the West Bank it
was "unrealistic" to expect Israel to fully withdraw from the territory as part
of a final peace deal.
</P>
<P>
"This administration has not yet recognised the arrangements made between the
Israeli government and the Bush administration," said Katz. "That can only raise
concerns over future arrangements."
</P>
<P>
Aside from the settlements, there is stark disagreement between Washington and
Israel over the creation of a Palestinian state, with Obama repeatedly saying he
was committed to the principle and Netanyahu thus far refusing to endorse it in
public.
</P>
<P>
Obama is due in Saudi Arabia and Egypt this week to try to reach out to Muslims
and end the deep mistrust of the United States felt across much of the Islamic
world.
</P>
</TEXT>

NABLUS, West Bank, May 31, 2009 (AFP)

<TEXT>

Six people were killed in a West Bank shoot-out on Sunday during an arrest

<P>
The Islamist Hamas movement ruling the Gaza Strip warned that the rival Fatah

</P>
<P>
Hamas-Fatah ties sharply deteriorated after the Islamists seized control of Gaza

The gunfight erupted when police tried to arrest Mohammed al-Samman, the

</P>

</P>

security forces."

"lies."
</P>
<P>
"The Palestinian Authority has one duty -- to impose security and the law and we
will not allow what happened in Gaza to happen here in the West Bank under any
circumstances," he said on condition of anonymity.
</P>
<P>
"We will not allow for any kind of chaos."
</P>
<P>

secular Fatah party out of Gaza, leaving him in control only in the occupied
West Bank.

<HEADLINE>
Iran defuses bomb in plane toilet
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Tehran, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Iranian security officials defused a bomb planted on a domestic passenger plane,
officials said on Sunday, the latest incident of violence ahead of next month's
presidential election.
</P>
<P>
The attempted bomb attack occurred on Saturday on a Kish Air flight headed to
Tehran from the oil-rich western city of Ahvaz near the border with Iraq, the
Fars news agency reported.
</P>
<P>
"Last night, 15 minutes after the plane with 131 passengers took off, flight
security guards found a handmade bomb placed in the lavatory," Fars said. "The
plane landed immediately at Ahvaz airport and the bomb was defused."
</P>
<P>
The incident occurred just two days after 25 people were killed in a powerful
bomb attack on a mosque in Zahedan in southeastern Iran claimed by a shadowy
Sunni rebel group.
</P>
<P>
"Security officials of the Islamic Republic Revolutionary Guards acted well and
the incident caused no casualties," Reza Jafarzadeh, spokesman for Iran's Civil
Aviation Organisation, told the state broadcaster.
</P>
<P>
A top security official blamed Iran's "enemies" for the plane bomb, saying they
wanted to stoke tensions ahead of the June 12 presidential election.
</P>
<P>
"The suspicious package and the details of the sabotage operation in the Tehran-
Ahvaz Boeing is under investigation," Mohammad Hassan Kazemi, the head of the
Revolutionary Guards aviation security operations, told the official IRNA news
agency.
</P>
<P>
"I do not confirm a link between this and the Zahedan operation," he said.
</P>
<P>
"But we believe our enemies want to create a threatening environment before the
presidential election and exploit the open space in the country and spark
despair among people."
</P>
<P>
On Thursday, a suicide bomber killed 25 worshippers and wounded 125 in a Shiite
mosque in Zahedan, capital of the southeastern Sistan-Baluchestan province
bordering Afghanistan and Pakistan.
</P>
<P>
A day later, gunmen on motorbikes fired at an election campaign office of
President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in Zahedan and wounded two campaign members and a
child.
</P>
<P>
The province, which is home to Iran's Baluch minority who adhere to Sunni Islam,
has been the scene of a deadly insurgency by a Sunni rebel group which is
strongly opposed to the government of predominantly Shiite Iran.
</P>
<P>
Iran on Saturday hanged three men in public accused of involvement in Thursday's
mosque bombing, just 48 hours after the attack, which was reportedly claimed by
the Sunni group Jundullah (Soldiers of God).
</P>
<P>
Iran summoned Pakistani envoy Mohammad Bakhsh Abbasi following the bombing.
Iranian officials claim Jundallah is known to have operated on several occasions
from across the broder in Pakistan.
</P>
<P>
The mosque attack was reminiscent of a similar outbreak of violence just days
before Iran's last presidential election in 2005 which brought Ahmadinejad to
power.
</P>
<P>
Bombs hit Tehran and Ahvaz, which has a sizable Arab minority, in June 2005,
killing at least eight people and wounding scores more.
</P>
<P>
Ahvaz, the capital of Iran's oil-rich Khuzestan province, which borders Iraq and
the Gulf, was also rocked by ethnic violence in April 2005.
</P>
<P>
Iran in the past has blamed US and British agents in neighbouring Iraq and
Afghanistan for launching attacks on its border provinces with significant
ethnic minority populations.
</P>
<P>
Jalal Sayah, Sistan-Baluchestan's deputy governor, said on Friday that those
arrested over the Zahedan attack were "hired by America and the agents of the
arrogance."
</P>
<P>
Iranian officials usually use the term "global arrogance" to refer to Iran's
arch-foe the United States.
</P>
<P>
But US State Department spokesman Ian Kelly denied Washington was behind the
attack, saying the United States does "not sponsor any form of terrorism in
Iran."
</P>
<P>
Iranian armed forces chief General Hassan Firouzabadi, in comments reported on
Saturday, accused Britain and "Zionists" of involvement in the bombing.
</P>
<P>
Sistan-Baluchestan has a substantial Sunni minority and lies on a major
narcotics-smuggling route from Afghanistan and Pakistan.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Breakaway South Ossetia votes for parliament
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
TSKHINVALI, Georgia, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The rebel Georgian region of South Ossetia voted Sunday in polls that could
secure the grip of its separatist leader nine months after it was the subject of
war between Russia and Georgia.
</P>
<P>
The local opposition says Eduard Kokoity is seeking to use the legislative
elections to forge a loyal parliamentary majority to push through an amendment
allowing him to run again for office when his second term lapses next year.
</P>
<P>
Russia -- which outraged the West by recognising South Ossetia as independent in
the wake of August's war with Georgia  --- has said South Ossetia should not
amend the existing term limits in its constitution.
</P>
<P>
Four parties are competing for the 34 seats in the parliament, but the central
election commission has barred the only two parties not loyal to Kokoity.
</P>
<P>
Opposition activities said voting would not make a difference. "I plan to sit at
home. There's nothing we can do," said Alan Gassiyev, an opposition leader,
calling the polls "completely illegal."
</P>
<P>
"It's too bad if he wants to change the constitution," added Grigory Dzassokhov,
a 55-year old former history teacher. "It would be nonsense. What kind of
democracy is that?"
</P>
<P>
Critics accuse Kokoity, an ex-wrestling champion, of muzzling opponents and
stealing the money sent from Russia.
</P>
<P>
Georgia ridiculed the vote, with the country's reintegration minister Temur
Iakobashvili saying the elections were "nothing but clownery, a farce and a
redistribution of a criminal power."
</P>
<P>
Kokoity insisted however the elections were in strict accordance with law,
saying the polls were "a maturity test for the small independent state."
</P>
<P>
A large number of voters at the polling stations was proof that the vote was
deemed genuine by people, he said.
</P>
<P>
"At 10:00 am I can already say there's a very high turnout," he added. Officials
said it already amounted to 19 percent by that time.
</P>
<P>
Eighty-eight polling stations have been set up for the region's 50,000 residents
as well as additional sites in Russia for expatriates and refugees from the
fighting.
</P>
<P>
Kokoity currently does not have the two-thirds of seats in the parliament to
amend the constitution.
</P>
<P>
As the region scrambles to rebuild itself in the aftermath of the war, the
opposition accuses Kokoity and his circle of diverting lorries carrying
construction material and humanitarian aid to traffic the goods in Russia.
</P>
<P>
Out of over 10 billion rubles (320 million dollars, 230 million euros) in aid
money budgeted by Moscow, South Ossetian authorities say they have spent just
1.5 billion rubles.
</P>
<P>
Kokoity -- who built connections in Moscow working as a trade official for the
rebel region when it was known as a highway for smuggling in the early 1990s --
has rejected accusations against him as Georgian propaganda.
</P>
<P>
"With what happened in August we need three to four years to rebuild," Kokoity
said.
</P>
<P>
And as the looming political scandal in the region threatens to become an
embarrassment for Moscow, there are signs that the Kremlin is scaling back its
support for the South Ossetian leader.
</P>
<P>
Sergey Naryshkin, the head of the Russian presidential administration, said on
Russian television this month that South Ossetia should not amend the existing
term limits in its constitution.
</P>
<P>
Moscow and Tbilisi fought a brief but intense war last August over the region,
which had enjoyed de facto independence since the early 1990s thanks to tacit
Russian support.
</P>
<P>
Following the conflict Russia formally recognised the region as independent, a
move followed only by Nicaragua.
</P>
<P>
Russia took formal control of guarding its borders this month, in a move
condemned by the West as a violation of an EU-brokered ceasefire that ended the
fighting last August.
</P>
<P>
The vote was a leading news item on the Russian television, which gave it
favorable coverage.
</P>
<P>
Voting was expected to end at 8:00 pm (1600 GMT), with the first results
expected two hours later.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Israel stages 'doomsday' drill
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Jerusalem, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Israel began its largest-ever exercise on Sunday to test the response of
emergency services to a "doomsday" mix of missile attacks, suicide bombings and
natural disasters.
</P>
<P>
The five-day exercise will simulate simultaneous rocket strikes from the Gaza
Strip and Lebanon and missile attacks from arch-foes Syria and Iran.
</P>
<P>
"The mere fact that Israel is preparing with such an exercise improves our
ability to better protect our citizens and ultimately lowers the threat," Prime
Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said at the cabinet meeting.
</P>
<P>
During the drill, Israel will be staging a "doomsday scenario" of simultaneous
strikes against the country, defence ministry spokesman Shlomo Dror told AFP
last week.
</P>
<P>
This will include conventional, chemical and biological strikes, as well as a
wave of Palestinian suicide bombings, against large population centres.
</P>
<P>
Exercise Turning Point 3 will also simulate the conduct of rescue and medical
services during earthquakes and epidemics and will involve the participation of
schools, government ministers and other state institutions.
</P>
<P>
The drill's main activity will come on Tuesday, when air-raid sirens sound
across the country and citizens must scramble to shelters, in some areas within
seconds and others within no more than three minutes.
</P>
<P>
There will also be simulated cabinet meetings in which ministers will weigh
their response to such attacks and scenarios.
</P>
<P>
"Schools, kindergartens and educational institutions across Israel will
participate in the exercise, practising emergency entry into protected spaces,"
the army said in a statement. "Rear military bases, governmental offices and
public institutions will also practice."
</P>
<P>
It is the third consecutive year Israel is conducting such an exercise, although
this year's drill is the largest-ever.
</P>
<P>
"It is an important exercise and it is good that it is happening at this time,"
Defence Minister Ehud Barak said.
</P>
<P>
The manoeuvres were first held in the aftermath of the July-August 2006 war with
Lebanon's Hezbollah militia, which revealed major weaknesses in how the Jewish
state's homefront dealt with the rocket attacks.
</P>
<P>
"The Second Lebanon War revealed that the homefront was not well prepared for
war and citizens found it hard to adapt to the special situation," Dror said.
</P>
<P>
Deputy Defence Minister Matan Vilnai told army radio on Sunday that "our enemies
think that the rear is our weak point, we have to reinforce this front and be
ready to face any situation."
</P>
<P>
The drill comes just two weeks after the air force wrapped up a massive four-day
exercise that tested its ability to defend against missile and jet strikes from
Syria and Iran.
</P>
<P>
It was the first time the army has simulated strikes from the Islamic republic,
located more than 1,000 kilometres (620 miles) away.
</P>
<P>
Israel considers Iran its biggest threat and is a leading campaigner against its
nuclear programme, which it suspects is a cover for ambitions to build atomic
weapons, charges vehemently denied by Tehran.
</P>
<P>
The Jewish state is itself regarded as having the strongest military in the
Middle East and is believed to have a nuclear arsenel which it has never
confirmed or denied.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Once mighty US auto industry faces day of reckoning
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Washington, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The once mighty US auto industry faces a day of reckoning on Monday with the
looming bankruptcy of General Motors and an expected court ruling on the sale of
Chrysler to a group led by Italy's Fiat.
</P>
<P>
The global economic crisis has hit the US industry hard, prompting massive
intervention by President Barack Obama's administration to prevent total
collapse and a new blow to the nation's economy, which is already in recession.
</P>
<P>
A government rescue plan for GM could put as much as 72.5 percent of the
country's biggest automaker under state ownership.
</P>
<P>
With the hours counting down for GM, company bondholders with slightly more than
50 percent of GM’s 27.2 billion dollars in bond debt voted Saturday in support
of the restructuring plan, The New York Times reported.
</P>
<P>
Among the backers was a committee of large investors holding about 20 percent of
GM’s outstanding bonds, The Times said.
</P>
<P>
No official announcement of the vote tally has yet been made.
</P>
<P>
Under the plan, the bondholders would obtain the rights to buy an extra 15
percent of GM's stock at a low price. They would also control 25 percent of the
new GM, after having supported the new company's creation in bankruptcy court.
</P>
<P>
Recalcitrant bondholders who opt for confrontation rather than cooperation "will
get nothing or very little," an Obama administration official told reporters
Thursday.
</P>
<P>
Government-backed restructuring in bankruptcy court for GM, once the world's
largest automaker, appeared all but certain.
</P>
<P>
Monday marks a deadline imposed by the Obama administration for the company to
submit a viable restructuring plan or file for bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile, a US bankruptcy court judge in New York was widely expected to
approve a deal between Chrysler and Fiat on Monday.
</P>
<P>
The third biggest US automaker has declared bankruptcy and is seeking a tie-up
with Fiat in a plan presented as the only way to save the company from
liquidation.
</P>
<P>
Developments at Chrysler could provide an example for restructuring at GM, which
will similarly have to sell some of its brands and close many dealerships.
</P>
<P>
But the administration official said a 60- to 90-day timeframe was "better" for
GM, contrasted with the fast-track process for Chrysler, which filed for
bankruptcy protection on April 30.
</P>
<P>
"This is a much more complicated company than Chrysler, as a global company.
It's three times the size," noted the official.
</P>
<P>
The United Auto Workers (UAW) union said Friday its members ratified a deal to
allow GM to radically cut costs and its debt load, clearing the way for a quick
exit from the expected bankruptcy filing.
</P>
<P>
GM also announced plans to retool an idled US plant to build small cars it had
originally planned to import, and two more US assembly plants could  potentially
be saved.
</P>
<P>
The automaker, which normally shuts downs plants for two weeks during the
summer, is planning longer-than-normal closures at a variety of facilities this
summer, The Detroit Free Press reported.
</P>
<P>
Some factories will be shut down for as long as nine weeks, according to the
newspaper report. This week, about eight out of its 15 assembly plants will be
running.
</P>
<P>
The bankruptcy filing could also be sped up by a deal struck Saturday after
marathon talks that saw Canadian parts maker Magna and its Russian backers
taking over GM's Opel.
</P>
<P>
The deal for GM's European operations, brokered by the German government,
amounted to a major development in the remaking of the global auto industry.
</P>
<P>
GM employs some 50,000 people throughout Europe and Magna plans to cut about a
fifth.
</P>
<P>
German Chancellor Angela Merkel, whose government agreed to stump billions of
euros (dollars) in loan guarantees and emergency loans to keep the ailing Opel
afloat, acknowledged that talks over the future of GM Europe had sometimes been
difficult.
</P>
<P>
Germany's Finance Minister Peer Steinbrueck had even denounced what he called
"scandalous" US negotiating tactics.
</P>
<P>
Yet despite what she called "huge mismanagement" by GM executives, a telephone
call to Obama helped seal the deal, Merkel said.
</P>
<P>
As for Chrysler, a new company could be born within days of approval for
bankruptcy. The Treasury said it had transferred 6.9 billion dollars in public
funds to New Carco, a newly created company to acquire Chrysler's "good assets."
</P>
<P>
If presiding judge Arthur Gonzalez rules against Chrysler, it faces a grim
future, with a worst-case scenario being Fiat abandoning the tie-up and the US
automaker going into liquidation, with massive job losses.
</P>
<P>
Legal appeals were expected if Gonzalez ruled in favor, meaning possible new
delays. Fiat has said it might back out if the transaction is not completed by
June 15.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Turks suspicious of West, radical Islam: poll
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Ankara, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Turks covet religion and are deeply suspicious of the West, but believe radical
Islam poses threats to their country and the world, according to a poll
published Sunday.
</P>
<P>
An overwhelming majority of poll respondents -- 76 and 86 percent respectively
-- believe the European Union and the United States aim to divide their country,
Milliyet newspaper reported.
</P>
<P>
Turkey is seeking to join the EU and the United States is among the country's
NATO allies.
</P>
<P>
The survey, conducted by Istanbul's Bahcesehir University among 1,715 people in
April and May, found that 62 percent see religion as their top value, followed
by secularism and democracy at 16 and 13 percent respectively.
</P>
<P>
Sixty-two percent said it was appropriate for Muslim women to cover their heads
outside home, while 58 percent considered it a "sin" for women to wear bathsuits
at the beach, Milliyet reported.
</P>
<P>
Seventy-two percent said they would not wish to have alcohol-consuming
neighbours.
</P>
<P>
Some 66 percent said they would not welcome non-religious neighbours and 67
percent said the same for unmarried couples living together, Milliyet reported.
</P>
<P>
The poll found that 64 percent do not wish to live next door to a Jew, 52
percent to a Christian, 42 percent to an American and 26 percent to anyone of a
different ethnicity or race.
</P>
<P>
But despite their conservative inclinations, the majority also expressed fears
over radical Islam and attacks on democracy.
</P>
<P>
Sixty-nine percent said extremist Islamist movements pose either a "great" or a
"certain" threat to Turkey, and a slightly smaller majority believed so for the
world.
</P>
<P>
About 80 percent said "anti-democratic actions and thoughts" are a threat for
Turkey.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Football: Bordeaux's champion vintage ripens with Blanc
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Bordeaux, which produces an estimated 700 million bottles of wine each year, may
be best known in gastronomic circles for its distinct clarets.
</P>
<P>
But in the world of French football this year's top vintage is a Blanc.
</P>
<P>
In leading Bordeaux to the French league title for the first time in a decade
Laurent Blanc has pulled off a double coup.
</P>
<P>
Not only has he taken the Girondins to glory in only his second season as a
coach but the 43-year-old from Ales has also managed to cure a bout of
nationwide yawning stretching back to 2002.
</P>
<P>
That year, Lyon won their first ever league title after some near misses and
romped past all-comers for the next six years.
</P>
<P>
But this year was no one horse race, with Blanc's men landing the crown after a
final-day win over relegated Caen gave them 80 points from 38 matches to 77 for
Marseille and 71 for Lyon, who next season will have to play in the Champions
League qualifiers.
</P>
<P>
"I am really delighted," said Blanc, who pinpointed the win over Lyon five weeks
ago as the moment he felt his men were destined to end up as top dogs.
</P>
<P>
"Last year we lost both matches to Lyon, our direct rivals, even if maybe we
didn't deserve to. Then, when Marseille lost to Lyon, that opened the way up for
us," noted Blanc, a mainstay of the French side which won the 1998 World Cup and
Euro 2000.
</P>
<P>
Blanc, who suggested it would be very difficult to replicate Lyon's long run of
titles, said rigorous hard work in training over the winter had been key.
</P>
<P>
"We really put in some physical grind in January. What also helped was that we
only really realised quite late in the day just what a great run we were on, so
we were under less pressure. And mentally we were very strong - several times we
turned things around right at the death when things weren't going well."
</P>
<P>
Two defeats in their first four games saw Bordeaux make not the brightest of
starts and by the end of September they had eight points to make up on Lyon, who
retained the margin going into December.
</P>
<P>
A pre-Christmas purple patch saw Bordeaux close to within three points but draws
against struggling Grenoble and Saint Etienne held up progress as Marseille
soared into top spot.
</P>
<P>
By April, Lyon were fading, their confidence dented by yet another failure to
impress in Europe as Barcelona dumped them easily in the Champions League second
phase, leaving Bordeaux and Marseille to scrap it out.
</P>
<P>
Lyon then ultimately did Bordeaux a decisive favour with a May 17 win at
Marseille's seething Stade Velodrome to prepare the coronation which came with
Saturday's denouement, Yoan Gouffran securing the title after a club record 11th
consecutive league win.
</P>
<P>
Gilding Bordeaux's lily was a League Cup win in April while a further bonus was
last week's signing up of star playmaker Yoann Gourcuff, who had only been on
loan from AC Milan and who has been the French league's shining star this term.
</P>
<P>
But now they will be judged on whether they can do what Lyon have consistently
failed to do - make a good impression in the Champions League.
</P>
<P>
Lyon have never made it past the quarter-finals while 1993 winners Marseille
remain the only French side to lift the European Cup.
</P>
<P>
Despite his relative touchline inexperience going into that challenge, Blanc
will take heart from the success of Barcelona's 38-year-old Pep Guardiola, who
outfoxed Sir Alex Ferguson to land the trophy in his debut season as a coach.
</P>
<P>
For Bordeaux, triumphing in Europe will demand a different, more elastic
mentality from that which suffices for domestic fare and they will be only too
aware the transition has traditionally proved awkward for French clubs.
</P>
<P>
That might be down to cultural issues for, as any Frenchman knows, the first
course is normally washed down with a glass of rouge.
</P>
<P>
But with Blanc's coaching genius out of the bottle, Bordeaux are now eying
dessert.
</P>
<P>
That would normally mean sampling any one of a host of the south west's finest
vins blancs - although lifting the Champions League would surely demand an
'upgrade' to champagne.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Indian court rules schools can bar Sikhs who pluck eyebrows
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
New Delhi, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
An Indian court has upheld a decision by a religious body to deny a female
student who plucked her eyebrows admission to a Sikh university, media reports
said Sunday.
</P>
<P>
The ruling said faith-based educational institutions had the right to refuse
admission to students who did not meet religious standards, as "maintaining hair
unshorn is an essential component of the Sikh religion," according to the Press
Trust of India.
</P>
<P>
The policy had been challenged by Gurleen Kaur after she was denied admission to
the Sri Guru Ram Das Institute of Medical Sciences and Research in the Sikh holy
city of Amritsar.
</P>
<P>
Kaur was excluded on the grounds that she was not a "true Sikh as she was
plucking her eyebrows," according to the Times of India.
</P>
<P>
Sikhism requires men and women to keep their hair uncut at all times, and many
men sport lengthy beards and wear turbans to cover their long hair.
</P>
<P>
Kaur's petition was supported by male students who had also been refused
admission to the university because they trimmed their beards.
</P>
<P>
The Punjab and Haryana High Court, which jointly serves both states, said it was
"perfectly legitimate" for Sikh organisations to refuse any benefit to members
of the community who did not strictly adhere to religious tenets.
</P>
<P>
Avtar Singh Makkar, the head of the Sikh body which administers the college in
Amritsar, said he was happy with the judgment.
</P>
<P>
"Our stand that unshorn hair is of paramount importance for Sikhs has been
vindicated," the Times quoted him as saying.
</P>
<P>
About 24 million people follow the Sikh faith in India, with a majority of them
living in the state of Punjab.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Sri Lanka rejects rights probe after crushing Tigers
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Colombo, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Sri Lanka on Sunday rejected growing calls to probe human rights violations amid
allegations that thousands of civilians perished in the final battle against
Tamil separatists.
</P>
<P>
Media Minister Lakshman Yapa Abeywardena said organisations calling for
investigations had "ulterior motives," and dismissed demands for independent
probes into the final phase of Sri Lanka's war against Tamil separatists.
</P>
<P>
"Those who give various civilian casualty figures and call for these probes must
have ulterior motives," Abeywardena told reporters here.
</P>
<P>
He said the government itself was in the process of assessing the civilian
casualties, but gave no figures.
</P>
<P>
"Our officials knew how many people were in the (war zone) area and we are
taking a tally on the number of people now in the IDP (internally displaced
persons) camps," Abeywardena said.
</P>
<P>
His remarks came a day after the London-based rights group, Amnesty
International, called for an independent probe into the number of civilians
killed while government forces crushed Tamil Tiger rebels two weeks ago.
</P>
<P>
Amnesty also urged the United Nations to reveal its own estimates for civilian
casualties.
</P>
<P>
The rights group's Asia Pacific director Sam Zarifi accused both sides of war
crimes and called for an independent international probe.
</P>
<P>
A report in the Times of London newspaper on Friday citing confidential UN
reports said that more than 20,000 non-combatants were killed by Sri Lankan army
shelling in May.
</P>

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, May 31, 2009 (AFP)

Pakistan's defence secretary said Sunday that a month-long offensive to crush

</P>

</P>

<HEADLINE>
Thousands hit by diarrhoea outbreak after Bangladesh cyclone
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
KOYRA, Bangladesh, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
An outbreak of diarrhoea has spread across Bangladesh's south-west after a
cyclone slammed into the south of the country and neighbouring India earlier in
the week, officials said Sunday.
</P>
<P>
At least 237 people were killed after Cyclone Aila on Monday hit the low-lying
coast north of the Bay of Bengal, where a military and civilian relief operation
is now underway.
</P>
<P>
Doctors said diarrhoea had broken out at an "alarming rate" as inundation and
waterlogging in a vast swathe of land close to the world's largest mangrove
forest Sundarbans has destroyed supplies of drinking water.
</P>
<P>
In the worst affected Koyra, Dakope and Khulna districts at least two people
have died and over 5000 people treated for diarrhoea, half in the last 24 hours,
regional medical chief Lutfur Rahman Khan told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"The situation is alarming. So far we have more than 5000 people who are sick
with diarrhoea in this region. Another 3000 have been treated for water borne
diseases like dysentery," Khan said.
</P>
<P>
Khan said breached levees and washed away embankments enabled tidal seawater to
inundate the region, destroying almost all sources of fresh drinking water.
</P>
<P>
"The crisis is worsening every day. People are leaving their villages for cities
and towns," he said.
</P>
<P>
In neighbouring Satkhira district doctors have treated over 2000 cases of
diarrhoea since the cyclone hit, again with half the cases reported in the last
24 hours, head of the district medical service Mohammad Ibadullah said.
</P>
<P>
The government said it has dispatched nearly 900 medical teams to tackle the
crisis but charities and local officials warned any improvement would depend on
how soon the authorities can rebuild the destroyed embankments.
</P>
<P>
The army had brought in fresh water supplies but not enough for the cyclone
victims.
</P>
<P>
On Saturday Oxfam's Bangladesh operations chief Heather Blackwell called the
situation "an emerging humanitarian crisis. And it's getting worse every day,"
adding more than one million people had been affected.
</P>
<P>
Some 167 people died in Bangladesh, where hundreds of thousands of homes were
damaged or destroyed, while 70 people were killed in India as a result of the
cyclone.
</P>
<P>
Of those killed in India's West Bengal state, 20 were killed in mudslides caused
by rainfall a day after the storm hit.
</P>
<P>
The low-lying region frequently experiences tropical storms and cyclones during
the monsoon season. In 2007, more than 3,500 people were killed, most of them in
Bangladesh, when Cyclone Sidr lashed the same districts.
</P>

HANOI, May 31, 2009 (AFP)

Vietnam has recorded its first case of swine flu after a man tested positive for

Nguyen Huy Nga told AFP, adding that the case was "confirmed officially by our
ministry this morning."
</P>

was positive, and two follow-up tests at the city's Pasteur Institute confirmed
the diagnosis, Phan Van Tu, a doctor with the Institute, told AFP.
</P>

Tu added.
</P>
<P>

the United States via Hong Kong.
</P>
<P>
The World Health Organization (WHO) said it had been formally notified of the
case.
</P>
<P>
It said the patient sought medical attention after noticing flu symptoms a day
after returning from the United States. Five members of his family have been
given medication and placed in isolation, while passengers on the same flight as
the man are being tracked down, the WHO said.
</P>
<P>
Emergence of the virus in Vietnam was "highly likely" given the country's
international travel links, Shelaye Boothey, a WHO spokeswoman, told AFP.
</P>
<P>
Vietnam has been monitoring the health of passengers arriving at its airports in
a bid to detect swine flu.
</P>
<P>
The virus was first detected last month in the United States and Mexico.
</P>
<P>
In its latest update the WHO said 53 countries had reported 15,510 cases of
swine flu, including 99 deaths.

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0307" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Europe's desperate bid to bring out voters
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
brussels, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
European leaders on Sunday stepped up a desperate battle to persuade people to
vote for the EU parliament this week, but the campaign has opened up new
political divisions across the continent.
</P>
<P>
With polls indicating a record low turnout for the June 4-7 election, French
President Nicolas Sarkozy and German Chancellor Angela Merkel issued a joint
plea to voters, saying a strong parliament was essential to confront the
economic crisis.
</P>
<P>
The two leaders said they want "a strong Europe that protects" its people and
called for "all Europeans to vote" in the statement, published by the Journal du
Dimanche newspaper in France and Die Welt am Sonntag in Germany.
</P>
<P>
A "strong Europe does not necessarily mean more powers for the European Union,
even more European legislation or even more financial means," said Merkel and
Sarkozy.
</P>
<P>
First steps "to assure real European regulation in the financial sector, based
on coordination and cooperation between regulators" should be taken at the next
EU summit in June, they said.
</P>
<P>
"For speculative funds, tax havens, payment for executives and financial
traders, we want an exemplary Europe," they added.
</P>
<P>
The pair also gave strong backing to the Lisbon reform treaty, intended to
streamline EU decision-making but deadlocked by Ireland's rejection in a
referendum last year.
</P>
<P>
"Europe must play a leading role in the world. For that, it must have efficient
institutions. That is why we need the Lisbon Treaty," they said.
</P>
<P>
Merkel and Sarkozy also reaffirmed opposition to Turkey joining the EU, without
naming the country. "To be able to act, the EU needs frontiers. Unlimited
enlargement is not possible."
</P>
<P>
The joint statement highlighted fears that the vote for the 736 member European
assembly could prove a new embarrassment for the 27-nation European Union, after
a record 45 percent abstention at the last election in 2004.
</P>
<P>
In France, a poll for the Le Parisien newspaper Sunday suggested that 55 percent
of the nation's would not bother going to the polls. In Britain, Poland and
Romania, fewer than one in three plan to vote, according to recent surveys.
</P>
<P>
In Spain, which has benefited enormously from EU development funds, political
analysts expect turnout of 40 percent at best. Portugal expects a record
abstention rate.
</P>
<P>
The stakes are higher now, however, as the European Parliament -- the only
directly elected EU institution -- will have a bigger voice in decisions that
affect 500 million Europeans if the Lisbon treaty comes into force.
</P>
<P>
"A lot of voters don't understand what the European Parliament does," said
Philip White, senior research fellow at the Centre for European Reform think-
tank in London.
</P>
<P>
"You're not voting to keep a government in office or kick it out. The stakes can
seem a little bit less clear than they are in national elections."
</P>
<P>
But in many countries the EU vote will be a test of the national governments in
power, with far-right and left-wing parties expected to benefit from protest
votes and low turnouts in some member states.
</P>
<P>
In Britain, where euroscepticism runs deep, the governing Labour Party is
expected to garner only 16 to 17 percent of the vote, putting it in third place
against the rival Conservatives and Liberal Democrats, weekend polls in the
Times and Sunday Telegraph suggested.
</P>
<P>
The leader of the main opposition Conservatives, David Cameron, has opened up
new divisions in Europe by saying he would withdraw his party from the main
centre-right bloc in the EU parliament, the European People's Party (EPP), and
join a new eurosceptic alliance with Czech and Polish parties.
</P>
<P>
The EPP is still expected to remain the biggest single party in the parliament,
which already has a key role approving the EU budget and passing laws on a wide
range of issues.
</P>
<P>
The parliament will also endorse the new president of the European Commission
after a nomination is made by the EU summit. Jose Manuel Barroso, the
conservative former Portuguese prime minister, is widely expected to get a
second term.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Niger president in 'dangerous' bid to keep power
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
niamey, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The Niger president's dismissal of parliament and plans for a referendum to
allow him a third term have sparked deep concern, with the opposition calling it
a coup bid in the uranium-producing nation.
</P>
<P>
Mamadou Tandja, a former colonel elected president in 1999 following a military
coup, on Friday announced he would go ahead with plans for a referendum on a new
constitution.
</P>
<P>
If approved, it would allow him to stay in power after his second five-year term
expires on December 22.
</P>
<P>
His announcement came after the Constitutional Court, the nation's highest, said
Monday it was opposed to the holding of the referendum.
</P>
<P>
On Tuesday, Tandja dissolved parliament, which was reportedly on the verge of
objecting to his plans, before it could make its position known. Tandja, 71, did
not give a date for the referendum.
</P>
<P>
The moves caused alarm at both home and abroad.
</P>
<P>
Niger's main opposition group said it sees Tanjda's determination to push ahead
with the referendum despite the refusal of the nation's highest court and the
reluctance of parliament as being tantamount to a coup.
</P>
<P>
"Right from the minute Tandja says he was calling a referendum, he ... loses his
legitimacy as he'll have proclaimed a coup. We will treat him as a mere
putschist," Hassoumi Massaoudou of the Niger Party for Democracy and Socialism
(PNDS) said.
</P>
<P>
Tandja took part in the 1974 coup that toppled the country's first civilian
president, Diori Hamani, and was a pillar of the military regime that governed
Niger until the advent of multi-party politics in 1991.
</P>
<P>
Both the United States and Canada expressed concern about the developments in
the country, which despite being a major uranium producer has also been one of
the world's poorest nations.
</P>
<P>
"We believe this risks undercutting Niger's hard won social, political, and
economic gains of the past decade, and would be a set-back for democracy, based
on the regular, peaceful transition of political power and faithful adherence to
constitutional due-process," said US State Department spokesman Ian Kelly.
Canadian Foreign Minister Lawrence Cannon said in a statement that his country
was following the events "with concern" and "considers that respect for the
integrity of democratic institutions and mechanisms is paramount to a firm
commitment to democracy."
</P>
<P>
One analyst said the president's actions were a reminder of past turmoil.
</P>
<P>
"The history of Niger has shown that once there is political impasse ... the
military tends to intervene," Abubakar Sadiq, a political science professor at
Ahmadu Bello University in Zaria in neighbouring Nigeria, told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"This is why what Tandja is doing is very, very dangerous.
</P>
<P>
"Tandja of course belongs to the military class, being a former colonel ... but
that is not a guarantee the military will not strike."
</P>
<P>
Parliamentarians from French-speaking countries, meeting in Dakar earlier this
week, also called for the "strict respect" of Niger's constitution.
</P>
<P>
The regional grouping the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS)
warned that Niger could face sanctions if it forged ahead with the referendum.
</P>
<P>
But Libyan leader and current African Union head Moamer Khadafi, himself in
power for the past four decades, was more understanding of Tandja's position.
</P>
<P>
"If the people decide the president deserves to be re-elected, they can choose
him once, three times or even 10 times," he said at a regional summit Friday.
</P>
<P>
Sadiq said "the world should not keep quiet and allow the rape of democracy
again in Niger."
</P>
<P>
"The situation in Niger Republic is symptomatic of a trend in Africa where
democracy is not well entrenched. Virtually all African leaders don't respect
democratic institutions, they only want to remain in power until they die," he
said.
</P>
<P>
"Pressure has to be brought to bear on Tandja by the whole Nigerian nation, the
African Union and the international community to respect the constitution of
Niger Republic."
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Israel fumes over US settlement demands
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Jerusalem, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Israel refused on Sunday to bow to US calls for a freeze to all settlement
activity in the occupied West Bank, as it fumed over the "unfair" demands that
have raised tensions between the close allies.
</P>
<P>
"I want to say in a crystal clear manner that the current Israeli government
will not accept in any fashion that legal settlement activity be frozen," said
Transport Minister Yisrael Katz, a close ally of Prime Minister Benjamin
Netanyahu.
</P>
<P>
The premier himself did not address the issue at the opening of the weekly
cabinet meeting, but the fighting words were echoed by other members of the
largely right-wing cabinet, including from its most liberal party Labour.
</P>
<P>
A senior Israeli official complained that Washington under President Barack
Obama -- who has vowed to pursue Middle East peace talks as part of a changed
approach to the region -- was placing unfair demands on its close ally.
</P>
<P>
"The Americans have demanded almost nothing from the Palestinians but are asking
Israel to take steps that are a real sacrifice. These demands are unfair," he

</P>
<P>
"The Palestinians are taking a passive approach. They're not even ready to meet
the Israeli side and Abu Mazen (Palestinian president Mahmud Abbas) wants the
Americans to do all the work," he said.
</P>
<P>
Abbas, who met Obama last week, 10 days after the US president met Netanyahu,
has vowed that that he will not relaunch talks unless Israel freezes settlements
in the occupied West Bank.
</P>
<P>
The Obama administration has demanded that Israel stop all its activity in the
settlements, including the so-called natural growth construction that allows for
building to accommodate a growing population.
</P>

president could put pressure on the Jewish state as part of his new approach to

</P>
<P>

accept," Interior Minister Eli Yishai of the ultra-Orthodox Shas party.
</P>
<P>
Social Affairs Minister Isaac Herzog of the centre-left Labour party that is the
most liberal in Netanyahu's government, said that "one has to understand that
there are various statuses within the settlements" and "saying that the picture
is black and white or write or wrong is wrong."
</P>
<P>
More than 280,000 Israelis live in settlements dotted throughout the West Bank,
which Israeli captured in war in 1967. The international community considers all
settlements illegal.
</P>
<P>
Israeli officials have also complained that Obama's administration has yet to
say it will honour commitments in a letter that then US president George W. Bush
sent to then Israeli premier Ariel Sharon in 2004.
</P>
<P>
Bush said that given the existence of major Israeli settlement blocs in the West
Bank it was "unrealistic" to expect Israel to fully withdraw from the territory
as part of a final peace deal.
</P>
<P>
"This administration has not yet recognised the arrangements made between the
Israeli government and the Bush administration," said Katz. "That can only raise
concerns over future arrangements."
</P>
<P>
Aside from the settlements, there is stark disagreement between Washington and
Israel over the creation of a Palestinian state, with Obama repeatedly saying he
was committed to the principle and Netanyahu thus far refusing to endorse it in
public.

<HEADLINE>
French physicists claim breakthrough in ultra-fast data access
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
French physicists said on Sunday they had used ultra-fast lasers that could
accelerate storage and retrieval of data on hard discs by up to 100,000 times,
pointing the way to a new generation of IT wizardry.
</P>
<P>
The research builds on achievements that earned the 2007 Nobel physics prize for
Albert Fert of France and Peter Gruenberg of Germany, who ushered in a
revolution in miniaturised storage in the 1990s.
</P>
<P>
Fert and Gruenberg discovered that tiny changes in magnetic fields can yield a
large electric output.
</P>
<P>
These differences in turn cause changes in the current in the readout head that
scans a hard disk to spot the ones and zeroes in which data is stored.
</P>
<P>
That discovery opened the way to "spintronics", a form of electronics that uses
not only electrical charge but also the spin of electrons in individual atoms to
provide a more compact, denser storage on hard drives.
</P>
<P>
But reading and writing data through spintronics has been hampered by the
relative slowness of magnetic sensors.
</P>
<P>
In a study published in the specialist journal Nature Physics, a team led by
Jean-Yves Bigot of the Institute of Materials Physics and Chemistry in
Strasbourg employed a "femtosecond" laser, using ultra-fast bursts of laser
light, to alter electron spin and thus speed up retrieval and storage.
</P>
<P>
"Our method is called the photonics of spin, because it is photons [particles of
light] that modify the state of the electrons' magnetisation" on the storage
surface, Bigot told AFP.
</P>
<P>
Data is retrieved with a burst that lasts just a millionth of a billionth of a
second, said Bigot.
</P>
<P>
Femtosecond lasers currently measure around 30 centimetres (12 inches) by 10
centimetres (four inches) which means they are too big for consumer electronics,
he cautioned.
</P>
<P>
Bigot added, though, that their miniaturisation is likely to be achieved over
the next decade.
</P>
<P>
IBM, Hitachi and other corporations are "extremely interested" by the research,
Bigot said.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0316" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
First genes spotted for testicular cancer
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Scientists in Britain said Sunday they had found the first genes that are
associated with testicular cancer, the commonest form of cancer for men between
the ages of 15 and 45.
</P>
<P>
Telltale variants in chromosomes 5, 6 and 12 are linked with an increased risk
of the disease, according to their study, which compared the genetic code of 730
men who had testicular cancer with that of healthy men.
</P>
<P>
Inheriting the basket of three factors boosts the risk of the cancer, called
testicular gem cell tumour, by up to fourfold.
</P>
<P>
The study is published online in the journal Nature Genetics.
</P>
<P>
"We have known for some time that men whose father, brothers or sons had
testicular cancer are much more likely to get it themselves and we have been
searching for this genetic link," said one of the investigators, Elizabeth
Rapley of the Institute of Cancer Research, in the southern English county of
Surrey.
</P>
<P>
"We believe there are more (risk factors) still to be found and we are working
on identifying the rest."
</P>
<P>
The three telltales lie near genes that nurture testicular cells which are
precursors in sperm development.
</P>
<P>
Worldwide incidence of testicular cancer is 7.5 cases per 100,000 men, but the
rates vary remarkably between countries and according to ancestry, the ICR said
in a press release.
</P>
<P>
Why this is so is unclear. Inheritance, though, is a well-known risk factor and
seems to be far higher than for other cancer types.
</P>
<P>
Studies have found that the risk to brothers of testicular cancer patients is
eight to 10 times higher than the general population, while for fathers of
patients, the risk is four to six times higher.
</P>
<P>
Testicular cancer is 99 percent curable if caught in its early stages, the ICR
said.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Iran's city of migrants set for intense vote battle
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ISLAMSHAHR, Iran, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
With less than two weeks until Iran's presidential election, Islamshahr -- a
city of migrant workers on the outskirts of Tehran -- is gearing up for an
intense election battle.
</P>
<P>
Located southwest of the capital, Islamshahr, a city of 500,000 inhabitants, had
largely voted for Mahmoud Ahmadinejad during the 2005 presidential poll.
</P>
<P>
But four years on, the situation has changed in the city of migrants who have
come from various provinces of Iran to earn a livelihood.
</P>
<P>
Ahmadinejad, who is seeking a second term in office, is still popular in
Islamshahr, but his key challenger in the June 12 poll -- former prime minister
Mir Hossein Mousavi -- is making deep inroads.
</P>
<P>
While the incumbent conservative president appears to be assured of the support
of middle and lower income voters, Mousavi is gaining popularity among the
city's shopkeepers and traders.
</P>
<P>
He was due to address a campaign rally in the city on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
"He is a good man. During the war, he handled the situation very well," said
Hamzeh Shirzad, 38, speaking about Mousavi who was Iran's prime minister in the
1980s when Iran fought an eight-year war with Iraq.
</P>
<P>
Mousavi is regarded as having steering Iran's economy efficiently during the
war, which erupted when the Islamic revolution that toppled the shah was still
in an infant stage.
</P>
<P>
Shirzad, who owns a fruit and vegetable shop in the centre of Islamshahr, is
clear of his choice for president.
</P>
<P>
A green poster bearing a picture of Mousavi adorns the wall behind him as he
sorts vegetables in a rather empty shop. Green is the colour of Mousavi's
election campaign.
</P>
<P>
Large banners and posters of Mousavi have sprung up in the dusty streets of
Islamshahr, where ethnic Turkish-speaking Azeris and Kurds mingle with Persians.
</P>
<P>
In recent years the city -- which saw violent demonstrations in 2000 by
residents protesting against poor living conditions -- has also attracted
numerous young Tehran couples unable to afford high rents in the capital.
</P>
<P>
Pictures of Mousavi, who was Iran's last premier before the post was scrapped in
1989, have been plastered on street lights, stalls and shop windows.
</P>
<P>
Over the past two decades Mousavi, a moderate, has been in the political
wilderness, but he is now attempting a comeback and has emerged as the main
rival to conservative Ahmadinejad.
</P>
<P>
"The economy is in crisis again and he is the right man to stop it from
worsening," said Shirzad, an ethnic Azeri who has been living in Islamshahr for
more than 20 years.
</P>
<P>
"Last year I used to earn five million rials (500 dollars) a month. Now I am
losing money," said the fruit and vegetable vendor.
</P>
<P>
"The prices of all food items have doubled. A kilo of watermelon used to cost
3,500 rials (35 cents). It now costs 7,000 rials," he said. "I will definitely
vote for Mousavi."
</P>
<P>
His view is shared by Ali Karimi, a 23-year-old factory worker.
</P>
<P>
"Mousavi is the right choice. Even if the situation remains bad, he can stop it
from worsening."
</P>
<P>
Energy-rich Iran is reeling under an inflation rate of about 25 percent amid the

a single digit if he is elected.
</P>
<P>

<P>

<P>

monthly pension of 4.2 million rials after the election.

Mousavi's absence from politics since 1989 is seen as a negative point by

</P>
<P>
"We do not know what he did in these 20 years, while Ahmadinejad has done good
for workers. We will vote for him," he said.

<P>

</P>
<P>

the poor."

<HEADLINE>
Slack rebuilding angers battered South Ossetia
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
TSKHINVALI, Georgia, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The windows of the houses are still blown-out, rusting armaments are everyday
objects in the streets and the only heating in a bitter winter came from wood-
burning stoves.
</P>
<P>
Residents of Tskhinvali -- the "capital" of Georgia's breakaway region of South
Ossetia battered in the August war between Moscow and Tbilisi -- could be
forgiven for wondering if anything has changed in the last nine months.
</P>
<P>
Russia vowed to plough hundreds of millions of dollars into the region of 50,000
people high in the Caucasus mountains after recognising South Ossetia's
independence. But the legacy of the fighting remains all too apparent.
</P>
<P>
"Half of Tskhinvali is destroyed and nothing has been done. Russia sent money,
but it's up to the government to build things," complained Nadar Sokhrebov, 70.
</P>
<P>
A GRAD rocket still leans propped against the wall of his stone house, gutted in
the fighting. Since August, he has lived squeezed with 10 family members in a
one-room cottage previously used for storage.
</P>
<P>
The sheared-off top of a tank has been left upright in the centre of the rebel
capital Tskhinvali as a monument to the recent war.
</P>
<P>
In the city's old Jewish quarter -- an area rocked by the heaviest fighting
after the Georgian assault on August 8 to restore its control over South Ossetia
-- homes crumpled by rocket fire look as they did last summer.
</P>
<P>
As the region votes Sunday in legislative elections marked by the sidelining of
the opposition to rebel president Eduard Kokoity, questions are mounting over
what the local authorities have done with Moscow's money.
</P>
<P>
"Those who don't have their own means to rebuild are just waiting and waiting
for when the government does something," said Anna Parastayeva, adding her
husband had bought all the materials to patch up their own home.
</P>
<P>
"A fact is a fact -- people lived through the winter as if they were on the
street, with it all leaking into their homes. That is what I saw," she sighed.
</P>
<P>
Only two days ago, some ruined houses were bulldozed in the authorities' first
moves at housing reconstruction, residents said.
</P>
<P>
Russia has budgeted over 10 billion rubles (320 million dollars, 230 million
euros) in postwar reconstruction funds to the region on top of subsidies put
aside before the conflict in 2008.
</P>
<P>
Kokoity acknowledged that there were "specific problems" and the first phase of
the reconstruction did not include private homes. But he insisted that the
process was now on track.
</P>
<P>
"I think that by June 10, South Ossetia will be transformed into one huge
construction site," he said.
</P>
<P>
South Ossetia -- backed by Moscow since it won de-facto autonomy in a first war
in the early 1990s -- more than ever seems a Russian protectorate.
</P>
<P>
Other than Russia, the distant Central American state of Nicaragua is the only
other country to have recognised the rebel region.
</P>
<P>
"True, I can travel to Nicaragua now, but I don't even have a home to go back to
and there's no work there," taxi driver German Zaseyev said sarcastically.
</P>
<P>
Before, residents in this rural region depended on supplies bought in Georgia
and could travel just one hour to Tbilisi for medical help.
</P>
<P>
Now their only outside link is a 120 kilometre (75 mile) drive to Russia over a
winding mountain road often blocked by avalanches throughout the long winter.
</P>
<P>
There is just one factory in South Ossetia that produces building material, a
small asphalt plant, but even it is not often working. Georgia also cut gas
supplies to the region in the wake of the war.
</P>
<P>
After moving between friends' houses for a few weeks at a time all winter,
Gregory Dzassokhov set up a tent in the yard behind his destroyed house on
Khetagurova street for his family this summer.
</P>
<P>
"What are we going to do? Live in the street? They last promised to start
building on June 1, but they have so many houses to rebuild I don't know how
they are going to do it all. Soon I hope," he said.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Japanese take a broom to the Eiffel Tower
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
PARIS, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Donning green vests and yellow gloves, a team of Japanese took the cleanliness
of Paris into their own hands this weekend to sweep up litter around the Eiffel
Tower, the world's most visited landmark.
</P>
<P>
Joined by passers-by of several nationalities, the Green Bird squad -- part of a
volunteer movement in Japanese and European cities -- was aiming to encourage
residents and visitors alike to keep the French capital tidy.
</P>
<P>
"I don't think that Paris is particularly dirty, but it's a good way to set an
example and make our cities clean," said Masataka Tanigawa, 25, a Japanese
expatriate who joined Saturday's effort under a cloud-free sky.
</P>
<P>
Like their counterparts in Berlin, Geneva or London, Greenbird volunteers in
Paris descend on a tourist site every month for an hour-long sweep-up. Past
targets have included the Champs-Elysee and Place de le Concorde.
</P>
<P>
"I like doing this," said El Shafey Ayman, 36, an Egyptian who came with his
Japanese friend. "Cleaning up my city makes me feel like a better person. If
everyone did this, it would be very clean."
</P>
<P>
City councillor Francois Dagnaud joined the effort. "The Japanese have emerged
from urban civilisations; they're a bit more advanced than us," he said. "The
cleanest cities are the ones that people don't litter."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Two cases of swine flu in Turkey: ministry
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ankara, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Two Turks who travelled to the United States have been diagnosed with swine flu
after returning home, the health ministry said.
</P>
<P>
Both had gone to hospitals with complaints of high fever and muscle pain, and
subsequent tests "established they have been infected with swine flu, or
influenza A(HIN1)," the statement said late Saturday.
</P>
<P>
"The patients, whose general condition is good, have been isolated and put under
monitoring."
</P>
<P>
One of the patients was hospitalised in Istanbul after returning from  Houston
via Amsterdam on Friday, while the second was under treatment in the western
port city of Izmir after returning from New York the same day.
</P>
<P>
The health ministry asked passengers on the flights the two patients used to
call a hotline and register themselves for a check-up.
</P>
<P>
Earlier this month, two Iraqi-born US nationals passing from Turkey on their way
from the United States to Iraq were diagnosed with the A(HIN1) virus and treated
in Istanbul for eight days before recovering and being discharged.
</P>
<P>
The 26-year-old man and his mother were hospitalised after thermal cameras, set
up at Istanbul's Ataturk airport as a precaution against the disease, picked up
that the man was running a high fever. The virus was later also detected in the
woman.
</P>
<P>
The disease has killed nearly a hundred and infected over 15,500 people
worldwide, according to World Health Organization (WHO) figures, since it
emerged in the United States and Mexico in late April.

<HEADLINE>
Iran defuses bomb in plane toilet
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Tehran, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Iranian security officials defused a bomb planted on a domestic passenger plane,
officials said on Sunday, the latest incident of violence in the run-up to the
June 12 presidential election.
</P>
<P>
The attempted bomb attack occurred on Saturday on a Kish Air flight headed to
Tehran from the oil-rich western city of Ahvaz near the border with Iraq, the
Fars news agency reported.
</P>
<P>
"Last night, 15 minutes after the plane with 131 passengers took off, flight
security guards found a handmade bomb placed in the lavatory," Fars said. "The
plane landed immediately at Ahvaz airport and the bomb was defused."
</P>
<P>
The incident occurred just two days after a bomb attack on a mosque in
southeastern Iran claimed by a Sunni rebel group killed 25 people, while Ahvaz
itself has witnessed several bouts of unrest in recent years.
</P>
<P>
"Security officials of the Islamic Republic Revolutionary Guards acted well and
the incident caused no casualties," Reza Jafarzadeh, spokesman for Iran's Civil
Aviation Organisation, told the state broadcaster.
</P>
<P>
The passengers were calmed and the plane continued the flight to Tehran, Kish
Air manager Reza Nakhjavani told the ILNA news agency.
</P>
<P>
On Thursday, a suicide bomber killed 25 worshippers and wounded 125 in a Shiite
mosque in Zahedan, capital of the southeastern Sistan-Baluchestan province
bordering Afghanistan and Pakistan.
</P>
<P>
A day later, gunmen on motorbikes fired at an election campaign office of
President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in Zahedan and wounded two campaign members and a
child.
</P>
<P>
The province, which is home to Iran's Baluch minority who adhere to Sunni Islam,
has been the scene of a deadly insurgency by a Sunni rebel group which is
strongly opposed to the government of predominantly Shiite Iran.
</P>
<P>
Iran on Saturday hanged three men in public accused of involvement in Thursday's
mosque bombing, just 48 hours after the attack, which was reported claimed by
the Sunni group Jundullah (Soldiers of God).
</P>
<P>
The mosque attack was reminiscent of a similar outbreak of violence just days
before Iran's last presidential election in 2005 which brought Ahmadinejad to
power.
</P>
<P>
Bombs hit Tehran and Ahvaz, which has a sizable Arab minority, in June 2005,
killing at least eight people and wounding scores more.
</P>
<P>
Ahvaz, the capital of Iran's oil-rich Khuzestan province, which borders Iraq and
the Gulf, was also rocked by ethnic violence in April 2005.
</P>
<P>
Iran in the past has blamed US and British agents in neighbouring Iraq and
Afghanistan for launching attacks on its border provinces with significant
ethnic minority populations.
</P>
<P>
Jalal Sayah, Sistan-Baluchestan's deputy governor, said on Friday that those
arrested over the Zahedan attack were "hired by America and the agents of the
arrogance."
</P>
<P>
Iranian officials usually use the term "global arrogance" to refer to Iran's
arch-foe the United States.
</P>
<P>
But US State Department spokesman Ian Kelly denied Washington was behind the
attack, saying the United States does "not sponsor any form of terrorism in
Iran."
</P>
<P>
Iranian armed forces chief General Hassan Firouzabadi, in comments reported on
Saturday, accused Britain and "Zionists" of involvement in the bombing.
</P>
<P>
Sistan-Baluchestan has a substantial Sunni minority and lies on a major
narcotics-smuggling route from Afghanistan and Pakistan.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Wanted Tiananmen dissident enters Hong Kong
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Hong Kong, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
One of the 21 "most-wanted" Tiananmen Square student protesters has been allowed
to enter Hong Kong, a surprise move ahead of the 20th anniversary of the
crackdown on the demonstrations.
</P>
<P>
Xiong Yan, who was a leading student protester during the 1989 demonstrations in
Beijing and now lives in exile in the United States, was allowed into Hong Kong
without questioning, he said Sunday.
</P>
<P>
"I was very surprised as I have tried many, many times to come," said Xiong, who
arrived Saturday night, the first time he had set foot on Chinese soil in 17
years.
</P>
<P>
"I hope in the future I can not only go to Hong Kong, but also to Beijing," he
added.
</P>
<P>
On Sunday, he took part in an annual March to mark the military crackdown on the
pro-democracy protests and said he would join the candlelight vigil in the city
this Thursday, which is expected to be attended by tens of thousands.
</P>
<P>
The 1989 military crackdown in Beijing followed weeks of protests and left
hundreds, possibly thousands dead across Beijing and led to the imprisonment of
scores of protesters.
</P>
<P>
Xiong, a law graduate, met then-Premier Li Peng during the demonstrations 20
years ago.
</P>
<P>
He was placed on a list of 21 most-wanted students in the weeks after the
crackdown and jailed for two years, before being smuggled out of China via Hong
Kong to the United States.
</P>
<P>
He is now a chaplain in the US army and arrived in the city travelling on a US
passport.
</P>
<P>
In Hong Kong, he was also launching a book about his life, including his role in
the protests and his experiences during the Iraq War, where he was posted in
2004, the Sunday Morning Post said.
</P>
<P>
Several other Tiananmen dissidents have been denied entry to Hong Kong in recent
years, although the city operates a separate legal and immigration system from
mainland China.
</P>
<P>
Commenting on Xiong's entry, chairman of the city's Democratic Party, Albert Ho,
told AFP he was surprised and said it was "probably due to an omission" by the
immigration authorities.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile, a Danish sculptor who flew to Hong Kong to protest the Tiananmen
crackdown has been refused entry to the city.
</P>
<P>
Jens Galschiot, whose sculpture commemorating those who died in 1989, "Pillar of
Shame," is displayed at Hong Kong University, was stopped by officials Saturday,
an immigration spokesman said.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
SKorea, ASEAN to hold summit overshadowed by NKorea threat
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
SEOGWIPO, South Korea, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
South Korea will Monday host one of its biggest-ever diplomatic gatherings,
overshadowed by the growing security threat from North Korea.
</P>
<P>
Seoul planned the ASEAN-Korea Commemorative Summit to promote its "New Asia
Initiative" to strengthen its ties with the continent.
</P>
<P>
But North Korea's relations with its neighbour and the world have worsened
dramatically in recent months.
</P>
<P>
Last week it tested its second nuclear bomb, renounced the truce in force on the
Korean peninsula and threatened attacks on the South.
</P>
<P>
Seoul has heightened vigilance for the June 1-2 meetings with leaders of the
10-nation Association of Southeast Asian Nations on the southern resort island
of Jeju.
</P>
<P>
"During the summit meetings, our military will escalate its alert and mobilise
additional intelligence assets," Lieutenant General Jang Kwang-Il of the Joint
Chiefs of Staff said last week.
</P>
<P>
Military analysts say any North Korean action would likely be staged well away
from Jeju, but timed to coincide with the summit to cause maximum embarrassment.
</P>
<P>
Security was tight, with a surface-to-air missile unit set up next to the
convention centre, checkpoints on major roads and explosives-sniffing dogs.
</P>
<P>
Yonhap news agency said 5,000 police officers are patrolling the island and
operating high-tech chemical detectors. Patrol boats and destroyers were
stationed near the venue.
</P>
<P>
"We are maintaining watertight security to cope with all possible
contingencies," a senior summit organiser told AFP, declining to link the
measures to any potential North Korean threat.
</P>
<P>
Seoul says North Korea will be a topic at the summit, called to mark the 20th
anniversary of relations between South Korea and ASEAN.
</P>
<P>
Leaders will also debate the global financial crisis, climate change and
regional cooperation in trade, economic matters, security and culture.
</P>
<P>
"In recent years, especially as we entered the 21st century, Asia has emerged as
a great power economically and in many other aspects," South Korean President
Lee Myung-Bak said recently.
</P>
<P>
"That is why cooperation within the Asian region is important and that is why it
is especially important to improve ties between Korea and ASEAN."
</P>
<P>
The Southeast Asian leaders will discuss the trial of Myanmar's pro-democracy
leader Aung San Suu Kyi on the sidelines of the summit, Thai Prime Minister
Abhisit Vejjajiva said Sunday in a television programme.
</P>
<P>
ASEAN has been reluctant to speak out against its most notorious member Myanmar,
but in May it expressed "grave concern" over the trial and reiterated its demand
for her freedom.
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi was charged with violating the terms of her house arrest after
an uninvited American swam to her lakeside home. She has been under various
forms of detention without trial for more than 13 of the past 19 years.
</P>
<P>
Some 700 business leaders from the 11 countries began their own summit Sunday.
Abhisit in a keynote speech said Asia and especially East Asia would emerge
relatively stronger from the global downturn.
</P>
<P>
"In my view, the current crisis will not dampen but hasten the rise of Asia as
the centre of growth and prosperity," the Thai prime minister said.
</P>
<P>
South Korea sees ASEAN's almost 600 million people as a market for its export-
dominated economy that can offset the recession in developed countries.
</P>
<P>
The resource-poor nation is also eyeing the bloc's abundant raw materials.
</P>
<P>
ASEAN is already South Korea's third-largest trading partner, with two-way trade
worth around 90 billion dollars last year, and its second-largest destination
for overseas investment.
</P>
<P>
Korean investment in the region was worth 5.86 billion dollars last year.
</P>
<P>
The figures will rise further when the two sides on Tuesday sign an investment
pact, completing negotiations on a free trade agreement which began in 2005.
</P>
</TEXT>
