</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
HERAT, Afghanistan, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Troops killed 12 Taliban linked to a battle with US troops earlier this month
that caused scores of civilian casualties, officials said Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Afghan and US forces raided late Saturday a group of militants said to have
gathered to plan an attack in Afghanistan's southwestern province of Farah, the

</P>
<P>
"Afghan soldiers and US Special Forces surrounded them to arrest them. Taliban
fought back but all of the 12, including their commander, were killed," deputy

</P>
<P>

the US air strikes. The US military acknowledges 20-30 may have died in the
fighting along with 60-65 Taliban.

said the targeted group was involved in the battle in Bala Buluk.

<P>
The militants had also shot rockets into the town of Farah on May 19 when
President Hamid Karzai had visited to meet victims of the air strikes, he said.
</P>

There were reports of rockets fired into the town the night before the visit but
they caused no casualties.
</P>

it one of the deadliest incidents for civilians since international troops
invaded Afghanistan in late 2001 to remove the Taliban for sheltering Al-Qaeda.

did not have a figure, he said.
</P>
<P>

is supported by Islamist fighters from other countries, notably Pakistan.
</P>
<P>
The violence has spiralled in the past three years with 2008 the deadliest.

<TEXT>

</P>
<P>
Boyle put in a shaky performance of "Memory" in the show's semi-finals last
weekend, singing occasionally out of tune and out of time, and some fans on
YouTube questioned whether she could handle the weight of expectations.
</P>
<P>
News media meanwhile reported some erratic behaviour over the past week,
including how she had lost her temper in the foyer of the London hotel where she
was staying.
</P>
<P>
Morgan, a tabloid journalism veteran who forged a friendship with Boyle,
described her in his blog as a "frightened rabbit in headlights" and revealed
she considered quitting the contest.
</P>
<P>

never heard such powerful confident vocals."

global success, with the News of the World saying one of the show's judges,
music promoter Simon Cowell, had big plans for her.

<HEADLINE>

</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
TSKHINVALI, Georgia, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The rebel Georgian region of South Ossetia voted Sunday in polls that could
secure the grip of its separatist leader nine months after it was the subject of
war between Russia and Georgia.
</P>
<P>
The local opposition says Eduard Kokoity is seeking to use the legislative
elections to forge a loyal parliamentary majority to push through an amendment
allowing him to run again for office when his second term lapses next year.
</P>
<P>
Russia -- which outraged the West by recognizing South Ossetia as independent in
the wake of August's war with Georgia  --- has said South Ossetia should not
amend the existing term limits in its constitution.
</P>
<P>
Four parties are competing for the 34 seats in the parliament, but the central
election commission has barred the only two parties not loyal to Kokoity.
</P>
<P>
Opposition activities said voting would not make a difference. "I plan to sit at
home. There's nothing we can do," said Alan Gassiyev, an opposition leader,
calling the polls "completely illegal."
</P>
<P>
"It's too bad if he wants to change the constitution," added Grigory Dzassokhov,
a 55-year old former history teacher. "It would be nonsense. What kind of
democracy is that?"
</P>
<P>
Critics accuse Kokoity, an ex-wrestling champion, of muzzling opponents and
stealing the money sent from Russia.
</P>
<P>
As the region scrambles to rebuild itself in the aftermath of the war, the
opposition accuses Kokoity and his circle of diverting lorries carrying
construction material and humanitarian aid to traffic the goods in Russia.
</P>
<P>
Out of over 10 billion rubles (320 million dollars, 230 million euros) in aid
money budgeted by Moscow, South Ossetian authorities say they have spent just
1.5 billion rubles.
</P>
<P>
Kokoity -- who built connections in Moscow working as a trade official for the
rebel region when it was known as a highway for smuggling in the early 1990s --
has rejected accusations against him as Georgian propaganda.
</P>
<P>
Speaking to reporters on Sunday, he pledged that the vote would be carried out
strictly in accordance with law, saying the polls were "a maturity test for the
small independent state."
</P>
<P>
"At 10:00 am I can already say there's a very high turnout," he added. Officials
said it already amounted to 19 percent.
</P>
<P>
Eighty-eight polling stations have been set up for the region's 50,000 residents
as well as additional sites in Russia for expatriates and refugees from the
fighting.
</P>
<P>
Kokoity currently does not have the two-thirds of seats in the parliament to
amend the constitution.
</P>
<P>
And as the looming political scandal in the region threatens to become an
embarrassment for Moscow, there are signs that the Kremlin is scaling back its
support for the South Ossetian leader.
</P>
<P>
Sergey Naryshkin, the head of the Russian presidential administration, said on
Russian television this month that South Ossetia should not amend the existing
term limits in its constitution.
</P>
<P>
Moscow and Tbilisi fought a brief but intense war last August over the region,
which had enjoyed de facto independence since the early 1990s thanks to tacit
Russian support.
</P>
<P>
Following the conflict Russia formally recognised the region as independent, a
move followed only by Nicaragua.
</P>
<P>
Russia took formal control of guarding its borders this month, in a move
condemned by the West as a violation of an EU-brokered ceasefire that ended the
fighting last August.
</P>
<P>
Some locals said however that they owe everything to Russia.
</P>
<P>
"It's only thanks to Russia that we are here. If Russia didn't help us, we would
not exist in this world, we would be destroyed," said Elena Dzhaviyeva, 72.
</P>
<P>
Voting was expected to end at 8:00 pm (1600 GMT), with the first results
expected two hours later.
</P>

in 2007, lashed out over the incident.

security forces," Hamas said in a statement released in Gaza, adding that Samman
had been wanted by Israel for six years. "This crime is a red line."

concerning this collaborator gang responsible for this crime."

reconcile but to no avail and the two sides have frequently accused their rivals
of campaigns of persecution.
</P>

widening the rift.

Recession-hit Croatia votes in local polls

<TEXT>
<P>
Croatians cast ballots on Sunday in a second round of local and regional

<P>
The elections are seen as a test of the country's governing coalition's ability

</P>
<P>
Some four million voters were being asked to elect 221 mayors and municipal

</P>

Democrats (SDP) is being tipped to see off a challenge from independent
candidate Josip Kregar and win a fourth mandate.
</P>
<P>
On May 17, Prime Minister Ivo Sanader's ruling conservative Croatian Democratic
Union (HDZ) was re-elected in most counties in the first round while the SDP
asserted their control in major cities.
</P>

The HDZ and its coalition partners won seven prefect posts and held a majority
in 14 out of 21 county assemblies. The SDP got four county prefects and secured
control of five county assemblies.
</P>
<P>
The conservatives lost the mayoral post in the country's second biggest town of
Split, on the Adriatic coast, where an SDP candidate is to face an independent.
</P>
<P>
Local analysts said the vote confirmed that the SDP and left bloc dominate in
more developed parts of Croatia as well as in cities, while the HDZ and right-
wing parties are more popular in less developed and rural areas.
</P>
<P>
The polls give voters the right for the first time to directly elect mayors,
county prefects and municipal heads, along with 21 county assemblies and more
than 550 city and town councils.

<HEADLINE>
Once mighty US auto industry faces day of reckoning
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Washington, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The once mighty US auto industry faces a day of reckoning on Monday with the
looming bankruptcy of General Motors and an expected court ruling on the sale of
Chrysler to a group led by Italy's Fiat.
</P>
<P>
The global economic crisis has hit the US industry hard, prompting massive
intervention by President Barack Obama's administration to prevent total
collapse and a new blow to the nation's economy, which is already in recession.
</P>
<P>
A government rescue plan for GM could put as much as 72.5 percent of the
country's biggest automaker under state ownership.
</P>
<P>
With the hours counting down for GM, company bondholders with slightly more than
50 percent of GM’s 27.2 billion dollars in bond debt voted Saturday in support
of the restructuring plan, The New York Times reported.
</P>
<P>
Under the plan, the bondholders would obtain the rights to buy an extra 15
percent of GM's stock at a low price. They would also control 25 percent of the
new GM, after having supported the new company's creation in bankruptcy court.
</P>
<P>
Recalcitrant bondholders who opt for confrontation rather than cooperation "will
get nothing or very little," an Obama administration official told reporters
Thursday.
</P>
<P>
Government-backed restructuring in bankruptcy court for GM, once the world's
largest automaker, appeared all but certain.
</P>
<P>
Monday marks a deadline imposed by the Obama administration for the company to
submit a viable restructuring plan or file for bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile, a US bankruptcy court judge in New York was widely expected to
approve a deal between Chrysler and Fiat on Monday.
</P>
<P>
The third biggest US automaker has declared bankruptcy and is seeking a tie-up
with Fiat in a plan presented as the only way to save the company from
liquidation.
</P>
<P>
Developments at Chrysler could provide an example for restructuring at GM, which
will similarly have to sell some of its brands and close many dealerships.
</P>
<P>
But the administration official said a 60- to 90-day timeframe was "better" for
GM, contrasted with the fast-track process for Chrysler, which filed for
bankruptcy protection on April 30.
</P>
<P>
"This is a much more complicated company than Chrysler, as a global company.
It's three times the size," noted the official.
</P>
<P>
The United Auto Workers (UAW) union said Friday its members ratified a deal to
allow GM to radically cut costs and its debt load, clearing the way for a quick
exit from the expected bankruptcy filing.
</P>
<P>
GM also announced plans to retool an idled US plant to build small cars it had
originally planned to import, and two more US assembly plants could  potentially
be saved.
</P>
<P>
The automaker, which normally shuts downs plants for two weeks during the
summer, is planning longer-than-normal closures at a variety of facilities this
summer, The Detroit Free Press reported.
</P>
<P>
Some factories will be shut down for as long as nine weeks, according to the
newspaper report. This week, about eight out of its 15 assembly plants will be
running.
</P>
<P>
The bankruptcy filing could also be sped up by a deal struck Saturday after
marathon talks that saw Canadian parts maker Magna and its Russian backers
taking over GM's Opel.
</P>
<P>
The deal for GM's European operations, brokered by the German government,
amounted to a major development in the remaking of the global auto industry.
</P>
<P>
GM employs some 50,000 people throughout Europe and Magna plans to cut about a
fifth.
</P>
<P>
German Chancellor Angela Merkel, whose government agreed to stump billions of
euros (dollars) in loan guarantees and emergency loans to keep the ailing Opel
afloat, acknowledged that talks over the future of GM Europe had sometimes been
difficult.
</P>
<P>
Germany's Finance Minister Peer Steinbrueck had even denounced what he called
"scandalous" US negotiating tactics.
</P>
<P>
Yet despite what she called "huge mismanagement" by GM executives, a telephone
call to Obama helped seal the deal, Merkel said.
</P>
<P>
As for Chrysler, a new company could be born within days of approval for
bankruptcy. The Treasury said it had transferred 6.9 billion dollars in public
funds to New Carco, a newly created company to acquire Chrysler's "good assets."
</P>
<P>
If presiding judge Arthur Gonzalez rules against Chrysler, it faces a grim
future, with a worst-case scenario being Fiat abandoning the tie-up and the US
automaker going into liquidation, with massive job losses.
</P>
<P>
Legal appeals were expected if Gonzalez ruled in favor, meaning possible new
delays. Fiat has said it might back out if the transaction is not completed by
June 15.
</P>
</TEXT>

Sri Lanka appealed Sunday for international support in dismantling the global

<P>

</P>
<P>

trafficking, human smuggling, arms smuggling, and other means of terrorist
networking the world over ..." he said.
</P>
<P>
Bogollagama also emphasised the importance of the immediate post-war actions
taken by the government.
</P>
<P>
"This post-conflict phase is crucial in restoring confidence in people. We know
these chances won't come all the time, and some chances only come once, and this
is one such chance that we have got, and we will not miss out on this
opportunity."
</P>
<P>
He said the rehabilitation and resettlement of the 280,000 refugees displaced by
the conflict was one of the key priorities of the Sri Lankan government,
promising they would be treated fairly.
</P>
<P>
"The government is firmly committed to reaching a political settlement
acceptable to all... We'll have an inclusive process in this regard, and we'll
have everyone who is conscious of our country onboard irrespective whatever
ethnic identity one might have by birth."
</P>
<P>

Sinhalese-majority island. Much of its funding came from Tamil communities
overseas.

<HEADLINE>
'Curry bashings' strain Australia-India relations
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
MELBOURNE, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Indian students rallied in Melbourne on Sunday as Australia scrambled to contain
outrage over a wave of attacks that has seen it labelled racist and strained
diplomatic relations with New Delhi.
</P>
<P>
What began as a local policing issue in Australia's second largest city has
spiralled into a crisis that prompted talks between Prime Minister Kevin Rudd
and Indian counterpart Manmohan Singh on student safety last week.
</P>
<P>
Students and Indian officials are demanding action after more than 70 assaults
on their peers in a year in Melbourne, including at least four in the past
fortnight, attracting prominent coverage in newspapers here and in India.
</P>
<P>
Pictures from a hospital bed of a comatose Sravan Kumar Theerthala, who was
stabbed with a screwdriver by gatecrashers at a party, were splashed across
front pages in India. A teenager faces charges of attempted murder.
</P>
<P>
"They were saying, 'Don't touch us you Indians' and 'Indians go home' before
they got the screwdriver," said Theerthala's friend, Jayasanka Bagpelli.
</P>
<P>
Another student, Baljinder Singh, told last week how his attackers laughed as he
pleaded with them during a robbery at a Melbourne train station.
</P>
<P>
"I was saying to them, 'I'm giving you all my money, don't kill me, don't kill
me'," said Singh, who was stabbed and left with a six-inch (15-centimetre) wound
to his stomach and has advised Indians to stay away from Australia.
</P>
<P>
Indian media have dubbed the attacks "curry bashings", a term reportedly used by
youths behind the violence in Melbourne's western suburbs, where 30 percent of
assault victims are Indian.
</P>
<P>
It is a grossly disproportionate figure in a city of almost four million with an
Indian student population of less than 50,000.
</P>
<P>
Police deny any racial element to the attacks, arguing Indian students were
often simply in the wrong place at the wrong time as they travelled home late
with items such as mobile phones and MP3 players.
</P>
<P>
But Indian High Commissioner to Australia Sujatha Singh said racism was playing
a part, even if some of the crimes were "opportunistic".
</P>
<P>
Federation of Indian Students president Amit Menghani, who led the rally of more
than 1,000 supporters through central Melbourne Sunday, said the police attitude
had frustrated students.
</P>
<P>
Bagpelli, who attended the rally, added: "It's only because the Indian
government is now applying pressure that they are doing anything."
</P>
<P>
While the attacks are unlikely to result in any permanent damage at a diplomatic
level, Canberra is concerned parents in India may prevent their children
studying in Australia.
</P>
<P>
That would threaten the international education sector here, a 15.5 billion
dollar (12.2 billion US) a year industry that has attracted more than 90,000
Indians nationwide.
</P>
<P>
More broadly, with headlines such as "Australia, land of racism" running in
overseas media, there are also fears Australia's reputation for tolerance is
sustaining long-term damage.
</P>
<P>
"We need to help make sure that the mothers and fathers of all students who come
here are assured that Australia is a safe location to come to, that our general
crime rates and violence rates are very low," Foreign Minister Stephen Smith
told commercial television Sunday.
</P>
<P>
There are already signs the controversy is souring popular attitudes in India
towards Australia, with Bollywood legend Amitabh Bachchan threatening to snub
the offer of an honorary doctorate from an Australian university.
</P>
<P>
"My conscience is profoundly unsettled at the moment," Bachchan said on his
blog, in which he also reported an "overwhelming" response from the Indian
public over the issue.
</P>
<P>
Theerthala's assault proved the catalyst for widespread anger in India, sparking
a flurry of high-level diplomatic activity and strong public statements from
Indian officials indicating they had run out of patience.
</P>
<P>
"Such attacks cannot be allowed to happen," High Commissioner Singh said.
</P>
</TEXT>

Auckland, May 31, 2009 (AFP)

<TEXT>
<P>
The All Blacks selectors Sunday named a largely predictable squad for their

<P>
The 26-man squad for two Tests against France and one against Italy next month

<P>
But head coach Graham Henry maintained that game had no bearing on the All

<P>
In addition to McCaw, loose forwards Rodney So'oialo and Scott Waldrom, wing

</P>
<P>
Two other injured players, scrumhalf Brendon Leonard and lock Ali Williams, have
been selected but are unlikely to be considered for the first Test against
France.
</P>
<P>
With the exception of the three new internationals -- prop Wyatt Crockett, lock
Isaac Ross and loose forward Tanerau Latimer -- the selectors have stayed loyal
to players with proven Test experience.

<P>

<HEADLINE>
Progress in fighting lung cancer at specialist summit
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Orlando, Florida, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Cancer specialists, gathered for an annual meeting, are reporting progress in
the fight against lung cancer, the most common and deadliest form of cancer, but
little progress in treating colorectal cancer.
</P>
<P>
Doctors and researchers at the 45th gathering of the American Society of
Clinical Oncology (ASCO) -- the world's main cancer conference -- on Saturday
learned of two studies showing progress in the battle against lung cancer.
</P>
<P>
The first study showed how the combination of two anti-cancer treatments
following standard chemotherapy can slow the advance of lung cancer.
</P>
<P>
Patients treated with a combination of Tarceva, sold by the Swiss drugmaker
Roche, and Avastin, a drug by Roche's Genentech unit, saw their cancer growth
slow more than a control group treated with Avastin.
</P>
<P>
More than 750 patients were randomized to receive Avastin and a placebo, or
Avastin and Tarceva. Those in the Tarceva group survived an average of 4.8
months before the cancer started growing again, compared to 3.7 months for the
control group, said Vincent Miller, the study's main author.
</P>
<P>
The numbers translated to a 29 percent reduced risk of disease progression for
patients who took a combination of Tarceva and Avastin.
</P>
<P>
"This is the first study to show that adding erlotinib (Tarceva) to maintenance
therapy with bevacizumab (Avastin) delays disease progression in patients who
have already received bevacizumab as part of their initial chemotherapy," said
Miller.
</P>
<P>
A second study with 663 patients with advance lung cancer were given the drug
Alimta, from US pharmaceutical Eli Lilly, which blocks cell growth.
</P>
<P>
Preliminary results showed that patients who took the drug lived 26 percent
longer compared to a control group that took a placebo: 13.4 months against 10.6
months.
</P>
<P>
As in the first study, all the patients had already received four standard
chemotherapy sessions.
</P>
<P>
"This study will change the overall standard of care," said Chandra Belani, the
deputy director of the Penn State Cancer Institute, as she presented the
research.
</P>
<P>
"Maintenance therapy with Alimta (permetrexed) offers a new paradigm for
patients who have advanced lung cancer, because it has a low toxicity and can be
given on an ongoing basis over a prolonged period of time to extend patients'
lives," she said.
</P>
<P>
However there were few advances to report in the fight against colorectal
cancer, the fourth most common in the United States and the second deadliest
type of cancer.
</P>
<P>
Research on 2,710 patients with Phase Three colorectal cancer taking the drug
Avastine along with standard chemotherapy treatment showed no difference in the
survival rate or the recurrence of the tumor after three and a half years when
compared to those not taking the drug.
</P>
<P>
Another study conducted in Italy among 747 patients with advanced colorectal
cancer showed that the drug Eloxatine from the French firm Sanofi did not reduce
the size of the tumor when combined with standard treatment used ahead of cancer
surgery.
</P>
<P>
On Sunday, several sessions at the ASCO event, scheduled to end on Tuesday, will
focus on the result of clinical tests on female breast and uterus cancer.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
After stumble, US Treasury chief reaches out to China
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
washington, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
US Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner makes his first trip to Beijing Sunday,
exploiting his early links with China to steer relations with the Asian giant
under President Barack Obama's watch.
</P>
<P>
Having started on the wrong foot by criticizing China for currency manipulation,
Geithner will now have to grapple with issues ranging from key Chinese holdings
of dollar based assets to the global economic turmoil when he meets President Hu
Jintao, Premier Wen Jiabao and others during his visit.
</P>
<P>
But analysts are confident that his previous Chinese connections will come a
long way to establishing links with the leadership in Beijing as the Obama
administration banks on China's credit to bankroll the recession-struck US
economy and its growing influence to help ease the global economic crisis.
</P>
<P>
This despite the fact that he lacks the firm business background of his
predecessor, Henry Paulson, reputedly the most well-connected post-war Treasury
Secretary, having travelled extensively to Beijing as a private banker.
</P>
<P>
"Yes, he doesn't quite have the same business background as that of Mr. Paulson
but I think Mr Geithner will turn that to his advantage," said Nicholas Lardy, a
China expert at the Peterson Institute for International Economics in
Washington.
</P>
<P>
"I think quite frankly that Mr. Geithner will be a better listener with the
Chinese," he said, citing Paulson's sometimes "very strong advice" to the
Chinese on reforming the financial system.
</P>
<P>
"Now they recognize that what Paulson was advocating did not turn up so well,"
Lardy added.
</P>
<P>
China has not introduced any of the risk-carrying exotic derivative products,
such as the unregulated credit default swap contracts, which are at the center
of the current American financial chaos that erupted during the Bush
administration.
</P>
<P>
Geithner, an ex-governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is a China
hand. He studied and taught Mandarin during his college days and later also
learned Chinese at the influential Peking University in Beijing.
</P>
<P>
He also helped former globe trotting US diplomat Henry Kissinger, who was
instrumental in the landmark opening of diplomatic ties with Beijing, write the
China and Japan chapters in one of his books.
</P>
<P>
His father Peter Geithner was also the first representative in Beijing for the
Ford Foundation, possibly the oldest US non-government organization in China.
</P>
<P>
Obama administration officials took pains to emphasize the Treasury chief's
Chinese connections at a media briefing before his departure from Washington
Saturday for his two day Beijing visit beginning Monday.
</P>
<P>
Geithner would deliver a speech at Peking university, his alma mater, during the
trip and "will meet with students and with professors and we hope with some
former professors of his," one official said.
</P>
<P>
He would also visit the offices of the Ford Foundation, which has funded
economics education in the United States of a large group of Chinese who are now
senior officials, academics and members of the economic establishment in
Beijing.
</P>
<P>
"Coincidentally, the Ford Foundation was established by secretary Geithner's
father," the official said.
</P>
<P>
Despite his history with China, Geithner created a stir at his confirmation
hearing in January when he said in a written reply to a senator that Obama
"believes that China is manipulating its currency."
</P>
<P>
It triggered a storm in China and signaled that Obama will take the Chinese head
on over the currency manipulation charges.
</P>
<P>
But Obama administration officials swiftly moved to contain the damage, saying
the reply was written by midlevel staff helping Geithner answer the plethora of
questions from senators.
</P>
<P>
On taking office, Geithner also rapidly reached out to the Chinese.
</P>
<P>
"I have talked to my counterparts in China over the past few months much more
than I’ve talked to my counterparts from any other country," he told the New
York Times in a recent interview.
</P>
<P>
In Beijing however Geithner faces the tough task of convincing the Chinese to
maintain their massive US bond holdings under threat by burgeoning US debt and
prodding them to make their their currency more flexible.
</P>
<P>
Being the top holder of the bonds, China is the largest creditor to the United
States aside from being the world's largest holder of US dollars as a reserve
currency, at nearly two trillion dollars.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Obama seeks new start with Muslim world
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Washington, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
President Barack Obama will journey to the center of Arab-Muslim civilization
this week, to begin the daunting task of draining deep mistrust of the United
States felt across the Islamic world.
</P>
<P>
In Egypt on Thursday, Obama will make a personal address to the world's Muslims,
harnessing his own ancestral ties to Islam and globalizing his message of change
in an speech rich in trademark political ambition.
</P>
<P>
Obama's trip next week to Egypt, Saudi Arabia and World War II commemorations in
France and Germany, comes as some observers scent a moment of opportunity amid
the perpetual Middle East crisis.
</P>
<P>
But others see only peril, with a showdown gathering pace between Washington and
Israel over Jewish settlements and no end in sight to Iran's nuclear drive.
</P>
<P>
Obama targeted reconcilation with Islam and rigorous Middle East diplomacy from
his first moments in office.
</P>
<P>
"To the Muslim world, we seek a new way forward, based on mutual interest and
mutual respect," Obama said in his inaugural address in January.
</P>
<P>
He quickly called Palestinian leader Mahmud Abbas and spoke to the Al-Arabiya
satellite network.
</P>
<P>
Obama made an unprecedented video address to Iranians and reassured Muslims the
United States was not at war with them from the Turkish parliament.
</P>
<P>
This trip's first stop, on Wednesday, will be Saudi Arabia, for talks with King
Abdullah, seeking Arab support for US peace efforts.
</P>
<P>
But the highlight will be the speech at the University of Cairo, co-hosted by
Al-Azhar University, an ancient hub of Islamic scholarship.
</P>
<P>
Obama may try to use the charismatic rhetoric which helped make him president as
a balm for region-wide mistrust of the United States.
</P>
<P>
"I want to use the occasion to deliver a broader message about how the United
States can change for the better its relationship with the Muslim world," Obama
said last week.
</P>
<P>
The speech will also be a promise kept -- way back in the presidential campaign
Obama pledged to speak before a major Islamic forum.
</P>
<P>
In major speeches, Obama embroiders his exotic personal biography into a a
political narrative -- as in his frank 2008 speech about race.
</P>
<P>
In Egypt Obama will reference the Islamic faith of some of his paternal family
in Kenya, time spent in Indonesia as a young boy and contacts with Muslim
communities in Illinois.
</P>
<P>
"The President himself experienced Islam on three continents before he was able
to visit, really, the heart of the Islamic world," said foreign policy advisor
Denis McDonough.
</P>
<P>
Some analysts predict though Obama may fall short.
</P>
<P>
"Expectations in the region have gotten pretty high and I think there is a very
good chance that those expectations will be disappointed," said Flynt Leverett,
a former US official who quit the Bush administration over differences on Middle
East policy.
</P>
<P>
"I think people are looking for this to be the place where is he going to get in
the lead on the Palestinian issue.
</P>
<P>
"I will be rather surprised if that is what he does."
</P>
<P>
The US image in the Muslim world has been stained by the invasion of Iraq,
stalled Palestinian hopes for statehood and Bush administration aquiesence in
Israel's offensives in Lebanon and Gaza.
</P>
<P>
In 2004, a survey by WorldPublicOpinion.org, based at the University of
Maryland, found just four percent of Egyptians had a favourable opinion of the
United States.
</P>
<P>
A McClatchy/Ipsos poll this month found that only 33 percent of those surveyed
in six Arab countries had a favorable opinion of the United States
</P>
<P>
But Obama's favorable ratings beat those of the United States by 26 points in
Kuwait, 22 points in Jordan, 18 points in the United Arab Emirates, 15 points in
Saudi Arabia, 13 points in Egypt and 11 points in Lebanon.
</P>
<P>
That suggests he might be the ideal messenger.
</P>
<P>
Since bursting onto the political scene in 2004, Obama has repeatedly leveraged
his ability to move people with words.
</P>
<P>
But that might be a tough sell in the Middle East.
</P>
<P>
"There's nothing Barack Obama could say to Muslims on June 4th that will make
the United States popular, and he shouldn't try," said Jon Alterman, of the
Center of Strategic and International Studies.
</P>
<P>
"The underlying interests are simply not allied with the policies that many
Muslims around the world would like to see the United States pursue."
</P>
<P>
"We're going to have to agree to disagree, and that's the first task for the
president -- to frame US policy in a way that takes some of the passion out of
widespread hostility to the United States
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Myanmar's Suu Kyi trades barbs with junta over trial
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
YANGON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Myanmar's military regime accused Aung San Suu Kyi Sunday of covering up a visit
to her home by a US man which led to her trial, as the pro-democracy icon hit
back against the "bullying" junta.
</P>
<P>
The claim by the ruling generals is the latest defiant reaction to the storm of
international outrage over the case against the Nobel laureate, who faces up to
five years' jail on charges of breaching her house arrest.
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi has proclaimed her innocence at the closed trial being held at
Yangon's notorious Insein Prison, insisting that she only offered "temporary
shelter" to American John Yettaw after he swam to her lakeside house.
</P>
<P>
"It is no doubt that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi has committed a cover-up of the truth
by her failure to report an illegal immigrant to the authorities concerned,"
Major General Aye Myint, Myanmar's deputy defence minister, told a security
forum in Singapore.
</P>
<P>
"Thus there was no option but to open legal proceedings in accordance with the
law," Aye Myint said. "She permitted him to stay.... She communicated, provided
him food and shelter."
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi, who has spent 13 of the past 19 years in detention, met with
her lawyers at Insein prison on Saturday ahead of final arguments in the case
which are due to be heard on Friday.
</P>
<P>
Her opposition party said Sunday that she was upset that Myanmar authorities had
entered her residential compound without permission to stage a reconstruction of
Yettaw's visit for the purposes of the trial.
</P>
<P>
"Aung San Suu Kyi said she is not completely satisfied as Mr Yettaw and the
authorities went into her compound last week for a demonstration (of how he got
into the property)," party spokesman Nyan Win told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"It was not in accordance with the law. She said it was unjust bullying," added
Nyan Win, who is also part of her legal team.
</P>
<P>
Yettaw, a 53-year-old Mormon and former US military veteran, was arrested on May
6 after swimming to Aung San Suu Kyi's house using a pair of homemade flippers
and spending two nights there.
</P>
<P>
He has told the court that he had had a vision that Aung San Suu Kyi would be
assassinated by "terrorists" and was told by God to warn both the opposition
leader and the Myanmar government.
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi said in a statement to the court this week that she could not
be held responsible as the junta had failed to boost security despite her having
reported that Yettaw made a previous visit to the house in November 2008.
</P>
<P>
However Nyan Win quoted the democracy campaigner as saying that she "has no
grudge to Mr Yettaw and his family."
</P>
<P>
International critics accuse Myanmar's military regime of trumping up the
charges in a bid to keep her locked up ahead of elections in 2010, as the latest
six-year period of her house arrest expired on Wednesday.
</P>
<P>
But in his speech to regional security officials and experts, Myanmar's Aye
Myint said the case against Aung San Suu Kyi was an internal matter.
</P>
<P>
"Countries should refrain from interfering in the internal affairs of Myanmar
that will affect peace and security of the region," said Aye Myint.
</P>
<P>
Ann Taylor, Britain's minister for international defence and security, said at
the meeting earlier Sunday that Aung San Suu Kyi should be released.
</P>
<P>
Myanmar last week hit back at rare criticism from the normally placid fellow
members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) over the treatment
of the democracy campaigner.
</P>
<P>
Thai Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva, whose country holds the rotating
chairmanship of the 10-member bloc, said ASEAN leaders would discuss Myanmar at
a summit in South Korea on June 1-2.
</P>
<P>
"ASEAN leaders will meet and discuss an issue that has received international
attention -- about a neighbouring country -- for further cooperation," the Thai
premier said in his weekly television programme.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Climate change: 'Bali Road Map' looks for a compass
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
paris, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Gruelling efforts to craft a pact on climate change enter a crucial phase on
Monday when the 192-nation UN forum takes its first look at a draft text for
negotiations.
</P>
<P>
The 12-day huddle in the German city of Bonn under the UN Framework Convention
on Climate Change (UNFCCC) means that, after 18 months of swapping visions, the
process will at last get down to the gritty stuff.
</P>
<P>
Little more than six months are left before the "Bali Road Map", launched in
Indonesia in 2006, reaches its supposed destination at a Copenhagen summit: an
accord that will transform global warming from a monster into a manageable
problem.
</P>
<P>
On the table is a small mountain of paper whose notable feature is curly
brackets, denoting discord among scores of submissions.
</P>
<P>
Despite the sprawling range of proposals, UNFCCC Executive Secretary Yvo de Boer
said he hoped that the draft will be endorsed as a workable basis for talks over
the coming months.
</P>
<P>
"There will be a negotiating text on the table for the first time," he told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"I hope it will be well received, that it will be seen as a balanced
representation of the different ideas that countries have come with."
</P>
<P>
The big goal is to slash emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 compared to 1990
levels.
</P>
<P>
But that's where consensus largely ends. Exactly how deep should be the cut be?
How can it be achieved? And who should shoulder the burden?
</P>
<P>
In their proposals, many developing countries say rich countries, which bear
historical responsibility for today's warming, should take the lead by cutting
their emissions by 25-40 percent by 2020.
</P>
<P>
China has led the charge, demanding a cut of "at least" 40 percent.
</P>
<P>
But only the European Union (EU), which has set its own reduction of 20 percent
by 2020, deepened to 30 percent if other advanced economies play ball, is
anywhere near such a figure.
</P>
<P>
After eight long years of vilification, the United States is now being warmly
embraced in the climate arena as Barack Obama bulldozes George W. Bush's
policies.
</P>
<P>
But Washington is also warning that the world cannot expect miracles.
</P>
<P>
A bill put before Congress would cut US emissions by 17 percent by 2020 over
2005 levels using a cap-and-trade system of the kind Bush loathed.
</P>
<P>
This approach would translate to a reduction of only four percent compared to
the 1990 benchmark, but it would also ratchet up to 83 percent by 2050, the top
US climate change negotiator, Todd Stern, said in Paris last week.
</P>
<P>
"We are jumping as high as the political system will tolerate," said Stern,
characterising China's demand of a 40 percent cut by 2020 as "not realistic".
</P>
<P>
Just as unresolved is what the emerging giant countries should do.
</P>
<P>
The draft should at least "call for those wealthier, more capable countries to
take actions," said Stern's deputy, Jonathan Pershing.
</P>
<P>
China is now the world's No. 1 polluter, and Brazil and India have also leapt up
the emission ranks as their economies have grown.
</P>
<P>
Yet all refuse binding emissions targets of the kind that apply only to rich
countries under the Kyoto Protocol, the UNFCCC treaty to be superseded from 2013
by the Copenhagen accord.
</P>
<P>
Then there is how to muster finance to help poor countries adapt to the impacts
of climate change, and how to transfer clean technology so that they avoid
becoming the greenhouse-gas villains of the future.
</P>
<P>
Keya Chatterjee, deputy director of the climate change programme with the World
Wildlife Fund (WWF) said emerging countries were thirsting for the energy
switch.
</P>
<P>
"It's sort of a green arms race where everybody wants to have access to clean-
energy industry," she said. "That's a pretty huge change in the negotiations
that will affect the dynamics."
</P>
<P>
Even so, she said, developing countries were suspicious. "This lack of trust
comes from a long tradition of industrialised countries not living up to their
obligations."
</P>
<P>
These are just a few of the many obstacles besetting the Bali Road Map.
</P>
<P>
The complexity is such that many experts now predict Copenhagen will not be a
complete treaty but, at best, a good deal on the main points.
</P>
<P>
"I think that what we are looking at in Copenhagen is a deal that will lock in
some specific emission reductions goals, will create commitments both for
investment and adaptation and then... the details will have to be filled in
later," said Angela Anderson of the US Climate Action Network (CAN).
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0347" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
US and Russia hold second round of START arms talks
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Geneva, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Russian and US negotiators are due to meet in Geneva on Monday for a second
round of talks on renewing a key Cold War-era arms reduction deal, a month
before their leaders hold a landmark summit.
</P>
<P>
Diplomats said the three day meeting on the START treaty would be held behind
closed doors at an undisclosed location, mirroring the discretion surrounding
the first round in Moscow nearly two weeks ago.
</P>
<P>
"On the details of the negotiation, I think we prefer to keep that in private
right now. I think that's just the best way to conduct these kinds of
negotiations," US State Department spokesman Ian Kelly said in Washington.
</P>
<P>
First results from the talks are expected to be unveiled by Presidents Barack
Obama and Dmitry Medvedev during their summit meeting in Moscow on July 6 to 8,
a Russian diplomat said.
</P>
<P>
Despite a thaw in US-Russian relations following the departure of the Bush
administration, analysts were expecting little concrete progress on the 1991
Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, which expires on December 5.
</P>
<P>
On top of the complex technical issues surrounding the landmark treaty -- which
took a decade to reach agreement on the deep cuts in US and Soviet nuclear
arsenals after the fall of the Iron Curtain -- the negotiations are also
hampered by differing ambitions.
</P>
<P>
"The sides are not in the same position. Obama needs a result to demonstrate
that the 'reset' of US-Russian relations is getting somewhere," said Evgeny Volk
of the Heritage Foundation.
</P>
<P>
Earlier this year, Vice President Joseph Biden unveiled the Obama
administration's fresh approach to fractious US relations with the old Cold War
foe, saying it wanted to press the 'reset' button.
</P>
<P>
Disarmament expert Jozef Goldblat said the START talks allowed the United States
to create a climate "propitious for help with other more complicated subjects"
where Washington needs Moscow's support, such as Iran and North Korea's
controversial nuclear programmes.
</P>
<P>
However, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has not concealed Moscow's
desire to broaden the talks to take account of the planned US anti-missile
shield in Europe.
</P>
<P>
The United States has insisted that the defensive shield is meant to counter an
Iranian threat.
</P>
<P>
But Russia regards the shield, which would partly be based in former eastern
bloc countries close to its borders, as a threat to its own security.
</P>
<P>
"The number one stumbling block is the anti missile shield," said Volk. "Moscow
wants Washington to give up deployment but the Americans are against that."
</P>
<P>
Russian military analyst Alexander Goltz said the negotiations also helped
Moscow recover some of its prestige.
</P>
<P>
"The Russians are aiming to make the process last as long as possible, because
the talks restore their status as a world power," he explained.
</P>
<P>
Russian officials hailed the "constructive and business-like" atmosphere of the
first round, but US delegation chief Rose Gottemoeller warned before the talks
even began that the process could be more drawn out than expected.
</P>
<P>
Goltz played down expectations for the Obama-Medvedev summit because the two
sides were too far apart.
</P>
<P>
But veteran disarmament observer Goldblat suggested an elegant way out: a five
year extension of START that would give time for negotiations on a "broader"
disarmament deal between the world's biggest nuclear powers.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Major security plan drawn up for Lebanon vote: minister
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Beirut, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Lebanon will deploy 50,000 police and soldiers to prevent any outbreak of
violence during the June 7 parliamentary election as part of a major security
plan, Interior Minister Ziad Baroud has said.
</P>
<P>
"We will have 30,000 police and soldiers deployed at polling stations and their
vicinity and 20,000 other police and soldiers deployed elsewhere nationwide,"
Baroud told AFP in an interview.
</P>
<P>
He said the plan takes into account sensitive regions where violence could erupt
on election day between members of the current Western-backed ruling majority
and supporters of the Hezbollah-led opposition alliance, which is backed by Iran
and Syria.
</P>
<P>
Sectarian violence between the two sides left around 100 people dead last May
when Hezbollah staged a spectacular takeover of mainly Sunni parts of west
Beirut, prompting fears of a new civil war.
</P>
<P>
Baroud said security measures on election day had taken into account the risk of
violence in each of the 26 electoral districts.
</P>
<P>
"In some districts there is minimal risk and in others it's more serious," he
said. "And it's according to the risk factor that troops will be deployed."
</P>
<P>
For example, he said there was little likelihood of violence erupting in most of
the regions in southern Lebanon where Hezbollah and its allies are assured
victory.
</P>
<P>
However, the situation is expected to be more tense in regions where the vote is
set to be tight, including the southern coastal town of Sidon and in the eastern
Bekaa valley town of Zahle.
</P>
<P>
Baroud said he was nonetheless optimistic the vote would proceed smoothly,
noting that there had been few security incidents in the run-up to the election.
</P>
<P>
"Of course, I am anxious ... but the political situation (locally and
regionally) is more reassuring than alarming," he said.
</P>
<P>
"It's up to the country's political factions and every Lebanese man or woman to
ensure there is no outbreak of violence."
</P>
<P>
Baroud, 39, a widely popular minister in the current 30-member national unity
government in which Hezbollah is represented, said measures had also been
adopted to prevent fraud at the 5,200 polling stations.
</P>
<P>
The vote this year for the first time is taking place on a single day rather
than over a month-long period.
</P>
<P>
"We have taken anti-fraud measures including placing transparent boxes in
polling stations, more secrecy of voting and we have adopted international
standards," Baroud said.
</P>
<P>
"Also the indelible ink we will be using will prevent someone from voting
twice."
</P>
<P>
Some 2,200 national observers and 250 international monitors will oversee the
vote including from the European Union, the Carter Center, the Arab League and
several countries.
</P>
<P>
The 128 seats in parliament are divided equally between Christians and Muslims.
</P>
<P>
Baroud said he expected final results to be announced on June 8, barring any
major security incidents or fraud.
</P>
<P>
"I am crossing my fingers on a daily basis," he said.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Nearly half Israeli outpost land is private: Peace Now
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Jerusalem, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Nearly half of the land occupied by Israeli settlement outposts in the occupied
West Bank is private Palestinian property, a watchdog group said on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Forty-four percent of the land where the wildcat settlements were built belong
to private Palestinian owners, Peace Now said.
</P>
<P>
The vast majority of the outposts -- 80 of the more than 100 in the territory --
were either partially or wholly built on private Palestinian land without
authorisation of the owners, it said.
</P>
<P>
"Defence Minister Ehud Barak said recently that he wanted to dismantle the
outposts built on private Palestinian land -- he is going to have lots of work
in the coming weeks and months," Peace Now head Yariv Oppenheimer told army
radio.
</P>
<P>
A senior settler official, Danny Dayan, rejected the report, saying that "not a
single Arab has been harmed" by settlement activities.
</P>
<P>
Although the international community considers all Israeli settlements illegal,
Israel makes a distinction between those authorised by the government and so-
called wildcat outposts, set up by zealous settlers without state approval.
</P>
<P>
More than 280,000 people live in Israeli settlements in the West Bank. The
majority moved to the settlements for economic reasons, but an extremely vocal
and often violent minority thinks the Jewish people have a God-given, biblical-
era right to the land.
</P>
<P>
The residents of the outposts tend to be the most radical settlers, establishing
their homes on any land they see fit.
</P>
</TEXT>

<P>

<P>

<P>

</P>

that will affect peace and security of the region," said Aye Myint.

house arrest expired on Wednesday.
</P>
<P>
"Solving one's internal affairs through its legal system with legal proceedings
in accordance with law does not amount to the threat of peace or breach of
security of the region," Aye Myint said in an apparent reaction to criticism

</P>
<P>
"It is the universal legal principle that no one is above the law," he said.
</P>

the meeting earlier Sunday that Aung San Suu Kyi should be released.
</P>
<P>

isolation, but Aung San Suu Kyi is not alone," Taylor said.
</P>
<P>
"People all around the world are standing with her and the Burmese people and we
say to the generals: Now is the time for transition to democracy starting with
the release of Aung San Suu Kyi."
</P>
<P>

rulers to release all political prisoners.
</P>
<P>

including Aung San Suu Kyi, and the institution of meaningful dialogue between

<HEADLINE>
Troops hunt Taliban as Pakistan says victory nears
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
PESHAWAR, Pakistan, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Pakistan's defence secretary said Sunday that a month-long offensive to crush
Taliban fighters in the northwest could end within days, as security forces
hunted down the militant leadership.
</P>
<P>
Swat valley's main town Mingora is back in government hands, the military
announced late Saturday, and Syed Athar Ali told a security forum in Singapore
that three targeted northwest districts were almost clear of Taliban rebels.
</P>
<P>
"Operations in Swat, Buner and adjoining areas have almost met complete
success," the secretary of defence said.
</P>
<P>
"Only five to ten percent job is remaining and hopefully within the next two to
three days these pockets of resistance will be cleared."
</P>
<P>
The army remains locked in battle in some areas, but the fall of Mingora was a
critical milestone in an offensive launched after the Taliban thrust to within
100 kilometres (60 miles) of Islamabad.
</P>
<P>
Washington, which is firmly backing the military drive, had warned that the
rebels threatened Pakistan's very existence and identified the country and
neighbouring Afghanistan as central to its 'war on terror'.
</P>
<P>
"We are trying to target the top leadership of militants and they are constantly
being followed," chief military spokesman Major General Athar Abbas said as he
announced the Mingora win.
</P>
<P>
Officials said lower-ranking leaders had been killed but it was harder to get to
the top leaders, who had a network of hardcore militants around them and had
slipped into the rugged mountain terrain.
</P>
<P>
"They will be eliminated wherever we find them," said one military official, who
did not wish to be named as he was not authorised to speak to the media, adding:
"We believe that they are somewhere in the mountains."
</P>
<P>
Pakistan has slapped a 600,000-dollar price on the head of firebrand Swat
Taliban commander Maulana Fazlullah for masterminding the nearly two-year
uprising in Swat valley to enforce sharia law.
</P>
<P>
The insurgency has transformed a scenic region once popular with Western
tourists for its soaring peaks, pristine ski slopes and cool mountain air into a
battle ground, with armed Taliban in April patrolling the streets of Mingora.
</P>
<P>
Fazlullah led thousands of supporters, a mixture of hardcore ideologues and
disenfranchised young men, in a brutal campaign that beheaded opponents, burned
scores of schools and fought against government troops since November 2007.
</P>
<P>
The government has also offered rewards for 21 rebel chiefs -- wanted dead or
alive -- from Swat and has listed their names and published mugshots.
</P>
<P>
But as the government ups its campaign to stamp out the militants, fears are
growing of a wave of revenge attacks on cities across Pakistan.
</P>
<P>
The northwestern capital Peshawar and the eastern cultural centre of Lahore have
both been rocked by deadly explosions in the last five days, killing a total of
39 people and wounding hundreds more.
</P>
<P>
A spokesman for Pakistan Taliban chief Baitullah Mehsud -- who has a five-
million-dollar bounty on his head posted by the United States -- has claimed the
suicide attack Wednesday on a police building in Lahore.
</P>
<P>
Hakimullah Mehsud also warned of more "massive attacks" on government buildings
to revenge the Swat military operation and in protest at Islamabad's ties with
Washington.
</P>
<P>
Baitullah Mehsud commands Tehreek-e-Taliban from the lawless tribal area of
Waziristan on the Afghan border, where militants branded by Washington as the
greatest terror threat to the West are holed up.
</P>
<P>
In South Waziristan on Sunday, military officials said that at least 28
suspected insurgents and one soldier were killed in fierce clashes.
</P>
<P>
Nearly 2.4 million people have fled the current offensive in the northwest and
now huddle in refugee camps or with relatives.
</P>
<P>
The military said it had relaxed its strict curfew Sunday in most parts of the
northwest including Mingora to allow people trapped on the roads as they tried
to flee the offensive to return home or leave the region.
</P>
<P>
Hundreds of people were seen trudging along the main roads out of the region on
foot amid a long, snaking traffic jam, a government official said.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Iran defuses bomb on domestic flight
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Tehran, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Iranian security officials defused a handmade bomb on board a domestic flight,
officials said on Sunday, the latest violence  the run-up to Iran's presidential
election less than two weeks away.
</P>
<P>
The incident occurred on a Kish Air flight headed to Tehran from Ahvaz in the
west of the country near the border with Iraq, the Fars news agency reported.
</P>
<P>
"Last night, 15 minutes after the plane with 131 passengers took off, flight
security guards found a handmade bomb placed in the lavatory," Fars said. "The
plane landed immediately at Ahvaz airport and the bomb was defused."
</P>
<P>
"Security officials of the Islamic Republic Revolutionary Guards acted well and
the incident caused no casualties," Reza Jafarzadeh, spokesman for Iran's Civil
Aviation Organisation, told the state broadcaster.
</P>
<P>
The passengers were calmed and the plane continued the flight to Tehran, Kish
Air manager Reza Nakhjavani told the ILNA news agency.
</P>
<P>
It was the latest unrest to shake Iran in the run-up to the country's
presidential election on June 12, while Ahvaz itself has witnessed several
deadly incidents in recent years.
</P>
<P>
On Thursday, a suicide bomber killed 25 worshippers and wounded 125 in a Shiite
mosque in Zahedan in the southeastern Sistan-Baluchestan province bordering
Afghanistan and Pakistan.
</P>
<P>
The province, which is home to Iran's Baluch minority who adhere to Sunni Islam,
has been the scene of a deadly insurgency by a Sunni rebel group which is
strongly opposed to the government of predominantly Shiite Iran.
</P>
<P>
Iran on Saturday hanged three men in public accused of involvement in the mosque
bombing, just 48 hours after the incident.
</P>
<P>
The mosque attack was reminiscent of a similar outbreak of violence just days
before Iran's last presidential election in 2005 which brought Mahmoud
Ahmadinejad to power.
</P>
<P>
Bombs hit Tehran and Ahvaz, which has a sizable Arab minority, in June 2005,
killing at least eight people and wounding scores more.
</P>
<P>
Ahvaz, the capital of Iran's oil-rich Khuzestan province, which borders Iraq and
the Gulf, was also rocked by ethnic violence in April 2005.
</P>
<P>
Iran in the past has blamed US and British agents in neighbouring Iraq and
Afghanistan for launching attacks on border provinces with significant ethnic
minority populations.
</P>
<P>
Jalal Sayah, Sistan-Balustan's deputy governor, said on Friday that those
arrested over the Zahedan attack were "hired by America and the agents of the
arrogance."
</P>
<P>
Iranian officials usually use the term "global arrogance" to refer to Iran's
arch-foe the United States.
</P>
<P>
But US State Department spokesman Ian Kelly denied emphatically that Washington
was behind the attack, saying the US does "not sponsor any form of terrorism in
Iran."
</P>
<P>
The chief of the Iranian armed forces, General Hassan Firouzabadi, in comments
reported on Saturday, accused Britain and "Zionists" of involvement in the
bombing.
</P>
<P>
Ahmadinejad is running for a second four-year term in the June 12 election but
faces challenges from three other candidates.
</P>
</TEXT>

<P>
One of the 21 "most-wanted" Tiananmen Square protesters has been allowed to
enter Hong Kong, a surprise move ahead of the 20th anniversary of the crackdown
on the demonstrations, a report said Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Xiong Yan, who was a leading student protester during the 1989 demonstrations in
Beijing and now lives in exile in the United States, was allowed into Hong Kong
without questioning, the Sunday Morning Post reported.
</P>
<P>
"I have not been to China for 17 years and... just feel very happy to be back in
the motherland," said Xiong, who is now a chaplain in the US army, according to
the Post. He arrived in the city on Saturday evening.
</P>
<P>
Xiong plans to join the annual candlelight vigil in the city this Thursday,
where tens of thousands are expected to mark the military crackdown on pro-
democracy protests, which left hundreds, possibly thousands dead across Beijing.
</P>
<P>
He is also launching a book about his life, including his role in the protests
and his experiences during the Iraq War, where he was posted in 2004, the
English-language paper said.
</P>
<P>
Several other Tiananmen dissidents have been denied entry to Hong Kong in recent
years, although the city operates a separate legal and immigration system from
mainland China.
</P>
<P>
Commenting on Xiong's reported entry, chairman of the city's Democratic Party
Albert Ho, told AFP he was surprised and said it was "probably due to an
omission" by the immigration authorities.
</P>
<P>
Xiong told the Post he would continue his fight for democracy so "people in
China can live with freedom like America one day."
</P>
<P>
Travelling on his US passport, the 45-year-old father-of-two said he was
relieved to have been allowed into the city. "In the weeks leading up to this
trip I couldn't sleep at night, I was so nervous," he told the Post.
</P>
<P>
Xiong, a law graduate, met then-Premier Li Peng during the demonstrations 20
years ago.
</P>
<P>
He was placed on a list of 21 most-wanted students in the weeks after the
crackdown and jailed for two years, before being smuggled out of China via Hong
Kong to the United States.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile, a Danish sculptor who flew to Hong Kong to protest the Tiananmen
crackdown has been refused entry to the city.
</P>
<P>
Jens Galschiot, whose sculpture commemorating those who died in 1989, "Pillar of
Shame," is displayed at Hong Kong University, was stopped by officials Saturday,
an immigration spokesman said.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Swedish pirates have wind in their sails for EU vote
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
stockholm, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
A Swedish party which wants an Internet filesharing free-for-all, the Pirate
Party, could become one of the surprise new entrants to the European parliament
this week.
</P>
<P>
The party, which also wants to beef up Internet privacy, was founded in January
2006 and quickly attracted members angered by controversial laws adopted in the
Scandinavian country that criminalised filesharing and authorised monitoring of
emails.
</P>
<P>
Its membership shot up after a Stockholm court on April 17 sentenced four Swedes
to a year in jail for running one of the world's biggest filesharing sites, The
Pirate Bay.
</P>
<P>
"When the verdict was announced at 11:00 am, we had 14,711 members," Rick
Falkvinge, the 37-year-old founder of the party, told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"We tripled in a week, becoming the third-biggest party in Sweden in terms of
numbers. All of a sudden we were everywhere."
</P>
<P>
Opinion polls ahead of the June 7 European parliament elections credit the party
with between 5.5 and 7.9 percent of votes, well above the four percent required
to win a seat.
</P>
<P>
In the 2006 general election, held eight months after it's creation, the Pirate
Party won just 0.6 percent of votes.
</P>
<P>
"They have been very lucky because The Pirate Bay verdict came at the same time
as the start of the election campaign, but I think The Pirate Party had the
potential to grow anyway," a political scientist at Gothenburg University, Ulf
Bjereld, told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"The Pirate Party has taken advantage of a new cleavage in Swedish politics,
about civil liberties, about who should have the right to decide over knowledge,
and that's not a left-right cleavage," Bjereld said.
</P>
<P>
"The traditional parties have been sleeping, they have underestimated the
political potential in these issues," he added.
</P>
<P>
The European parliament election, with little at stake in Sweden and a low
turnout expected, is considered the perfect opportunity for an election
sensation, according to experts.
</P>
<P>
"People tend to think there are very few differences between the parties in the
EU elections. If you could have a (unique) profile there, it's easier to
succeed," said Toivo Sjoeren, head of the Sifo polling institute.
</P>
<P>
The typical Pirate Party supporter is a young, male Internet buff.
</P>
<P>
According to Sifo, some 13 percent of people under 30 plan to vote for the
party, compared to seven percent of those aged 30 to 49, and only three percent
of those over the age of 49.
</P>
<P>
The party garners some 10.5 percent support among male voters, but only 1.5
percent of women.
</P>
<P>
"It's a 'geek' party," admitted Brian Levinsen, a 31-year-old member, attending
a recent campaign meeting in Stockholm.
</P>
<P>
"We use Twitter, Skype, we use blogs," explained Jan Lindgren, the party's
campaign director in Stockholm.
</P>
<P>
"There is always someone (from the party) online, even at 2:00 or 4:00 in the
morning," he added.
</P>
<P>
Many members say they joined not only because they are die-hard fans of the
Internet and filesharing, but because they fear a "Big Brother" society.
</P>
<P>
"Sweden was built on protecting the freedom of its citizens. This pact is now
disappearing," said Levinsen.
</P>
<P>
"They want to impose controls on what we're saying, like in China or in North
Korea. We're not there yet, but we're on the way," said Robert Nyberg, a 29
-year-old demolition worker clad in a purple tee-shirt bearing the party's black
flag.
</P>
<P>
The Pirate Party, which has sister parties in 20 countries, is also standing in
the European elections in Poland and Germany.
</P>
<P>
An estimated 375 million voters across the 27 nation bloc will elect 736
deputies for a five-year term at the parliament, which has an important role
passing pan-European legislation and the EU commission's annual budget.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Sarkozy exiles glamorous Dati
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
PARIS, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The outfits are still elegant, the heels still vertiginous, but Rachida Dati's
flashing smile seems just a little more forced since she found out she was being
exiled to the European parliament.
</P>
<P>
For the 42-year-old Dati, a virtually guaranteed victory in the EU election is
seen as proof of the justice minister's dramatic fall from President Nicolas
Sarkozy's good graces.
</P>
<P>
Once her seat in the EU parliament is confirmed after France's vote on June 7,
Dati, the first French minister from North African immigrant stock, will have to
resign from Sarkozy's government.
</P>
<P>
"I had the immense honour of being the justice minister, so I'm not going to be
bitter about it," Dati said in a television interview, warning: "They won't get
rid of me like that!"
</P>
<P>
Having risen to power as Sarkozy's devoted aide, she will now have to launch
into electoral politics away from her natural habitat in the glittering salons
of the Parisian elite.
</P>
<P>
Mocked by opponents as a lightweight, Dati was all steel and seriousness at a
recent electoral meeting in a well-heeled western Paris suburb.
</P>
<P>
She replied with poise to questions from the crowd, many drawn to the event more
by her celebrity status and reputation for gaffes than by enthusiasm for the
European parliament election.
</P>
<P>
"Rachida Dati lacks neither skill nor determination," said analyst Philippe
Braud. "She can bounce back. She has political trump cards: she represents
ethnic diversity, she's a fighter and she fascinates the media."
</P>
<P>
Dati, a lawyer by training who became an advisor and spokeswoman for Sarkozy,
was an outsider without political experience when he made her justice minister
after his 2007 election triumph.
</P>
<P>
Dati, with her rags to riches background, and other surprise female picks added
energy to the line up, and Sarkozy was visibly proud of her.
</P>
<P>
She threw herself into an ambitious programme to reform the French legal system,
closely following promises made by the president, but antagonised a generation
of magistrates and ministerial aides with her domineering style.
</P>
<P>
A close friend of Sarkozy's second wife, Cecilia, she became a regular feature
in celebrity magazines and gossip columns, gaining a reputation for her couture
outfits and jet set parties.
</P>
<P>
Eyebrows were also raised when the government was forced to confirm that the
justice ministry had overspent its 200,000-euro (272,000-dollar) annual
entertainment budget after she hosted several luxury receptions.
</P>
<P>
Concerned that his protegee needed a power base of her own, Sarkozy had her
parachuted into Paris' 7th district as mayor, and began to push for her to take
on a more party political role.
</P>
<P>
But Dati's star slipped as magistrates demonstrated against her bid to
streamline the court system and jail wardens against conditions said to have
contributed to a spate of prison suicides.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile, other changes were afoot. Nicolas and Cecilia Sarkozy divorced and
Dati has never been as close to his third wife, former super model Carla Bruni.
</P>
<P>
Dati's private life is also, in her own term, "complicated". In January, she
gave birth to a daughter, Zohra. Her refusal to name the child's father has
triggered a whirl of media speculation about his identity.
</P>
<P>
She rushed back to work five days later, earning praise from some quarters as a
role model for career women, but brickbats from those who thought her haste
undermined the fight for generous maternity leave.
</P>
<P>
Nevertheless, despite Dati's display of unruffled commitment to his cause,
Sarkozy took personal charge of the judicial reform agenda, in an early sign
that he was tiring of his former ally.
</P>
<P>
Rather than sack her and call into question his own judgment in picking her,
Sarkozy set about strong-arming her into the European campaign, which she had
previously said she had no interest in.
</P>
<P>
The race began badly when a video of her giggling inanely and failing to answer
questions on European policy at a youth event made the rounds of the Internet.
She has since showed more determination and ambition in the campaign.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0361" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Guide to Europe's four day election marathon
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
BRUSSELS, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The European Union parliament has long had the image of being a gravy-train but
an EU election is no picnic.
</P>
<P>
The voting system is as arcane as the 27-nation EU is widespread. The election
for the 736 lawmakers takes four days and there will be weeks of bargaining
afterwards to settle the assembly's top jobs.
</P>
<P>
Voting starts on Thursday in Britain and the Netherlands. Ireland holds its
election on the following day, the Czech Republic on June 5 and 6, and Slovakia
Latvia, Malta and Cyprus vote on June 6.
</P>
<P>
France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the other 15 countries in the EU all hold
their elections on the Sunday. The first reliable forecasts will come out about
2000 GMT on the night of June 7.
</P>
<P>
Each country uses its own preferred voting system.
</P>
<P>
While any EU citizen can stand as a candidate or vote in any EU country where he
or she is resident and registered on the electoral list, rules such as the
minimum age for voting changes from country to country.
</P>
<P>
There were 785 deputies in the old assembly. The Treaty of Nice ordered the
cutback but this could be only temporary. If the Treaty of Lisbon is ever
ratified by every member the number will go up again to 754.
</P>
<P>
Each country's representation is roughly in line with its population. Malta, the
smallest member, has five deputies. Germany, the biggest, has 99. The other main
powers -- Britain, France and Italy -- have 72 each, while Poland and Spain
elect 50 each.
</P>
<P>
One of the big unknowns is how the extra 18 deputies will be shared out, if the
Lisbon reform treaty comes into force.
</P>
<P>
The first meeting of the new assembly will be on July 14-16 in Strasbourg.
</P>
<P>
It will have to elect a new parliament president to take charge of the assembly
for the first half of its five year term.
</P>
<P>
As the centre-right bloc is expected to gain the upper hand in the election,
their candidates, former Polish prime minister Jerzy Buzek, and Italian Euro
deputy Mario Mauro, a close ally of Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi,
are favourites.
</P>
<P>
One of their first duties will also be to approve the European Commission
president nominated by an EU summit at the end of June. Jose Manuel Barroso, the
former Portuguese prime minister, is widely expected to get a second term.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0362" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Europe's desperate bid to bring out voters
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
brussels, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
European leaders on Sunday stepped up a desperate battle to persuade people to
vote for the unloved EU parliament this week, but the campaign has opened up new
political divisions across the continent.
</P>
<P>
With polls indicating a record low turnout for the June 4-7 election, French
President Nicolas Sarkozy and German Chancellor Angela Merkel issued a joint
plea to voters, saying a strong parliament was essential to confront the
economic crisis.
</P>
<P>
The two said they want "a strong Europe that protects" its people and called for
"all Europeans to vote" in the statement, published by the Journal du Dimanche
newspaper in France and Die Welt am Sonntag in Germany.
</P>
<P>
A "strong Europe does not necessarily mean more powers for the European Union,
even more European legislation or even more financial means," said Merkel and
Sarkozy who still called for "real European regulation" to tackle the financial
crisis.
</P>
<P>
They said first steps "to assure real European regulation in the financial
sector, based on coordination and cooperation between regulators" should be
taken at the EU summit in June.
</P>
<P>
"For speculative funds, tax havens, payment for executives and financial
traders, we want an exemplary Europe," the French and German leaders said.
</P>
<P>
The pair also gave strong backing to the Lisbon reform treaty, deadlocked by
Ireland's rejection in a referendum last year.
</P>
<P>
"Europe must play a leading role in the world. For that, it must have efficient
institutions. That is why we need the Lisbon Treaty," they said.
</P>
<P>
Merkel and Sarkozy said they were ready to work on "political accord on
guarantees for Ireland" at the June summit and they have "confidence in the
Irish to choose Europe" when they hold a new referendum this year.
</P>
<P>
The two also reaffirmed opposition to Turkey joining the EU, without naming the
country. "To be able to act, the EU needs frontiers. Unlimited enlargement is
not possible."
</P>
<P>
The statement highlighted fears that the vote for the 736 member European
assembly could prove a new embarrassment for the 27-nation EU.
</P>
<P>
There was a record 45 percent abstention at the last election in 2004.
</P>
<P>
Surveys in France indicate that only a third of the electorate will take part in
the country's EU vote next Sunday.
</P>
<P>
In Britain, Poland and Romania, fewer than one in three people plan to vote,
according to recent surveys.
</P>
<P>
In Spain, which has benefited enormously from EU funds, analysts expect turnout
of 40 percent at best. Portugal expects a record abstention rate.
</P>
<P>
The stakes are higher now however as the parliament is likely to win a bigger
voice in decisions that affect the EU's 500 million population if the Lisbon
treaty comes into force.
</P>
<P>
"A lot of voters don't understand what the European Parliament does," said
Philip White, senior research fellow at the Centre for European Reform in
London.
</P>
<P>
"You're not voting to keep a government in office or kick it out. The stakes can
seem a little bit less clear than they are in national elections," he said.
</P>
<P>
But in many countries the EU vote will be a test of the national governments in
power. Far right and left wing parties are expected to benefit from protest
votes in some countries.
</P>
<P>
Polls indicate Britain's ruling Labour Party will be hammered in the election,
which will be held on Thursday, possibly dropping into third place.
</P>
<P>
The leader of the main opposition Conservative Party, David Cameron, has opened
up new divisions in Europe by saying he would withdraw his party from the main
centre-right bloc in the EU parliament, the European People's Party (EPP), and
join a new more euro-sceptic alliance with parties from the Czech Republic and
Poland.
</P>
<P>
Swedish Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt's conservative Moderates are also
losing ground in the run-up to the elections, according to opinion poll released
Saturday.
</P>
<P>
The EPP is still expected to remain the biggest single party in the parliament,
which already has a key role approving the EU budget and passing laws on a wide
range of issues.
</P>
<P>
The parliament will also endorse the new president of the European Commission
after a nomination is made by the EU summit. Jose Manuel Barroso, the
conservative former Portuguese prime minister, is widely expected to get a
second term.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
SKorean carmaker Ssangyong closes strike-hit plant
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
SEOUL, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
South Korea's smallest automaker Ssangyong Motor said Sunday that it had
temporarily shut its main factory, which has been occupied by workers striking
over massive planned job cuts.
</P>
<P>
"The closure was inevitable because of mounting losses, which have endangered
our survival," the company said in a statement, adding it would ask police to
evict the workers from the plant in Pyeongtaek, south of Seoul.
</P>
<P>
The work stoppage began on May 21 after the company announced plans to sack
2,646 employees -- 36 percent of its workforce -- in what would be the country's
first mass layoffs since the onset of the global economic crisis.
</P>
<P>
Workers occupying the factory are demanding managers minimise job losses through
work-sharing.
</P>
<P>
The debt-stricken company in February won court protection from creditors.  The
court told its Chinese majority owner, Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp (SAIC),
to give up management control.
</P>
<P>
Court-appointed managers have since struggled to turn the company around through
job cuts and cost savings.
</P>
<P>
Ssangyong specialises in sports-utility vehicles and luxury sedans.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Israel rescue services begin 'doomsday' drill
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Jerusalem, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Israel began its largest-ever national exercise on Sunday to test the response
of emergency services to potential missile attacks, bombings and natural
disasters.
</P>
<P>
The five-day exercise will simulate simultaneous rocket strikes from the Gaza
Strip and Lebanon and missile attacks from arch-foes Syria and Iran and test the
way rescue services deal with the attacks.
</P>
<P>
"We will be exercising the doomsday scenario of simultaneous strikes against
Israel on all fronts and by different means," defence ministry spokesman Shlomo
Dror told AFP last week.
</P>
<P>
This will include conventional, chemical and biological strikes against large
population centres. It will also simulate a wave of Palestinian suicide
bombings.
</P>
<P>
On Tuesday, when air-raid sirens sound across the country and citizens must
scramble to shelters, in some areas within seconds and others within no more
than three minutes.
</P>
<P>
Exercise Turning Point 3 will also simulate the conduct of rescue and medical
services during earthquakes and epidemics.
</P>
<P>
And there will be simulated cabinet meetings in which ministers will weigh their
response to such attacks and scenarios.
</P>
<P>
It is the third consecutive year Israel is conducting such an exercise, although
this year's drill is the largest-ever.
</P>
<P>
The manoeuvres began in the aftermath of the July-August 2006 war with Lebanon's
Hezbollah militia, which revealed major weaknesses in how the Jewish state's
homefront dealt with the rocket attacks.
</P>
<P>
"The Second Lebanon War revealed that the homefront was not well prepared for
war and citizens found it hard to adapt to the special situation," Dror said.
</P>
<P>
The drill comes just two weeks after the air force wrapped up a massive four-day
exercise that tested its ability to defend against missile and jet strikes from
Syria and Iran.
</P>
<P>
It was the first time the army has simulated strikes from the Islamic republic,
located more than 1,000 kilometres (620 miles) away, he said.
</P>

<HEADLINE>

Jerusalem, Israel, May 31, 2009 (AFP)

Israel makes a distinction between those the government authorised and so-called
wildcat outposts, set up by zealous settlers without state approval.
</P>
<P>
Netanyahu has said his government would dismantle the outposts, but has argued
that expansion of existing blocks should be allowed to continue.
