<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0373" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Pakistan hunts Taliban leadership after Swat gain
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Peshawar, Pakistan, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Pakistan on Sunday pursued the Taliban leadership in the northwest after seizing
the main town in Swat valley from the militants, as it continues its drive to
flush out extremists.
</P>
<P>
The business and administrative hub of Mingora was back in government hands,
military officials announced late Saturday, more than a month after Islamabad
began its blistering assault against advancing Taliban insurgents.
</P>
<P>
The army is still fighting Taliban guerrillas, but the fall of Mingora is a
critical milestone in an offensive across three northwest districts launched
after the Taliban thrust to within 100 kilometres (60 miles) of Islamabad.
</P>
<P>
Washington, which is firmly backing the military drive, had warned the rebels
threatened Pakistan's very existence and identified the country and neighbouring
Afghanistan as central to its 'war on terror'.
</P>
<P>
"We are trying to target the top leadership of militants and they are constantly
being followed," chief military spokesman Major General Athar Abbas said as he
announced the Mingora win.
</P>
<P>
Officials said lower-ranking leaders had been killed but it was harder to get to
the top leaders, who had a network of hardcore militants around them.
</P>
<P>
"They will be eliminated wherever we find them," said one military official, who
did not wish to be named as he was not authorised to speak to the media, adding
that: "We believe that they are somewhere in the mountains."
</P>
<P>
Pakistan has slapped a 600,000-dollar price on the head of firebrand Swat
Taliban commander Maulana Fazlullah for masterminding the nearly two-year
uprising in Swat valley to enforce sharia law.
</P>
<P>
The insurgency has transformed a scenic region once popular with Western
tourists for its soaring peaks, pristine ski slopes and cool mountain air into a
battle ground, with armed Taliban in April patrolling the streets of Mingora.
</P>
<P>
Fazlullah led thousands of supporters, a mixture of hardcore ideologues and
disenfranchised young men, in a brutal campaign that beheaded opponents, burned
scores of schools and fought against government troops since November 2007.
</P>
<P>
The government has also offered rewards for 21 rebel chiefs -- dead or alive --
from Swat, and on Thursday listed names and published mugshots.
</P>
<P>
Pakistan's northwestern capital Peshawar and the eastern cultural centre of
Lahore have both been rocked by deadly explosions in the last five days, as
fears grow that the Taliban is exacting revenge for the offensive.
</P>
<P>
A spokesman for Pakistan Taliban chief Baitullah Mehsud -- who has a five-
million-dollar bounty on his head posted by the United States -- had on Thursday
claimed the suicide attack on a police building in Lahore.
</P>
<P>
Hakimullah Mehsud also warned of more "massive attacks" on government buildings
to revenge the Swat military operation and in protest at Islamabad's close ties
with Washington.
</P>
<P>
Baitullah Mehsud commands Tehreek-e-Taliban from the lawless tribal area of
Waziristan on the Afghan border in the rugged mountains, where militants branded
by Washington as the greatest terror threat to the West are holed up.
</P>
<P>
Nearly 2.4 million people have fled the fighting in the northwest and now huddle
in refugee camps or with relatives, and as the crisis drags on analysts warn
that public opinion against the offensive may sour.
</P>
<P>
The military said it had relaxed its strict curfew Sunday in most parts of the
northwest including Mingora to allow people trapped on the roads as they tried
to flee the offensive to return home or leave the region.
</P>
<P>
"The curfew will be relaxed from 6:00 am to 1:00 pm in Swat and Malakand," a
statement issued by the military said.
</P>
<P>
Hundreds of people were seen trudging along the main roads out of the region on
foot amid a long, snaking traffic jam, a government official said.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Iran defuses bomb on board domestic flight: Fars agency
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Tehran, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Iranian security officials have defused a handmade bomb on board a domestic
flight headed from Ahvaz, in the west of Iran, to the capital Tehran, Fars news
agency reported on Sunday.
</P>
<P>
"Last night, 15 minutes after the plane with 131 passengers took off, flight
security guards found a handmade bomb placed in the lavatory," Fars said. "The
plane landed immediately in Ahvaz airport and the bomb was defused."
</P>
<P>
It said the Kish Air flight had taken off at 10:20 pm (1750 GMT) Saturday.
</P>
<P>
Ahvaz is the capital of Iran's oil-rich Khuzestan province, which borders Iraq
and the Gulf. Sunday's incident occurred as Iran prepares for presidential
elections on June 12.
</P>
<P>
On Thursday a suicide bomber killed 25 and wounded 125 worshippers in a Shiite
mosque in Zahedan in southeastern Sistan-Baluchestan province bordering
Afghanistan and Pakistan.
</P>
<P>
The province, which is home to Iran's Baluch minority who adhere to Sunni Islam,
has been the scene of a deadly insurgency by a Sunni rebel group which is
strongly opposed to the government of predominantly Shiite Iran.
</P>
<P>
The attack on the mosque was reminiscent of a similar outbreak of violence just
days before Iran's last presidential election in 2005 which brought Mahmoud
Ahmadinejad to power.
</P>
<P>
Bombs hit Tehran and Ahvaz, which has a sizable Arab minority, in June 2005,
killing at least eight people and wounding scores more.
</P>
<P>
Some 500 kilometres (320 miles) southeast of Tehran and 50 kilometres from the
Iraqi border, Ahvaz was also rocked by ethnic violence in April 2005.
</P>
<P>
Iran in the past has blamed US and British agents in neighbouring Iraq and
Afghanistan for launching attacks on border provinces with significant ethnic
minority populations.
</P>
</TEXT>

New Delhi, May 31, 2009 (AFP)

Bollywood legend Amitabh Bachchan has  rejected an honorary doctorate from a

<P>
"Under the prevailing circumstances I find it inappropriate at this juncture to

contribution to the world of entertainment.

</P>

A series of attacks on Indian students has unleashed a furious reaction in India

saying the students were simply in the wrong place at the wrong time.
</P>

India has said it is "closely monitoring" the situation, while Australia's High
Commissioner in New Delhi, John McCarthy, sought to defend his country's
reputation Sunday and allay fears that foreign students were in danger.
</P>
<P>
"I would deny that we are a racist country. Australia is generally a safe
country," he told the NDTV news channel.
</P>
<P>
Indians form the second-largest group of overseas students in Australia, and
police estimate they make up 30 percent of robbery victims in Melbourne's
western suburbs, where many of the students live.

<HEADLINE>
Myanmar's Suu Kyi upset after authorities enter home: party
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
YANGON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Myanmar democracy icon Aung San Suu Kyi has accused the ruling junta of
"bullying" after authorities entered her home without permission while she is in
prison facing trial, her party said Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Officials took US national John Yettaw to her lakeside house last week to stage
a reconstruction, for the purposes of the trial, of a bizarre incident in early
May in which he swam to her home, party spokesman Nyan Win said.
</P>
<P>
The Nobel laureate is on trial at Yangon's notorious Insein Prison and faces up
to five years in jail on charges of breaching the terms of her house arrest. She
has spent 13 of the past 19 years in detention.
</P>
<P>
"Aung San Suu Kyi said she is not completely satisfied as Mr Yettaw and the
authorities went into her compound last week for a demonstration (of how he got
into the property)," Nyan Win told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"It was not in accordance with the law. She said it was unjust bullying," added
Nyan Win, who is both the spokesman for her National League for Democracy party
and also part of her legal team.
</P>
<P>
Yettaw, a 53-year-old Mormon and former US military veteran, was arrested on May
6 after swimming to Aung San Suu Kyi's house using a pair of homemade flippers
and spending two nights there. He is also on trial.
</P>
<P>
Critics say Myanmar's military regime has trumped up the charges in a bid to
keep her locked up ahead of elections in 2010, as the latest six-year period of
her house arrest expired on Wednesday.
</P>
<P>
Nyan Win said that despite the apparently unfortunate timing of the incident,
Aung San Suu Kyi did not harbour hard feelings against Yettaw.
</P>
<P>
"She also said she has no grudge to Mr Yettaw and his family," he said.
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi told the trial last week that she had not violated her house
arrest and that she had only offered Yettaw ""temporary shelter" as he was ill.
</P>
<P>
She insisted that she could not be held responsible as the junta had failed to
boost security despite her having reported that Yettaw made a previous visit to
the house in November 2008.
</P>
<P>
But Major General Aye Myint, Myanmar's deputy defence minister, told a security
forum in Singapore on Sunday that Aung San Suu Kyi had "committed a cover-up of
the truth" by failing to report Yettaw's visit in May.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Fate of Tamil Tiger spy chief unclear: report
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Colombo, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The Sri Lankan military is probing the possibility that the Tamil Tiger's spy
chief may still be alive, despite testimony that he was killed with the rest of
the rebel leadership.
</P>
<P>
"The military is still investigating Tiger intelligence wing leader Pottu
Amman's death as they could not find his body among the top level Tiger
leaders," the state-run Sunday Observer said.
</P>
<P>
Amman was seen as the number two in the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE)
hierarchy after rebel leader Velupillai Prabhakaran and was believed to have
masterminded the 1991 assassination of Indian premier Rajiv Gandhi.
</P>
<P>
The newspaper, which reflects government policy, said the military had testimony
from a surrendered Tiger cadre who claimed that the spy leader had been killed
before the final battle in which Prabhakaran perished.
</P>
<P>
However, no body was ever found.
</P>
<P>
Amman is the subject of an international arrest warrant for the Gandhi slaying
as well as the 1996 bombing of the Sri Lankan Central Bank which killed 91
people.
</P>
<P>
The Observer said the military could not confirm the deaths of Prabhakaran's
wife, Mathiwathini, and their daughter, Dwarka, although they were suspected to
have been in the same area during the final military offensive against the LTTE.
</P>
<P>
The military on Thursday identified Prabhakaran's parents, who had sought
shelter with security forces after fleeing the conflict zone.
</P>
<P>
Government troops announced the defeat of the LTTE two weeks ago.
</P>
<P>
Ethnic Tamils displaced by the fighting are now being held in camps ringed by
barbed wire and security forces, who say they need to weed out former rebel
fighters disguised as civilians.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Student bashings strain Australia-India relations
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Melbourne, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Indian students rallied in Melbourne on Sunday as Australia scrambled to contain
outrage over a wave of attacks that has seen it labelled racist and strained
diplomatic relations with New Delhi.
</P>
<P>
What began as a local policing issue in Australia's second largest city has
spiralled into a crisis that prompted Prime Minister Kevin Rudd to call his
Indian counterpart Manmohan Singh last week to assure him about student safety.
</P>
<P>
The students are demanding action after more than 70 assaults on their peers in
a year in Melbourne, including at least four in the past fortnight, and there
has been prominent coverage in newspapers here and in India.
</P>
<P>
Pictures from a hospital bed of a comatose Sravan Kumar Theerthala, who was
stabbed with a screwdriver by gatecrashers at a party, were splashed across
newspapers in India. A teenager has been charged with attempted murder.
</P>
<P>
"They were saying, 'Don't touch us you Indians' and 'Indians go home' before
they got the screwdriver," said Theerthala's friend, Jayasanka Bagpelli.
</P>
<P>
Another student, Baljinder Singh, told Australian public radio last week how his
attackers laughed as he pleaded with them during a robbery at a Melbourne train
station.
</P>
<P>
"I was saying to them, 'I'm giving you all my money, don't kill me, don't kill
me'," said Singh, who was stabbed and left with a six-inch (15-centimetre) wound
to his stomach and advised Indians to stay away from Australia.
</P>
<P>
Indian media have dubbed the attacks "curry bashings", picking up on a term
reportedly used by some of the youths behind the violence in Melbourne's western
suburbs, where police say 30 percent of assault victims are Indian.
</P>
<P>
It is a grossly disproportionate figure in a city of almost four million people
where the Indian student population numbers less than 50,000.
</P>
<P>
Police deny any racial element to the attacks, arguing Indian students were
often simply in the wrong place at the wrong time as they travelled home late at
night with items such as mobile phones and portable MP3 players.
</P>
<P>
But Indian High Commissioner to Australia Sujatha Singh said last week that
racism was playing a part, even if some of the crimes were "opportunistic".
</P>
<P>
Federation of Indian Students president Amit Menghani, who led the rally of more
than a thousand supporters through central Melbourne Sunday, said the police
attitude had frustrated many students.
</P>
<P>
Bagpelli, who attended the rally, added: "It's only because the Indian
government is now applying pressure that they are doing anything."
</P>
<P>
While the attacks are unlikely to result in any permanent damage at a diplomatic
level, Canberra is concerned parents in India may prevent their children
studying in Australia.
</P>
<P>
That would threaten the international education sector here, a 15.5 billion
dollar (12.2 billion US) a year industry that has attracted more than 90,000
Indians to the country.
</P>
<P>
More broadly, with headlines such as "Australia, land of racism" running in
overseas media, there are also fears Australia's reputation for tolerance is
sustaining long-term damage.
</P>
<P>
A string of government ministers have made statements recently emphasising the
country's multi-cultural society and relatively low levels of violence.
</P>
<P>
"We need to help make sure that the mothers and fathers of all students who come
here are assured that Australia is a safe location to come to, that our general
crime rates and violence rates are very low," Foreign Minister Stephen Smith
told commercial television Sunday.
</P>
<P>
The assault on Theerthala proved the catalyst, High Commissioner Singh
describing it as a particularly distressing case.
</P>
<P>
It sparked a flurry of high-level diplomatic activity and strong public
statements from Indian officials that indicated they had run out of patience.
</P>
<P>
"Such attacks cannot be allowed to happen," Singh said.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Indian author Kamala Das dead at 75
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
New Delhi, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Writer and poet Kamala Das, known for her frank discussion of female sexuality
in conservative India, died in hospital on Sunday, the Press Trust of India
reported. She was 75.
</P>
<P>
Das died in the western city of Pune after a long illness, PTI said, without
specifying the cause of death.
</P>
<P>
Das was born into a family of writers and wrote poems and short stories in
English and Malayalam, the language of her southern home state of Kerala.
</P>
<P>
She was one of the first Indian writers to explore sexual themes in her work,
and her 1976 autobiography, My Story, was a candid recollection of her own
sexual coming of age that was translated into 15 languages.
</P>
<P>
Das converted to Islam in 1999 and took the name Kamala Surayya, but later
appeared to regret it, saying "God has no connection with any religion. There is
no respect for women anywhere."
</P>
<P>
She also dabbled in politics, launching the Lok Seva Party but failing to win a
seat in parliament.
</P>
<P>
Das is survived by two sons.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<TEXT>
<P>
Result of an international friendly match between El Salvador and Jamaica on
Saturday:
</P>
<P>
El Salvador 0 Jamaica 0

<HEADLINE>
GM bondholders approve debt restructuring deal: report
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Washington, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Ailing General Motors moved closer Sunday to its expected bankruptcy filing as
company bondholders approved a  government-sponsored debt for equity deal, The
New York Times reported.
</P>
<P>
The bondholders had until 5:00 pm (2100 GMT) Saturday to indicate whether they
supported the group's new offer ahead of the once mighty corporation's looming
bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
The government's rescue plan for GM could put as much as 72.5 percent of the
country's biggest automaker under state ownership.
</P>
<P>
Citing "people briefed on the matter," the newspaper said the bondholders with
slightly more than 50 percent of GM’s 27.2 billion dollars in bond debt agreed
to support the plan by the government-set deadline.
</P>
<P>
Among the backers was a committee of large investors holding about 20 percent of
GM’s outstanding bonds, The Times said.
</P>
<P>
No official announcement of the vote tally has yet been made.
</P>
<P>
Under the plan, the bondholders would obtain the rights to buy an extra 15
percent of GM's stock at a low price. They would also control 25 percent of the
"new GM," after having supported the new company's creation in bankruptcy court.
</P>
<P>
Recalcitrant bondholders who opt for confrontation rather than cooperation "will
get nothing or very little," an Obama administration official told reporters
Thursday.
</P>
<P>
Government-backed restructuring in bankruptcy court for GM, once the world's
largest automaker, appeared all but certain ahead of a Monday deadline imposed
by the Obama administration on the company to submit a viable restructuring plan
or file for bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
It could take place as early as Sunday.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0388" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Sri Lanka seeks help in dismantling Tigers' global network
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Singapore, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Sri Lanka appealed Sunday for support in dismantling the Tamil Tigers'
international support network after declaring victory over the rebels following
the decades-long conflict.
</P>
<P>
Foreign Minister Rohitha Bogollagama told a high-level security forum in
Singapore that the global organisation of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam
(LTTE) remained "largely intact."
</P>
<P>
"Many of the operatives have clearly cultivated powerful, political lobbies in
certain capitals with a view to resurrecting the LTTE," he said.
</P>
<P>
"It is important for the international community to take all measures to assist
the government of Sri Lanka to track down the global network of the LTTE," he
told an annual forum of defence and military officials organised by the London-
based International Institute for Strategic Studies.
</P>
<P>
Sri Lanka's military claimed complete victory over the separatist Tamil Tigers
after wiping out the guerrillas' leadership nearly two weeks ago, but has been
dogged by accusations that thousands of civilians were killed in the final weeks
of the campaign.
</P>
<P>
The LTTE launched a campaign in 1972 to create a Tamil homeland in the
Sinhalese-majority island. Much of its funding came from Tamils overseas.
</P>
<P>
Bogollagama dismissed allegations that heavy weapons were used by the military
in civilian areas as part of the "propaganda of genocide against the Tamil
people."
</P>
<P>
"This was both fictional and well-fabricated, with ulterior and sinister motives
in order to discredit the armed forces as well as to embarrass the government of
Sri Lanka," he added.
</P>
<P>
"Sri Lanka will no doubt enter the annals of history as a classic textbook
example of a nation that successfully prevailed over the scourge of terrorism,
whilst tenaciously upholding the cherished values of democracy and human rights
that have been deeply engraved in the psyche of our people," he said.
</P>
<P>
"The government is firmly committed to reaching a political settlement
acceptable to all," the foreign minister said.
</P>
<P>
Sri Lanka's handling of the LTTE "has sent a strong signal to the international
community that terror can be defeated and terrorism can be eliminated," he
added.
</P>
<P>
Amnesty International called Saturday for an independent probe into the number
of civilians killed following a report in London's Times newspaper citing
confidential UN reports that said more than 20,000 civilians were killed by Sri
Lankan army shelling.
</P>
<P>
Sri Lanka's Human Rights Minister Mahinda Samarasinghe has dismissed Amnesty's
call and said the organisation was being "ridiculous to keep harping on things
they cannot substantiate."
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0389" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Boxing: Berto retains WBC welterweight title
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
HOLLYWOOD, Florida, May 30, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Haitian-born American Andre Berto retained his World Boxing Council welterweight
title Saturday with a lopsided unanimous 12-round decision over Colombian Juan
Urango.
</P>
<P>
Two judges scored the bout 118-110 for the Florida-based Berto, while a third
saw it 117-111.
</P>
<P>
Berto remained unbeaten in 25 professional fights, with 19 wins inside the
distance.
</P>
<P>
Urango was frustrated by the nimble Berto, who kept his distance and scored to
the head with the jab and with his right.
</P>
<P>
Urango' best round was the fourth, when he landed a series of lefts to the head
and body.
</P>
<P>
But Berto largely avoided Urango's pressure, givig him little opportunity to get
inside in the middle rounds while connecting himself with shots to Urango's head
with both hands.
</P>
<P>
After a lackluster ninth round drew jeers from the crowd, Berto stepped it up in
the last three rounds.
</P>
<P>
Urango, who fell to 21-2-1 with 16 wins inside the distance, will now return to
the super lightweight ranks, where he is still the International Boxing
Federation title holder.
</P>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0391" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Taliban take war to Pakistan cities
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Islamabad, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Taliban rebels in Pakistan are taking their war to the cities, honing terror
tactics to maximise civilian carnage after suffering heavy losses in a
blistering military offensive, analysts say.
</P>
<P>
Pakistan has been rocked by 14 bomb blasts that have killed more than 80 people
in urban areas since it launched a determined air and ground assault against the
Taliban in pockets of the northwest at the end of April.
</P>
<P>
The military said on Saturday that troops had regained control of the main town
of Mingora in Swat valley from the Taliban, in what is being touted as a
significant milestone in the month-long ongoing offensive.
</P>
<P>
But the rebels, who Washington fears threaten Pakistan's very existence, are
striking back in cities like the regional capital Peshawar, about 200 kilometres
(125 miles) from Mingora and previously shielded from major attacks.
</P>
<P>
"They are taking this war to the cities, hoping to build up enough pressure on
the government to halt the military activity," security analyst Hasan Askari
told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"The Taliban challenge now threatens routine life and commercial activity in
cities... allied extremist groups are facilitating their agenda," he added.
</P>
<P>
Attackers are becoming increasingly sophisticated, analysts say, executing
commando-style assaults armed with suicide vests, vehicle bombs, guns, grenades
and rockets.
</P>
<P>
Over the last two weeks in Peshawar, bombs have exploded outside a cinema, near
crowded electronics shops, at a police checkpoint and even alongside a bus full
of children with special needs.
</P>
<P>
And in Lahore, Pakistan's entertainment capital, a bomb, gun and grenade assault
killed 24 people and partially damaged the provincial headquarters of the
country's premier spy agency on Wednesday.
</P>
<P>
It was the third spectacular assault in and around the eastern city -- hundreds
of miles from the offensive in the northwest -- in as many months.
</P>
<P>
The Tehreek-e-Taliban (TTP) militant group claimed responsibility, telling
people in a statement they should get out of the cities because there will be
more violence to come.
</P>
<P>
Newspaper columnist Shafqat Mehmood said the Taliban, who want to enforce sharia
law, are becoming more and more desperate in the face of the military onslaught
in the northwest, which the army says has claimed 1,200 rebels.
</P>
<P>
"Militants are under pressure and will employ any tactic to cause maximum
damage. Urban terrorism is one of those tactics," said Mehmood.
</P>
<P>
While the government could do more to protect key targets, he said, underfunded
and overstretched security forces can only do so much.
</P>
<P>
"It is difficult to patrol markets and streets," he added.
</P>
<P>
"Our province is facing a war-like situation," the police chief of North West
Frontier Province, Malik Naved Khan, told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"We have 9,000 police. In a big city like Peshawar, this is not enough to deal
with situations like the one we're facing," said Khan.
</P>
<P>
Northwest expert Rahimullah Yusufzai said the Taliban were increasingly focused
on civilian targets as widespread public opinion turns -- for the first time --
in favour of Pakistan's military operation.
</P>
<P>
The offensive already has the firm backing of Washington, which says Al-Qaeda
and Taliban have carved out safe havens in the northwestern areas bordering
Afghanistan to plot terror attacks on the West.
</P>
<P>
"The Taliban have jacked up attacks targeting civilians as they have failed to
target security forces," Yusufzai said.
</P>
<P>
Echoing Hasan Askari, he added the Taliban will likely have willing allies from
a catalogue of banned radical groups that traditionally have battled India in
Kashmir.
</P>
<P>
These include Lashkar-i-Jhangvi, Yusufzai said, an extremist element linked to
Al-Qaeda, and Lashkar-e-Taiba, accused of carrying out the Mumbai attacks last
year that left 166 dead.
</P>
<P>
"These extremist outfits and TTP (Tehreek-e-Taliban) have a relationship that
runs in their blood. They are natural allies who lived and fought together."
</P>
<P>
Alarmingly, the government in Islamabad had no particular strategy to prevent
attacks on cities, Yusufzai said, warning he did not see an end to the urban
bloodshed any time soon.
</P>
<P>
"I don't think the situation can be brought under control quickly because it has
roots in (the tribal areas of) Waziristan and Bajaur, and what is happening in
those two regions is linked to the Taliban in Afghanistan," he said.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0392" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Aung San Suu Kyi 'covered up' truth: Myanmar junta
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Singapore, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi "covered up" the truth by failing to report
an American man in her home, a senior Myanmar official said Sunday, warning
foreigners not to interfere in the case.
</P>
<P>
"It is no doubt that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi has committed a cover-up of the truth
by her failure to report an illegal immigrant to the authorities concerned,"
Major General Aye Myint, Myanmar's deputy defence minister, told a security
forum in Singapore.
</P>
<P>
"Thus there was no option but to open legal proceedings in accordance with the
law," he said.
</P>
<P>
"She permitted him to stay.... She communicated, provided him food and shelter,"
Aye Myint said.
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi, a Nobel peace laureate, is facing up to five years' detention
on charges relating to the surprise visit of an eccentric American to her
lakeside prison home in early May.
</P>
<P>
In his speech to regional security officials and experts, the general said the
case against Aung San Suu Kyi was an internal matter for Myanmar to resolve
without foreign intervention.
</P>
<P>
"Countries should refrain from interfering in the internal affairs of Myanmar
that will affect peace and security of the region," sid Aye Myint.
</P>
<P>
"Solving one's internal affairs through its legal system with legal proceedings
in accordance with law does not amount to the threat of peace or breach of
security of the region," he said in an apparent reaction to criticism of the
charges against Aung San Suu Kyi from other forum participants.
</P>
<P>
Ann Taylor, Britain's minister for international defence and security, said at
the meeting earlier Sunday that Aung San Suu Kyi should be released.
</P>
<P>
"The continued imprisonment of Aung San Suu Kyi by the Burmese regime is a
reminder that we cannot take for granted the institution of democracy," she
said, referring to Myanmar by its former name.
</P>
<P>
"The people of Burma have suffered for nearly half a century of conflict and
isolation, but Aung San Suu Kyi is not alone," Taylor said.
</P>
<P>
"People all around the world are standing with her and the Burmese people and we
say to the generals: Now is the time for transition to democracy starting with
the release of Aung San Suu Kyi."
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0393" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
3 Palestinian police and 1 Hamas militant killed in clash: police
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
NABLUS, West Bank, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Three Palestinian police officers and one Hamas militant were killed in an

Palestinian police said.
</P>
<P>
The policemen were killed while they were attempting to arrest Mohammad Yassine,
a member of the Ezzedine al-Qassam Brigades, Hamas's military wing, who had

</P>
<P>

</P>
<P>
A curfew was imposed on the town following the incident, said the police.
</P>
<P>

Mahmoud Abbas, violently ousted Fatah from the Gaza Strip in June 2007,
effectively limiting Abbas's rule to the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

<HEADLINE>
Basketball: Magic beat Cavaliers to book NBA finals berth
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
ORLANDO, Florida, May 30, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The Orlando Magic will battle the Los Angeles Lakers for the National Basketball
Association title after defeating Cleveland 103-90 on Saturday in game six of
the Eastern Conference finals.
</P>
<P>
Orlando's "Superman" Dwight Howard poured in 40 points for the Magic, who are
returning to the NBA finals championship series for the first time in 14 years.
</P>
<P>
To get there they stunned Cleveland - the team with the best regular-season
record in the league and Most Valuable Player LeBron James - four-games-to-two
in the best-of-seven Eastern Conference finals.
</P>
<P>
The Magic will be making their first finals appearance since 1995, one year
before Shaquille O'Neal departed as a free agent for Los Angeles.
</P>
<P>
Rashard Lewis added 18 points for the Magic, who hit 12 3-pointers in the
victory.
</P>
<P>
"Total domination," Lewis said of Howard's performance. "He totally dominated
the game. He carried us on his back tonight."
</P>
<P>
The Cavaliers had won 66 regular-season games and won both of their opening
playoff series in four-game sweeps.
</P>
<P>
But Orlando pushed them to the brink of defeat with a 116-114 overtime victory
on Tuesday that gave the Magic a 3-1 series lead.
</P>
<P>
Cleveland had responded with a victory on Thursday to force Saturday's game, but
could get no further.
</P>
<P>
Orlando will travel to Los Angeles for game one against the Lakers on Thursday.
</P>
<P>
The Magic had beaten Philadelphia in six games and then beat the reigning
champion Boston Celtics in seven games before subduing "King" James and the
Cavaliers.
</P>
<P>
"I just think this team all year long has shown an incredible amount of heart,"
Magic coach Stan Van Gundy said. "This team just keeps fighting back. They
deserve it."
</P>
<P>
James scored 25 points with seven rebounds and seven assists in his least-
impressive outing of the series. He was scoreless in the second quarter as the
Magic seized an 18-point lead.
</P>
<P>
The defeat overshadowed the fact that James had a superb series, averaging more
than 38 points, eight rebounds and eight assists in the six games.
</P>
<P>
However, he had too little support from his teammates, with Mo Williams
struggling to score and Orlando's bench solidly outplaying Cleveland's reserves.
</P>
<P>
A dejected James left the arena without speaking to the media.
</P>
<P>
After Howard slammed home a dunk with 2:21 to play, the chant of "Beat LA!" went
up from the Orlando crowd - which included golf superstar Tiger Woods.
</P>
<P>
Howard was even solid from the free-throw line, making 12 of 16 on Saturday.
</P>
<P>
While Cleveland powered through the regular season, the Magic had to contend
with a season-ending shoulder injury to point guard Jameer Nelson in February.
</P>
<P>
Orlando brought in guard Rafer Alston in a trade with Houston and helped revive
the team's playoff bid.
</P>
<P>
For Howard, the top draft selection in 2004, it was a vindication of his
prediction two years ago that the Magic could challenge for the title.
</P>
<P>
"Everybody laughed," Howard said. "I mean everyone."
</P>
<P>
Now the Magic are looking forward to another tough series.
</P>
<P>
"You guys like to talk about pressure," said Mickael Pietrus, who scored 14
points off the bench for the Magic. "It's a game of basketball. They made the
game to compete for the trophy. Every game is a dogfight.
</P>
<P>
"Basketball is what we like, what we share with 20,000 fans every night," he
said. "It's fun."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
South Ossetians vote for parliament
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
TSKHINVALI, Georgia, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Polling stations opened Sunday across the breakaway Georgian region of South
Ossetia for legislative elections, less than one year after Moscow and Tbilisi
clashed over the province.
</P>
<P>
Four parties are competing for the 34 seats in the parliament, but the central
election commission has barred the only two parties not loyal to president
Eduard Kokoity.
</P>
<P>
Analysts say Kokoity is seeking to use the vote to forge a loyal parliamentary
majority to be able to push through an amendment to the constitution to allow
him to run again for office when his second term is up next year.
</P>
<P>
Eighty eight polling stations have been set up for the region's 50,000
residents, plus additional sites in Russia for expatriates and refugees from the
fighting.
</P>
<P>
Moscow and Tbilisi fought a brief war over the region last August, which had
enjoyed de facto independence since the early 1990s thanks to tacit Russian
support. Following the conflict Russia formally recognised the region, a move
followed only by Nicaragua.
</P>
<P>
Voting ends at 8 pm (1600 GMT), with the first results expected two hours later.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Ice hockey: Red Wings down Penguins to take Stanley Cup finals lead
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
DETROIT, Michigan, May 30, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Defending champions Detroit seized the early advantage in the National Hockey
League Stanley Cup finals Saturday with a 3-1 victory over Pittsburgh in game
one of the championship series.
</P>
<P>
Johan Franzen scored the go-ahead goal late in the second period and Chris
Osgood made 31 saves for the Red Wings as they took a 1-0 lead in the best-of-
seven series.
</P>
<P>
Franzen and Brad Stuart both had goals that went off Pittsburgh goalie Marc-
Andre Fleury.
</P>
<P>
"We're going to have to get goals like that," Red Wings coach Mike Babcock said.
"I don't think there are going to be a whole lot of skill plays."
</P>
<P>
There was no fortuitous bounce of the puck for Pittsburgh's Sidney Crosby, whose
third-period shot bounced off Osgood and a post and landed on the sprawled
goalie's back.
</P>
<P>
"It's a race to four, and they got one," said Penguins coach Dan Bylsma, whose
team will try to even the score in game two on Sunday in Detroit.
</P>
<P>
Crosby and Evgeni Malkin, the two leading scorers in the postseason, were
limited to one assist between them - by Malkin.
</P>
<P>
"When you're on the road, the goal is win one of two, and if we play the way we
did in the second period for 60 minutes, we like our chances," Pittsburgh
forward Max Talbot said. "When they get the lead they're a very good team, so
maybe we need to get the lead (in game two).
</P>
<P>
Detroit rookie Justin Abdelkader gave the Red Wings a little extra breathing
room with his first career playoff goal early in the third period.
</P>
<P>
Detroit welcomed back Swedish defensemen Nicklas Lidstrom and Jonathan Ericsson,
and they played a key role in containing Crosby and Malkin.
</P>
<P>
Red Wings captain Lidstrom had missed the last two games of the Western
Conference finals against Chicago with a lower body injury, while Ericsson
played just three days after having an appendectomy.
</P>
<P>
"They're a huge help on the blue line," Red Wings forward Darren Helm said. "The
guys that played in their absence did an unbelievable job, but definitely having
Nick, one of the best 'D' in the league, for him to come back and play against
Crosby all night and keep him off the scoreboard's really big for this team."
</P>
<P>
Crosby and the Penguins are seeking to avenge their six-game loss to Detroit in
last year's finals.
</P>
<P>
It's the first Stanley Cup finals rematch in 25 years, and Stuart put the Red
Wings ahead when he deposited the puck behind Fleury and saw it carom off Fleury
and into the net with 6:22 to play in the opening period.
</P>
<P>
"I think he sat on it and pushed it in the net," Stuart said. "One of those
lucky breaks - but we'll take it."
</P>
<P>
The Penguins answered as Malkin capitalized on turnover with a slap shot that
Osgood couldn't control, leading to Ruslan Fedotenko's backhander off the
rebound.
</P>
<P>
Detroit went ahead 2-1 in the final minute of the second period when Brian
Rafalski's shot bounced off the boards and Franzen corralled the loose puck and
flipped a backhander over and off of the goalie.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Blogging guru chips away at Great Firewall of China
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Hong Kong, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
How would you react if one million of your customers were suddenly stopped from
coming into your shop? Matt Mullenweg just shrugged.
</P>
<P>
The 25-year-old American is the founder of Wordpress, software that allows
computer users worldwide to easily create their own websites, or blogs.
</P>
<P>
The simplicity of Wordpress has made it one of the world's top blogging
platforms six years after it was set up, its adherents ranging from knitting
fanatics (jessinohio.wordpress.com) to CNN's resident doctor Sanjay Gupta
(pagingdrgupta.blogs.cnn.com/site).
</P>
<P>
But in 2006, as the site was growing from strength to strength, Chinese
authorities suddenly blocked it.
</P>
<P>
Overnight, one million Chinese visitors to the various blogs disappeared,
accounting for about a quarter of all traffic to the site.
</P>
<P>
"I wish there was a better story, but really it just went away one day and we
didn't know what to do about it," Mullenweg told AFP, during a visit to Hong
Kong to speak to some of his bloggers.
</P>
<P>
After some discussions, Mullenweg realised the site would be allowed back online
if he agreed to block certain words or topics and give up information to the
Chinese communist government about users.
</P>
<P>
"I started thinking about the DNA of the company," he said. "That sort of
company is not one I would wake up every day and feel passionate about working
in."
</P>
<P>
The site remains blocked, although Mullenweg, unable to suppress a giggle,
points out that the official Chinese line insists it is freely available.
</P>
<P>
His decision not to pander to China contrasts sharply with other companies that
have agreed to the country's extensive Internet controls -- often dubbed the
Great Firewall of China -- in the hope of gaining access to what is now the
world's biggest online market.
</P>
<P>
Yahoo! faced fierce criticism when it helped Chinese authorities identify a
journalist who had passed on a sensitive Communist Party message to foreign
websites. The journalist, Shi Tao, was subsequently jailed in 2005.
</P>
<P>
"I imagine that weighs very heavily on both the leadership of that company and
also the morale of an entire organisation," said Mullenweg, who is based in San
Francisco and has done several recent deals with Yahoo!.
</P>
<P>
Despite the ban, Chinese bloggers still use Wordpress technology in huge
numbers, downloading its free access software and pasting their blogs through
another server to avoid the censors.
</P>
<P>
That's just the kind of technology-inspired rebellion that appeals to Mullenweg,
who has also refused to submit to similar government demands in Turkey, and
whose instinct is to make things freely-available.
</P>
<P>
He is considering putting all the firm's expenses online, so everyone at
Automattic, Wordpress's parent company, can access them. And his camera, which
goes everywhere with him, carries a global positioning system, so he records the
exact location of all his pictures.
</P>
<P>
This openness is reflected in Wordpress's approach -- the blogging software is
open source, so it can be downloaded and tinkered with as users see fit.
</P>
<P>
As a result of its accessibility and it simplicity, it now has more than 15
million bloggers using its technology, according to statistics on the site.
</P>
<P>
While setting up a blog is free, the site makes money by advertising or charging
for extras, such as enhanced statistics packages or better promotion of a
particular blog.
</P>
<P>
Mullenweg has become the darling of the Internet world, regularly featuring on
lists of the "most powerful people in cyberspace" and accepting invitations to
talk about how the web is changing the world.
</P>
<P>
The company, which still has fewer than 100 employees, remains privately held
and so does not have to reveal earnings, and though reports have said Mullenweg
turned down an offer of 200 million dollars in 2007 for a stake in the firm,
money one of the few subjects he is reluctant to discuss.
</P>
<P>
"We are doing well, capital is not a limiting factor for us," said Mullenweg,
dressed in battered trainers and jeans after addressing a group of business
leaders.
</P>
<P>
"I like that we always get the question how do you make money, because it means
that we are not crassly over-commercialising," he said.
</P>
<P>
His passion for simplicity was learned as teenage volunteer at the Houston Area
League of PC Users, in the US city where he grew up. His job was fixing
computers every Saturday for mainly elderly PC users.
</P>
<P>
"You saw all the cliches -- CD-ROMS being used as a cup holder, but they were
just trying to connect with (the technology). It was inspiring," he said.
</P>
<P>
"You really develop an appreciation (for simplicity) and developing software is
the same.
</P>
<P>
"People don't want to use Wordpress (for its own sake), they want to talk to
their audience, share photos of their family and (Wordpress) is either a way for
them to do that or it is not."
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Nia Vardalos back in spotlight after big fat Greek hit
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Los Angeles, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Seven years after being catapulted to fame and fortune with her hit comedy "My
Big Fat Greek Wedding", Nia Vardalos makes a long-awaited return to the big
screen this month with another film that takes the Canadian-born actress back to
her ancestral roots.
</P>
<P>
Vardalos, 46, became an overnight success in 2002, when the romantic comedy she
wrote and starred in went on to become a monster hit, earning more than 350
million dollars worldwide after being made for only five million dollars.
</P>
<P>
The success of the film -- which also earned Vardalos a best original screenplay
nomination at the Oscars -- allowed Vardalos to take her time deciding her next
career move.
</P>
<P>
Although she starred in a short-lived television spin-off of "Greek Wedding",
Vardalos has been largely inactive since 2002 preferring to focus on starting a
family before relaunching her career with "My Life in Ruins."
</P>
<P>
Her new film, which goes on release in North America on June 5, sees her play a
Greek-American history professor who returns to Greece to work as a tour guide
in Athens.
</P>
<P>
Vardalos said the script for the film, which includes several scenes shot at the
Acropolis and other historic sites, had fired her enthusiasm after years out of
the spotlight as she attempted to start a family.
</P>
<P>
"When we got the permission to shoot this film, it was so exciting and it was
the first that I had found something where I wanted to be on camera in for a
long time," she told reporters in Beverly Hills.
</P>
<P>
"In 2004, I had come to the end of a 10-year infertility battle and I just chose
to privately deal with it, so I stepped back out of acting," said Vardalos, who
recently adopted a three-year-old girl with her husband.
</P>
<P>
"I was really happy to be offered a nice clean script that celebrates Greece and
is a love letter to Greece," she adds.
</P>
<P>
Vardalos says that despite the commercial success of "My Big Fat Greek Wedding",
her business relationships with her producers, who include actor Tom Hanks and
his wife Rita Wilson, have not changed.
</P>
<P>
"The good news is that you strive for what happened with my first movie for your
whole life," Vardalos said. "And so it happened and its like, 'oh that's over,
the rest is gravy.'
</P>
<P>
"The greater news is that my producers are the same producers. They treated me
like gold before 'My Big Fat Greek Wedding' made a dime. And they don't expect
anything from me, except let's have fun and let's tell fun stories."
</P>
<P>
Vardalos, who did not write "My Life In Ruins," continues to pen screenplays.
</P>
<P>
But she says she has resisted the temptation to try and regurgitate the formula
from "My Big Fat Greek Wedding" in an attempt to score another commercial
bullseye.
</P>
<P>
"I write little movies and then the rest is up to the audience," she said. "It's
the audience that made 'My Big Fat Greek Wedding' a success.
</P>
<P>
"I think if you create with a financial goal in mind, artistically you are dead.
Its best to tell fun stories and let the audience decide."
</P>
<P>
However Vardalos makes no apologies for the fact that "My Life In Ruins" and
another upcoming film "I Hate Valentine's Day," which she wrote, directed and
stars in, are both romantic comedies, like "Greek Wedding."
</P>
<P>
"I think that reviewers and the industry think that romance is dead," Vardalos
said. "I think the audience wants it and needs it. I know I do.
</P>
<P>
"As I keep saying, as the average person, I like to escape into a movie. I like
movies like 'Terminator' and 'Star Trek' as well."
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0403" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Ethiopia: lifting the mystery on rock churches 'built by angels'
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LALIBELA, Ethiopia, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The ancient mystery shrouding Lalibela, Ethiopia's revered medieval rock-hewn
churches, could be lifted by a group of French researchers given the go-ahead
for the first comprehensive study of this world heritage site legend says was
"built by angels".
</P>
<P>
The team will have full access to the network of 10 Orthodox chapels chiseled
out of volcanic rock -- some standing 15 metres (42 feet) high -- in the
mountainous heart of Ethiopia.
</P>
<P>
Local lore holds they were built in less than 25 years by their namesake, the
13th-century King Lalibela, with the help of angels after God ordered him to
erect a "New Jerusalem".
</P>
<P>
The monolithic structures are located 500 kilometres (300 miles) north of the
capital Addis Ababa. Long a holy pilgrimage site in a land proud of its
Christian Orthodox heritage, they are also a travel draw in a poverty-stricken
country hoping to boost tourism.
</P>
<P>
The multidisciplinary team of historians, archaeologists, topographers and a
specialist in liturgy will spend several weeks probing the subterranean complex
to try to identify its origins.
</P>
<P>
Historian Marie Laure Derat, with the French Centre for Ethiopian Studies
(CFEE), said "there are several theories". In one, "an Egyptian patriarch was
believed to be the source of these structures, another says the 13th-century
King Lalibela built the site from scratch."
</P>
<P>
"During the day the king would work with Ethiopian artisans and at night he
would 'be helped by angels'. Some even cite a key role by the Knights Templar,"
she said, referring to one of the key Western Christian military orders of the
Middle Ages.
</P>
<P>
Though earlier studies have been carried out, they were generally by lone
researchers with restricted access who studied mainly church interiors .
</P>
<P>
Derat said the heretofore reluctant Orthodox church gave the French team carte
blanche to probe "the entire site, not just the churches, to understand how the
periods overlap and to read history in this open book that is Lalibela".
</P>
<P>
Funded by the French government and Ethiopian Airlines, the team is already
certain the chapels were not built in one go.
</P>
<P>
Research chief Francois Xavier Fauvelle said three distinct periods have been
identified in the maze of deep tunnels, passageways and chapels, some of which
resemble ancient Greek temples.
</P>
<P>
"There was originally a basalt dome under which we found evidence of cave
dwellers. Then there was the construction of a fortress with trenches, a
perimetre wall and underground tunnels," he said pointing to rocks he said where
once part of the defence wall.
</P>
<P>
"The third period was established thanks to an enormous mound of earth about 20
metres high that came from the excavation of the church of Gabriel Ruphael," he
said, referring to the chapel some believe was once King Lalibela's residence.
</P>
<P>
"The Ruphael Gabriel church was probably part of the fortress and was turned
into a church: the facade was extended, windows opened and a chapel dug out,"
said Fauvelle.
</P>
<P>
UNESCO added Lalibela to its world heritage list in 1978, a boon for tourism
efforts in this country of 85 million where poverty is rampant and agriculture
accounts for nearly half the economy. Visitors can already join organized tours
of the site.
</P>
<P>
But the bid to shed light on its origins has not shaken the Orthodox clergy and
faithful here, who contend that Lalibela arose with divine intervention.
</P>
<P>
"It is God through his angels who made these churches," said Alebachew Reta,
spokesman for the Lalibela clergy who insisted "the 10 churches were created in
just 24 years."
</P>
<P>
"You can observe that even one would be difficult to build in that space of
time. So for us it is God's work," said Reta. "For the one who created mankind,
building these churches was not difficult."
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0404" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Jewish settlers say they remain in West Bank on God's orders
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Havat Gilad, West Bank, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The world outcry over Israeli settlements in the West Bank is absurd since God
gave this land to the Jews, says Rabbi Yaakov Savir. The Arabs, he says, should
make their home elsewhere.
</P>
<P>
"This territory is Jewish territory," says Savir, a settler who runs a religious
school in the Havat Gilad outpost which consists of little more than a few tin
huts and weather-worn trailers, some horses and chickens and several car wrecks.
</P>
<P>
"This is our home," he says, making a sweeping gesture towards the Jewish
settlements that dominate nearby hilltops to show he means the entire West Bank,
which Israel captured from Jordan in the 1967 Six-Day-War.
</P>
<P>
Havat Gilad, which 20 families call home, is a wildcat outpost, meaning that
unlike full-scale settlements, it is not authorised by the Israeli government.
</P>
<P>
The international community considers all settlements illegal, and the issue is
one of the thorniest in peace efforts with the Palestinians.
</P>
<P>
With US pressure mounting, Israel could soon make good on its years-old pledge
to tear down a couple of dozen outposts.
</P>
<P>
In Havat Gilad's case, it wouldn't be the first time.
</P>
<P>
Built by Moshe Zar, a former member of a Jewish underground movement that
planted bombs in the cars of Arab mayors, the outpost was torn down by the
Israeli authorities barely hours after a group of teenagers pitched the first
tents in 2002. Rebuilding started the next day.
</P>
<P>
Savir is outraged the government of right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu
would even consider bulldozing Jewish homes.
</P>
<P>
"Jewish people live here by Biblical right," he claims, standing in the trailer
that houses the religious school, surrounded by students who sport the look
favoured by ideologically motivated religious settlers -- long locks, knitted
skullcap, loose clothing and sandals.
</P>
<P>
Savir insists he has nothing against Arabs -- he won't speak of Palestinians
other than to say there is no such people.
</P>
<P>
"If Arabs want to stay, we won't kill them, we won't expel them.
</P>
<P>
"They are the ones who want to kill us, who don't want us to live in our home,"
he says.
</P>
<P>
"Arabs," he adds "should find another place to live."
</P>
<P>
The vast majority of the 280,000 Jews who live in the 120 West Bank settlements
which Israel considers legal, have moved to the area for economic reasons. But
the hardliners who share Savir's views that Jewish people have a God-given right
to the land are extremely vocal and at times violent.
</P>
<P>
Rabbi Savir is convinced the residents of Havat Gilad, like others in similar
outposts, "will certainly fight for every millimeter. No one will leave his
home."
</P>
<P>
Israel agreed in 2003 to freeze all settlement activity and raze wildcat
outposts but has not followed through on those commitments.
</P>
<P>
Outposts, typically located a few hundred metres (yards) from government-
authorised settlements, include anything from a few shacks to communities of
several dozen semi-permanent homes connected to the electricity and water grids.
</P>
<P>
Many of the 100 or so outposts were built on West Bank hills by militant
teenagers, known as "hilltop youths," with the aim of planting the seeds of new
full-fledged settlements.
</P>
<P>
A 2005 government-commissioned report said that in some cases officials
authorised seizure of private Palestinian land to create outposts, and
facilitated their connection to the water and power mains.
</P>
<P>
Palestinians see the outposts as part of a land grab and a scheme to further
consolidate Israel's control over the West Bank, which is home to 2.4 million
Palestinians.
</P>
<P>
Faced with mounting pressure from within his right-wing coalition on the one
hand and the United States on the other, Netanyahu has vowed to continue
building in existing settlement blocs while indicating he will dismantle wildcat
outposts.
</P>
<P>
But he has failed to placate either side.
</P>
<P>
The premier has faced fierce criticism from the right for his willingness to
tear down Jewish homes, and some blunt talk from Washington over settlement
expansion.
</P>
<P>
US President Barack Obama told Netanyahu during May 18 White House talks he
wants a complete freeze of settlement activity.
</P>
<P>
"Not some settlements, not outposts, not natural growth exceptions," Secretary
of State Hillary Clinton said, explaining the demand.
</P>
<P>
Israeli police did tear down Maoz Esther, north of the West Bank political
capital of Ramallah, on May 21, but the move was dismissed by Israeli media as a
meaningless token gesture. The outpost consisted of just seven tin and plywood
shacks.
</P>
<P>
One week after the demolition, one house had already been rebuilt and another
was being constructed without any hindrance from the authorities.
</P>
<P>
"We must settle here, God has ordered us to live on this land," says Daniel
Landesberg, 20, as he and a group of teenagers spread out cement being poured
out of a large concrete mixer truck to form the base of a new house.
</P>
<P>
Landesberg is a firm believer in the "doubling" tactic adopted by hardline
settlers.
</P>
<P>
"They tore down seven homes, we will build 14," he says, smiling.
</P>
<P>
And if the 14 are razed? "We'll build twice that many."
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0406" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Struggling GM thrives in China
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Shanghai, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
GM's overall future may look grim, but half a world away from Detroit in
Shanghai, business has never been better.
</P>
<P>
The US auto giant is beating sales records in China and may soon be exporting
Chinese-made cars to the United States.
</P>
<P>
"I don't think it makes much difference to us. Obviously we'd prefer to have
this restructuring done outside the courts," Kevin Wale, GM China's president
and managing director, told AFP in a recent interview.
</P>
<P>
"We operate as independent joint ventures here in China so we would continue
pretty much as we are today."
</P>
<P>
While GM pares back at home, it may add a plant in China to meet its goal of
doubling annual sales to two million within five years with products developed
for "the most important growth market in the world", Wale said.
</P>
<P>
That extra capacity could also help produce GM cars which for the first time
would be exported from China to the United States, under a proposal the
automaker has reportedly submitted to US lawmakers.
</P>
<P>
GM has proposed shipping 17,335 Chinese-made cars to the US in 2011 and
increasing that to 51,546 by 2014 -- representing 1.6 percent of its forecast
3.1 million cars five years from now, the Automotive News reported.
</P>
<P>
China led the world in auto sales in April, and GM China's joint ventures led
the pack, with sales rising 29.9 percent on year to 151,084 vehicles, driven by
demand for Buicks and small Wuling "bread vans" that cost less than 5,000
dollars.
</P>
<P>
"It's definitely one of the market leaders here -- in drastic contrast to their
performance in the US," said Shen Jun, an auto analyst at Roland Berger.
</P>
<P>
GM's first Shanghai sales office opened in 1929, boasting: "Buick owners are
mostly the leading men in China."
</P>
<P>
Pu Yi, the last emperor, revolutionary leader Sun Yat-sen and premier Zhou Enlai
all owned Buicks.
</P>
<P>
But that history is barely known, allowing GM to recast Buick as a car for
China's young and fast-growing middle class.
</P>
<P>
"Volkswagen has good prices and good quality, but their cars look very average,
not unique," said Li Pengxiang, a 29-year-old telecoms project manager,
referring to China's number two carmaker.
</P>
<P>
"These new (GM) models look fresh and suit young people."
</P>
<P>
GM has earned a reputation for savvy marketing with moves like enlisting "Prison
Break" star Wentworth Miller -- a top celebrity in China despite the show never
airing here legally -- to star in its latest campaign, Shen said.
</P>
<P>
"They think they are doing much better than the parent company in the US," he
said, saying GM's success in China boils down to smart decisions, good timing
and luck that has put it far ahead of US rivals Ford and Chrysler.
</P>
<P>
GM teamed with China's largest automaker Shanghai Automotive Industry Group or
SAIC, in 1997 -- foreign carmakers here need a local joint venture partner --
after SAIC rejected Toyota and before Ford could sign a deal, Shen said.
</P>
<P>
Tension among joint venture partners is common, but GM and SAIC are known to
have unrivalled chemistry, according to Zhu Junyi, an auto analyst at the
Shanghai Information Centre.
</P>
<P>
GM spends heavily on research and development while delegating key
responsibilities to its partner, he said.
</P>
<P>
"German and Japanese investors are more reluctant to give away any leadership
role," Zhu said. "GM has done a better job with localisation."
</P>
<P>
GM's growing sales are impressive but competitors are growing faster -- Hyundai
shot up 74 percent on year last month while Nissan sales grew 55 percent, Shen
said.
</P>
<P>
Even as the Chinese market's growth slows -- to eight percent in 2008 after
years of double digit growth -- more players are piling in.
</P>
<P>
"The Japanese automakers are steamrolling China's auto market," said Eric Xu,
head of Timer-Auto Consulting in Shanghai.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0407" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
GM's collapse will mark end of a blue collar dynasty
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Detroit, Michigan, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The expected collapse of General Motors will mark the death of a blue collar
dynasty which bestowed upon generations of Americans the security of a job for
life and a ticket to the middle class.
</P>
<P>
"GM represented the good life," said Gary Chaison, a professor of labor
relations at Clark University.
</P>
<P>
"There was a social contract: you worked hard and the company would reward you
with job security and good pay," Chaison told AFP. "And this was something you
could pass on (to your kids.) It was an inheritance."
</P>
<P>
In towns and cities scattered across the midwest, GM's sprawling plants and the
businesses which cropped up to service them brought prosperity and stability.
</P>
<P>
The United Auto Workers union won wages high enough to allow factory workers to
own a home, a cottage, a boat, to take summer vacations in cars they bought with
employee discounts.
</P>
<P>
Their health insurance was paid for. Pensions would offer guaranteed income in
retirement. They worked for the biggest corporation in the world.
</P>
<P>
That dream began to slip away in the 1980s, when GM began shutting down plants
and shipping production to Mexico and Asia.
</P>
<P>
Once bustling company towns like Flint, Michigan -- memorialized in Michael
Moore's documentary "Roger &amp; Me" -- emptied and died. Abandoned houses and
darkened storefronts transformed the once rich region into the Rust Belt.
</P>
<P>
GM employed 440,000 hourly workers in the United States in 1981.
</P>
<P>
By 2000, that had dropped to 133,000. In the next eight years it would fall to
62,000.
</P>
<P>
The latest restructuring plan calls for the unionized workforce to shrink to
38,000 by 2011: less than a tenth of what it was two decades earlier.
</P>
<P>
But even through the downsizing and plant closures of the 1980s and 1990s, the
workers who remained at General Motors were able to hang onto their high wages
and benefits.
</P>
<P>
That ended in the latest round of restructuring, which began in 2005 and ended
with the union agreeing to slash benefits, cut wages in half for new workers,
and even give up the right to strike until 2015.
</P>
<P>
"It could have been worse," said Doug Bowman, the president of UAW Local 594 in
Pontiac, Michigan.
</P>
<P>
Bowman has worked for GM for 30 years and has watched employment at his complex
shrink from 14,000 in the late 1970s to 1,000 today.
</P>
<P>
He's anxiously awaiting news about whether his truck plant will be among 14 GM
plants slated for closure. But he's resigned himself to the massive concessions
the union has made in recent years.
</P>
<P>
"The one thing I regret is that we couldn't protect the retirees," he told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"We have no choice," said Jim Hall, another UAW official from Pontiac.
</P>
<P>
"We have to vote for the concessions to help the company survive."
</P>
<P>
But Hall hasn't given up hope. If GM manages to emerge from bankruptcy
protection, which it is expected to seek in the coming days, Hall thinks some of
jobs, and some of those benefits, might come back.
</P>
<P>
GM, which only months ago lost the title of the world's biggest automaker to
Toyota after holding it for 77 years, had made huge steps in recent years to
revitalize its products and slash its bloated structural costs.
</P>
<P>
But the restructuring cost billions and the debt-laden automaker was unable to
survive the collapse of auto sales last fall amid a credit crunch and deepening
recession.
</P>
<P>
GM racked up nearly 88 billion dollars in losses from 2005 through the first
quarter of 2009, and has only managed to keep its operations afloat in recent
months with 19.4 billion dollars in loans from the US Treasury.
</P>
<P>
The hope is that, like Chrysler, GM will emerge from bankruptcy in a matter of
weeks as a leaner, meaner company able to get back to the business of making
cars and trucks.
</P>
<P>
But while the union is likely to hold a large stake in the new General Motors,
its power to shape the American social landscape through sheer numbers is gone.
</P>
<P>
"Certainly an era has ended," said Harley Shaiken, a labor expert from the
University of California - Berkeley.
</P>
<P>
"We're in uncharted waters."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Once the world's biggest corporation, GM faces collapse
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Detroit, Michigan, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Once the biggest corporation in the world, steady growth overseas was unable to
rescue General Motors from spiralling losses in the United States.
</P>
<P>
Founded in 1908, GM sold more vehicles than any other automaker from 1931 until
2008, when it was overtaken by Japan's Toyota.
</P>
<P>
The largest of the Detroit Three automakers, GM has seen its US market share
fall from a peak of 54 percent in the 1954 to just 22 percent in 2008.
</P>
<P>
It nonetheless sold a whopping 8.35 million vehicles in 2008 despite a collapse
in global auto sales amid a credit crunch and widening economic downturn.
</P>
<P>
GM last made a profit in 2004, earning 2.8 billion dollars, and has been
operating under ever-deepening restructuring plans ever since. It lost nearly 88
billion dollars from 2005 through the first quarter of 2009.
</P>
<P>
Global employment levels reached more than 850,000 in 1978, of which more than
600,000 were in the United States, making GM the nation's largest private
employer.
</P>
<P>
By 2005 it had already shrunk to 335,000 people and further cuts this year will
bring it below 200,000 worldwide.
</P>
<P>
GM's unionized workforce has taken the most dramatic hit. GM employed 440,000
hourly workers in the United States in 1981.
</P>
<P>
By 2000, that had dropped to 133,000 and the automaker ended 2008 with just
62,000.
</P>
<P>
The latest restructuring plan calls for the unionized workforce to shrink to
38,000 by 2011: less than a tenth of what it was two decades earlier.
</P>
<P>
Once studied in business schools for the success of its brands, which operated
as separate divisions aimed to satisfy different segments of the market, GM is
shedding most of its marks -- including Sweden's Saab, Hummer, Pontiac and
Saturn. It will concentrate on Cadillac, Buick, Chevrolet and GMC.
</P>
<P>
The latest restructuring plan will shrink GM's US dealer network by 40 percent
and will cut its US plants from 47 to 31.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Troubled road which led to GM's breakdown
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
DETROIT, Michigan, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Here are the principal events marking GM's troubled path over the past 18
months, with the once mighty automaker expected to file for bankruptcy soon.
</P>
<P>
JANUARY 2008
</P>
<P>
-- Toyota comes close to overtaking GM as the world's biggest automaker, a title
GM has held since 1931. GM sells 9.369 million vehicles in 2007 while the
Japanese automaker sold 9.366 million.
</P>
<P>
FEBRUARY 2008
</P>
<P>
-- GM posts a 38.7 billion dollar annual loss for 2007 and announces plans to
eliminate the jobs of 74,000 unionized workers in the United States.
</P>
<P>
MARCH 2008
</P>
<P>
-- A two-month long strike begins at key supplier American Axle. GM is forced to
shut many of its plants and takes a 1.8 billion dollar hit.
</P>
<P>
APRIL 2008
</P>
<P>
-- GM slashes production of trucks and sport utility vehicles by 140,000 units
in the wake of poor sales.
</P>
<P>
JULY 2008
</P>
<P>
-- GM announces plans to slash its white collar workforce by 20 percent, double
truck production cuts to 300,000 units and bolster its liquidity by 15 billion
dollars through internal operating actions, asset sales and the capital markets.
</P>
<P>
AUGUST 2008
</P>
<P>
-- GM reports a second quarter loss of 15.5 billion dollars.
</P>
<P>
SEPTEMBER 2008
</P>
<P>
-- GM marks its 100th anniversary.
</P>
<P>
OCTOBER 2008
</P>
<P>
-- Merger talks between GM and Chrysler heat up as US sales collapse amid a
deepening recession.
</P>
<P>
NOVEMBER 2008
</P>
<P>
-- GM announces October sales fell 45 percent amid the US auto industry's worst
performance in the post World War II era.
</P>
<P>
-- GM, Chrysler and Ford executives head to Washington to request billions in
emergency loans.
</P>
<P>
-- Merger talks with Chrysler are dropped.
</P>
<P>
DECEMBER 2008
</P>
<P>
-- GM announces plans to cut another 31,000 jobs by 2012 and idles a third of
its US factories.
</P>
<P>
-- The White House offers GM and Chrysler 13.3 billion dollars in emergency
loans.
</P>
<P>
-- The Canadian government offers 3.3 billion US dollars in aid to GM and
Chrysler.
</P>
<P>
JANUARY 2009
</P>
<P>
-- Toyota claims the crown of world's biggest automaker after selling 8.97
million vehicles in 2008. GM's global sales have fallen to 8.35 million
vehicles.
</P>
<P>
-- Industry data shows 2008 US auto sales were down 18 percent. GM's sales fell
23 percent.
</P>
<P>
FEBRUARY 2009
</P>
<P>
-- GM and Chrysler present restructuring plans to the US Treasury. GM asks for
another 16.6 billion in loans and says it will cut 47,000 jobs worldwide this
year. That will bring its global workforce down to 200,000 from 335,000 in 2005.
</P>
<P>
-- GM asks Canada to boost its loans to six billion dollars.
</P>
<P>
-- GM reports a 31 billion dollar loss for 2008, bringing its cumulative losses
since 2005 to 86 billion dollars.
</P>
<P>
-- GM washes its hands of Saab after the Swedish government refuses to bail out
the troubled unit. Saab seeks legal restructuring protection to avoid
bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
MARCH 2009
</P>
<P>
-- GM's auditors express "substantial doubt" about its ability to stay afloat in

</P>
<P>

</P>
<P>
APRIL 2009
</P>
<P>
-- GM deepens its restructuring plan to cut more jobs, eliminate Pontiac and
Saturn, shrink its dealer network by 42 percent by 2010.
</P>
<P>
-- Attempts to swap 27 billion dollars in debt for a 10 percent stake in common
shares.
</P>
<P>
-- Idles 13 plants for "multiple weeks."
</P>
<P>
-- Enters talks to sell a major stake in Opel.
</P>
<P>
MAY 2009
</P>
<P>
-- Posts a first quarter loss of 5.9 billion dollars as quarterly production is
slashed by 40 percent, or 903,000 units.
</P>
<P>
-- Reaches cost-cutting deals with its US and Canadian unions.
</P>
<P>

billion.
