<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0410" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Collapse of once mighty GM was decades in the making
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Chicago, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The downfall of General Motors comes after decades of mistakes and missteps
chipped away at the reputation and market share of the once mighty automaker and
buried the Detroit giant in debt.
</P>
<P>
"It'll have a huge impact in the United States because it's more than just a
corporation -- it's an icon," said Gary Chaison, a professor of labor relations
at Clark University.
</P>
<P>
"It represented manufacturing supremacy and good jobs for American workers.
That's gone."
</P>
<P>
GM, which only months ago lost the title of the world's biggest automaker to
Toyota after holding it for 77 years, had made huge steps in recent years to
revitalize its products and slash its bloated structural costs.
</P>
<P>
But the restructuring cost billions and the debt-laden automaker has fought hard
to survive the collapse of auto sales last fall amid a credit crunch and
deepening recession.
</P>
<P>
GM racked up nearly 88 billion dollars in losses from 2005 through the first
quarter of 2009.
</P>
<P>
It managed to keep its operations afloat in recent months with 19.4 billion
dollars in loans from the US Treasury but is now expected to seek bankruptcy
protection in the coming days.
</P>
<P>
"GM's problems go back at least three decades," said Terrence Guay, a professor
at Penn State's business school.
</P>
<P>
"The company became complacent in terms of products and customers, assuming that
American car-buyers would choose GM vehicles," he told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"They didn't take the Japanese threat seriously, and consequently steadily lost
market share to Toyota, Honda, Nissan, and other imports."
</P>
<P>
GM was a giant in its chrome-detailed heyday, employing more than 600,000 people
worldwide and 464,000 in the United States back in 1962 when it sold more than
half the cars in America.
</P>
<P>
Founded in 1908, GM grew to be the largest private US employer, the world's
biggest company, had revenues higher than the gross domestic product of most
nations, and currently operates in 140 countries.
</P>
<P>
After transforming its plants to make planes, tanks and munitions during World
War II, GM expanded far beyond cars in the decades to follow, building
everything from trains and rockets to home air conditioners.
</P>
<P>
GM also helped expand the American middle class with the standard-setting high
wages and solid benefit packages won by hundreds of thousands of unionized auto
workers.
</P>
<P>
The phrase "what's good for GM is good for the country" became commonplace.
</P>
<P>
"Between 1921 and 1980 they never lost money," said Sean McAlinden, chief
economist at Michigan's Center for Automotive Research.
</P>
<P>
"The target was a 20 percent return on capital every year no matter what. And
they did it."
</P>
<P>
But GM and its Detroit neighbors, Ford and Chrysler, let their quality slip and
fumbled the shift to smaller, more fuel efficient vehicles in the wake of the
oil crises of the 1970s.
</P>
<P>
"The baby boom generation has never forgiven them for the defects of the 1970s
and 80s," McAlinden told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"They will go to their graves without buying a GM vehicle."
</P>
<P>
Japanese automakers Toyota and Honda steadily gained market share first with the
low cost of their vehicles and then with their reputation for higher quality.
</P>
<P>
Plant closures became a part of the American motif and GM shed most of its
subsidiaries.
</P>
<P>
The Detroit Three were able to revive their fortunes in the 1990s with the
development of sport utility vehicles and the rising popularity of trucks, but
the profits were short-lived.
</P>
<P>
Japanese automakers responded to Detroit's hulking truck-based suvs with
smaller, more efficient car-based crossovers suvs and once again GM was slow to
follow suit.
</P>
<P>
When fuel prices began to rise and consumers shifted away from gasoline guzzles,
GM's sales -- and profits -- crashed.
</P>
<P>
The latest round of plant closures and layoffs began in November 2005.
</P>
<P>
Since then, GM's US workforce has been slashed by nearly half from 160,000 at
the end of 2004 to 83,315 at the end of April.
</P>
<P>
The real problem, analysts say, is that GM waited too long to address the
ballooning "legacy costs" associated with supporting generations of retirees
with a US market share that had slipped to 26 percent by 2005.
</P>
<P>
GM's costs for each vehicle built were about 2,000 to 2,500 dollars higher than
the US plants of its Asian rivals.
</P>
<P>
GM was able to reach a historic deal with the United Auto Workers union to slash
labor costs in 2007, but only after spending 103 billion dollars to fund
pensions and retiree health care from 1993 through 2007.
</P>
<P>
And though GM has managed to dramatically improve its product quality and
offerings in recent years, it was too little too late.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0411" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Can GM succeed as 'Government Motors'?
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
WASHINGTON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
General Motors, readying a massive bankruptcy filing backed by billions in
public funds, faces a complex set of challenges as a virtually nationalized
"Government Motors," analysts say.
</P>
<P>
With the US government expected to hold as much as 72.5 percent of the new firm
that would emerge from bankruptcy, analysts say a big question is whether GM can
concentrate on the difficult auto marketplace.
</P>
<P>
"The tricky part is to leave day-to-day management to the executives of the
company," said Jeremy Anwyl, chief executive at auto research firm Edmunds.com.
</P>
<P>
For the government, he said, "the temptation is to influence product decisions
based on political considerations instead of market considerations, and that's
always a danger."
</P>
<P>
Anwyl said it is too soon to tell how the matter will be handled by the
administration of President Barack Obama, which has pledged to get out of the
business as soon as GM gets back on its feet.
</P>
<P>
David Cole, chairman of the Michigan-based Center for Automotive Research, said
the government officials "are smart, dedicated people, but they can't learn the
key issues of this industry in a short time."
</P>
<P>
Cole said the government can succeed if it focuses on the goal of restoring
profitability, getting taxpayer money repaid and then getting out of GM.
</P>
<P>
"If the government forces a company to go out of step with the reality of the
marketplace, that's a problem," Cole said.
</P>
<P>
"If you force the industry to build products they can't sell profitably, that's
a problem."
</P>
<P>
Cole said it was "almost unavoidable that the government will try to superimpose
other agendas" on the carmaker.
</P>
<P>
Cole and Anwyl said it would be a mistake for the government to use its role as
the financial backer of GM or Chrysler to push the firms into building certain
types of cars to meet environmental or other goals because consumer demands can
change quickly.
</P>
<P>
Anwyl said that with the current level of fuel prices, demand for small, fuel-
efficient cars is decreasing. He added the Obama administration's effort to
further boost fuel efficiency may hurt efforts to help Detroit automakers become
profitable again.
</P>
<P>
Peter Cohan, a management consultant and faculty member at Babson College, said
GM must keep a focus on "developing a line of products that can compete with
Toyota, Nissan and the rest of the world."
</P>
<P>
"I hope the government doesn't push GM to make hybrids just for the sake of
doing it but because it will be profitable strategy ... They need to design and
build a vehicle that will last longer than a Toyota with lower maintenance
costs."
</P>
<P>
Although some GM critics blame existing management for its woes, Anwyl said the
carmaker's biggest problems stemmed from decisions made years or even decades
earlier.
</P>
<P>
"These festered over the years and GM never really confronted them," he said.
</P>
<P>
The US government is expected to invest an additional 30 billion dollars to help
GM on top of its 20 billion dollars in loans, with most of the funds being
converted to the equity stake of as much as 72.5 percent.
</P>
<P>
The US stake could be reduced by a share given to the governments of Canada and
Ontario province, expected to pitch in with around nine billion dollars.
</P>
<P>
John Pottow, a law professor and bankruptcy specialist at the University of
Michigan, said the proposed ownership structure raises a lot of hackles.
</P>
<P>
"Everyone is terrified of government mandates as opposed to market forces," he
said. "But I take it as face value the government saying they want to be
reluctant shareholders."
</P>
<P>
GM vice chairman Robert Lutz said the administration is taking appropriate
measures to help an industry vital to the US economy, and praised Obama's
Automotive Task Force.
</P>
<P>
"Their prime goal is not to gain government control of the automobile industry,"
he said.
</P>
<P>
"They absolutely don't want that ... their number one goal is to make us
successful. There finally is a realization that our country cannot remain
economically strong and militarily strong and have a global impact if it’s not
backed up by wealth-producing industries."
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0412" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
GM to lose prestigious spot on Dow
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
New York, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
General Motors' fall from grace is not yet complete. The firm's expected
bankruptcy would spell its eviction from the Dow Jones coveted list of 30 top US
companies, of which GM has been a pillar since 1925.
</P>
<P>
Even if GM's court filing has not yet been inked, speculation is rife about
which firm might take its place on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, as the
former behemoth's share price tumbled 47 percent last week.
</P>
<P>
GM's shares fell to 75 cents each on Friday, well below the one dollar minimum
for listing on the New York-based exchange.
</P>
<P>
It is a confluence of factors that means GM will suffer the same fate as AIG. In
September, the insurance giant was removed from the Dow Jones index two days
after its nationalization, replaced by Kraft Foods.
</P>
<P>
"Once a company files for bankruptcy protection it is disqualified from being
one of the 30 Dow components," said Dow spokesperson Sybille Reitz.
</P>
<P>
"We are aware of GM's situation and are taking steps accordingly. We have been
following the situation closely."
</P>
<P>
There is great competition to replace GM on the venerable list, which has served
as a bellwether for US business since it was launched in 1896.
</P>
<P>
One solution could be to replace GM with its rival Ford -- which has so far
managed to escape the crisis without government aid.
</P>
<P>
But Ford's share price is far from stellar, trading at around 5.75 dollars.
According to John Ogg of 247wallst.com, that makes the firm -- which had
previously been a member of the elite club -- an unlikely inductee.
</P>
<P>
One of the more frequently cited names is that of Wall Street darling Goldman
Sachs.
</P>
<P>
The investment giant should be one of the first to pay back government loans,
thanks to a share price of more than 144 dollars.
</P>
<P>
Nicholas Colas, head of investment strategy at the BNY ConvergEx Group, said
that makes Goldman Sachs a favorite.
</P>
<P>
It may also have been helped by AIG's departure.
</P>
<P>
During the AIG shakeout in September the Dow Jones group noted that the exit of
one financial firm meant that that economically vital sector was under-
represented.
</P>
<P>
But there are other contenders. From the technology sector Apple, Google, Cisco
and Oracle are mentioned as possible replacements.
</P>
<P>
Google's candidature runs into the difficulty that its share price -- at over
400 dollars a piece -- may skew the index.
</P>
<P>
And technology stocks are already well represented by heavyweight IBM.
</P>
<P>
A recent poll by CNBC has further muddied the picture. The financial news
provider asked customers who should replace GM. The response was Abbott Labs, a
pharmaceuticals firm.
</P>
<P>
From the biotech field, Monsanto is an outsider. Owen Patrick of Deutsche Bank
pointed out that Monsanto was an important member of another index, the Standard
and Poor's 500.
</P>
<P>
"It is a little smaller in market cap," said BNY's Colas, "and not as well
known, but its technology and competitive advantage would be unique in the Dow."
</P>
<P>
If the GM change has been keenly anticipated, that is because change on the Dow
is rare.
</P>
<P>
Only six firms have come in this decade, with three in 2008 including Kraft --
Bank of America and Chevron replaced Altria and Honeywell.
</P>
<P>
According to Ogg the index's managers may use the opportunity to dump other
listings hit by the financial crisis.
</P>
<P>
Citigroup, now trading at four dollars a share, must feel its head is on the
chopping block.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Malaysia's Islamic party at a crossroads
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
KUALA LUMPUR, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
A power struggle in Malaysia's Islamic party will be put to the test in
leadership polls this week which pit hardline clerics against young moderates
who want to rebrand the party.
</P>
<P>
The Pan-Malaysia Islamic Party (PAS) has enjoyed a surge in popularity thanks to
deep public disillusionment with the Barisan Nasional coalition that has
governed the multiracial country for half a century.
</P>
<P>
PAS has formed an unlikely alliance with two other opposition parties which has
stuck together despite wide differences in their ideologies, giving them a
chance to unseat the coalition in the next elections due in several years.
</P>
<P>
But the PAS general assembly on June 5-7 will lay bare the dilemma at the
party's core -- whether to swing back to its hardline roots or to put on a more
moderate face to continue winning back support after some barren years.
</P>
<P>
"The party is at a threshold -- whether it can transcend its history of catering
largely to Muslims and put in place a model that everyone in the country
including non-Muslims can accept," said pollster Ibrahim Suffian.
</P>
<P>
"They need to be able to articulate issues relating to the economy, security,
international trade... to not only look after your hereafter, but look after
your here and today," said Ibrahim, from Merdeka Centre research.
</P>
<P>
Some 60 percent of Malaysians are Muslim Malays, but the population includes
large ethnic Chinese and Indian communities, and if PAS wants to break out
beyond its niche it needs to attract support from minorities.
</P>
<P>
Curiously, despite pushing for the creation of an Islamic state and the
introduction of "hudud" laws like chopping off thieves' hands, PAS has won the
trust and support of many non-Muslims.
</P>
<P>
Chinese and Indian voters have enthusiastically supported PAS candidates in
seats where they stood for the Pakatan Rakyat opposition alliance, and thousands
have joined PAS "Supporters' Clubs" around the country.
</P>
<P>
Much of the attraction stems from PAS's reputation as a clean party untainted by
the corruption which is endemic in the ruling coalition.
</P>
<P>
And in northern Kelantan state, where it has long been in power, minorities have
few complaints and are not obliged to observe local bylaws that discourage
skimpy clothing and high heels.
</P>
<P>
Reforms introduced before landmark 2008 elections, when the Pakatan Rakyat
snatched a third of parliamentary seats in an unprecedented performance,
reversed a decline that had seen PAS decimated in 2004 polls.
</P>
<P>
"They stopped talking about wanting to impose stricter sharia laws and they had
much more moderate faces in the party, people who were professionals and able to
converse in English," said Ibrahim.
</P>
<P>
But this rebranding exercise is now in jeopardy with a vote for top leadership
posts, including the deputy presidency, which will see a clash between incumbent
Nasharuddin Mat Isa and challenger Husam Musa.
</P>
<P>
Husam is an economist who typifies the party's new generation of educated
professionals, while Nasharuddin is closely identified with the party's
conservative president Abdul Hadi Awang.
</P>
<P>
Husam is an ally of PAS's iconic spiritual leader Nik Abdul Aziz Nik Mat, a
quirky figure who is a highly respected religious leader and also a big
supporter of opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim.
</P>
<P>
Nasharuddin meanwhile played a leading role in "secret" talks last year with the
ruling party UMNO -- which leads the Barisan Nasional coalition -- that were
hugely controversial within the party.
</P>
<P>
Observers say that if Nasharuddin retains his post, the fragile bonds between
the opposition partners will begin to erode, jeopardising its ability to
challenge the coalition.
</P>
<P>
"PAS is at a crossroads now. This meeting will see whether PAS is inclined to
have a good relationship with UMNO or have a good relationship with its
opposition partners," a party insider told AFP.
</P>
<P>
He said that a rebuke to Husam would also send out a negative message to non-
Muslims that it remains the "party of the ulamas", the elderly cohort of clerics
who have historically dominated the party.
</P>
<P>
"As a political party PAS has to go with the (reform) approach, that which is
accepted by the Malaysian people. During the last general election PAS had a lot
of support from non-Muslims and it has to maintain that," he said.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Malaysia's Islamic party at a crossroads
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
KUALA LUMPUR, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
A power struggle in Malaysia's Islamic party will be put to the test in
leadership polls this week which pit hardline clerics against young moderates
who want to rebrand the party.
</P>
<P>
The Pan-Malaysia Islamic Party (PAS) has enjoyed a surge in popularity thanks to
deep public disillusionment with the Barisan Nasional coalition that has
governed the multiracial country for half a century.
</P>
<P>
PAS has formed an unlikely alliance with two other opposition parties which has
stuck together despite wide differences in their ideologies, giving them a
chance to unseat the coalition in the next elections due in several years.
</P>
<P>
But the PAS general assembly on June 5-7 will lay bare the dilemma at the
party's core -- whether to swing back to its hardline roots or to put on a more
moderate face to continue winning back support after some barren years.
</P>
<P>
"The party is at a threshold -- whether it can transcend its history of catering
largely to Muslims and put in place a model that everyone in the country
including non-Muslims can accept," said pollster Ibrahim Suffian.
</P>
<P>
"They need to be able to articulate issues relating to the economy, security,
international trade... to not only look after your hereafter, but look after
your here and today," said Ibrahim, from Merdeka Centre research.
</P>
<P>
Some 60 percent of Malaysians are Muslim Malays, but the population includes
large ethnic Chinese and Indian communities, and if PAS wants to break out
beyond its niche it needs to attract support from minorities.
</P>
<P>
Curiously, despite pushing for the creation of an Islamic state and the
introduction of "hudud" laws like chopping off thieves' hands, PAS has won the
trust and support of many non-Muslims.
</P>
<P>
Chinese and Indian voters have enthusiastically supported PAS candidates in
seats where they stood for the Pakatan Rakyat opposition alliance, and thousands
have joined PAS "Supporters' Clubs" around the country.
</P>
<P>
Much of the attraction stems from PAS's reputation as a clean party untainted by
the corruption which is endemic in the ruling coalition.
</P>
<P>
And in northern Kelantan state, where it has long been in power, minorities have
few complaints and are not obliged to observe local bylaws that discourage
skimpy clothing and high heels.
</P>
<P>
Reforms introduced before landmark 2008 elections, when the Pakatan Rakyat
snatched a third of parliamentary seats in an unprecedented performance,
reversed a decline that had seen PAS decimated in 2004 polls.
</P>
<P>
"They stopped talking about wanting to impose stricter sharia laws and they had
much more moderate faces in the party, people who were professionals and able to
converse in English," said Ibrahim.
</P>
<P>
But this rebranding exercise is now in jeopardy with a vote for top leadership
posts, including the deputy presidency, which will see a clash between incumbent
Nasharuddin Mat Isa and challenger Husam Musa.
</P>
<P>
Husam is an economist who typifies the party's new generation of educated
professionals, while Nasharuddin is closely identified with the party's
conservative president Abdul Hadi Awang.
</P>
<P>
Husam is an ally of PAS's iconic spiritual leader Nik Abdul Aziz Nik Mat, a
quirky figure who is a highly respected religious leader and also a big
supporter of opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim.
</P>
<P>
Nasharuddin meanwhile played a leading role in "secret" talks last year with the
ruling party UMNO -- which leads the Barisan Nasional coalition -- that were
hugely controversial within the party.
</P>
<P>
Observers say that if Nasharuddin retains his post, the fragile bonds between
the opposition partners will begin to erode, jeopardising its ability to
challenge the coalition.
</P>
<P>
"PAS is at a crossroads now. This meeting will see whether PAS is inclined to
have a good relationship with UMNO or have a good relationship with its
opposition partners," a party insider told AFP.
</P>
<P>
He said that a rebuke to Husam would also send out a negative message to non-
Muslims that it remains the "party of the ulamas", the elderly cohort of clerics
who have historically dominated the party.
</P>
<P>
"As a political party PAS has to go with the (reform) approach, that which is
accepted by the Malaysian people. During the last general election PAS had a lot
of support from non-Muslims and it has to maintain that," he said.

<HEADLINE>
Danish Tiananmen sculptor denied entry to Hong Kong
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Hong Kong, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
A Danish sculptor who flew to Hong Kong to protest the bloody crackdown on pro-
democracy protests in Beijing 20 years ago has been refused entry to the city,
an official and a legislator said Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Jens Galschiot, whose sculpture commemorating those who died in the 1989
military crackdown, "Pillar of Shame," is displayed at Hong Kong University, was
stopped by officials Saturday, an immigration spokesman said.
</P>
<P>
Albert Ho, the chairman of the Democratic Party and a lawyer, said the Dane was
detained for five hours before being put on a flight to Zurich late Saturday.
</P>
<P>
Galschiot, who was also refused entry to the city ahead of the Beijing Olympics
last year, had planned to join the annual June 4 vigil to mark the anniversary
of the crackdown.
</P>
<P>
He was also planning to repair his sculpture and donate two more.
</P>
<P>
"We are looking at the possibility of legal action following the decision," Ho
told AFP. Ho had been allowed to see Galschiot during his detention.
</P>
<P>
Other members of his family and a filmmaker accompanying them were allowed to
pass through immigration.
</P>
<P>
The Danish Consulate was not immediately available for comment.
</P>
<P>
The immigration department spokesman said it had acted in accordance with the
law.
</P>
<P>
The 20th anniversary of the crackdown on the protests -- which left hundreds,
possibly thousands, dead across the Chinese capital -- will be marked on
Thursday in Hong Kong with a candlelight vigil expected to draw tens of
thousands.
</P>
<P>
Hong Kong, which has a different legal system from the mainland, is the only
place in China where the anniversary is publicly commemorated.
</P>

Orlando's "Superman" Dwight Howard poured in 40 points for the Magic, who are

</P>
<P>
They downed Cleveland - the team with the best regular-season record in the
league and Most Valuable Player LeBron James - four-games-to-two in the best-of-

</P>
<P>

</P>

victory.
</P>

</P>
<P>

</P>
<P>

on Tuesday that gave the Magic a 3-1 series lead.
</P>

could get no further.
</P>
<P>
Orlando will travel to Los Angeles for game one against the Lakers on Thursday.

champion Boston Celtics in seven games before subduing "King" James and the
Cavaliers.

deserve it."

impressive outing of the series. He was scoreless in the second quarter as the
Magic seized an 18-point lead.
</P>
<P>
The defeat overshadowed the fact that James had a superb series, averaging more
than 38 points, eight rebounds and eight assists in the six games.
</P>

However, he had too little support from his teammates, with Mo Williams
struggling to score and Orlando's bench solidly outplaying Cleveland's reserves.
</P>
<P>
After Howard slammed home a dunk with 2:21 to play, the chant of "Beat LA!" went
up from the Orlando crowd - which included golf superstar Tiger Woods.
</P>
<P>
Howard was even solid from the free-throw line, making 12 of 16 on Saturday.
</P>
<P>
While Cleveland powered through the regular season, the Magic had to contend
with a season-ending shoulder injury to point guard Jameer Nelson in February.
</P>
<P>
Orlando brought in guard Rafer Alston in a trade with Houston and helped revive
the team's playoff bid.

Two charged over plot to murder top Hong Kong democrat

<DATELINE>
Hong Kong, May 31, 2009 (AFP)

<TEXT>
<P>
Hong Kong police have charged two men over a plot to assassinate one of the

The plot to kill Lee, a veteran activist and long-time critic of Beijing, was
revealed on Saturday, but took place last summer during elections for Hong
Kong's legislature.
</P>
<P>

</P>

</P>

</P>

carrying a firearm with intent, possession of a firearm and ammunition without a
licence and conspiracy to commit grievous bodily harm.
</P>

licence.
</P>
<P>
Lee, who stepped down as a legislator last July, told reporters Saturday: "I was
never afraid because, as a Catholic, death to me is just like pushing the door
open to another life."
</P>

The plot was uncovered during the 2008 Legislative Council elections, one of the
limited voting opportunities in the city.
</P>
<P>
Universal suffrage was promised to Hong Kong when it was handed back to China by
colonial power Britain in 1997, but no timetable was set and democrats remain
frustrated at the slow pace of constitutional reform.
</P>
<P>
As well as his pro-democracy stance, Lee has been at the forefront of the
campaign to remember and vindicate pro-democracy activists who led a six-week
protest in Tiananmen Square in Beijing in 1989.
</P>
<P>
The 20th anniversary of the crackdown on the protests -- which left hundreds,
possibly thousands, dead across the Chinese capital -- will be marked on
Thursday in Hong Kong with a candlelight vigil expected to draw tens of
thousands.
</P>
<P>
Hong Kong, which has a separate legal system from China, has an outspoken and
vibrant political culture, but violence against politicians is rare.

<HEADLINE>
Insein prison: Myanmar's 'silent killing field'
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Bangkok, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Described by inmates as a "hell" where beatings are common and disease is rife,
Myanmar's Insein Prison, where Aung San Suu Kyi is on trial, is the brutal
symbol of the ruling junta's repression.
</P>
<P>
The Nobel laureate has spent the past three weeks incarcerated in a so-called
"guest house" at the jail on the outskirts of Yangon while her trial takes place
behind closed doors at the notorious compound.
</P>
<P>
Her party has expressed concerns for her health after she suffered leg cramps in
recent days while at the prison. The authorities say she is receiving medical
care.
</P>
<P>
But if Aung San Suu Kyi has been kept in relatively bearable conditions at the
prison -- which was built by former colonial power Britain -- for hundreds of
other political prisoners it is the heart of Myanmar's darkness.
</P>
<P>
"It's like a hell where people really suffer. It's some kind of silent 'killing
field,'" Bo Kyi, who spent seven years in the jail following a failed student
uprising in 1988, told AFP.
</P>
<P>
Several political prisoners told of how they suffered bruising weeks-long
interrogations at the hands of the junta's jailers at Insein.
</P>
<P>
Bo Kyi said during one round of questioning he was whipped with a rubber cord as
he lay on his stomach and counted 150 lashes before he lost consciousness and
awoke in a solitary cell.
</P>
<P>
He said he was then forced to assume different positions for hour-long periods
while shackled in chains with a bar between his legs.
</P>
<P>
The heavily secured Insein is home to many of the 2,100 political prisoners
which the United Nations says are held in Myanmar's prisons, often on spurious
sentences of up to 60 years.
</P>
<P>
At least 139 political detainees have died in detention in the country since
1988, several of them in Insein, according to the Assistance Association for
Political Prisoners of Burma (AAPPB), co-founded by Bo Kyi.
</P>
<P>
Details of conditions inside the secretive jail emerge mostly from former
prisoners, although Tomas Okea Quintana, the UN Special Rapporteur on Myanmar,
visited the prison for four hours in February and met five inmates.
</P>
<P>
He said after his visit that many detainees suffered from a lack of medical care
during imprisonment.
</P>
<P>
Former prisoner Aung Myo Naing, who spent more than eight years there, said that
each cell in Insein is 8 by 11 feet (2.5 by 3.5 metres), furnished with two
bamboo mats and two uncovered toilet buckets.
</P>
<P>
"Insein Prison is a deadly torture camp," the 41-year-old said, describing one
period of about 45 days when he was kept in solitary confinement and forbidden
to read, write or bathe.
</P>
<P>
Past prisoners have described novel methods of communicating during these times,
scratching messages to one another on cigarette filter papers and feeding them
through holes in prison walls.
</P>
<P>
Inmates are given 15 minutes outside of the cell daily to shower, but they have
no soap and no spare clothes to change into.
</P>
<P>
Many prisoners are starving -- their rations of food consist of boiled water
with a few sparse vegetables, fish paste and occasional rations of meat along
with overcooked rice, while water is not purified.
</P>
<P>
The conditions mean that diseases such as tuberculosis and hepatitis B are rife,
while joint pains, eyesight problems and mental illness are commonplace.
</P>
<P>
But access to a doctor is rare.
</P>
<P>
"They give you aspirins and another drug for sneezing, whatever illness you've
got," said Aung Myo Thein, whose elder brother was also imprisoned and now
suffers severe depression.
</P>
<P>
Due to dirty needles, medical treatment can itself be hazardous.
</P>
<P>
Last year media watchdog Reporters Without Borders said that poet Aung Than, a
member of Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy, was probably infected with
the HIV virus when he was forcibly injected in Insein prison hospital.
</P>
<P>
Many other prominent prisoners have been denied access to healthcare and have
been moved since October 2008 to jails hundreds of miles from their families.
</P>
<P>
The International Committee of the Red Cross made its last visit to Insein
Prison in November 2005, and two months later suspended its prison visits saying
it could not fulfil its independent, impartial mandate.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0420" type="story" >

</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Hanoi, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
A 23-year-old Vietnamese man has tested positive for swine flu in what would be

Ho Chi Minh City was positive, Phan Van Tu, a doctor with the city's Pasteur

diseases, would conduct another test on Sunday.
</P>

</P>
<P>
State-linked Tuoi Tre newspaper reported that the patient is a student recently
returned from the United States.
</P>
<P>
Tuoi Tre said he arrived in Ho Chi Minh City from the US Monday night and was
admitted to hospital there after being checked by health authorities.
</P>
<P>
The newspaper, which did not give a source for its report, said the student
later left hospital to go home but on Friday went to the tropical diseases
hospital, where he tested positive for the A(H1N1) virus.
</P>
<P>
Swine flu was first detected last month in the United States and Mexico.
</P>
<P>
In its latest update the World Health Organisation said 53 countries have
reported 15,510 cases of swine flu, including 99 deaths.
</P>
<P>
Vietnam has been monitoring the health of passengers arriving at its airports in
a bid to detect swine flu.
</P>
<P>
Earlier this month authorities in South Korea said a 22-year-old Vietnamese
woman returning home from the US was infected with A(H1N1) and placed in
quarantine while on a transit stop at Incheon.
</P>
<P>
Vietnam has the world's second-highest death toll from bird flu, at 56.
</P>
<P>
Preventing swine flu from infecting patients sick with the deadly H5N1 avian flu
should be a top priority, especially in Asia, experts have said.

<HEADLINE>
Japan's shadow finance minister wants single Asian currency
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
tokyo, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The man who hopes to be Japan's next finance minister envisions an Asia united
by a single currency, saying the dollar may no longer reign supreme in future.
</P>
<P>
The opposition's 'shadow finance minister' Masaharu Nakagawa also says he hopes
to reshape the world's number two economy into a kinder, gentler place if his
Democratic Party of Japan (DPJ) wins elections this year.
</P>
<P>
"You can't invigorate society only through... the law of the jungle where the
strong become stronger," he told AFP. "The same player would always win if there
were no handicaps in golf."
</P>
<P>
Japan's conservative Prime Minister Taro Aso must call elections by September,
when the DPJ hopes to topple his Liberal Democratic Party, which has been in
power for almost all of the past half century.
</P>
<P>
In an interview with AFP, Nakagawa outlined some of the changes he would like to
make if he becomes finance minister in Asia's largest economy, which is now in
the throes of its worst post-World War II recession.
</P>
<P>
Looking at the broader region, he said Asia should tackle security and economic
issues as "a unified community."
</P>
<P>
"Asian currencies should be unified into a common currency in the course of the
region's forming a single economic zone," Nakagawa told AFP.
</P>
<P>
He did not give a timeframe, saying it would largely depend on economic and
political developments in China.
</P>
<P>
Nakagawa said people must "take into account the possibility that the dollar
might not function as the key currency any more in the medium and long term" as
the world seeks a new order in the post-Cold War era.
</P>
<P>
Until an Asian common currency emerges, he said, "the Japanese government should
make efforts to have the 'Asia zone' use the yen, not the dollar, for trade
settlements. It's time for Japan to launch this plan."
</P>
<P>
Japan's government could extend lending to the International Monetary Fund on
condition that it is in yen while guaranteeing bonds by Asian countries if they
are denominated in the Japanese currency, he said.
</P>
<P>
Nakagawa, who turns 59 in June, studied foreign affairs at Georgetown University
in the United States in the 1970s. The father-of-four represents a constituency
in central Mie prefecture.
</P>
<P>
He says he is a "generalist" rather than an economic expert.
</P>
<P>
Speaking more broadly on his vision for Japan, he said the country had followed
the United States and its liberalism in the past, but the time had come for the
nation to be "more Asian."
</P>
<P>
"Now is the time for Japan to say what kind of world it would like to create,
not to adapt itself to the given circumstances as it has done" since its defeat
in World World II, he said.
</P>
<P>
At home, Nakagawa's vision is in line with the goal of a "compassionate society"
advocated by his new party boss, Yukio Hatoyama.
</P>
<P>
The DPJ has proposed slashing corporate taxes for small companies so that they
have a better chance to compete.
</P>
<P>
The party has said it will spend 21 trillion yen (220 billion dollars) over the
next two years to revive the economy, including the tax cuts, payouts for
families with children, as well as scrapping expressway tolls.
</P>
<P>
Prime Minister Taro Aso's government plans spending of 15.4 trillion yen for the
current business year to March 2010.
</P>
</TEXT>

</P>
<P>
Dwight Howard poured in 40 points for Orlando, who are returning to the NBA
finals championship series for the first time in 14 years.
</P>
<P>
They downed Cleveland - the team with the best regular-season record in the
league and Most Valuable Player LeBron James - four-games-to-two in the best-of-
seven Eastern Conference finals.
</P>
<P>
The Magic will be making their first finals appearance since 1995, one year
before Shaquille O'Neal departed as a free agent for Los Angeles.
</P>
<P>
Rashard Lewis added 18 points for the Magic, who hit 12 3-pointers in the
victory.
</P>
<P>
The Cavaliers had won 66 regular-season games and won both of their opening
playoff series in four-game sweeps.
</P>
<P>
But Orlando pushed them to the brink of defeat with a 116-114 overtime victory
on Tuesday that gave the Magic a 3-1 series lead.
</P>
<P>
Cleveland had responded with a victory on Thursday to force Saturday's game, but
could get no further.
</P>
<P>
Orlando will travel to Los Angeles for game one against the Lakers on Thursday.
</P>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0425" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
India economy headed higher, reforms in sight: analysts
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
New Delhi, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
India's economy is on the upswing with eyes now keenly focused on July's planned
budget for new market-opening moves by the freshly re-elected Congress
government, analysts say.
</P>
<P>
The country logged unexpectedly strong 5.8 percent growth in the final quarter
to March 2009, against forecasts of 5.0 percent, figures late last week showed,
prompting analysts to say the economy had turned the corner.
</P>
<P>
"We see a new growth cycle taking shape with the first stop seven percent and
then eight percent," said Rajeev Malik, economist at Macquarie Securities.
</P>
<P>
India's economy expanded by 6.7 percent in the year to March 2009, down from
nine percent a year earlier.
</P>
<P>
But the country of nearly 1.2 billion people is performing far better than many
others caught in the global slump, thanks to its vast, resilient domestic
market, hefty government spending and aggressive rate cuts, analysts say.
</P>
<P>
Foreign capital is pouring back into India with the benchmark Sensex share index
near a nine-month high of 14,625 following a spurt in May after the Congress
party was swept back to power with its biggest seat haul in 18 years.
</P>
<P>
The strong mandate allows the Congress to govern without the support of the
communists who propped up the government in parliament during its last term.
</P>
<P>
Economists called the Congress win a "game changer" for the economy because it
raises hopes of political stability for the next five years and the introduction
of economic reforms that had been blocked by the Left.
</P>
<P>
There has already been a flurry of announcements by new ministers promising such
moves as loosening state-controlled fuel pump prices, which would help refinery
profits, and cutting mobile call rates to propel India's explosively growing
cellular sector.
</P>
<P>
Economic growth is forecast at around six percent in the first half of the year
and closer to seven percent in the second amid "green shoots" signs such as
higher car sales and cement output.
</P>
<P>
Next year, economists expect expansion of eight percent.
</P>
<P>
"We expect a pick-up in economic activity from lower borrowing costs and higher
government spending which is feeding through the system," said Shubhada  Rao,
economist at Yes Bank.
</P>
<P>
In another positive sign, the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and
Industry (FICCI) announced Saturday a sharp upturn in business optimism.
</P>
<P>
Some 57 percent of 300 firms polled in the final quarter to March declared
economic conditions were "moderately to substantially" better -- up from the
nine percent in the previous quarter who reported an improvement.
</P>
<P>
"Companies are looking forward to a recovery on the basis of their order books
and performance," FICCI economist Anjan Roy said.
</P>
<P>
Economists are now focused on the budget that Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee
has promised to present in the first week of July to see what steps he will take
to open up India's still relatively inward-looking economy.
</P>
<P>
Mukherjee said last week the government would press ahead with some long stymied
reforms "in the financial sector and real economy" to make it more competitive
and draw foreign investment.
</P>
<P>
The government may privatise some state-owned firms and raise  foreign-ownership
caps in insurance and aviation as well as possibly broadening overseas
investment access in retailing.
</P>
<P>
But Mukherjee said his "top priority" was "reviving the growth momentum" and
helping the poor and he would step up spending even if this meant scant progress
in closing India's yawning fiscal deficit, which at 6.2 percent is at a seven-
year peak.
</P>
<P>
HSBC economist Robert Prior Wandesforde forecast no "big bang" reforms in a
country where economic changes can provoke huge debate.
</P>
<P>
But "even if they (the government) do a few things, the multiplier effect will
be quite significant," said Macquarie's Malik.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0426" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Foreign investors eye Angola
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Luanda, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
In the lobby bar of one of Luanda's few decent hotels, suited businessmen sit in
deep leather armchairs waiting for a meeting in the oil-rich country which could
change their fortunes.
</P>
<P>
"Angola is one of the last great emerging market opportunities," one European
man told AFP between sips of whisky.
</P>
<P>
"I don't care about the logistical problems as long as the solutions and rewards
are there -- I'm in this for the long term to make money."
</P>
<P>
Thanks to high oil prices and a peacetime construction frenzy, Angola has
enjoyed annual double-digit growth since a 27-year civil war ended in 2002 to
become one of the world's fastest growing economies.
</P>
<P>
Growth is set to slow this year, but interest from international investors has
not abated with a recent flurry of high profile trade delegations, all hoping to
get a piece of the action.
</P>
<P>
The government's response to falling commodity prices, which threaten public
spending aimed at Angola's poor majority, is diversification into areas such as
agriculture and manufacturing.
</P>
<P>
Until now, Angola's main foreign players have been Brazilian and Portuguese
firms, and Chinese companies helped along by close ties and credit lines
believed to exceed five billion dollars.
</P>
<P>
But along with visits from the United States, France and South Korea in the past
month, there have also been business forums in Rome and Cairo and state visits
by President Jose Eduardo dos Santos to Germany and Portugal.
</P>
<P>
Last week a trade agreement was signed with US Secretary of State Hillary
Clinton in Washington.
</P>
<P>
Among the recent American delegation was Delta Air Lines which hopes to launch
the first direct scheduled flight from the United States to Luanda in September.
</P>
<P>
"There's no question, Angola is a very strong market and there is a lot of
potential," the airline's government affairs advisor Scott Yohe told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"The amount of time it takes to get to Angola from the US, via Europe or via
South Africa, has an impact on trade and the new flight will definitely be a
catalyst for investment."
</P>
<P>
Dubai-based Emirates starts flying three times a week from Luanda to Dubai in
August.
</P>
<P>
"Angola is a country which is really moving," explained Nigel Page, senior vice
president of Emirates in Americas and Africa.
</P>
<P>
"We predict that there will be a lot of business exchanges between Luanda and
Dubai and this route will channel more companies into Angola from the east."
</P>
<P>
There is already plenty of Asian investment in Angola, particularly from China
which holds a number of key construction contracts, including four 2010 Africa
Cup of Nations football stadiums.
</P>
<P>
China's interest in Angola has aroused concern in the west, especially as a
number of the loans have been oil backed, but Alex Vines, of the London-based
think tank Chatham House, believes the Sino-Angolan relationship may be waning.
</P>
<P>
"From a geo-strategic point of view, Angola wants to woo lots of different
investment, not just from China," he told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"And that's why we've seen Dos Santos making these high profile visits to Europe
and these other trade trips being invited to Angola."
</P>
<P>
Despite predicting a three-percent contraction in 2009, World Bank economist
Ricardo Gazel said: "Angola's economy is still in a much better position than
most and medium and long term, the prospects are very good.
</P>
<P>
"There is a lot of investment interest, particularly in the non-petroleum sector
which is good for diversifying the economy and for the economy as a whole."
</P>
<P>
For businesses hoping to break into the Angolan market however, it's not easy
and good contacts go a long way.
</P>
<P>
The World Bank's Doing Business Report ranks Angola as one of the hardest places
to set up a company with 68 days needed to start a business, although this has
halved since 2008.
</P>
<P>
But, big on capital if low on know-how, Angola has been spreading the word about
investment opportunities and it seems the world is listening.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0429" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Bordeaux bets on top quality but cheap 2008 vintage
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
BORDEAUX, France, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
After months of gloom, Bordeaux wine traders are hoping the 2008 vintage will
revive the market after steep price cuts and rave reviews from the world's most
influential connoisseur.
</P>
<P>
The southwestern French region's rarest wines are sold every spring as a futures
commodity, 12 months prior to bottling. With the world gripped by recession,
many had been fearing financial disaster.
</P>
<P>
The futures sale only concerns a tiny percentage of the 800 million bottles the
Bordeaux region produces annually, but the prices of the top 20 wines help
determine the public perception of the quality of the vintage.
</P>
<P>
This year, the big wine estates brought prices down sharply, opening the way for
traders to target middle market wine drinkers after a period when the finest
wines were priced for sale to only the richest speculators.
</P>
<P>
As Patrick Bernard, owner of wine merchant powerhouse Millesima, explained: "If
the top 20 wines double or triple their prices as they did in 2005, all of
Bordeaux wine is perceived as expensive.
</P>
<P>
"The first wine on the market was Angelus, one of those 20 wines, and they cut
their price by 40 percent. A few days later, the First Growths came out with a
45 percent decrease and then Yquem with a 65 percent decrease."
</P>
<P>
Other premium wines were released at the same time to maintain momentum.
Leoville Barton dropped its ex-cellar price to 23 euros and sold out within a
few hours.
</P>
<P>
"It was much better than I expected," said Lilian Barton, co-owner of the
legendary estates Chateaux Leoville Barton and Langoa Barton, and director of
her family wine merchant, Les Vins Fins Anthony Barton.
</P>
<P>
In addition to dropping their prices, the chateaux had hoped to demonstrate
their independence from US wine critic Robert Parker, nicknamed the "Million
Dollar Nose" for his influence on the market.
</P>
<P>
Parker is a champion of Bordeaux's wines, but many in the industry feel that he
wields too much power with his rankings, and three-quarters of the wines were
put on sale before he had given his verdict.
</P>
<P>
The demonstration of defiance was only partly successful, at best.
</P>
<P>
Several sources said that sales prior to the release of Parker's ratings, with
the exception of a few star buys, were subdued. The tempo changed when Parker
awarded the vintage spectacular ratings.
</P>
<P>
"The buyers went berserk," said Barton.
</P>
<P>
Clients who had pleaded poverty in early April suddenly found the wherewithal to
buy on futures.
</P>
<P>
Despite annoyance with the fickle importers, Barton, Anson, Bernard and others
were relieved to see the return of traditional customers who had been pushed out
of the market in recent years by skyrocketing prices.
</P>
<P>
The vintage was very good and there was a dramatic drop in price -- buyers are
stocking up for customers who buy wine to drink rather than to invest.
</P>
<P>
"This was the vintage to buy for the consumer," enthused Bernard.
</P>
<P>
Unlike nearly all of the other 400 wine merchants, Millesima, with annual
revenues of 52 million euros, sells directly to the consumer in 11 European
countries and America.
</P>
<P>
"Direct sales to European consumers has been good. There's no currency problem
and they haven't been able to afford it over the last few years."
</P>
<P>
Bernard will buy 35,000 cases this year, a 10 percent increase over last year
even though most chateaux are offering customers only 80 percent of their usual
allocations because of a small crop.
</P>
<P>
While the 2008 futures campaign is slowly drawing to a close, there is little
doubt that for many it succeeded in resuscitating not only sales but the image
of Bordeaux wine as a consumer product.
</P>
<P>
Already merchants and winegrowers are looking forward to Vinexpo, the
International Wine and Spirits Exhibition held from June 21 to 25, with 45,000
professionals expected to attend.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0430" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Eurozone interest rate locked, new steps on tap: analysts
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Frankfurt, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The main eurozone interest rate is probably locked in at 1.0 percent for now,
but credit flows remain weak and the European Central Bank will detail this week
new ways to get money flowing again.
</P>
<P>
The ECB will also release Thursday its latest staff forecasts for growth and
inflation in the 16-nation bloc, with a downward revision likely for the former
owing to a disastrous first quarter in its leading economies.
</P>
<P>
With interest rates most likely on hold for a while, "the focus has shifted to
any developments regarding unconventional policies," said Capital Economics
economist Jennifer McKeown.
</P>
<P>
The ECB has already said it will buy 60 billion euros' (85 billion dollars')
worth of covered, or collateralised, bonds, a move that should help restore cash
flows in French, German and Spanish markets where such instruments are traded
most widely.
</P>
<P>
Details are expected after a meeting of the bank's governing council.
</P>
<P>
But the amount corresponds to just 0.6 percent of the eurozone's gross domestic
product, McKeown noted, whereas bolder moves by the US Federal Reserve and Bank
of England are worth around 10 percent of their respective GDP.
</P>
<P>
It also remains to be seen whether the ECB will "sterilise" the purchases by
issuing its own debt or selling other assets, or whether it will just print new
money, a move that could fuel inflation.
</P>
<P>
The bank's priority is to keep inflation just below 2.0 percent, but it now
faces the prospect of a broad-based fall in prices that could end in a
deflationary spiral which could strangle economic activity.
</P>
<P>
If businesses and individuals become convinced that prices will fall further,
they postpone purchases, causing production to fall and raising unemployment,
which can depress prices further.
</P>
<P>
Eurozone inflation hit a record low of zero in May, European Union statistics
showed, and will likely turn negative in coming months owing to comparisons with
the same period last year when oil prices spiked to record highs.
</P>
<P>
But UniCredit economist Marco Valli said: "We don't think the ECB will be overly
impressed" by the development, which has been forecast for several months.
</P>
<P>
ECB president Jean-Claude Trichet has stressed that short term price volatility
is not a factor in the bank's decisions, and with oil prices on the rise again,
a deflationary episode is unlikely to last long.
</P>
<P>
"The recent strong rally in oil prices makes the inflation picture more
uncertain than just a couple of weeks ago," Valli said.
</P>
<P>
"The central bank will continue to see the risk of deflation as very low," he
added.
</P>
<P>
The ECB can also point to indications that the eurozone's first recession has
probably passed its trough even though the European Commission still expects the
economy to contract by 1.9 percent this year.
</P>
<P>
That leaves the thorny problem of credit growth, which according to the bank's
figures continued to slow sharply in April.
</P>
<P>
"There is no easing in the very tight credit conditions that are facing
companies and individuals," noted Howard Archer at IHS Global Insight.
</P>
<P>
"Tighter credit conditions are a serious handicap to recovery prospects in the
eurozone," he said, and raise pressure on the ECB "to take additional 'non-
standard' measures."
</P>
<P>
Commerzbank analyst Rainer Guntermann felt "the ECB has not yet closed the door
to more easing measures," but that an expansion of the already announced bond
purchases in June was unlikely.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0431" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Germany rescues Opel, for now
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
berlin, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Germany has ensured that Opel's tens of thousands of workers will still have a
job on Monday when its once-mighty US parent General Motors, as is expected,
makes history and files for bankruptcy.
</P>
<P>
But Chancellor Angela Merkel's decision to support with taxpayers' money a
Kremlin-backed rescue may come back to haunt her, and could fail to prevent Opel
crashing and burning further down the road, experts say.
</P>
<P>
"All this seems to rest on a very fragile base. Let's say there is a 60 or 70
percent chance that it won't work," Juergen Pieper, an automotive analyst at
Metzler Bank, told AFP.
</P>
<P>
In a mammoth effort over recent months climaxing in a frenzy of activity last
week, the German government agreed in the early hours of Saturday morning to
back a takeover of Opel by a consortium formed around Canada's Magna.
</P>
<P>
Under the deal, GM would keep 35 percent of the company and Opel's workers would
retain 10 percent. Magna, which makes auto parts, would hold a 20 percent stake
and state-owned Russian lender Sberbank 35 percent.
</P>
<P>
Government sources told AFP that Germany would act as guarantor for around three
billion euros (4.2 billion dollars) worth of loans, and the government would
also itself make an emergency loan of 1.5 billion euros to Opel.
</P>
<P>
Magna meanwhile, which until recently was relatively unknown outside the auto
industry, has pledged to cough up 300 million euros to keep the cash-starved
Opel alive in the coming weeks.
</P>
<P>
The Canadian firm, which thrashed out an eleventh-hour agreement with GM
executives in a luxury Berlin hotel on Friday, has pledged to keep all Opel's
German factories open and limit job cuts there to around 2,500.
</P>
<P>
But across Europe as a whole, where GM employs some 50,000 people including
7,000 in Spain and 4,700 at Britain's Vauxhall, the picture may be less rosy
with Magna saying it plans to lay off one in five workers.
</P>
<P>
Last week Germany came under pressure from Britain and Belgium not to save
German jobs at the expense of workers elsewhere, and on Saturday Britain's
biggest trade union Unite voiced concern about the fate of Vauxhall workers.
</P>
<P>
It was also unclear whether Magna's intention to start making Opel cars at a
factory in Russia owned by precious metals tycoon Oleg Deripaska's GAZ automaker
would mean some production will be taken away from plants in the European Union.
</P>
<P>
Russian involvement also raises eyebrows because it strengthens the already
strong business ties -- most notably in gas -- between Berlin and Moscow.
Critics say that these ties make Germany too soft on the Kremlin.
</P>
<P>
For analysts, it was September's elections in Germany that helped win Merkel
over to Russian involvement.
</P>
<P>
"Money doesn't smell at election time," said Andrew Wilson at the European
Council of Foreign Relations think tank.
</P>
<P>
Magna and its Russian backers have their work cut out making the deal work, with
Opel part of a global automotive industry that was already facing huge
challenges even before the world economy hit the skids last year.
</P>
<P>
Frank Schwope, an analyst at Germany's NordLB bank, predicted that the Canadian-
Russian investors "will try everything, and then fail and Opel will be insolvent
in two or three years."
</P>
<P>
Magna also has very little experience making cars -- unlike Fiat, which also
wanted to snap up Opel but then got cold feet -- and the financial details of
the deal are unclear.
</P>
<P>
Merkel admitted on Saturday that the road ahead is a rocky one.
</P>
<P>
"For Opel and Magna, the work is now just beginning and there are several
difficulties still to overcome," she said.
</P>
<P>
But cynics say that for the chancellor and her partners in the governing
coalition, even if Opel does end up collapsing further down the road, it is
mission accomplished: Opel will not be issue in September's vote.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0432" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Coup leader says no deal on Mauritania poll delay
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
DAKAR, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
General Ould Abdel Aziz, who toppled Mauritania's government last year, said
that no deal was near on delaying a controversial election scheduled to be held
later this week.
</P>
<P>
Supporters of Ould Abdel Aziz and the opposition have been holding talks with
international mediators in the Senegalese capital Dakar, with sources on
Saturday on saying an accord was close on resolving the political deadlock in
the northwest African country.
</P>
<P>
But Ould Abdel Aziz dismissed such talk.
</P>
<P>
"A group of criminals is spreading these rumours and lies because they recognise
their inevitable defeat at elections," he said at a campaign meeting on
Saturday.
</P>
<P>
Ould Abdel Aziz often calls supporters of the main opposition parties criminals.
</P>
<P>
"We are not negotiating in Dakar with criminals and bandits but with the
international community to ensure democracy and move forward on the path of
change," he was quoted as saying by Mauritania's ANI news agency.
</P>
<P>
"The election is still planned for June 6," he added.
</P>
<P>
Ould Abdel Aziz quit the military in April to run for president, and is widely
expected to win if the vote goes ahead as he doesn't have serious contenders due
to the boycott by the main opposition parties.
</P>
<P>
The intensive talks launched in Dakar on Thursday -- which include officials
from the United Nations, African Union, European Union and Arab League -- have
focused on postponing the election to allow the opposition to end its boycott
and participate in the vote.
</P>
<P>
Under a five-page draft accord seen by AFP have Ould Cheikh Abdallahi, who was
toppled in last August's coup, would formally resign as president after signing
a decree to usher in a transitional period under a temporary government of
national unity.
</P>
<P>
This government would update the electoral rolls and issue voting cards to the
electorate ahead of elections.
</P>
<P>
A general amnesty would be declared, including for politicians arrested by the
military in the wake of the coup and subsequently accused of corruption.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0437" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Progress in fighting lung cancer at specialist summit
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Orlando, Florida, May 30, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Cancer specialists, gathered for an annual meeting, are reporting progress in
the fight against lung cancer, the most common and deadliest form of cancer, but
little progress in treating colorectal cancer.
</P>
<P>
Doctors and researchers at the 45th gathering of the American Society of
Clinical Oncology (ASCO) -- the world's main cancer conference -- on Saturday
learned of two studies showing progress in the battle against lung cancer.
</P>
<P>
The first study showed how the combination of two anti-cancer treatments
following standard chemotherapy can slow the advance of lung cancer.
</P>
<P>
Patients treated with a combination of Tarceva, sold by the Swiss drugmaker
Roche, and Avastin, a drug by Roche's Genentech unit, saw their cancer growth
slow more than a control group treated with Avastin.
</P>
<P>
More than 750 patients were randomized to receive Avastin and a placebo, or
Avastin and Tarceva. Those in the Tarceva group survived an average of 4.8
months before the cancer started growing again, compared to 3.7 months for the
control group, said Vincent Miller, the study's main author.
</P>
<P>
The numbers translated to a 29 percent reduced risk of disease progression for
patients who took a combination of Tarceva and Avastin.
</P>
<P>
"This is the first study to show that adding erlotinib (Tarceva) to maintenance
therapy with bevacizumab (Avastin) delays disease progression in patients who
have already received bevacizumab as part of their initial chemotherapy," said
Miller.
</P>
<P>
A second study with 663 patients with advance lung cancer were given the drug
Alimta, from US pharmaceutical Eli Lilly, which blocks cell growth.
</P>
<P>
Preliminary results showed that patients who took the drug lived 26 percent
longer compared to a control group that took a placebo: 13.4 months against 10.6
months.
</P>
<P>
As in the first study, all the patients had already received four standard
chemotherapy sessions.
</P>
<P>
"This study will change the overall standard of care," said Chandra Belani, the
deputy director of the Penn State Cancer Institute, as she presented the
research.
</P>
<P>
"Maintenance therapy with Alimta (permetrexed) offers a new paradigm for
patients who have advanced lung cancer, because it has a low toxicity and can be
given on an ongoing basis over a prolonged period of time to extend patients'
lives," she said.
</P>
<P>
However there were few advances to report in the fight against colorectal
cancer, the fourth most common in the United States and the second deadliest
type of cancer.
</P>
<P>
Research on 2,710 patients with Phase Three colorectal cancer taking the drug
Avastine along with standard chemotherapy treatment showed no difference in the
survival rate or the recurrence of the tumor after three and a half years when
compared to those not taking the drug.
</P>
<P>
Another study conducted in Italy among 747 patients with advanced colorectal
cancer showed that the drug Eloxatine from the French firm Sanofi did not reduce
the size of the tumor when combined with standard treatment used ahead of cancer
surgery.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Malaysian Sikh family in new 'bodysnatching' case
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
KUALA LUMPUR, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
A Malaysian Sikh family is demanding to be given the remains of their relative
who Islamic authorities say had converted to Islam, in the latest "body
snatching" case to hit the country.
</P>
<P>
The family's lawyer said that religious authorities insisted Mohan Singh, a 41
-year-old art director who died of a heart attack last Monday, had died a Muslim
-- a claim the family disputes.
</P>
<P>
His body has been kept at the mortuary of a government hospital in central
Selangor state which has refused to release the remains to the family, lawyer
Rajesh Kumar told AFP.
</P>
<P>
"When he died, he was a practising Sikh, he never told anybody and nobody knew
that he had converted to Islam, including family and close friends. His
identification card to date stated that he is still a non-Muslim," Kumar said.
</P>
<P>
"The family is very upset. All they want is to claim the body and cremate him
according to the Sikh rites," he added.
</P>
<P>
The lawyer said that the Islamic authorities claimed Mohan, who had directed
some local films, had converted to Islam in 1992 and was seeking confirmation of
his conversion from an Islamic sharia court.
</P>
<P>
"Our contention is that at the time of his death, he was still practising
Sikhism and even when his mother died three years ago, he performed the last
rites for the mother according to the Sikh faith," said Kumar.
</P>
<P>
"He wouldn't be able to do so if he is a Muslim," he said.
</P>
<P>
Conversion rows, including "body-snatching" cases when Islamic authorities have
battled with relatives over the remains of people whose religion is disputed,
are common in Muslim-majority Malaysia.
</P>
<P>
The tussles have raised allegations that the country of 27 million people is
being "Islamised" and that the rights of the ethnic Chinese and Indian
minorities are being eroded.
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Key Tiananmen dissident still defiant, 20 years on
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Beijing, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Former top Chinese Communist official Bao Tong was purged for supporting the
1989 pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square, but he says his
frustrations with the system started decades before.
</P>
<P>
"China's people have wasted 60 years," Bao, now one of the country's top
political dissidents, told AFP recently -- before authorities moved him out of
Beijing to wait out Thursday's 20th anniversary of the deadly crackdown.
</P>
<P>
His harsh assessment of the history of the People's Republic of China, founded
in October 1949, is one few ordinary Chinese would dare to make.
</P>
<P>
But the 76-year-old Bao, once a top aide to former Chinese leader Zhao Ziyang,
is not your average citizen.
</P>
<P>
He has spent the past 20 years either in jail, under house arrest or facing
other restrictions in his small west Beijing flat, just one block from a major
road where protesters battled tanks and troops.
</P>
<P>
He sees no sign of political openness on the horizon and says Beijing's failure
to come clean on the events of June 3-4, 1989 and give justice to victims has
been a key factor stunting democratic development.
</P>
<P>
"It has had a seriously negative impact. It has made China a country with no
voice.... a country in which no one can demand fairness," he said in the
interview at his apartment.
</P>
<P>
"I am a sample on display," Bao says with a smirk, charging the government only
allows foreign journalists to interview him to give the impression of openness,
while preventing anything he says from being disseminated in China.
</P>
<P>
Bao was dragged down along with Zhao, who was ousted from his position as
general secretary of the Communist Party for sympathising with the student
protesters who had rallied for weeks.
</P>
<P>
Zhao had opposed the use of force against the demonstrators, but was overruled
by party hardliners. Hundreds, and possibly thousands, were killed in the army
crackdown.
</P>
<P>
Bao, who once directed a top Communist party political reform office, is still
lean and energetic.
</P>
<P>
He now spends much of his time doing interviews with or fielding calls from
foreign media on a phone whose ring tone is the Disney theme "It's a Small
World."
</P>
<P>
Bao said China's current leaders bear no blame for what happened in Tiananmen
Square -- and could earn great praise both at home and abroad on this
anniversary by being more forthcoming.
</P>
<P>
"They are still the nation's leaders and I hope they can openly tell the Chinese
people and the world what happened," he said.
</P>
<P>
But the party's unwillingness to admit any mistakes will prevent that and the
Chinese people are too intimidated to demand such honesty, he added.
</P>
<P>
Much of the blame lies with the rest of the world for refusing to push China to
heal the wounds, said Bao, adding that other countries were increasingly
hesitant to rile China due to its growing economic and diplomatic clout.
</P>
<P>
"Not wanting to offend China means they cannot help China, cannot help China's
people attain their own rights, and cannot help the world community gain a
reliable, stable, peaceful member," he said.
</P>
<P>
"This is not a good thing."
</P>
<P>
As the Communist Party gears up to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the
founding of the People's Republic of China on October 1, Bao said there was
little to celebrate.
</P>
<P>
The party wasted a lifetime with collectivisation of the economy launched in
1953, only to come full circle with today's run-away capitalism.
</P>
<P>
"(We) have come back to the original point. The work of 1.3 billion people has
been wasted for 56 years," he said.
</P>
<P>
"This is a crime greater than (the Tiananmen crackdown)."
</P>
<P>
Bao expressed delight with the May release in English of Zhao's memoirs, put
together from secret tape recordings the deposed leader made while under house
arrest. His son, Bao Pu, is publishing the Chinese version of the book.
</P>
<P>
He said he hoped the book, likely to be banned in China, could somehow be
distributed in the country and spark debate.
</P>
<P>
But he admitted the ghosts of Tiananmen would not likely be laid to rest any
time soon due to the nature of a government for which he wishes he had never
worked.
</P>
<P>
"I regret that I only realised all of this 20 years ago. Why couldn't I have
realised it 40 years ago or 60 years ago?" he lamented.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Tiananmen: Six weeks of protests, and then a crackdown
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Beijing, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
In April 1989, young Chinese with dreams of democracy staged an unprecedented
wave of protests after the death of former Communist Party leader Hu Yaobang, a
popular reformer.
</P>
<P>
The Tiananmen movement lasted six weeks before being violently quashed by the
army, leaving hundreds, and possibly thousands, dead.
</P>
<P>
Here is a timeline of the main events:
</P>
<P>
April 1989
</P>
<P>
- 15: Death of Hu Yaobang, who had been dismissed two years earlier.
</P>
<P>
- 17: First student protest on Tiananmen Square, to lay a wreath in honour of
Hu, adorned with pro-democracy slogans.
</P>
<P>
- 18: The students issue a list of demands to the government that includes
freedom of speech and democratic elections.
</P>
<P>
- 22: Hu's official funeral takes place at the Great Hall of the People on
Tiananmen Square, where 200,000 students are gathered.
</P>
<P>
- 25: Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, says the protest movement seeks to
topple the Communist Party -- a claim that forms the basis of an explosive
editorial in the official People's Daily newspaper the next day.
</P>
<P>
- 27: Huge student demonstrations take place in Beijing, and protests erupt
across the country, including in towns that had been calm until that time.
</P>
<P>
May
</P>
<P>
- 4: The anniversary of the patriotic movement of May 4, 1919 triggers a new
mass demonstration in Beijing and in 50 other towns. The head of the Communist
Party, Zhao Ziyang, urges dialogue.
</P>
<P>
- 13: Students launch the occupation of Tiananmen Square and a hunger strike.
</P>
<P>
- 15: A historic visit by then Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev for the
normalisation of Sino-Soviet ties is completely disrupted.
</P>
<P>
- 17: About 1.2 million students, workers, civil servants, and intellectuals
protest in Beijing. Major demonstrations take place in most provinces across the
country.
</P>
<P>
- 18: The conservative Prime Minister Li Peng attempts to start a dialogue with
student leaders.
</P>
<P>
- 19: Zhao goes to Tiananmen Square, and pleads with the hunger strikers to
leave, with tears in his eyes. It is his last public appearance.
</P>
<P>
- 20: Martial law is declared, and army troops that are summoned either stop or
are stopped by barricades.
</P>
<P>
- 26: Zhao is purged from the Communist leadership, and put under house arrest
on the 28th.
</P>
<P>
- 29: Fine arts students erect a statue -- the 'Goddess of Democracy' -- in
front of the portrait of Mao Zedong, the founder of communist China, on the
square, where students are growing tired and divided.
</P>
<P>
June:
</P>
<P>
- 1st: An official report brings up for the first time the notion of a "counter-
revolutionary riot."
</P>
<P>
- 2: The Communist Party's leadership decides to clear the square.
</P>
<P>
- 3: Students and citizens block military vehicles at Beijing's major
intersections. That night, messages broadcast by loudspeaker call on the
population to clear the roads. The students equip themselves with sticks and
makeshift weapons.
</P>
<P>
- June 3-4: The army evacuates Tiananmen Square without firing shots. Soldiers
flanked by tanks open fire elsewhere. Fighting on roads ensues. Hundreds, and
possibly thousands, are killed.
</P>
<P>
- 5-20: China is widely condemned abroad and is targeted with sanctions.
</P>
<P>
- 24: Jiang Zemin, the future Chinese president, is officially made General
Secretary of the Communist Party, replacing Zhao.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0444" type="story" >

<HEADLINE>
Tiananmen: Six weeks of protests, and then a crackdown
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Beijing, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
In April 1989, young Chinese with dreams of democracy staged an unprecedented
wave of protests after the death of former Communist Party leader Hu Yaobang, a
popular reformer.
</P>
<P>
The Tiananmen movement lasted six weeks before being violently quashed by the
army, leaving hundreds, and possibly thousands, dead.
</P>
<P>
Here is a timeline of the main events:
</P>
<P>
April 1989
</P>
<P>
- 15: Death of Hu Yaobang, who had been dismissed two years earlier.
</P>
<P>
- 17: First student protest on Tiananmen Square, to lay a wreath in honour of
Hu, adorned with pro-democracy slogans.
</P>
<P>
- 18: The students issue a list of demands to the government that includes
freedom of speech and democratic elections.
</P>
<P>
- 22: Hu's official funeral takes place at the Great Hall of the People on
Tiananmen Square, where 200,000 students are gathered.
</P>
<P>
- 25: Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, says the protest movement seeks to
topple the Communist Party -- a claim that forms the basis of an explosive
editorial in the official People's Daily newspaper the next day.
</P>
<P>
- 27: Huge student demonstrations take place in Beijing, and protests erupt
across the country, including in towns that had been calm until that time.
</P>
<P>
May
</P>
<P>
- 4: The anniversary of the patriotic movement of May 4, 1919 triggers a new
mass demonstration in Beijing and in 50 other towns. The head of the Communist
Party, Zhao Ziyang, urges dialogue.
</P>
<P>
- 13: Students launch the occupation of Tiananmen Square and a hunger strike.
</P>
<P>
- 15: A historic visit by then Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev for the
normalisation of Sino-Soviet ties is completely disrupted.
</P>
<P>
- 17: About 1.2 million students, workers, civil servants, and intellectuals
protest in Beijing. Major demonstrations take place in most provinces across the
country.
</P>
<P>
- 18: The conservative Prime Minister Li Peng attempts to start a dialogue with
student leaders.
</P>
<P>
- 19: Zhao goes to Tiananmen Square, and pleads with the hunger strikers to
leave, with tears in his eyes. It is his last public appearance.
</P>
<P>
- 20: Martial law is declared, and army troops that are summoned either stop or
are stopped by barricades.
</P>
<P>
- 26: Zhao is purged from the Communist leadership, and put under house arrest
on the 28th.
</P>
<P>
- 29: Fine arts students erect a statue -- the 'Goddess of Democracy' -- in
front of the portrait of Mao Zedong, the founder of communist China, on the
square, where students are growing tired and divided.
</P>
<P>
June:
</P>
<P>
- 1st: An official report brings up for the first time the notion of a "counter-
revolutionary riot."
</P>
<P>
- 2: The Communist Party's leadership decides to clear the square.
</P>
<P>
- 3: Students and citizens block military vehicles at Beijing's major
intersections. That night, messages broadcast by loudspeaker call on the
population to clear the roads. The students equip themselves with sticks and
makeshift weapons.
</P>
<P>
- June 3-4: The army evacuates Tiananmen Square without firing shots. Soldiers
flanked by tanks open fire elsewhere. Fighting on roads ensues. Hundreds, and
possibly thousands, are killed.
</P>
<P>
- 5-20: China is widely condemned abroad and is targeted with sanctions.
</P>
<P>
- 24: Jiang Zemin, the future Chinese president, is officially made General
Secretary of the Communist Party, replacing Zhao.
</P>
</TEXT>
