<HEADLINE>
Key dates in post-Tiananmen China
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
beijing, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The following is a list of key dates in the history of China, following the
crushing of the Tiananmen pro-democracy protests by army troops in June 1989:
</P>
<P>
1989
</P>
<P>
After 10 years of market reform and opening to the outside world, China finds
itself again isolated internationally and the target of sanctions after the
Tiananmen crackdown. Arms embargoes by the United States and the European Union
are implemented and remain in place 20 years later.
</P>
<P>
1990
</P>
<P>
Deng Xiaoping formally retires from all of his official positions, but remains
influential from behind the scenes.
</P>
<P>
1992
</P>
<P>
Deng embarks on his "southern tour" which relaunches the economic reforms that
have been paralysed since 1989.
</P>
<P>
The government calls for students staying overseas to return to China no matter
what their attitude on past political events has been.
</P>
<P>
1993
</P>
<P>
Jiang Zemin, who was named head of the Communist Party after the crushing of the
protests in 1989, is made the nation's president in March.
</P>
<P>
1997
</P>
<P>
February 19: Deng dies.
</P>
<P>
July 1: The British colony of Hong Kong is returned to China.
</P>
<P>
2001
</P>
<P>
Beijing wins the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
</P>
<P>
December 11: China becomes a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO).
</P>
<P>
2002
</P>
<P>
Hu Jintao is named General Secretary of the Communist Party.
</P>
<P>
2003
</P>
<P>
Hu succeeds Jiang as China's president.
</P>
<P>
October 15: China launches its first man into outer space.
</P>
<P>
Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) sweeps the world, killing nearly 800
people including 349 in China. The government tried to cover up the initial
outbreak of the epidemic in the southern part of the country.
</P>
<P>
2006
</P>
<P>
December: China opens up its banking sector in accordance with WTO rules.
</P>
<P>
2008:
</P>
<P>
March 14: Anti-Chinese riots explode in Lhasa and spread to other Tibetan
populated areas around China. They are crushed by security forces.
</P>
<P>
March 15: Hu is given another five years as head of state and Wen Jiabao begins
his second term as prime minister following a prolonged economic expansion that
has seen China grow from the world's sixth biggest economy to its third largest.
</P>
<P>
May 12: A devastating earthquake strikes China's southwestern Sichuan province,
leaving nearly 87,000 people dead or missing.
</P>
<P>
August 8-24: China hosts the Olympic Games in Beijing.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0447" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Tiananmen Square: 10 key figures
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
beijing, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The following are brief profiles of the 10 people -- students, politicians and
others -- who played key roles in the drama that unfolded in Beijing's Tiananmen
Square in 1989:
</P>
<P>
THE STUDENTS
</P>
<P>
-- Wang Dan, the moderate (born 1969). A student from the elite Peking
University, he was replaced as leader of the movement by more radical
protesters. After his arrest in July 1989, he was sentenced in 1991 to four
years in jail. He was released in 1993, but arrested again in 1995 on subversion
charges and sentenced to another 11 years in prison. In 1998, he was deported to
the United States. He continues his campaign for democracy in China in the west.
</P>
<P>
-- Chai Ling, the muse (born 1966). The tiny woman was known as the "general
commander" of the protest headquarters at Tiananmen Square. After the crackdown,
she was put on the list of the 21 most wanted students, but after 10 months on
the run she managed to escape to France. She now lives in the United States,
where she works as an Internet entrepreneur.
</P>
<P>
-- Wu'er Kaixi, the rebel (born 1968). A member of the Uighur ethnic minority,
he became a celebrity overnight after he interrupted Premier Li Peng during a
meeting between student leaders and politicians aired live on state television
on May 18, 1989. He was able to flee China after the June 4 crackdown and now
lives in Taiwan.
</P>
<P>
THE POLITICIANS
</P>
<P>
-- Deng Xiaoping, the patriarch (1904-1997). The most influential of the
leaders, the chairman of the Central Military Commission and father of economic
reform tilted the balance in favour of a hard line and ordered the army to fire
on protesters after six weeks of rallies that left the government paralysed.
</P>
<P>
-- Zhao Ziyang, the disgraced reformer (1919-2005). As general secretary of the
Communist Party, he supported dialogue between the government and the
protesters. On May 19, 1989, he visited the students on Tiananmen Square, and,
in tears, urged them to leave. This was his last public appearance. He was
relieved of his duties in June and placed under house arrest until his death.
</P>
<P>
-- Li Peng, the hardliner (born 1928). He was made prime minister in 1988 and
also a member of the Standing Committee of the Communist Party's Politburo, the
heart of political power in China. Announcing martial law on May 19, he paved
the way for the crackdown.
</P>
<P>
THE INTELLECTUALS
</P>
<P>
-- Fang Lizhi, the veteran dissident (born 1936). Even if this famous
astrophysicist did not participate directly in the Tiananmen movement, his ideas
were a clear inspiration. He had been thrown out of the Communist Party in 1987,
and shortly after the crackdown in 1989, the authorities issued an arrest order
against him. He escaped into the US embassy, and was granted political asylum in
the United States in 1991.
</P>
<P>
-- Liu Xiaobo, the mediator (born 1955). The author was popular among the young
for his criticism of traditional Chinese values, and further joined the students
in a hunger strike on Tiananmen Square. On the night of June 3 and into the
early hours of June 4, as the army proceeded to clear the square, he attempted
to negotiate an orderly evacuation. He was later arrested and spent a year and a
half in jail without ever being formally sentenced.
</P>
<P>
THE ARTIST
</P>
<P>
-- Cui Jian, the rocker (born 1961). The "father of rock" in China appeared
several times on Tiananmen Square in 1989, and one of his works, "Nothing to My
Name", became the unofficial fight song of the student movement.
</P>
<P>
THE UNKNOWN HERO
</P>
<P>
-- On June 5, the day after the crackdown, a young man placed himself in front
of a column of tanks, preventing it from passing down the Avenue of Heavenly
Peace in the heart of Beijing. At one point he even mounted the front tank to
appeal to its crew, but bystanders eventually dragged him away. Photos and
footage of the "Tank Man" immediately made top news around the world, and he
went down in history as a symbol of peaceful and unarmed protesters confronting
military repression. His name remains unknown to this day.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0448" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
China faces dark memory of Tiananmen
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
beijing, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Authorities in China are bracing for the 20th anniversary of the deadly June 4
crackdown on pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square, a pivotal moment that
still haunts the nation.
</P>
<P>
The way the government will likely mark the sensitive date on Thursday -- with
deafening silence -- shows it is keenly aware of the emotional scars that remain
after the army ended six weeks of peaceful rallies in central Beijing.
</P>
<P>
China's Communist leaders have made any discussion of the brutal quelling of the
student-led demonstrations -- in which hundreds, maybe thousands, were killed --
taboo, but dissidents say the public could yet hold them accountable.
</P>
<P>
"People remember this date because they want the Communist Party to take
responsibility for the crimes it committed," said 53-year-old Qi Zhiyong, who
lost a leg after being shot by troops near Tiananmen Square.
</P>
<P>
"It reminds them the party will resort to unbridled violence whenever it feels
threatened."
</P>
<P>
In a bid not to rankle the wary authorities, the main public commemoration
planned for Thursday will probably be silent.
</P>
<P>
Activist groups have called on citizens simply to wear white -- the traditional
colour of mourning -- to honour those killed in the mayhem that erupted when
tanks and troops rolled in to crush the protests.
</P>
<P>
The year 1989 was a disastrous one for communism across the globe and in China
the ruling party found itself in a struggle with democracy activists who
challenged its authoritarian rule over the world's most populous nation.
</P>
<P>
The Tiananmen movement began in mid-April, when public grief over the death of
former party leader and popular reformer Hu Yaobang gradually morphed into bold
calls from students for political reform and steps to combat corruption.
</P>
<P>
Young students started to occupy Tiananmen Square, the symbolic centre of
political power in China. A sense of euphoria saturated the plaza as they took
part in rallies no one would have thought possible just weeks earlier.
</P>
<P>
"There were banners everywhere. This was the first unauthorised political
demonstration in the (history of the) People's Republic of China," recalled one
of the student leaders, Wang Dan.
</P>
<P>
Calls for democracy and freedom filled the square, thousands went on hunger
strike, and one charismatic activist, Wu'er Kaixi, brazenly challenged Premier
Li Peng during a meeting broadcast live on state television.
</P>
<P>
Indeed, the whole world was watching, as news crews from around the globe
gathered in Beijing to cover the historic visit by then Soviet leader Mikhail
Gorbachev, only to stumble upon an event that would be far more significant.
</P>
<P>
In the corridors of power, the protests drove a wedge between hardline leaders
led by Premier Li and moderates headed by Communist Party general secretary Zhao
Ziyang.
</P>
<P>
The hardliners won, with patriarch Deng Xiaoping, China's most powerful man,
tilting the balance in their favour. Zhao was removed from his post as party
leader and spent 16 years under house arrest until his death in 2005.
</P>
<P>
The student movement was declared a "counterrevolutionary rebellion", and
soldiers of the People's Liberation Army descended on the capital, crushing the
democratic dreams of an entire generation.
</P>
<P>
The number of people killed in the night of June 3-4 remains a mystery. China's
official death toll is 241, including 36 students. Dissidents say thousands may
have died.
</P>
<P>
The crackdown set off a wave of condemnation across the globe, and for several
years China was treated as a near-pariah, as Western governments offered asylum
to student leaders fleeing into exile.
</P>
<P>
The international community has long since welcomed China back into the fold,
and Beijing's communist leaders have cemented their hold on power, transforming
the country into the world's number three economy.
</P>
<P>
But they have shown no willingness to change their position that the protests
threatened Communist Party rule and had to be quelled in order to maintain
economic reforms.
</P>
<P>
"Facts have proven that the socialist road with Chinese characteristics that we
pursue is in the fundamental interests of our people," foreign ministry
spokesman Ma Zhaoxu told journalists in May.
</P>
<P>
But, undeterred, victims of the crackdown have called for renewed international
pressure on Beijing to reverse the official verdict on the quelling, saying
failure to stand up to a rising China tacitly abets the repression.
</P>
<P>
"So far, the international community... has adopted a policy of appeasement
towards the Chinese government," said Ding Zilin, 72, whose teenage son was shot
dead by the army.
</P>
<P>
Bao Tong -- a former aide to Zhao who was jailed for seven years following the
crackdown -- said the world has failed to push China to be more open about the
events of Tiananmen because of Beijing's increasing global clout.
</P>
<P>
"Not wanting to offend China means they cannot help China, cannot help China's
people attain their own rights, and cannot help the world community gain a
reliable, stable, peaceful member," Bao told AFP recently.
</P>
<P>
"This is not a good thing," he added.
</P>
<P>
Bao has since been ordered to sit out the anniversary at a resort more than
1,000 kilometres (625 miles) from Beijing -- evidence that the authorities in
the capital are not yet ready to reopen the Tiananmen wounds.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
US urges rejection of Guantanamo Uighurs case
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
US NAVAL BASE AT GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, May 30, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
President Barack Obama's administration has asked the Supreme Court to reject a
request by Chinese Uighurs held at the Guantanamo Bay prison and cleared of all
charges to be released on US soil.
</P>
<P>
The petitioners "have already obtained relief. They are no longer being detained
as enemy combatants," wrote US Solicitor General Elena Kagan in the
administration's filing to the Supreme Court Friday.
</P>
<P>
Kagan wrote that the men, members of a Turkic-speaking Muslim minority who fear
persecution if returned to China, "are being housed in relatively unrestricted
conditions given the status of Guantanamo Bay as a United States military base."
</P>
<P>
Four years ago US authorities cleared the 17 imprisoned Uighurs, but they are
stuck at the Guantanamo prison due to fears that Beijing would torture them if
they returned to their homeland in northwestern China's remote Xinjiang
province.
</P>
<P>
At the prison, the Uighurs are held at "Camp Iguana," a special area for
detainees cleared for release. They have more freedom and greater privileges
than most other prisoners, including a recreational space and a library,
according to the Pentagon.
</P>
<P>
In October 2008 a federal judge ordered that the Uighurs be released in the
United States. The most likely place for the detainees to be released would be
in Washington's suburbs in northern Virginia, which is home to a significant
Uighur expatriate community.
</P>
<P>
A federal appeals court in February however overturned that ruling. It is the
Uighurs' appeal to that decision that the Supreme Court must now address.
</P>
<P>
But for the Obama administration, which is repeating some of the reasoning that
his predecessor George W. Bush used, "the decision whether to allow aliens
abroad to enter the United States and if so, under what terms, rests exclusively
in the political branches," according to the filing, which AFP obtained a copy.
</P>
<P>
For the government, the "petitioners' continued presence at Guantanamo Bay is
not unlawful detention but rather the consequence of their lawful exclusion from
the United States under the constitutional exercise of authority by the
political branches, coupled with the unavailability of another country willing
to accept them," Kagan wrote.
</P>
<P>
The nine justices sitting on the US high court have not yet said whether they
would examine the politically explosive case, and could announce a decision by
June.
</P>
<P>
The legal case was filed by 14 of the 17 Uighur prisoners.
</P>
<P>
The Guantanamo camp was established by the Bush administration as an offshore
prison for "war on terror" detainees. Some 800 youth and adults have passed
through the prison camp and about 240 remain today.
</P>
<P>
The US navy established a base in Guantanamo Bay at the end of the 1898 Spanish-
American War, then signed a long-term lease with the Cuban government. Cuba's
communist government has been demanding its return since the 1960s.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>

<HEADLINE>
Blockbuster videogame line-up to spark E3 magic
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
San Francisco, May 30, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Videogame makers are defying horrid economic times with an annual Electronic
Entertainment Expo (E3) brimming with blockbuster titles and unbridled pizzazz.
</P>
<P>
The expo kicking off Tuesday in Los Angeles is expected to revive dazzle of
years past and offer previews of hot videogames that will hit the market for the
prime year-end holiday shopping season.
</P>
<P>
"We are starting to see an industry waking up to the fact that we've been out of
the limelight," said Scott Steinberg, publisher of DigitalTrends.com, a game and
gadget website with 40 million readers.
</P>
<P>
"E3 is the public face of the industry. You will see all sorts of surprises. At
this point, it is anyone's game."
</P>
<P>
Videogame sales grew through much of the financial crisis, but slid in March and
April of this year, according to industry figures.
</P>
<P>
Analysts remain optimistic about videogames, citing surveys indicating players
would rather cut back on other entertainment, such as movies or dining out.
</P>
<P>
Major videogame makers are playing it safe by rolling out sequels to hit
franchises and freshening faded successes.
</P>
<P>
French videogame star Ubisoft will show off "Assassins Creed 2" and "Red Steel
2" along with the latest in a line of popular "Rabbids" titles featuring zany
animated rabbits.
</P>
<P>
Ubisoft will also unveil videogames made from television game shows "Family
Feud," "The Price Is Right" and "Press Your Luck" tailored for Nintendo's Wii
consoles.
</P>
<P>
"(These) are some of the most popular game shows of all time," said Ubisoft
senior vice president of sales and marketing Tony Key."
</P>
<P>
"These video games will appeal to all generations and make a great addition to
family game night."
</P>
<P>
Eagerly-anticipated sequels to be touted at E3 include "Mass Effect 2,"
"Bioshock 2," "God of War 3," and a "Modern Warfare" title likely to be a
powerhouse in the "Call of Duty" franchise."
</P>
<P>
"What we are seeing is a shift toward higher quality, risk-averse publishing,"
Steinberg said.
</P>
<P>
"Right now, if you are going to ask someone to pony-up 60 bucks for a title,
even though you can argue they get 30 hours of game play, it has to be good."
</P>
<P>
Videogame makers are expected to continue a trend toward downloadable content
(DLC) for titles as well as letting people play on the Internet as teammates or
opponents.
</P>
<P>
"Online is a feature everyone is trying to exploit," said videogame analyst Mike
Hickey of Janco Partners.
</P>
<P>
Microsoft Xbox, Sony PlayStation3, and Wii each offer arenas for online play.
</P>
<P>
"Publishers love it because they can capture an audience for a longer time,
delay trade-ins and hold up pricing; then there is always the idea of micro
transactions for downloadable content."
</P>
<P>
The makers of controversial but hot-selling "Grand Theft Auto" are to provide a
look at DLC titled "The Ballad of Gay Tony." Bethesda Softworks will expand on
DLC for its winning "Fallout 3" videogame.
</P>
<P>
Bethesda will also debut a "Brink" videogame that "does some really cool and
innovative things for a shooter," according to studio marketing director Pete
Hines.
</P>
<P>
Pressure is on Nintendo to deliver captivating titles for the Wii, which has
been a sales sensation but could lose momentum in the absence of must-have new
videogames to play on the consoles.
</P>
<P>
"Nintendo needs something; everyone is saying that," Hickey said.
</P>
<P>
A MotionPlus gadget that makes Wii motion-sensing remote controls more precise
is to hit the market during E3, and videogame giant Electronic Arts will preview
athlete-themed golf and tennis titles that work with the gizmos.
</P>
<P>
Sword action in Ubisoft's "Red Steel" is also tailored for MotionPlus.
</P>
<P>
The popularity of music-based videogames continues, with Harmonix and MTV
rolling out a "Rock Band" title that "takes players on a journey through the
legacy and evolution" of The Beatles.
</P>
<P>
Activision is to offer a glimpse of "DJ Hero," a "Guitar Hero" style videogame
in which the virtual instruments are turntables.
</P>
<P>
Analysts are watching for price cuts or new videogame hardware. Sony is expected
to introduce a next-generation PSP handheld videogame device to compete with
Nintendo's freshly-launched DSi model.
</P>
<P>
Microsoft and Sony might ramp-up motion-sensing abilities of console controllers
in the spirit of Wii.
</P>
<P>
"We are going to see a little of the magic come back to E3," Steinberg said.
"Games that really push the boundaries for high-definition audio/visual and
really stretch."
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Ubisoft's madcap 'Rabbids' breeding US fans
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
San Francisco, May 30, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
French videogame titan Ubisoft is turning E3 into a playground for "Rabbids,"
madcap videogame rabbits breeding fans throughout Europe and the United States.
</P>
<P>
A team of Rabbids, accompanied by a street band from Romania, will "wreak havoc"
outside an annual Electronic Entertainment Expo videogame industry extravaganza
that begins Tuesday in Los Angeles.
</P>
<P>
E3 attendees will be invited to hurl t-shirts and other tchotchkes given away at
the event into a colossal faux toilet.
</P>
<P>
Rabbids will heap offerings on a trash mountain of items that will be donated to
charity or recycled after E3 concludes on Thursday.
</P>
<P>
The stunt is intended as levity as well as an unmasked promotion of an Ubisoft
"Rabbids Go Home" videogame making an E3 debut.
</P>
<P>
The Romanian band's music is featured in the fourth installment of an
increasingly popular videogame franchise.
</P>
<P>
"Go Home" play centers of getting the wacky animated characters to snatch all
the "human stuff" they can find and pile it high enough to reach the moon.
</P>
<P>
"They are like spoiled four-year-olds; distracted by everything," said Ubisoft
game producer Adrian Lacey of the Rabbids team in southern France.
</P>
<P>
"They are the child in everyone; the rebellious creature that does all the
things we don't dare do but would like to."
</P>
<P>
The Rabbid weapon of choice is a bathroom plunger, and antics in games includes
cow hurling; pumping carrot juice into mouths, and demolishing portions of Paris
by belching.
</P>
<P>
Lacey notes that "Rayman Raving Rabbids TV Party" was the first videogame to let
players control action with their butts.
</P>
<P>
Players sitting on Wii console balance boards lean and shift to steer Rabbits in
a downhill sleigh race.
</P>
<P>
"What is true about the Rabbids is there are no regulations; go crazy and have
fun with them," Lacey said. "He has an edgy humor."
</P>
<P>
The Rabbids franchise was launched in 2006, with each subsequent version
outselling its predecessor.
</P>
<P>
Ubisoft has sold more than six million Rabbids videogames, with one million of
those sales in the United States.
</P>
<P>
"We've seen the appeal just grow and grow," Lacey said. "We are not at the point
where we are a 'Super Mario' yet, but it would be nice to get there."
</P>
<P>
Lacey laughingly equates the look of a Rabbid to "a sack of potatoes on two
stumpy legs" and credits their unintelligible language to a team member prone to
annoying people with strange sounds.
</P>
<P>
"He never looks ridiculous because he is," Lacey said of each Rabbid. "It is one
of those funny things."
</P>
<P>
The Rabbids appeal prompted French car maker Renault to feature the characters
in advertising and Kraft to use them to promote Capri Sun brand drinks.
</P>
<P>
"We're always looking for inventive ways to keep the brand cool and relevant
with our audience," said Capri Sun senior brand manager Vinay Sharma.
</P>
<P>
Rabbid fever has resulted in toys and figurines based on the characters.
</P>
<P>
"They should take over the world," Lacey quipped. "If I keep losing hair, I may
turn into a Rabbid."
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Clinton faces possible Cuba 'minefield' on trip south
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
WASHINGTON, May 30, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton risks walking into what one analyst calls
a Latin American minefield over ties with Cuba when she visits El Salvador and
neighboring Honduras this week.
</P>
<P>
The issue will hover over Monday's inauguration of new Salvadoran president
Mauricio Funes in San Salvador and could cause a rift at the Organization of
American States (OAS) general assembly in San Pedro Sula, Honduras on Tuesday.
</P>
<P>
US officials could not even rule out the possibility of Clinton's skipping the
OAS meeting altogether if negotiators fail to agree on terms for bringing Cuba
back within the 35-member organization's fold.
</P>
<P>
The United States wants Cuba to free political prisoners and respect political
freedoms for it to participate fully in the OAS, saying it is holding the body
to the democratic principles enshrined in its own 2001 charter.
</P>
<P>
Other OAS members say that Cuba can be nudged toward democracy once inside the
OAS.
</P>
<P>
Many members point out that the reason for Cuba's suspension in 1962 -- its role
in the Cold War-era Soviet bloc -- does not apply today as the bloc no longer
exists.
</P>
<P>
Even though Cuba itself rejects the OAS, analysts said, many countries want to
use the issue to either push for a lifting of the decades-old US embargo on
Havana or for their own private agendas, such as to embarrass the United States.
</P>
<P>
Since a popular US President Barack Obama took office in January, he has raised
hopes among many of his southern neighbors that he will soon lift the embargo,
even if he insists that Cuba first undertake democratic reforms.
</P>
<P>
"This is going to be a complicated challenge for her (Clinton) to deal with,"
said Michael Shifter, an analyst for the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington
think tank.
</P>
<P>
"I sense the Obama people are a little bit nervous. I think they're aware that
it's a minefield, Cuba," said Shifter who pointed to the risk of a rift within
the OAS.
</P>
<P>
And Clinton's stop in San Salvador "creates a certain dynamic," Shifter said,
because the presence of a Cuban leader at the inauguration will mark the start
of El Salvador's own moves toward full diplomatic ties with Cuba.
</P>
<P>
It will expose the US position even more because, under the previous US-backed
right-wing government, El Salvador was the last Latin American countries not to
have normal relations with Cuba, he said.
</P>
<P>
Shifter said he has heard that Cuban President Raul Castro is attending, but AFP
was unable to confirm the information.
</P>
<P>
Asked if Clinton would meet with the Cubans at the inauguration, a senior US
official said on the condition of anonymity: "We're not at the stage right now
where the secretary would meet with Cuban officials."
</P>
<P>
Shifter said the OAS secretary general, Jose Miguel Insulza, as well as radical
leftist Venezuela, Nicaragua and host country Honduras were driving the agenda
to have Cuba readmitted to the OAS.
</P>
<P>
Instead of having Cuba as the burning issue, he said, the Obama team would have
preferred to highlight a new era of US cooperation with leftist but pragmatic
democratic governments like those in El Salvador, Brazil and Chile.
</P>
<P>
Her visit to San Salvador is symbolic of the shift because Funes brought to
power the Farabundo Marti Front for National Liberation, former leftist
guerrillas who fought the US-backed right-wing government in the 1980s civil
war.
</P>
<P>
Chris Sabatini, an analyst with the Council of Americas, said the new
administration is trying to show that the "tent of democracy is broad" even
while a few leftist radicals remain in the region.
</P>
<P>
"It is an attempt to not so much isolate them (radicals) but to create a
positive pole in the hemisphere of democrats that can't be easily labeled as
just pro-US, but range across the ideological spectrum," he said.
</P>
<P>
Sabatini also expected the consensus-driven OAS to come to some agreement on the
Cuba issue, saying the current debate amounted to a "tempest in a teapot" and a
distraction to important human rights issues.
</P>
<P>
On rare occasions, the OAS can vote on an issue, however.
</P>
<P>
A senior US State Department official told reporters late Friday "it's hard to
say" when asked if a consensus would be reached.
</P>
<P>
Nor could he exclude the possibility that Clinton might have to skip the
meeting. "I can't answer that question," he said.
</P>
<P>
Spokespeople at the OAS headquarters told AFP on Saturday that no resolution had
been reached and that the senior diplomats were leaving Washington this weekend
to continue their negotiations on the Cuba document in Honduras.
</P>
<P>
Clinton is due to depart for El Salvador on Sunday.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
US auto industry's future hangs in the balance
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Washington, May 30, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The US auto industry faces a day of reckoning Monday, with the looming
bankruptcy of auto giant General Motors and an expected court ruling on the sale
of automaker Chrysler to a group led by Italy's Fiat.
</P>
<P>
The once mighty US auto industry is reeling from the downturned market and
global economic crisis, which has prompted massive intervention by President
Barack Obama's administration to prevent total collapse and a new body blow to a
US economy already in recession.
</P>
<P>
The government's rescue plan for GM could put as much as 72.5 percent of the
country's biggest automaker under state ownership.
</P>
<P>
With the hours counting down for GM, the company bondholders' Saturday deadline
expired without indication on whether they support the group's new offer.
</P>
<P>
If they accept the plan, the bondholders would obtain the rights to buy an extra
15 percent of GM's stock at a low price. They would also control 25 percent of
the "new GM," after having supported the new company's creation in bankruptcy
court.
</P>
<P>
Recalcitrant bondholders who opt for confrontation rather than cooperation "will
get nothing or very little," an Obama administration official told reporters
Thursday.
</P>
<P>
Government-backed restructuring in bankruptcy court for GM, once the world's
largest automaker, appeared all but certain ahead of a Monday deadline imposed
by the Obama administration on the company to submit a viable restructuring plan
or file for bankruptcy. It could take place as early as Sunday.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile, a US bankruptcy court judge in New York was widely expected to
approve a deal between Chrysler and Fiat Monday.
</P>
<P>
The third biggest US automaker has declared bankruptcy and is seeking a tie-up
with Fiat in a plan presented as the only way to save the company from
liquidation.
</P>
<P>
Developments at Chrysler could provide an example for restructuring at GM, which
will similarly have to sell some of its brands and close many dealerships.
</P>
<P>
But the administration official said a 60- to 90-day timeframe was "better" for
GM, contrasted with the fast-track process for Chrysler, which filed for
bankruptcy protection on April 30.
</P>
<P>
"This is a much more complicated company than Chrysler, as a global company.
It's three times the size," noted the official.
</P>
<P>
The United Auto Workers (UAW) union said Friday its members ratified a deal to
allow GM to radically cut costs and its debt load, clearing the way for a quick
exit from the expected bankruptcy filing.
</P>
<P>
GM also announced plans to retool an idled US plant to build small cars it had
originally planned to import, and two more US assembly plants could potentially
be saved.
</P>
<P>
The bankruptcy filing could also be sped up by a deal struck in the early hours
Saturday after marathon talks that saw Canadian parts maker Magna and its
Russian backers taking over GM's Opel.
</P>
<P>
The deal for GM's European operations, which was brokered by Berlin, amounted to
a major development in the global rearranging of the auto industry.
</P>
<P>
GM employs some 50,000 people throughout Europe and Magna plans to cut about a
fifth.
</P>
<P>
German Chancellor Angela Merkel, whose government agreed to stump billions of
euros (dollars) in loan guarantees and emergency loans to keep the ailing Opel
afloat, acknowledged that talks over the future of GM Europe had sometimes been
difficult.
</P>
<P>
Germany's Finance Minister Peer Steinbrueck had even denounced what he called
"scandalous" US negotiating tactics.
</P>
<P>
Yet despite what she called "huge mismanagement" by GM executives, however, a
telephone call to Obama helped seal the deal, Merkel said.
</P>
<P>
As for Chrysler, a new company could be born within days of approval for
bankruptcy. The Treasury said it had transferred 6.9 billion dollars in public
funds to New Carco, a newly created company to acquire Chrysler's "good assets."
</P>
<P>
If presiding judge Arthur Gonzalez rules against Chrysler, it faces a grim
future, with a worst-case scenario being Fiat abandoning the tie-up and the US
automaker going into liquidation, with massive job losses.
</P>
<P>
Legal appeals were expected if Gonzalez ruled in favor, meaning possible new
delays. Fiat has said it might back out if the transaction is not completed by
June 15.
</P>
</TEXT>

<P>
US President Barack Obama swept First Lady Michelle Obama off to a Broadway show

The epitome of glamour, the Obamas earlier left the White House aboard his
Marine One helicopter.
</P>
<P>
At Andrews Air Force base outside Washington, they boarded the plane, the
president in a smart dark suit with no tie, and the First Lady in a black
cocktail dress and heels.
</P>
<P>
After landing in New York, they helicoptered into Manhattan and motorcaded to
the Blue Hill restaurant, before heading to the Belasco Theater and the Broadway
revival of the August Wilson play "Joe Turner's Come And Gone."

Obama's Republican foes however tried to make political hay out of the
president's date night.
</P>

"As President Obama prepares to wing into Manhattan’s theater district on Air
Force One to take in a Broadway show, GM is preparing to file bankruptcy and
families across America continue to struggle to pay their bills," the Republican
National Committee said in a statement.
</P>
<P>
The White House could not immediately put a price tag on the president's trip.
But US leaders, due to the tight blanket of security that follows them
everywhere they go, never travel on commercial aircraft.
</P>

Earlier, on the weekend before he heads off on a major trip to the Middle East
and Europe, Obama was seen cheering on the sidelines at his daughter Malia's

<HEADLINE>
Susan Boyle's dream collapses as she loses British talent show
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Scottish singing sensation Susan Boyle was dealt an unexpected blow Saturday
when she lost out to a group of young street dancers in the final of the British
talent show that made her a global star.
</P>
<P>
Despite winning praise from the audience and the judges in her final performance
on live television, the 48-year-old graciously accepted second place, saying the
"best people won" and wishing the winners "all the best".
</P>
<P>
Boyle enjoyed a meteoric rise to fame over the past two months after video
footage of her audition piece for the show, "I Dreamed A Dream" from the musical
"Les Miserables", was posted on video-sharing website YouTube.
</P>
<P>
It has had about 100 million hits, brought her celebrity fans including actress
Demi Moore and rock star Jon Bon Jovi and seen her feted in the media from the
United States to China, Japan and Australia.
</P>
<P>
Bookmakers made her the favourite to win, but after an unconvincing performance
in the semi-final there were fears that the church volunteer, who lives alone
with her cat outside Edinburgh, was suffering under the pressure.
</P>
<P>
However, in a live performance in the "Britain's Got Talent" final Saturday,
Boyle proved the critics wrong and repeated her audition piece with gusto.
</P>
<P>
Judge Piers Morgan said it was the "greatest performance I've seen on the
history of Britain's Got Talent -- you should win the competition, I loved it."
</P>
<P>
Boyle was up against nine other acts to win the show, which brings with it a
cheque for 100,000 pounds (115,000 euros, 160,000 dollars) and the chance to
perform for Queen Elizabeth II.
</P>
<P>
More than a million viewers cast their vote following the live performances, and
in the end, Boyle lost out to a group of ten young dancers, named Diversity.
Saxophonist Julian Smith came in third place.
</P>
<P>
After singing earlier in the evening, Boyle, wearing a grey-blue, long sequined
dress, thanked all her fans.
</P>
<P>
"I want to thank people for all the support they've given me," she said.
</P>
<P>
Asked if it was worth all the media pressure, she replied emphatically: "Well
worth it!... I really feel at home on stage, I'm among friends."
</P>
<P>
Boyle put in a shaky performance of "Memory" in the show's semi-finals last
weekend, singing occasionally out of tune and out of time, and some fans on
YouTube had questioned whether she could handle the weight of expectations.
</P>
<P>
The British media had also reported some erratic behaviour over the past week,
including how she had lost her temper in the foyer of the London hotel where she
was staying prompting police to intervene.
</P>
<P>
Morgan said that she even considered quitting, describing her in his blog as a
"frightened rabbit in headlights".
</P>
<P>
But his fellow judge Amanda Holden said after Saturday's performance: "I have
never heard such powerful confident vocals."
</P>
<P>
Reports on Sunday suggested Boyle could make millions of pounds in the next year
if she capitalised on her global success, with the News of the World saying one
of the show's judges, music promoter Simon Cowell, had big plans.
</P>
<P>
"It's the biggest phenomenon I've ever seen out of any of my shows," Cowell told
the newspaper, which suggested an album, a film of her life and a memoir were in
the pipeline.
</P>
<P>
Asked about her plans on television after the show, Boyle said: "I hope to get
an album out -- I'll just play it by ear."
</P>
<P>
She added: "What a journey -- unbelievable, and very humbling. Thank you for
everything."
</P>
<P>
Hoards of fans had gathered in her hometown of Blackburn near Edinburgh to watch
the final and support Boyle, and Scottish First Minister Alex Salmond also
congratulated the singer, saying she could "hold her head up high".
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Cricket: Twenty20 comes home to England
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Cricket's newest format returns to its birthplace when England hosts the World
Twenty20 from Friday with the event kicking off a bumper summer which includes
one of the sport's oldest combats, the Ashes.
</P>
<P>
But, as with all the other forms of one-day cricket first played in England at
county level, the 'mother country' has found herself having to play catch-up
with the rest of the world.
</P>
<P>
Originally conceived as a fun way of bringing new audiences, particularly those
who couldn't watch cricket during the working day, into the game, Twenty20 has
taken the sport by storm.
</P>
<P>
Tournaments such as the Indian Premier League (IPL) are now far more lucrative
per match for a player than five-day Test cricket, the traditional pinnacle of
the sport.
</P>
<P>
India, whose administrators were originally hostile to Twenty20 because they
feared its commercial impact upon the 50-over game, won the inaugural global
tournament in South Africa two years ago.
</P>
<P>
Nine members of that winning squad, which defeated arch-rivals Pakistan by five
runs in a thrilling final in Johannesburg, will be coming to England.
</P>
<P>
But, in what above all other types of cricket is a game heavily weighted in
favour of batsmen, India will be without master run-maker Sachin Tendulkar, who
has now opted out of Twenty20 internationals.
</P>
<P>
Generally short boundaries and fielding restrictions put a premium on big-
hitting batsmen and in Yuvraj Singh they have someone who struck England's
Stuart Broad for six sixes in an over in South Africa.
</P>
<P>
Tendulkar, who himself played in this year's IPL, warned it was important that
openers Yuvraj and Gautam Gambhir were refreshed after failing to find top form
in the IPL.
</P>
<P>
"I think the key would be how soon they can shed the fatigue factor," Tendulkar
said.
</P>
<P>
Wicket-taking bowlers are an invaluable commodity in a game where economy rates
can go out the window and India look to have a promising pace attack.
</P>
<P>
Left-armer Rudra Pratap Singh, who took 12 wickets in South Africa in 2007, will
be supported this time around by Zaheer Khan and Ishant Sharma.
</P>
<P>
Pakistan, starved of international cricket at home after a terror attack on the
Sri Lanka team bus in Lahore in March made the country a 'no-go zone', will
fancy their chances of going one better this time around.
</P>
<P>
"I thought Australia would thrash them in the one-off T20 match in Dubai but it
was the other way round and now, if Pakistan play to their potential, they can
win the title," Pakistan great Wasim Akram told AFP this month.
</P>
<P>
Australia have dominated all forms of cricket during the last decade except
Twenty20 and captain Ricky Ponting is determined to improve both his and the
team's record.
</P>
<P>
"The past couple of games I've played have been very poor," he said. "In the two
games in South Africa I made one in each. It's not great form going into a World
Cup."
</P>
<P>
Ponting gave Australia a scare when he sustained a hand injury during practice
on Saturday.
</P>
<P>
But he is still expected to take part - which is more than England captain
Andrew Strauss.
</P>
<P>
The opening batsman has opted out of the tournament because he thinks he isn't a
good enough Twenty20 player and the suspicion remains that England are more
interested in the Ashes series against Australia that follows this event.
</P>
<P>
England have never won a major international one-day tournament and they will be
without all-rounder Andrew Flintoff (knee), now replaced by uncapped leg-spinner
Adil Rashid, while doubts persist over star batsman Kevin Pietersen (Achilles).
</P>
<P>
But the IPL and subsequent international form of Ravi Bopara has shown England
that there is life beyond "Freddie" and "KP".
</P>
<P>
Sri Lanka and New Zealand have repeatedly punched above their weight in
international tournaments and could do so again during a tournament that will
take place at three of English cricket's most historic venues - Lord's, the Oval
and Trent Bridge.
</P>
<P>
And the West Indies could yet put a largely disappointing tour of England behind
them in this format.
</P>
<P>
Meanwhile South Africa, who won both of their two previous Twenty20s against
Australia, are desperate to add a one-day title to set alongside their
achievements in winning Test series in both England and Australia during the
past 12 months.
</P>
<P>
Bangladesh and Ireland, who have both enjoyed shock wins on the global stage in
the past, will dream of further upsets although, with both Scotland and the
Netherlands taking part, there is also the capacity for some hugely lopsided
results too.
</P>
<P>
For the first time the corresponding women's tournament will run in parallel
with the main men's event, with both finals taking place on the same day at
Lord's where, thanks in part to Twenty20, permanent floodlights are now a
feature of the ground.
</P>
<P>
The tournament gets underway on June 5.
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0458" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Athletics: Gay signals his return with sizzling 200m
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
NEW YORK, May 30, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
US sprinter Tyson Gay signalled his World Championship intentions with the
third-fastest 200m time ever on Saturday at the Reebok Grand Prix Athletics
meeting.
</P>
<P>
Gay, a treble world champion in 2007 whose 2008 Olympic season was wrecked by
injury, won the 200m in 19.58sec.
</P>
<P>
Only Jamaica's Usain Bolt, who won Olympic gold in Beijing in a world record
19.30sec, and Michael Johnson (19.32 at the 1996 Atlanta Games), have clocked
faster times in the half-lap sprint.
</P>
<P>
Gay, whose previous best for the 200m was 19.62 - in 2007 - said he thought 2008
sprint revelation Bolt would be "excited" by his time.
</P>
<P>
"I would think he would be pretty excited," Gay said. "This is good news for our
sport. It's good for both of us.
</P>
<P>
"I don't know when or if we'll actually meet for a race," Gay said of the
possibility of facing Bolt before the World Championships in Berlin in August.
"But whenever it happens it figures to pretty good and pretty fast."
</P>
<P>
Gay, who was competing in his first serious race of 2009 and had put in little
speed-specific work in his training, said he had room for improvement in his
technique as well.
</P>
<P>
"I got out fast, but was probably leaning too much around the turn," he said.
"That might have slowed me down some, but considering this was my first big
race, it was a pleasure.
</P>
<P>
"I just wanted to stay focused the whole way, keep  my knees up, then when I
got to the straightaway, just run for my life ...  2008 that was all very
unfortunate," added Gay, who was injured at the US Olympic trials last year,
failed to reach the 100m final in Beijing and crashed out of the 4x100m Olympic
relay heats with his US teammates.
</P>
<P>
"But now 2009 is already looking pretty good, and the season is just getting
started."
</P>
<P>
American stars Wallace Spearmon (19.98), Xavier Carter (20.27) and Jeremy
Wariner (20.30) finished 2-3-4 in Gay's slipstream.
</P>
<P>
Bolt, who drew worldwide attention at this meeting last year with his 100m world
record-setting victory in 9.72sec - a record he lowered to 9.69 in Beijing -
didn't run here this year.
</P>
<P>
"I don't really know what his asking price is these days, but we probably
couldn't afford him," said meet promoter Mark Westmore.
</P>
<P>
But Gay's time was one of eight world-leading performances produced on Saturday
as he, fellow Americans Allyson Felix and Lauryn Williams and Kenyans Micah Kogo
and Linet Masai gave the Icahn Stadium sellout crowd of 11,127 plenty of value.
</P>
<P>
Proving once again that an Olympic gold medal is never a permanent invitation to
the top step of the podium, 2008 Beijing champions Tirunesh Dibaba, Angelo
Taylor and Veronica Campbell-Brown fell short.
</P>
<P>
Ethiopia's Dibaba had won Olympic gold at 5,000 and 10,000 meters and set a
world 5,000 record 14:11.15 in a brilliant 2008. But she was unable to match up
with Masai, the 19-year-old Kenya sensation, in the 5,000 here.
</P>
<P>
Masai broke away from Dibaba in the final two laps and won in a season's best
14:35.39, to Dibaba's 14:40.93.
</P>
<P>
Two-time (2000 and 2008) Olympic 400-meter hurdles champion  Taylor of the
United States hit the second barrier and was thrown offstride. But he rallied to
move into contention only to have more problems at the ninth hurdle and see the
top two places go to America's Bershawn Jackson (48.513) and Puerto Rico's
Javier Coulson (also 48.518.)
</P>
<P>
Jamaica's Campbell-Brown, the Olympic 200m champion, ran the 100 instead and
wound up third in 10.91 behind Americans Carmelita Jeter (10.85) and Muna Lee
(10.88) but their times were wind-aided.
</P>
<P>
Olympic 400m champion LaShawn Merritt fought through some tough in-his-face wind
on the backstretch and then fought off Trinidad's Rennie Quow (44.89) and the
Bahamas' Chris Brown (45.04) to take the men's one-lap race in 44.75, precisely
one second slower than his 2008 Beijing time.
</P>
<P>
"Given the conditions and everything else, I think 44.75 was pretty darn good,"
he said. "I'm ready to win the gold in Berlin."
</P>
<P>
Olympic silver medalist Jenn Stuczysnki won the women's pole vault in a season's
best 4.81m.
</P>
<P>
Christin Wurth-Thomas, a relatively unsung 28-year-old American, took out the
women's 1,500-meter pace from the starting gun and never weakened en route to a
surprising victory in 4:03.96, best time of her life and one more 2009 world
best.
</P>
<P>
  American women recorded three other world list-leading times: Williams in the

<HEADLINE>
SKorea, ASEAN to hold summit overshadowed by NKorean threat
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
SEOUL, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
South Korea will Monday host one of its biggest-ever diplomatic gatherings,
overshadowed by the growing security threat from North Korea.
</P>
<P>
Seoul planned the ASEAN-Korea Commemorative Summit to promote its "New Asia
Initiative" to strengthen its ties with the continent.
</P>
<P>
But North Korea's relations with its neighbour and the world have worsened
dramatically in recent months.
</P>
<P>
Last week it tested its second nuclear bomb, renounced the truce in force on the
Korean peninsula and threatened attacks on the South.
</P>
<P>
South Korea has heightened vigilance for the June 1-2 meetings with leaders of
the 10-nation Association of Southeast Asian Nations on the southern resort
island of Jeju.
</P>
<P>
"During the summit meetings, our military will escalate its alert and mobilise
additional intelligence assets," Lieutenant General Jang Kwang-Il of the Joint
Chiefs of Staff said last week.
</P>
<P>
One commander said any North Korean border provocation is likely to be timed for
the summit to cause maximum embarrassment.
</P>
<P>
Seoul says the North's security threat will be a topic at the summit, called to
mark the 20th anniversary of relations between South Korea and ASEAN.
</P>
<P>
Leaders will also debate the global financial crisis, climate change and
regional cooperation in trade, economic matters, security and culture.
</P>
<P>
"In recent years, especially as we entered the 21st century, Asia has emerged as
a great power economically and in many other aspects," South Korean President
Lee Myung-Bak said recently.
</P>
<P>
"That is why cooperation within the Asian region is important and that is why it
is especially important to improve ties between Korea and ASEAN."
</P>
<P>
South Korea sees ASEAN's almost 600 million people as a market for its export-
dominated economy that can offset the recession in developed countries.
</P>
<P>
The resource-poor nation is also eyeing its abundant raw materials.
</P>
<P>
ASEAN is already South Korea's third largest trading partner, with two-way trade
worth around 90 billion dollars last year, and its second largest destination
for overseas investment.
</P>
<P>
Korean investment in the region was worth 5.86 billion dollars last year.
</P>
<P>
The figures will rise further when the two sides on Tuesday sign an investment
pact, completing negotiations on a free trade agreement which began in 2005.
</P>
<P>
Lee is due to raise issues of democracy during a meeting with his counterpart
from military-ruled Myanmar.
</P>
<P>
ASEAN has been reluctant to speak out against its most notorious member, but in
May it expressed "grave concern" at the trial of pro-democracy leader Aung San
Suu Kyi and reiterated its demand for her freedom.
</P>
<P>
"With the eyes of the international community on Myanmar at present, the honour
and the credibility of the Government of the Union of Myanmar are at stake," it
added.
</P>
<P>
Aung San Suu Kyi was charged with violating the terms of her house arrest after
an uninvited American swam to her lakeside home.
</P>
<P>
She has been under various forms of detention without trial for more than 13 of
the past 19 years.
</P>
<P>
"Our government is greatly concerned about the circumstances of Aung San Suu
Kyi," South Korean Foreign Minister Yu Myung-Hwan said this month, calling for
Myanmar's ruling military junta to travel the path of democracy.
</P>
<P>
Lee will use the summit to promote his low carbon, green growth policy.
Presidential officials said he would also urge Southeast Asian leaders to help
build a strong bond market in the region and fight protectionism during the
global downturn.
</P>
<P>
Some 700 business leaders from the 11 countries are due to meet separately on
Sunday and Monday. An Economic Cooperation Forum Monday will consider ways to
combat the world downturn which is threatening regional development.
</P>

raising the country's total to 100.
</P>
<P>

capital Buenos Aires, where students had recently returned from the United
States, said Health Minister Graciela Ocana.
</P>
<P>
The outbreak prompted officials to close the schools for two weeks in a bid to
contain the A(H1N1) virus.
</P>
<P>
In Colombia officials raised the country's total to 20 following confirmation
that a man and woman in the southwest city of Cali who presented flu symptoms
after arriving back from New York did in fact have the swine flu.

In Bogota a man who returned from the US state of Texas was also confirmed to
have the virus, but was recovering well, officials said.
</P>
<P>

Central American nation bringing its number of cases to 11.

</HEADLINE>

LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Lasith Malinga is such an integral part of Sri Lanka's fast bowling arsenal that

</P>
<P>
The bowler with the rare sling-arm action, whose toe-crushing yorkers have

</P>
<P>
Malinga, 25, was unable to run or train, and the swollen bone in his right knee
was so painful that he could barely climb stairs.
</P>
<P>
Worried the prodigious talent could be lost to the game, Sri Lankan president
Mahinda Rajapaksa recommended that Malinga should meet a spiritual healer
Eliyantha White.
</P>
<P>
"He (White) works with supernatural powers and herbs," explained Malinga. "I
don't know what he does or how he does it, but it works. I am very grateful to
him and the president."
</P>
<P>
The treatment lasted five days and the pain disappeared. Malinga was fit to
start his training. White later reportedly cured veteran Sanath Jayasuriya of a
long-standing back problem.
</P>
<P>
Malinga marked his return to active cricket with a strong showing in the Indian
Premier League in South Africa where he grabbed 18 wickets in 13 matches for the
Mumbai Indians.
</P>
<P>
"He is fast and furious and never easy to get away," said an appreciative Mumbai
coach Pravin Amre. "Sri Lanka will be very happy he is back."

'X' factor' for turning a game on its head, was delighted his premier fast
bowler was raring to go.
</P>
<P>

"It's good to have him around again."
</P>
<P>
Sri Lanka's former coach Tom Moody, who now looks after both Western Australia
and IPL team Kings XI Punjab, said Malinga was an "unique" bowler.
</P>
<P>
"Everything about him is unique. His very unique action, unique that he bowls at
90 miles an hour," said Moody. "He is different."
</P>
<P>
Malinga's approach to bowling is simple and uncomplicated. Hurl the ball as fast
as possible, preferably near the batsmen's toes. It could rattle stumps or even
break bones, but will never be easy to hit.
</P>
<P>
Asked recently to name the toughest batsman he had bowled to, Malinga said:
"Lots of batsmen can be tough when they get in. But I try to focus on what I can
do. It just takes one ball to take a wicket."
</P>
<P>
He famously took four wickets off four deliveries in a World Cup match in the
Caribbean in 2007 where he guided Sri Lanka to the final with 18 wickets from
eight games at an average of 15.77.
</P>
<P>
A similar performance in the Twenty20 Worlds will see Sri Lanka progress far in
the tournament.

</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
England have never won a major international one-day tournament and, even

</P>
<P>
English one-day cricket has generally been based on the idea of the steady
accumulation of runs, followed by a dash at the finish, and steady, containing
bowling by medium-pacers who 'do a job' for their side.
</P>
<P>
What recent tournaments have shown is the need for wicket-taking bowlers in an
era where economy rates are of limited value, given how aggressive modern
batsmen are, and batsmen capable of scoring quickly, particularly in the early
overs of an innings.
</P>
<P>
The loss through a knee injury of all-rounder Andrew Flintoff, a dynamic seamer
with an ability to get reverse swing and, on his day, a hard-hitting batsman,

<P>

Africa-born shotmaker out of the recent homne one-day series with the West
Indies, also remains a concern.
</P>
<P>

keen to be on tour, England won that series 2-0.
</P>
<P>
And emerging England quick Stuart Broad, himself a handy lower order batsman,
believes that Flintoff's absence need not spell the end of England's victory
hopes.
</P>
<P>
"We've certainly won well without Fred in the past, but it's important we play
good cricket," Broad said.

step up and take responsibility when he's not here, that's very important.
</P>

the side there will be a lot of belief and confidence there.
</P>
<P>

but when he's not in the side someone else gets given the ball and takes
responsibility."
</P>
<P>

major nation in Twenty20 cricket since levelling their two match series against
the West Indies at The Oval in June 2007.
</P>
<P>
England's only win at the inaugural World Twenty20 in South Africa a few months
later was against Zimbabwe, with the side losing to South Africa, New Zealand
and India.
</P>
<P>
However, England's squad does now contain players with plenty of domestic
Twenty20 experience in Hampshire all-rounder Dimitri Mascarenhas and Essex
wicket-keeper James Foster.
</P>
<P>
And England coach Andy Flower believes Ravi Bopara can provide the solution to
the side's longtstanding problems at the top of the order in one-day cricket
which have been an issue since the international retirement of Somerset left-
hander Marcus Trescothick.
</P>
<P>
"You must be able to adapt, have strong hitters and top-class batsmen up front,"
Flower said in an interview with the Big Hitter magazine.
</P>
<P>
"Ravi Bopara has shown what a class player can do at the top of the order, which
you need against the new ball - not just lower order sloggers thrown in."
</P>
<P>
England captain Andrew Strauss is sitting out this tournament on the grounds
that he does not believe himself to be a good enough Twenty20 player, with the
leadership passing to Paul Collingwood.

aggressive switch hitting style where he often uses the back of his bat or takes
a right-handed stance to go after the bowling.
</P>
<P>
He generates enormous power from his strong forearms and uses his small stature
to get underneath deliveries and hit them high in the air.
</P>
<P>
In one T20 match for his state this year, he smoked a six off express bowler
Shaun Tait that landed on the roof of one of the Adelaide Oval stands.
</P>
<P>
"It's not like I'm trying to hit every ball into the next suburb," Warner says
of his pyrotechnic batting. "Basically, if it's in my area, I'm not going to
hold back.
</P>
<P>
"If it's ball one or the last ball of the day, I'm still not going to hold back.
I know when to be more careful, but basically, I want to score off every ball.
</P>
<P>
"I just have to back myself. You get a good start and the crowd starts going and
you want to keep going on the roll."
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0469" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Cricket: Unorthodox Van der Merwe adds punch to Proteas
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
JOHANNESBURG, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
He’s an unlikely cricket star - a short, stocky all-rounder with a mediocre
first-class record - but Roelof van der Merwe has become a Twenty20 player to be
reckoned with since he made his debut for South Africa in March.
</P>
<P>
Van der Merwe’s nickname with his Titans franchise is 'Bulldog' and he lives
up to it with his aggressive attitude as a left-arm slow bowler, hard-hitting
right-handed batsman or in the field.
</P>
<P>
Selected for the South African under-19 team in 2004, his cricket career seemed
to hit a dead end and he admits he spent more time partying than working on his
game in his first year or so after leaving school in Pretoria.
</P>
<P>
He started attracting serious attention in the 2007/08 season with his
economical bowling and effective pinch-hitting for the Titans in limited overs
cricket, helping the franchise win both the 45-overs and 20-overs competition.
</P>
<P>
On Twenty20 international debut he top-scored with 48 against Australia with a
frenzied mixture of wild hits and judicious bunts.
</P>
<P>
He swung his bat with such ferocity that one attempted pull shot flew off a top
edge over point for one of his four sixes.
</P>
<P>
Drafted into the South African one-day international side, he topped his
side’s bowling averages and was the most economical bowler, twice taking three
wickets in an innings in four appearances.
</P>
<P>
Snapped up by the Royal Challengers Bangalore, he became a regular member of the
team that reached the final of the Indian Premier League.
</P>
<P>
While his batting appears agricultural, his bowling is canny.
</P>
<P>
He bowls with tight control and his franchise coach Richard Pybus said: "He has
an instinct for anticipating what a batsman is going to do."
</P>
<P>
South African captain Graeme Smith likes Van der Merwe’s attitude.
</P>
<P>
"He really wants to be an active part of the game which, when you come in as a
youngster, is important. If you’re a bit sheepish then the game will test
you."
</P>
<P>
No-one can accuse Van der Merwe of being sheepish.
</P>
<P>
When he takes a wicket he roars his delight and shakes his fists above his head
like a victorious boxer.
</P>
<P>
And he’s unbowed when teased about his batting style.
</P>
<P>
"It’s not how you drive, it’s how you arrive," he said when presented with
the man of the match award in his first Twenty20 international.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0470" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Cricket: Gloveman McCullum holds key for New Zealand
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
WELLINGTON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
The weight of New Zealand's Twenty20 World Cup expectations rests heavily on the
shoulders of Brendon McCullum and his burning desire to be recognised as the
world's best wicketkeeper-batsman.
</P>
<P>
The diminutive gloveman is the key element in New Zealand's game plan with his
audacious batting at the top of the order and his lightning-fast reactions
behind the woodwork.
</P>
<P>
That the 27-year-old's name is often mentioned as a contender to inherit the
mantle of Australian great Adam Gilchrist speaks volumes for his ability.
</P>
<P>
In the Indian Premier League, the Kolkata Knight Riders valued McCullum at
700,000 US dollars, the biggest offer for a New Zealand player, when they
snapped him up last year.
</P>
<P>
They were immediately rewarded when he launched the inaugural IPL series by
smashing a record 158 off 73 balls and he ended the season with an average 62.66
with the bat at a strike rate of 204.35.
</P>
<P>
New Zealand's 2008 Player of the Year has also won high praise from Australia
where a cameo McCullum performance helped New South Wales qualify for the
Champions League Twenty20 tournament in October.
</P>
<P>
"There is no doubt having Brendon McCullum in your team increases your chances
of a win, that is an undeniable fact," said Cricket NSW chief executive David
Gilbert.
</P>
<P>
In the just-completed second IPL series leading up to the World Twenty20,
McCullum's batting was below par by his usual standards, finishing with an
average of 23.75 at a strike rate of 119.24.
</P>
<P>
But ominiously, McCullum was working his way into form as the World Twenty20
approached with two knocks in the 80s in his last four IPL innings.
</P>
<P>
In a side which struggles for consistancy, much is made of whether McCullum's
best role with the bat is as a blockbusting opener or an aggressive middle-order
hitter who can get New Zealand across the finish line.
</P>
<P>
Coach Andy Moles is adamant he will lead with McCullum in partnership with the
emerging Jesse Ryder.
</P>
<P>
"Opening is Brendon's place," he said with memories still fresh of the way
McCullum engineered a clean sweep over India in their Twenty20 two-match series
in February.
</P>
<P>
McCullum carried his bat through both innings and in a dramatic finish to the
second game he calmly stroked a single off the final ball to secure the win.
</P>
<P>
New Zealand will rely on that same McCullum calmness to get them through the
World Twenty20, while the gloveman will be looking to enhance his own reputation
as well as aiding his country.
</P>
<P>
"I want to be the best batsman-keeper in the world," he told the New Zealand
Herald.
</P>
</TEXT>
</DOC>
<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0471" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Cricket: Porterfield aiming for more Irish success
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Ireland may be heading into the World Twenty20 without their best player but
captain William Porterfield believes the side can still achieve great things
during the tournament.
</P>
<P>
The Irish have seen star batsman Eoin Morgan called up by England just as was
the case ahead of the 2007 World Cup in the Caribbean with Ed Joyce.
</P>
<P>
But five years ago Ireland still managed to beat Pakistan and Bangladesh - one
of their Group A opponents along with World Twenty20 champions India.
</P>
<P>
Porterfield, an opening batsman who plays English county cricket for
Gloucestershire, is hoping the form Ireland showed in dominating the 2011 World
Cup qualifying tournament in South Africa and then by thrashing Worcestershire
by 94 runs in an English Friends Provident Trophy 50-overs per side match, will
carry on into the World Twenty20.
</P>
<P>
He has already shown he knows how to play a captain's innings - his 69 off 110
balls was central to Ireland's win over Worcestershire - and Porterfield reckons
the side are getting better all the time
</P>
<P>
"The nucleus of the squad is still there from the 2007 World Cup. And we've
added the likes of Peter Connell and Regan West.
</P>
<P>
"We now have more depth and there's more quality to choose from."
</P>
<P>
Porterfield may be one day lost to Ireland, just as Morgan and Joyce have been.
</P>
<P>
But in the meantime his experience of top-class cricket - his 85 was vital in
the 2007 World Cup win over Bangladesh - could help the Irish again make a mark
in a global event.
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Cricket: Hamilton looks to restore Scottish pride
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Scotland captain Gavin Hamilton hopes the World Twenty20 will enable his side to
get back on track following their surprise failure to qualify for the 2011 World
Cup.
</P>
<P>
Long one of the most consistent nations outside the Test elite, a run of poor
results during the recent 2011 qualifying tournament in South Africa saw
Scotland fail to make it to the showpiece event in Asia.
</P>
<P>
Ryan Watson was stripped of the captaincy and in his place came all-rounder
Hamilton, whose one and only Test appearance a decade ago for England saw him
fail to take a wicket and record a pair against South Africa in Johannesburg.
</P>
<P>
Now 34, Hamilton's career in England was to suffer dramatically when a move from
Yorkshire to Durham saw him get what golfers would term the 'yips' with his seam
bowling.
</P>
<P>
But he has been able to continue his Scotland career and now Hamilton hopes a
new-look side can give a good account of themselves in a Group D also featuring
South Africa and New Zealand.
</P>
<P>
"We're realistic about our chances of winning games, but if there's ever a game
to win, it's Twenty20 because the whole thing can turn around in two or three
overs," he said.
</P>
<P>
"It's a case of having people playing well and hopefully catching teams on a
semi-bad day."
</P>
<P>
Scotland face England in a warm-up match on Tuesday at Trent Bridge but Hamilton
said his 1999 experience would not be something he would dwell on.
</P>
<P>
"That was a long time ago," he said. "I had my ups and downs thinking about that
in the couple of years after it. But not now.
</P>
<P>
"It was an experience I'd like to change but I came away from that tour a better
cricketer."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Cricket: Broad looking for better headlines
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
England quick Stuart Broad goes into the World Twenty20 determined to make the
most of a tournament often seen as a hiding to nothing for bowlers.
</P>
<P>
Broad, at 22 an improving paceman and a more than handy lower order batsman, is
quickly becoming an important member of the England team.
</P>
<P>
But it says something about the self-belief of the son of former England opening
batsman Chris that his confidence was not dented permanently when, during the
corresponding tournament in South Africa two years ago, he became the first
bowler to be hit for six sixes in an over during a Twenty20 international by
India's Yuvraj Singh in Durban.
</P>
<P>
"Anyone can get hit," said Broad. "You can see that in the amount of Twenty20
cricket that is being played now.
</P>
<P>
"They bring the boundaries in, they make it smaller and everyone wants to see
fours and sixes. So, as a bowler, you've got to accept sometimes you're going to
be on the receiving end.
</P>
<P>
"The important thing is how you bounce back, how you improve as a bowler and how
you learn new deliveries and practice different skills.
</P>
<P>
"It's important, certainly at a young age, to learn from it, take it in your
stride and turn everything into a positive.
</P>
<P>
"It was a chance to really improve me as a bowler and I couldn't be happier with
the way the last year has gone."
</P>
<P>
England were off the pace in South Africa, failing to beat a major nation during
a run of just one win in five matches.
</P>
<P>
But they will have home advantage on their side in a group that sees them take
on Pakistan, losing finalists in 2007, and outsiders the Netherlands.
</P>
<P>
"I think hosting the event is a massive plus for us," said Broad. "Twenty20 is
really big in England on the domestic side so to be having the World Twenty20 is
going to make the crowds even more excitable."
</P>
<P>
And while Andrew Flintoff's latest injury, a knee problem, has ruled the star
all-rounder out of the tournament, Broad said it was time England stopped
despairing when confronted with life without 'Fred'.
</P>
<P>
"When he's not in the side someone else gets given the ball and takes
responsibility," Broad explained.
</P>
<P>
"I thrive on that extra responsibility and I certainly like taking the new ball.
We talk about the first 10 overs setting the tone and that's my job with Jimmy
Anderson."
</P>
</TEXT>

<TEXT>
The 2009 World Twenty 20 championship gets under way in England on June 5 and
runs until June 21.

In the build-up to the tournament, where India will be defending the title they
won in South Africa in 2007, AFP Sports is filing a package of advancers looking
at the 12 teams and the potential stars.

AFP Sports World T20 contact: David.James@afp.com

LONDON

Cricket's newest format returns to its birthplace when England hosts the World
Twenty20 from Friday with the event kicking off a bumper summer which includes
one of the sport's oldest combats, the Ashes.

in the World Twenty20.

<HEADLINE>
RugbyU: Johnson calls for greater England 'urgency'
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
LONDON, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
England manager Martin Johnson admitted his side needed to show greater
"urgency" against Argentina at Old Trafford this coming weekend after Saturday's
33-26 Twickenham defeat by the Barbarians.
</P>
<P>
An England team shorn of its British and Irish Lions and boasting some
unfamiliar combinations were 33-5 down against the star-studded invitational
team before a late rally made the scoreline respectable.
</P>
<P>
However, 2003 World Cup winning captain Johnson was worried by the way in which
the Barbarians were able to score five tries, including one from in-form Wallaby
flanker Rocky Elsom, the hero of Irish province Leinster's European Cup win, and
two from ex-England wing Iain Balshaw.
</P>
<P>
"We were hesitant at times and lacked intensity. We must play with higher
intensity and put teams under greater pressure," Johnson said.
</P>
<P>
"Defensively the way we gave away the tries was disappointing. It was poor and
our urgency wasn't good enough.
</P>
<P>
"We can't make the same sort of mistakes against Argentina. Some of the guys
hadn't played for a while and we'll have to be sharper," the former lock added.
</P>
<P>
"We'll be picking our strongest team against Argentina."
</P>
<P>
Ex-England captain Martin Corry, who played with Johnson at Leicester and fellow
World Cup winner Josh Lewsey, whom the legendary second row captained to glory
in 2003, both played for the Barbarians on Saturday as they made their final
Twickenham appearances before retirement.
</P>
<P>
Back-row forward Corry said it would be wrong to make too much of this result.
"The way England finished was key. Everyone looks at the Barbarians as a scratch
side but so were England," he said.
</P>
<P>
"Thankfully it was our talent that got us through but England have some very
smart players who picked holes in us. They were very impressive.
</P>
<P>
"This is tough for Johnno because he has got to start again, as this is not the
same side that finished the Six Nations."
</P>

<HEADLINE>
Football: Cahill pride despite Everton's final misery
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
London, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Australia midfielder Tim Cahill insisted Everton had no reason to be ashamed
after losing the FA Cup final to Chelsea.
</P>
<P>
Cahill choked back tears on the Wembley pitch after Saturday's 2-1 defeat but
the Socceroos star had no intention of feeling sorry for himself for long.
</P>
<P>
Although Everton were briefly within touching distance of winning their first
trophy for 14 years after Louis Saha gave them the lead just 25 seconds into the
match, it was Chelsea who finished with the victory lap of honour.
</P>
<P>
The ecstacy of Saha's strike - the fastest goal in FA Cup final history - was
replaced by agony as Didier Drogba equalised before the break and then Frank
Lampard hit the second half winner.
</P>
<P>
Defeat was especially hard for Cahill to take as he had already lost one FA Cup
final with Millwall against Manchester United in 2004.
</P>
<P>
But the 29-year-old, the first Australian to play in two FA Cup finals, took
heart from the way his team-mates had dug deep to reach the final despite
injuries to key players like Mikel Arteta and Ayegbeni Yakubu.
</P>
<P>
"The best thing about this team is we stuck together, no matter what," Cahill
said.
</P>
<P>
"We've come so far with such a small squad and I'm just proud to be part of this
team and wear this shirt.
</P>
<P>
"I'm just gutted because this was a chance to win some silverware.
</P>
<P>
"But we lose as team and win as a team. We're going to hold our heads up high
and take this on the chin.
</P>
<P>
"We've had such a long season with such a small squad. I can't be happier
playing with a group of lads like this. I just hope everything stays the same
for next season."
</P>
<P>
As Cahill hid his face under his shirt at the full-time whistle, he was consoled
by Chelsea manager Guus Hiddink, who grew to admire the midfielder during his
spell as Australia coach.
</P>
<P>
Cahill was a key figure as Australia reached the last 16 of the 2006 World Cup
under Hiddink and he was keen to share a few words of encouragement with his
former player.
</P>
<P>
"I have a special relation with Tim Cahill," Hiddink said. "When I started
working with the Australians they didn't have the confidence to qualify for the
World Cup. He was one of the key players in that squad. You could use him
anywhere.
</P>
<P>
"I was happy he missed the chance he had (in the final) but it was typical Tim
to get in there. He is a big player and a big personality and a very beautiful
player in the Premier League."
</P>
</TEXT>

<DOC id="AFP_ENG_20090531.0480" type="story" >
<HEADLINE>
Football: Cup Final hero Lampard salutes Hiddink
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
London, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Frank Lampard described Guus Hiddink as managerial genius after the Dutchman
guided Chelsea to victory in the FA Cup final before saying an emotional
farewell to England.
</P>
<P>
Hiddink, who has been temporary manager at Chelsea for four months, is due to
fly to Moscow this week to resume his role as coach of the Russian national team
having made a big impact in west London.
</P>
<P>
Chelsea were in turmoil when he first arrived, having just sacked manager Luiz
Felipe Scolari following poor performances in the Premier League and a highly-
public falling out with star striker Didier Drogba.
</P>
<P>
But Drogba, left to train with the youth team by Scolari, completed a remarkable
turnaround in fortunes as he scored one of the goals in Saturday's 2-1 victory
over Everton in which Lampard hit the winner.
</P>
<P>
The result ended two years without a trophy for Chelsea, who are hotly tipped to
name AC Milan's Carlo Ancelotti as their next manager despite the popularity of
Hiddink who has always maintained his commitments with Russia made it impossible
to stay.
</P>
<P>
Lampard said: "Some people think that's bewildering but it's not. It was always
going to be until the end of the season so we understand. But he's been
absolutely fantastic to work with, every player will tell you that.
</P>
<P>
"The way he works on the training ground, how simple he keeps football is
something that is managerial genius. It's been a pleasure to work with him.
</P>
<P>
"It's sad to say goodbye but he got a couple of gifts from us all on Friday,
just as a gesture. We all feel the same and feel very close to him. I don't want
to sound too romantic about it all but that's true!"
</P>
<P>
Hiddink has left such a big mark on the Chelsea squad that many feel he will be
a tough act to follow, even for a manager of such immense experience as
Ancelotti.
</P>
<P>
Lampard added: "I think that's true but anyone who comes into a Chelsea job
knows it's a huge job. Success is what everyone craves here and quite rightly so
with the squad and the investment that here.
</P>
<P>
"So yes the new manager will have a hard act to follow but I'm sure he will have
credentials that will take the club forward."
</P>
<P>
Drogba has more reason than most to be nervous of what the future holds at
Stamford Bridge, especially as he is currently waiting to see what punishment he
will receive after being charged by UEFA for his behavior following the
Champions League semi-final against Barcelona.
</P>
<P>
But he was given a rousing reception by Chelsea fans at the final whistle at and
has yet to discuss his long-term future.
</P>
<P>
"The fans have been supportive to me," he insisted. "The only thing I have to
worry about is what happened after that match. But I'm delighted to finish the
season the way we have."
</P>
<P>
Drogba has been revitalised under Hiddink and was impressive again at Wembley as
Chelsea came back from conceding an opening goal to Everton's Louis Saha after
just 25 seconds, the fastest goal in FA Cup Final history.
</P>
<P>
It was Drogba who headed Chelsea level - his fifth goal in a major final for the
club - before Lampard's wonderful left-foot strike arrowed into the net for the
winner in the second half.
</P>
<P>
Drogba said: "It was a difficult start but you have to say it was a very good
goal. But our strength is to believe in ourselves and our qualities and we
played with more confidence. That's why we won."
</P>
<P>
Drogba also paid tribute to the effect Hiddink has had on Chelsea since he
replaced Scolari.
</P>
<P>
He added: "I think the discipline between us was always good. You don't win six
or seven trophies in five years if you don't have discipline in friendship. But
the manger has given us an extra bit."
</P>
</TEXT>
