<HEADLINE>
Football: Hiddink dances into the sunset with a message for Chelsea
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
London, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Guus Hiddink admitted Chelsea's riotous dance party after the FA Cup final was
the perfect way to end his brief reign, but the departing Blues manager wants
his side's victory over Everton to signal a more sedate period at Stamford
Bridge.
</P>
<P>
Hiddink joined Chelsea's stars in a wild dressing room celebration at Wembley on
Saturday, which saw even Roman Abramovich lose his inhibitions and throw a few
shapes alongside Michael Essien, John Obi Mikel and company.
</P>
<P>
A first trophy for two years does that kind of thing to a club who had grown
used to such occasions during Jose Mourinho's reign.
</P>
<P>
But, while Hiddink was delighted to savour every moment of a perfect farewell
before resuming his role as Russia coach on a full-time basis, the Dutchman
believes it is the Mourinho era that Abramovich must recreate if Chelsea are to
enjoy more champagne-soaked celebrations in the future.
</P>
<P>
Since Mourinho was eased out after a bitter power struggle in September 2007,
Chelsea have been through three managers and Abramovich is set to appoint a
fourth, most likely AC Milan's Carlo Ancelotti, in the next week.
</P>
<P>
Hiddink believes that constant change has had a negative effect on the players
and he wants Abramovich to stick with his new man for the good of the squad.
</P>
<P>
"We had a nice dance party with everyone participating, the players and the
staff," Hiddink said. "We have a multi-cultural squad and you must see the
African players; to see Essien break-dance is a joy.
</P>
<P>
"I did some good moves, the African way. At least that's what I was thinking!
</P>
<P>
"Roman danced with us. He is not a man of many words but he was in the middle of
the party.
</P>
<P>
"It was emotional in the dressing room because we were aiming for this cup.
</P>
<P>
"We had this beautiful African dance, then I gathered the players and technical
staff in another room because I won't get another opportunity now to speak to
them.
</P>
<P>
"I gave a five minute speech to thank them in a rather emotional way for the way
we have worked together in the last four months.
</P>
<P>
"Now I think stability is a big need for the club. They have had too many
changes in the past years and they recognise that themselves.
</P>
<P>
"They need a long-term strategy so that they can build a team and keep up their
high performance.
</P>
<P>
"The players know what they are capable of. This victory might be the foundation
for the future. They have shown they can do it."
</P>
<P>
After falling behind to Louis Saha's 25 second opener, the fastest goal in FA
Cup final history, Chelsea gradually overpowered Everton.
</P>
<P>
Didier Drogba equalised with a header from Florent Malouda's cross in the 21st
minute and Frank Lampard gave Chelsea their fifth FA Cup when he drove a long-
range shot past Tim Howard after 72 minutes.
</P>
<P>
Hiddink refused to rule out managing another Premier League club, or even
Chelsea, in the future, but for now he will visit his father before focusing on
leading Russia to the 2010 World Cup finals.
</P>
<P>
He will always have a place in the hearts of Chelsea's players and fans after
one of the most successful caretaker manager spells of all-time.
</P>
<P>
When Hiddink replaced Luiz Felipe Scolari in February he took over a squad in
danger of stagnating, but his direct, open approach produced a run of just one
defeat in his 22 matches.
</P>
<P>
And were it not for some dubious decisions by referee Tom Henning Ovrebo in the
Champions League semi-final second leg against Barcelona, Hiddink would have
taken Chelsea to two finals.
</P>
<P>
He admitted that controversial defeat was the only disappointment of his time in
England.
</P>
<P>
"It would have been even more perfect if we had been somewhere a few days ago
playing in another big final," Hiddink said.
</P>
<P>
"That is the only regret I have. I would have loved to play Man Utd in the
Champions League final, but it did not happen.
</P>
<P>
"I feel sadness to be leaving because the attitude from everyone was superb. On
the other hand leaving with silverware gives a feeling of satisfaction.
</P>
<P>
"This is the best way. You can say goodbye easier with a cup."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Football: We'll be back vows Moyes after Cup Final heartache
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
London, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
David Moyes insists Everton must use the pain of their FA Cup final defeat
against Chelsea as motivation for success next season.
</P>
<P>
Moyes' side were unable to take silverware back to Goodison Park for the first
time in 14 years despite the boost of Louis Saha's record-breaking first minute
strike at Wembley on Saturday.
</P>
<P>
Saha gave Everton a shock lead just 25 seconds after kick-off, claiming the
record for the fastest ever FA Cup final goal in the process.
</P>
<P>
But even that didn't shake Chelsea out of their stride. Guus Hiddink's team
methodically worked their way back into the game and equalised through Didier
Drogba before Frank Lampard drove home the second half winner.
</P>
<P>
Moyes cut a dignified figure after the match as he insisted Chelsea were
deserved winners, but deep down the Blues boss was feeling the pain more than
anyone.
</P>
<P>
He knew how significant a Cup Final victory would have been in his attempt to
establish Everton as a major threat to the Premier League's big four.
</P>
<P>
But the numbing sense of a missed opportunity couldn't totally dampen Moyes'
desire to emphasise that Everton are still within touching distance of success.
</P>
<P>
"I said last year when we got the League Cup semi-final and lost to Chelsea that
the next step was to get to a final. Well, we've got to a final beating
Manchester United, Liverpool and Aston Villa on the way," Moyes said.
</P>
<P>
"The next bit will hopefully come next year and we'll win a cup.
</P>
<P>
"We know it's really hard to win things in England, with so many teams fighting
for just a few prizes.
</P>
<P>
"But for us to finish fifth and reach the FA Cup final, then come here and not
look out of place was a great achievement. We played Chelsea twice this season
and drew and this was only 2-1.
</P>
<P>
"I'm really keen that the players are recognised for how well they have done
this season because they have been outstanding."
</P>
<P>
While Moyes rightly takes great heart from his team's achievements, he knows it
will take a stronger squad to make the transistion from nearly-men to big-game
winners.
</P>
<P>
Injuries to Spanish midfielder Mikel Arteta, Nigeria forward Ayegbeni Yakubu and
defender Phil Jagielka deprieved Everton of three key figures for the second
half of the season and Moyes concedes that left his side short of the quality
needed to live with Chelsea.
</P>
<P>
"If Chelsea had gone into this game without Lampard and Drogba it would have
given us a better chance. And we went in with Jagielka, Yakubu and Arteta. They
are the equivalent players for us as those Chelsea players," Moyes said.
</P>
<P>
"Players like Drogba, Lampard and (John) Terry are the people who win you cups.
That is the level we are at.
</P>
<P>
"We are trying to develop those players. We have one or two who are coming on. I
thought Steven Pienaar was outstanding. We just need a few more at that level
and then who knows."
</P>
</TEXT>

<HEADLINE>
Football: Rangers on holiday, happy with domestic double
</HEADLINE>
<DATELINE>
Glasgow, May 31, 2009 (AFP)
</DATELINE>
<TEXT>
<P>
Rangers assistant manager Ally McCoist said he was looking forward to his summer
break after a Nacho Novo wonder strike won the Scottish Cup as the Gers secured
a domestic double.
</P>
<P>
The Ibrox side's narrow 1-0 victory over a battling Falkirk side means Rangers
can add the Scottish Cup to the Scottish Premier League championship they won on
the final day of the season.
</P>
<P>
It brings to a close a long season for the Ibrox side which begun with a
Champions League qualifier against FBK Kaunas on July 30 last year.
</P>
<P>
The Glasgow giants, who the season before had reached the UEFA Cup final,
suffered a painful elimination from Europe at the hands of the Lithuanian
minnows.
</P>
<P>
And while McCoist says the club will look to buy more players in the summer, the
fact they put the disappointment of the Kaunas defeat behind them to secure a
league and cup double was testament to the effort the players had put in since
he and Walter Smith returned to the club in January 2007.
</P>
<P>
"It can always get better in terms of the team and the squad. With a bit of luck
we can maybe add to that and look to strengthen," McCoist said.
</P>
<P>
"But in terms of what the boys achieved in the last two years the team deserve
all the credit going.
</P>
<P>
"Last year was so close to being the best season in the club's history. It ended
up being, in many people's eyes, a disappointment when we lost the league on the
final day.
</P>
<P>
"We can sit and talk about it all day if we deserved or we didn't deserve it.
The fact is we didn't win it.
</P>
<P>
"I just felt that this year it was a real reward for the players."
</P>
<P>
McCoist added: "I am absolutely looking forward to my break like you have no
idea. I've got the golf clubs looked out and hopefully I'll take a few quid off
the manager in the summer.
</P>
<P>
"I think the players will be looking forward to getting away from us more but
they really need a break, especially with last season when they didn't get as
much of a break as we would've liked."
</P>
<P>
McCoist also heaped praise on striker Novo, who scored 36 seconds after coming
off the bench at half-time.
</P>
<P>
The Spaniard collected a Sasa Papac throw-in to send a sensational strike past
Falkirk keeper Dani Mello from 30 yards out as the Ibrox side lifted the
Scottish Cup for the 33rd time.
</P>
<P>
And McCoist, himself a legendary striker with the Gers, said it was a goal
worthy of winning any cup final.
</P>
<P>
"It was very good. Looking at the context of the game and the quality of the
goal it will take some beating," McCoist said. "It's certainly one of the great
goals to win any cup final in any country I would think.
</P>
<P>
"I can still see it. I was actually praying he would hit it as he got himself
that wee half yard in front and I thought, just have a hit and see what happens,
and I knew it would be close.
</P>
<P>
"Nacho is just an incredible wee guy. He's got a wonderful rapport with the fans
and the rest of the squad.
</P>
<P>
"He deserves his success because he works so hard every day in training.
</P>
<P>
"Anywhere lights up when the wee fellow walks in, whether it's onto a football
park or into a room, he‘s just that kind of person.
</P>
<P>
"If anyone deserves the success it's him as it's not easy when you're on the
bench."
</P>
<P>
And after securing his fourth double while in charge of the Glasgow giants
manager Walter Smith said he would be in charge next season to collect more
trophies, despite speculation to the contrary.
</P>
<P>
"Certainly in Glasgow you are surrounded by hundreds and hundreds of rumours.
You obviously just have to wait and see what happens," Smith said.
</P>
<P>
"Going upstairs today (to collect the Scottish Cup) is the kind of thing I
wanted to do when I came back to Rangers.
</P>
<P>
"They are the kind of stairs I want to walk up. That's why I came back."
</P>
</TEXT>
